div1.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div2.head: SPECIAL LAWS OF TEXAS, 1871.

div3.head: CHAPTER I.

opener.salute: An Act to promote ready access to the mountain woodlands near the capital, by means of ferries and bridges.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Tens, That any person or persons owning the land or banks on both sides of the Colorado river in Travis county, more than one mile above Austin, in the direction of the mountain woodlands, or that may have acquired the right to use the said land or banks for ferry or bridge purposes, who shall construct and maintain for the use of the public, a good and substantial ferry or bridge at any point thus controlled by him or them, shall, without license or other condition, have the right to do so, and to build abutments and piers in the river for the purpose, and to do and perform any other work on the banks of the river or in and about the premises that may be useful for maintaining and promoting the efficiency of the ferry or bridge, so long as he or they shall maintain a substan-
tial public ferry or bridge in good order and condition, and to de-
mand and receive toll from all persons crossing at the same, ac-
cording to the uniform rates of toll established by the police court of the county. But in no case shall toll be taken when the ferry or bridge is in an unsafe condition.
Sec. 2. That this act be in force from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER II.

opener.salute:
An Act to amend an act entitled “An act to incorporate the Wash-
ington Fire Engine Company No. 1, of the city of Austin,” ap-
proved July 19, 1870.

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That section four of the above named act, which reads as follows, viz: “That the actual active members of the company who shall hereafter have served therein for one year, shall be exempt from militia duty and service as jurymen, except in capital cases,” shall be amended so as to read hereafter as follows, viz:

“Section 4. That all members of said company who shall have performed service therein, or who shall perform service therein, for the term of twelve months, shall be exempt from militia duty and jury service.”
Sec. 2. That this act take effect from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER III.

opener.salute: An Act supplementary to and amendatory of an act entitled “An act to incorporate the Dallas Wire Suspension Bridge Company,” approved July 27, 1870.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That section first of said act shall hereafter read as follows: “Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That J. A. B. Record, T. C. Jourdan, W. H. Gaston, Sarah H. Cochrill, J. W. Haynes, J. W. Crowdus, and such other persons as they may associate with them, be and they are hereby created a body corporate and politic, under the name and style of the Dal-
las Bridge Company,’ and as such may make contracts, sue and be sued, have a corporate seal, and may own such property, real and personal, as may be necessary to carry out the objects of this char-
ter, not to exceed in value one hundred thousand dollars.”

Sec. 2. That section second of said act shall hereafter read as follows: “Section 2. That it shall be the duty of said company to
Laws of the State of Texas.build a good, safe and substantial bridge across the Trinity river at or within two hundred and fifty yards of a line drawn due west from the centre of the public square in said town of Dallas, Dallas county, Texas, and to construct a good and substantial causeway across the bottom on the west side of said river; said bridge and causeway to be completed and open for public travel within two years from the passage of this act.”

Sec. 3. That section fifth of said act shall hereafter read as fol-
lows: “Section 5. That when said bridge and causeway shall be completed, said company are authorized to demand and receive from each and every non-resident of Dallas county crossing said bridge or causeway, or crossing their property over the same, a toll not to exceed the following rates, to wit: For each wagon, cart, car-
riage, or other vehicle drawn by more than two horses or other ani-
mals, twenty cents per wheel, and five cents for each animal by which the same is drawn; and where the same is drawn by two ani-
mals or less, ten cents per wheel, and five cents for each animal by which the same is drawn; for each animal and rider, ten cents; for each loose horse, mule, jack or jennet, five cents; for each loose ani-
mal of the cattle kind, five cents; for each foot passenger, five cents; for each sheep, hog or goat, two cents; and from citizens of Dallas county, one-half the above rates. That said company shall have the right to regulate the crossing of persons and property over said bridge and causeway by appropriate rules and regulations, not in-
compatible with this act or the laws of the State of Texas, and any person who shall wilfully violate the regulations of said company in crossing their property over said bridge or causeway, shall be liable to forfeit and pay to said company the sum of five dollars, and costs of suit, and all damages that the property of the com-
pany may sustain by reason of the violation of such rules and regu-
lations, recoverable before any court of competent jurisdiction; pro-
vided, that such rules and regulations are plainly posted at each end of said bridge and causeway at the time.”

Sec. 4. That section eighth of said act shall hereafter read as fol-
lows: “Section 8. That no person shall be authorized or allowed to erect any bridge or keep any ferry across said Trinity river at or within three miles of the city of Dallas, after the said bridge herein authorized is completed; provided, that said company may keep a ferry boat while said bridge is in process of construction, and at such times as said bridge may be out of repair, with the tolls al-
lowed in this act, until the said bridge is put in order and safe con-
dition. That said company shall have the right of way over any land on which they may locate their bridge and causeway, in accord-
ance with this act, and may enter upon and take possession of said
Laws of the State of Texas.land, provided the same shall not exceed one hundred feet in width, by paying the owner or owners thereof whatever may be agreed upon; and should the said owner or owners of said lands and said company not be able to agree as to the price, the said company may petition the Judge of the District Court of said county giving a description of the land which they require, with the owner’s name or names, and the said judge shall summon a jury of six freehold-
ers not in any manner interested, who shall on oath make a report of the value of the land so required; and upon the payment to the owner or owners, or his or their agents, a good and bona fide title shall be granted by said judge to said company for said lands, a copy of which shall be recorded in the office of the district clerk of the comity aforesaid.”

Sec. 5. That section ninth of said act shall hereafter read as fol-
lows: “Section 9. That this charter of incorporation continue and remain in force for fifty years from and after the completion of the bridge of said company; and that this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.”

div3.head: CHAPTER IV.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Jefferson Gas Light Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That E. Marx, W. Q. Bateman, B. J. Terry, W. P. Wil-
liams, John C. Murphy, E. W. Taylor, and such other persons as are or may be associated with them, are hereby created a body cor-
porate and politic, under the name and style of the Jefferson Gas Light Company, and by that name shall have succession, and shall have and use a common seal, and shall be capable in law of suing and being sued, pleading and being impleaded, in all courts of this State; of contracting and being contracted with; and of purchasing, acquiring and holding such real estate and personal property as may be necessary to the successful prosecution of its business, as hereinafter described.

Sec. 2. That the capital stock of said company shall be one hun-
dred thousand dollars, to be divided into shares of one hundred dollars each, and said stock may be owned by individuals, com-
panies and corporations.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p:
Sec. 3. That the said company may pass and put into execu-
tion all such by-laws, rules and regulations, not contrary to the Constitution and laws of this State and the United States, as may be necessary for its good government, and for the efficient manage-
ment of its affairs.

Sec. 4. That said company shall keep an office in the city of Jef-
ferson, Texas, and its business shall be to make and furnish gas to the city of Jefferson and the residents thereof, and to vend the same.

Sec. 5. That said company may extend the main pipes for dis-
tributing the gas when in its judgment it may seem expedient so to do; but shall be bound to extend its main pipes whenever the public and private lights immediately arising from said extension will pay a profit of twelve per cent. on the cost thereof; and whenever an ex-
tension is required the company shall furnish the proper estimates of the cost of the same; and when the sum required shall be sub-
scribed the company shall be bound to make the extension, until their capital stock is absorbed in the gas works and extensions.

Sec. 6. That to enable said gas company to construct its gas works, and to extend and continue its pipes in the city of Jefferson, Texas, it is hereby authorized to continue the use of the pipes and conductors which have been laid down; and, with the consent of the city council, to own and extend its pipes and conductors through the other alleys and streets of said city; and for that purpose it shall be permitted to take up the pavements or dig up the streets and replace and repair the same, and shall be responsible to the city for any damage that may arise therefrom, or any unreasonable de-
lay in replacing or repairing the same; and said company shall be subject to all the regulations of the city as to the streets and alleys, and to the same ordinances and penalties that individuals may be subject to; provided, that such extensions be made with the con-
sent of the city council of Jefferson, Texas.

Sec. 7. That the said gas company shall put lamp posts and fixtures, etc., along the street mains as they are extended at a dis-
tance apart of three hundred feet, or as near that distance as the dimensions of the squares may admit, so as to make an equal dis-
tribution of the same; and on both sides of the street the lights are to be located so as to alternate, preserving the same distance, viz: three hundred feet for the lamps on each side of the street. The said gas company is to keep the lamps in order, to furnish gas and lights, and extinguish the same, giving to each light an illuminating power of about ten burning sperm candles; and the time of burning shall be from the close of twilight at evening until the dawn of day in the morning, except on clear moonlight nights, when the lights
Laws of the State of Texas.may be dispensed with; and said public lights shall be furnished to the city and to private consumers at a cost not to exceed that paid by public and private consumers in the cities of New Orleans, Louis-
iana, Mobile, Alabama, and Memphis, Tennessee; and ten per cent. of the profit may be drawn by the stockholders semi-annually; the remaining per centage shall be laid out in extension or capitalized as the company may determine.

Sec. 8. That if any person or persons shall wilfully, by any means whatever, injure or destroy any part of the gas pipes, or con-
ductors, lamps, lamp posts, burners, or any part of their gas works, or fixtures, or machinery, all such persons shall be bound to the company for any or all damages sustained thereby, and may, fur-
thermore, be liable within two years after the commitment of the offense, and, upon conviction, shall be fined in any sum, at the dis-
cretion of the jury, not exceeding one thousand dollars, or by im-
prisonment in the county jail at hard labor in the State prison not exceeding five years, but this section shall not be held to change the law as to arson or wilfully burning the houses of the company; provided, that so much of this section as imposes imprisonment shall not apply to infants.

Sec. 9. That the stockholders of the company shall elect a presi-
dent, vice president, treasurer, secretary, and five directors; and to said officers and directors shall be entrusted the real and personal estate, business, funds and property, and financial concerns of said company, and the administration of its affairs. All the directors and officers shall be stockholders in the company, to the amount of at least ten shares in their own right, and after their first election, shall have been stockholders in the company not less than three months before the election at which they are chosen; they shall serve for one year, or until their successors are regularly elected and chosen; and after the first election there shall be an annual election held on the first Monday of January of each and every year, of which due notice shall be given for ten days previous in a newspaper printed in the city of Jefferson. The president, officers and directors shall fill all vacancies that may occur in their body from death, resignation, removal from the city, of the failure to meet their engagements to the company with promptness; and it shall be the duty of the other directors to declare the seat of direc-
tor vacant for that cause, or for removal from the city. Each share of stock in the company shall entitle the owner, by himself, herself, or by proxy properly authorized, to one vote for each share up to and inclusive of ten shares, and for his or her excess of shares, over and beyond the ten shares specified, the owner shall be entitled to vote at the rate of one vote for every five shares in full, and no one
Laws of the State of Texas.individual, company or corporation, other than the city of Jeffer-
son, which, by purchase, may own and hold the entire stock, shall hold or own more than two hundred shares of stock, directly or in-
dictly; and if any one shall purchase and hold more, except the city, he shall forfeit his dividend on such excess of stock, to the said gas company.

Sec. 10. That certificates of stock shall be issued to the holders thereof whenever the same shall be paid for; and stock in this com-
pany shall be considered and pass as personal estate, and shall be transferrable on the books of the company in such manner as the stockholders or the president and directors, by their by-laws, shall prescribe; but no stock shall be transferrable until all the debts and demands of the company are discharged, and for all the debts and demands of the company shall have a lien on the stock. That on the second Monday in January and July in each and every year, the company shall make a statement of the affairs of the company, and furnish the same to the stockholders, at which times the semi-an-
nual dividends shall be declared. The president and board of di-
rectors shall keep a record of their proceedings, which they shall produce to the stockholders at the regular or called meetings, or at any time during the business of the day, for examination or in-
spection.

Sec. 11. That if any officer of this company shall, without the authority of the president and directors, appropriate any of the funds of the company to his own use or that of any other person, shall wilfully fail to make correct returns, or shall knowingly make false returns on the books of the company with intent to cheat or defraud the corporation or any person, or to hide or conceal any improper appropriation of the funds of the corporation, the officer so offending shall be deemed guilty of felony, and upon conviction thereof shall be sentenced to confinement in the jail and peniten-
tiary of the State for not less than two, nor more than twenty years.

Sec. 12. That the company shall allow the president, secretary and treasurer a reasonable compensation for their services; but no compensation shall be allowed to a director except by order of the stockholders; and if the president or any of the directors shall knowingly diminish the capital stock by dividends or otherwise, they shall be responsible to the stockholders for the deficiency thus created.

Sec. 13. That the Legislature may require the reports of the finances and affairs of the company, and such reports as may be re-
quired shall be rendered; and the Legislature shall have the right, by its committees, to investigate the condition of the company; and any violation of any of the essential provisions of this charter shall
Laws of the State of Texas.cause forfeiture thereof, but no forfeiture shall prevent the corpora-
tion from collecting its debts, enforcing its contracts, and disposing of its effects; and the District Court of Marion county shall have jurisdiction to hear and determine any alleged forfeiture of charter, on complaint of stockholders or of the State of Texas.

Sec. 14. The city of Jefferson, if it so elect, may purchase the gas works of the “Jefferson Gas Light Company,” at the termina-
tion of this charter, at a fair estimate of what the gas works, fix-
tures, etc., are worth at that time; provided, that the city shall notify said gas company of said election, on its part, at least one year before the termination of this charter, the value of the works to be agreed upon by the officers and board of directors of the com-
pany and the mayor and the board of aldermen of the city; and in case of disagreement between the said officers of the company and the said officers of the city, the value of the works may be ascer-
tained by two competent gas engineers, selected, one by each of the parties, and in case of their disagreeing, by an umpire whom they may select. The proceeds of the sale shall be divided, pro rata, among the stockholders.

Sec. 15. That said gas company shall have the exclusive right and privilege of erecting and establishing gas works in the city of Jefferson, during the continuance of this charter, and of furnish-
ing and vending gas light, and supplying the city and citizens with gas, by means of their works; provided, however, this shall not in-
terfere with the right of any one to erect or cause to be erected gas works on his or her own premises, for supplying his or her own premises exclusively with light.

Sec. 16. That this charter, when accepted by those who hold a majority of the shares of the subscribed stock of this company, and from and after the passing of this act of incorporation, shall be valid and of full force, and no alteration or amendment shall be made thereto, without the concurrence of two-thirds of the share-
holders and the officers and board of directors of said gas company.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER V.

opener.salute: An Act to reincorporate and grant a new charter to the town of Georgetown, and to repeal an act approved September 26, A. D. 1866, entitled “An Act to incorporate the town of Georgetown, in Williamson county, Texas.”

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the citizens of the town of Georgetown, in the county of Williamson, be and they are hereby declared and made a body politic and corporate, under the name and style of the “corporation of the town of Georgetown,” by which name they may sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, acquire and hold property both real and personal, and sell and dispose of the same at their will and pleasure.

Sec. 2. That the limits of said corporation shall extend as fol-
lows, to-wit: Beginning at a stake that is one-half mile due east from the centre of the court house, thence due south one-half mile; thence due west one mile to a stake, for the southwest corner of this corporation; thence due north to the middle of the channel of the “South San Gabriel;” thence down the same with its meanders to a point that a line due south would strike the place of beginning; thence due south to the place of beginning.

Sec. 3. It shall be the duty of the citizens of said corporation to elect a mayor, four aldermen and a marshal, who shall hold their offices for one year, and until their successors are elected and qualified. The mayor and aldermen shall compose the “town council,” any three of whom shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of all business; said council shall have power to pass such rules, regulations, ordinances and laws, as may be necessary for the regulation of the police and preservation of peace, order, and quiet, within the corporate limits of said town; and to impose such punishment both by fine and imprisonment, as may be necessary to enforce a proper observance of the same; provided, however, that no fine shall exceed two hundred dollars, and no imprisonment shall exceed fifteen days.

Sec. 4. Said council shall have power to impose a direct prop-
erty, poll and license tax, upon all such property, persons and em-
ployments, as are liable to taxation under the constitution and laws of this State, and to enforce the collection of the same under such rules and regulations as they may adopt; provided, that no prop-
erty tax shall exceed for any one year one-half of one per cent. of the
Laws of the State of Texas.value of said property, and no poll tax shall exceed five dollars, nor shall any license tax exceed two hundred dollars; and provided furthermore, that no tax shall ever be levied by said council upon any property, real or personal, that may be owned, occupied, and used exclusively for church, educational, or charitable purposes.

Sec. 5. Said council shall have exclusive control and super-
vision over all streets, sidewalks, alleys, and highways, within the corporate limits of said town, and they shall cause to be raised by taxation, a sufficient amount of money as may be necessary to im-
prove and keep the same in good repair, and all road tax, the citi-
zens within the limits may be required to pay under and by virtue of any general law of the Legislature shall, and the same is hereby required to be paid by the collector of taxes into the treasury of said corporation, to be by said council appropriated in improving and re-
pairing said streets and highways.

Sec. 6. Said council shall, at their first regular meeting, elect one of their number treasurer, who shall act as secretary of said council, and shall, before he enters upon the discharge of his duties, take and subscribe the oath of office prescribed by the Constitution of this State, and give bond to said corporation in such sum as may be required by said council, for the faithful performance of his duties, and shall receive such pay for his services as may be allowed him by said council.

Sec. 7. The marshal shall, before entering upon the duties of his office, take and subscribe the oath of office prescribed by the Constitution of this State, and give bond and security to the corpo-
ration for the faithful discharge of his duties in such sum as may be designated by the council, and it shall be his duty to execute all process issued to him by the mayor, suppress all riots and disorderly assemblies, make all arrests with or without warrant of persons for violations of any of the corporate laws; he shall have power to call to his aid the citizens within the corporate limits; and he shall re-
ceive such fees for his services as are prescribed by law for consta-
bles for similar services. He shall, by virtue of his office, be the as-
sessor and collector of taxes for said corporation, and for such serv-
ices shall be allowed such fees as the council may think him en-
titled to. The sheriff of said county of Williamson is, by virtue of this act, made the assistant deputy marshal of said corporation, with all the powers, authority, and privileges to which a deputy may be entitled; and for all services rendered by him as such deputy, he shall be entitled to the same fees as the marshal.

Sec. 8. The mayor shall take the oath of office prescribed by the Constitution of this State, and give bond for the faithful discharge of his duties in such sum as the council may determine. For all
Laws of the State of Texas.services rendered by him he shall receive such fees as are allowed justices of the peace for similar services, and he shall have jurisdic-
tion to try and determine all infractions or violations of the laws of the corporation, under such rules as may be prescribed by the coun-
cil. He shall have power to issue such warrants and process as may be necessary to enforce his jurisdiction.

Sec. 9. The Governor shall appoint a mayor, aldermen, and mar-
shal, of said corporation, who shall hold their offices respectively, until the next general election, or until otherwise provided by law; and it shall be the duty of the mayor and marshal to cause an elec-
tion to be held annually thereafter, at least ten days before the ex-
piration of their term of office, for the election of all officers herein provided for; and should said mayor and marshal fail or refuse to order any such election, then any five citizens of said corporation may order and hold said election after giving five days notice. All persons who reside within the corporate limits, and are entitled under the Constitution and laws of this State to vote, shall, under this charter, be entitled to vote at any election herein provided for, and the mayor shall have power to order elections to fill all vacan-
cies that may occur by reason of death, resignation, and otherwise.
Sec. 10. That this act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER VI.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the town of Millican, county of Brazos.

div3.p:
Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, as follows: Article 1. That all that part of the county of Brazos, to-wit: Having for a centre point the store house of R. J. Shelton, and ex-
tending from there north, one mile; south, one mile; west, one mile; east, one mile; shall constitute the town of Millican.

Art. 2. That the inhabitants of the town of Millican, as the same extends and is laid out as above, and their successors be and are hereby constituted a corporation and body politic in fact and in law, by the name and style of the “Town of Millican,” and by that name shall have perpetual succession, shall sue and be sued, im-
Laws of the State of Texas.plead and be impleaded, defend and be defended, in all courts of law and equity, and in all actions whatsoever.

Art. 3. That there shall be a town council, to consist of a Mayor and Board of Aldermen; that the Board of Aldermen shall consist of five members, to be chosen for two years, by the qualified voters; and no person shall be an alderman, unless he be a citizen of the State of Texas, and a bona fide resident of the town, and shall have resided within the town limits for six months preceding his election. That if any alderman shall, after his election, remove from the town, his office shall thereby be vacated. The town coun-
cil shall judge of the election returns and the qualification of its members, and shall determine contested elections. The majority of the town council shall constitute a quorum to do business; but a smaller number may adjourn from day to day, and may compel the attendance of absent members, in such manner and under such pen-
alties as they may prescribe. The town council may determine the rules of its proceedings, punish its members for disorderly conduct, and, with the concurrence of three members, may expel a member. All elections of officers shall be governed by the general law of the State concerning elections, and no property qualification for voters shall ever be required.

div4.head: Sessions of the Town Council.
div4.p:
Art 4. That all ordinances of the town council shall be read on three different days; and a majority of the votes of the town coun-
cil shall be necessary to pass all ordinances; and on the passage of all ordinances, the “yeas” and “nays” shall be recorded.

div4.head: General Powers of the Mayor and Town Council.
div4.p:
Art. 5. That the mayor and town council shall have power within the town, by ordinance: First—To make regulations for preventing the introduction of contagious diseases into the town. Second—To establish a hospital, and make regulations for the gov-
ernment thereof. Third—To make regulations to secure the general health of the inhabitants, and prevent and remove nuisances. Fourth—to erect a market house, and market place, and to pro-
vide for the government thereof. Fifth—To license, tax and regu-
late billiard tables, tippling houses, and dram shops, and to sup-
press gaming and gambling houses, and other disorderly houses. Sixth—To provide for the prevention and extinguishment of fires, and organizing and establishing fire companies, and to regulate and restrain the carrying on of manufactories dangerous in causing or
Laws of the State of Texas.producing fires. Seventh—To establish standard weights and measures and to regulate the weights and measures to be used in the town, in all cases not otherwise provided by law. Eighth—To fix the compensation of the town officers, not otherwise provided for, and to regulate the fees of all jurors, witnesses, and others, for services rendered under this act, or an ordinance. Ninth—To regulate the police of the town, to impose fines, forfeitures and pen-
alties, to provide for the recovery and appropriation of such fines and forfeitures, and the enforcement of such penalties; provided, no fine shall exceed one hundred dollars, nor shall any term of im-
prisonment exceed fifteen days for any one offense. Tenth—To prevent the assemblage of idle persons at or near store house doors, whereby the trade of such store is interrupted, and also to prevent or restrain any riot, disturbance or disorderly assemblage in any street, house, or place in the town. Eleventh—To prevent and re-
move all encroachments upon all streets, lanes, avenues and alleys established by law or ordinance. Twelfth—To exercise complete and perfect control over the common, and all property belonging to the town, real or personal, whether lying within or beyond the limits of the corporation created by this act, and the same to lease, sell, transfer and dispose of, either absolutely or within limitation, to any person or persons whomsoever, and generally to make such rules, regulations, by-laws, and ordinances for the purpose of main-
taining the peace, good order and government of the “town of Mil-
lican,” and the trade, commerce, and manufactures thereof, as the council may deem expedient, and as may not be repugnant to the laws and Constitution of the State; and to enforce the observance of said rules, regulations, by-laws, and ordinances, by inflicting penalties for the violation thereof, not exceeding one hundred dol-
lars for any one offense, recoverable with costs in any action of debt, by and in the name of the “town of Millican,” for the use of the town, before any court having cognizance of the same.

Art. 6. That the mayor shall be the chief executive officer of the town, and shall be elected by the qualified voters thereof, and shall hold his office for the term of two years. His salary shall be fixed by the aldermen of the town, but shall not, in any event, ex ceed the sum of five hundred dollars per annum and fees of office.

Art. 7. That there shall be a town marshal, whose duties shall be the same as those of other peace officers, and such other duties as may be prescribed by ordinances. The marshal shall be elected by the qualified voters of the town for the term of two years, and shall receive such salary, besides his fees in office, as the mayor and board of aldermen may, by by-law, determine.

Art. 8. That the mayor and the other officers of the corpora
Laws of the State of Texas.tion shall reside within the limits of the town during their continu-
ance in office; and if the mayor shall cease to reside within the limits of the town, his office shall thereby be vacated. The mayor shall have the same jurisdiction as justices of the peace, within the limits of the town, in all State cases; he shall have jurisdiction over all cases arising under any ordinance of the town, subject to an appeal or writ of certiorari, in all cases, to the district court; and every such appeal shall be taken and granted in the same manner as appeals or writs of certiorari are taken and granted from the justice’s court to the district court, under the general laws of the State. He shall charge in all cases the same fees as are now al-
lowed to justices of the peace for the same kind of services, which fees shall be charged and collected as other costs; and he shall act as president of the board of aldermen.
Art. 9. The mayor shall be authorized to procure a seal for the use of his office, on which shall be engraved “Town of Millican, Mayors Office.”

Art. 10. That from and after the passage of this act it shall be unlawful to fire any pistol, rifle, shot gun, or other kind of firearms, within the limits of the town of Millican, and any person violating this act shall be fined not less than five nor more than twenty-five dollars, to be collected by the mayor of the town; but this act shall not prevent any gunsmith within the limits of the town from dis-
charging on the premises thereof firearms made or repaired in his shop, for the purpose of training such firearms; provided, that none but gunsmiths shall have the privilege of being authorized to dis-
charge firearms, and for that purpose each gunsmith shall build a rock wall, in front of which he shall cause a target to be placed. The mayor shall issue a permit to any gunsmith applying for the same for the period of one year, which permit may be renewed after its expiration.

Art. 11. That it shall not be lawful for any person to establish a slaughter house within the corporate limits of the town without the permission of the town council, nor shall it be lawful for any person to slaughter any butcher’s meat of any kind within said cor-
porate limits, except for the use of the person so slaughtering. Any person or persons so offending shall be deemed guilty of a misde-
meanor, and, on conviction thereof, shall be fined not less than ten dollars for each offense.

Art. 12. That this act shall take effect from and after its pas-
sage, and shall be subject to the provisions of an act entitled “An act to authorize the Governor to appoint certain officers to fill vacan-
cies,” approved June 28, 1870.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER VII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the city of Hempstead, in the county of Austin.

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the inhabitants of the territory within the boundary hereinafter designated, are hereby continued corporate, by the name and style of the “city of Hempstead,” a body politic and corporate, with power to govern themselves by such ordinances and resolutions, for municipal purposes, as they may deem proper, not to conflict with this charter, nor the Constitution and laws of this State, nor of the United States; with power to contract and be contracted with, sue and be sued, defend and be defended in all courts; to acquire property, for municipal purposes, by purchase or otherwise; to hold the same and all property and effects now belonging to said city, either in its own name or the name of others, to the use of said city for the purposes and intents for which the same were granted or dedicated; to use, manage, improve, sell and convey, rent or lease, and have the like power over property hereafter acquired; to have a common seal, and change it at pleasure; and to act with or without a seal.

Sec. 2. That no person shall be a qualified voter at any election of officers of said corporation unless he possess the qualifications of a citizen of this State, and has resided within the corporate limits of the city at least six months next preceding the election.

Sec. 3. That no person shall be eligible as an officer of said city who, at the time of his election, is not a legal voter in the State, and has not resided in the city one year next preceding his election.

Sec. 4. That the qualified voters of said corporation shall, at the next general election, elect one mayor, one marshal and nine alder-
men, who shall hold their respective offices for the term of two years, and until their successors are qualified.

Sec. 5. The mayor and board of aldermen shall constitute the city council, over which the mayor shall preside when present; and in case of a tie in the vote of the board he shall give the casting vote.

Sec. 6. That the city council shall have power to regulate the manner and time of holding and conducting elections, not incon-
sistent with the laws of the State, and shall judge of the eligibility and election returns of its members, and punish its members for
Laws of the State of Texas.misconduct, and, two-thirds of the members elect concurring, may expel a member; and shall have power to enforce the attendance of members by fine not to exceed two dollars.

Sec. 7. That the officers of said corporation, before entering upon the discharge of their duties, shall subscribe the oath of office required by the Constitution and laws of the State, which may be taken before any officer qualified to administer oaths.

Sec. 8. That the mayor shall convene the council whenever re-
quired to do so by three of the board of aldermen, and no meeting shall proceed to the transaction of any business unless it be com-
posed of a majority of the whole number of aldermen qualified, and such a number, with or without the mayor, shall be a quorum for the transaction of business.
Sec. 9. That the sittings or assemblies of the city council shall be public, except when, at the request of two-thirds of the members present, they shall deem it necessary to sit with closed doors.

Sec. 10. That in case of the inability of the mayor to perform his duties, by reason of absence or other cause, or in case of a vacan-
cy in said office occasioned by death resignation or otherwise, the board of aldermen shall appoint from their own body a mayor, pro tempore, who shall have all the powers of the mayor, and shall per-
form all the dnties of his office until such inability is removed or a successor is duly qualified; provided, that in no case shall the city council order an election on less than ten days’ notice.

Sec. 11. That whenever any order, resolution, by-law or ordi-
nance is passed by the council, and disagreed to by the mayor, it shall be inoperative, unless the same shall be passed by a vote of three-fourths of the members present, taken by “yeas” and “nays,” and entered on the journal: and no ordinance shall be altered or amended in any way except by repealing it.

Sec. 12. That the city council may elect a city secretary and treasurer, and such other subordinate officers as may be necessary for the general welfare of the corporation, and shall prescribe their duties.
Sec. 13. That the city council shall have power to remove any officer by a vote of three-fourths of the whole number of aldermen.

Sec. 14. That the mayor is hereby vested with all the powers and jurisdiction, within the limits of said corporation, for the trial of causes which may, by law, be exercised by justices of the peace under the laws of the State; and prosecutions, proceedings and trials had before him under this act and the by-laws and ordinances of the said corporation, shall be governed by the same laws that govern the proceedings of justices of the peace; and he shall be
Laws of the State of Texas.entitled to the same fees that justices of the peace are allowed for similar services.

Sec. 15. The city council may require such officers as they may see proper, to execute bonds for the faithful discharge of their du-
ties and trusts, in such amounts as they may deem necessary, with security to be approved by the council.

Sec. 16. That all processes from the mayor or recorder may be directed to and executed by the sheriff, any constable or the city marshal, in the same manner that similar processes from the justices of the peace are executed.

Sec. 17. That it shall be the duty of the mayor and board of aldermen to cause all officers entrusted with money belonging to the corporation, to publish on the first Monday in May of each year an accurate and detailed statement of the receipts and expenditures of the corporation, the said statement being sworn to before some offi-
cer qualified to administer oaths.
Sec. 18. That the fines imposed by the corporation shall, in no case, exceed one hundred dollars.

Sec. 19. That the mayor and board of aldermen shall have power to construct and improve streets and sidewalks, and may ap-
propriate money from the public fund of the city therefor; and lots adjacent to or fronting where improvements are made, may be taxed fifty per cent. of the amount expended in repairs; provided, said lots are diretly benefited, and their value enhanced by such repairs.

Sec. 20. The mayor and board of aldermen of the corporation of Hempstead shall have full power and authority to pass such by-
laws and ordinances as they may deem necessary, to maintain the cleanliness and healthfulness of the city; to secure the safety and convenience of passing in the streets; to determine the completion and repair of pavements and sidewalks, one-half the expense of which shall be at the expense of the owners of adjacent houses and lots; to establish a city police; to determine the means to be resorted to to extinguish fires and to prevent the same; to regulate balls, theatres and other public amusements; to close dram shops or drink-
ing saloons, whenever the public good shall require it; to establish one or more market places; to define and suppress nuisances, and to make all such regulations and ordinances as may be necessary for the peace and good order of the city; provided, all by-laws and ordinances passed by said mayor and board of aldermen shall not be contrary or antagonistic to the Constitution and laws of the State.

Sec. 21. That the city council shall have power, by a vote of the majority of the board, taken by “yeas” and “nays” and entered on the minutes, to assess licenses and tax hucksters, peddlers, auction-
eers, theatrical and other exhibitions, billiard tables, pigeon-hole
Laws of the State of Texas.tables, nine and ten pin alleys, public drays and wagons, carriages, omnibusses, grog shops, eating houses, beer saloons, and such other trades and occupations not herein specially mentioned, as are taxed by the laws of the State; and to suppress all disorderly houses, by whatever name known.

Sec. 22. That the city council shall have power to assess and col-
lect an annual direct tax upon all property, real and personal, situate and being within the limits of the corporation, not exceeding one half of one per centum, ad valorem.

Sec. 23. That any person or persons on whom or on whose voca-
tion a license tax has been assessed, shall, before engaging in such vocation, pay the city assessor and collector the amount of his tax, taking his receipt therefor, which receipt shall entitle him, or her, or them, to a corresponding license, to be issued by the mayor; and if any person or persons shall engage in any vocation within the limits of the city on whom or which a license tax has been as-
sessed by the city council, without having obtained a license there-
for from the mayor, such person or persons shall be liable to pay one-fourth the annual license tax for each week that he, she or they, may be so engaged, and in the same proportion for each day, recov-
erable before the mayor or any justice of the peace, or the district court; one-fourth part of the amount so recovered to go to the in-
formant, and the balance to the city.

Sec. 24. That after the time prescribed by law for the payment of city taxes, such officer as the city council may charge with the assessment and collection of taxes may proceed to seize on any property, real or personal, on which the tax has not been paid, or that belongs to a delinquent tax payer; and after advertising the same by posting in at least three public places within the city, or by advertisement in some newspaper at least fifteen days, specifying the time and place of sale, may sell so much of such property to the highest bidder, for cash, as will pay the taxes due thereon, or that may be due from such delinquent, as the case may be, together with the costs of advertising and selling, unless the tax and costs be paid before the day of sale. If the sales be not completed in one day they may be continued from day to day till completed.

Sec. 25. That for any property sold for taxes the mayor shall be and is hereby authorized and empowered to make title, in con-
formity with the laws of the State governing the sale of property for taxes.

Sec. 26. That the assessor and collector shall, after his sales, make return to the council of all property sold, and the name of the purchaser of each parcel of property, which returns shall be preserved among the archives of the city.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p:
Sec. 27. The boundaries of the city of Hempstead shall be as follows: Beginning at a stake two hundred feet south of the south-
east corner of the Abbott tract; thence three thousand nine hun-
dred and twenty feet westward to a stake, which is the northwest corner of the town of Hempstead; thence nine thousand two hun-
dred and sixty feet southwestward to a stake, which is the south-
west corner of said town; thence nine thousand four hundred and eight feet eastward to a stake, which is the southeast corner of said town; thence nine thousand two hundred and sixty feet north-
ward to a stake, which is the northeast corner of said town; thence five thousand four hundred and eighty-eight feet westward, to the point of beginning; the whole area being two thousand acres, as surveyed in January, A. D. 1857.

Sec. 28. The mayor and board of aldermen shall pass needful ordinances regulating the assessor and assessment of taxes; the re-
ceiver and collection of taxes; the advertising, sale and redemption of property, and conveyances of the same when sold to enforce pay-
ment of taxes, as herein authorized; and for correction of assess-
ments, so as to include all property omitted in previous assessments, not extending back more than four years; and put the property omitted in any person’s assessment upon a corrected bill, charging for the years omitted according to the value in that year; and may deduct for prompt payment of taxes not exceeding ten per cent. on the amount, and may add for delayed payment not exceeding six per cent. and interest.

Sec. 29. That the mayor shah have power to employ a prosecuting attorney, to prosecute for or defend the interests of the city in all suits brought in the name of the corporation, or against it, where the services of such attorney, in the opinion of the mayor, may be necessary; and that for such services the attorney shall be paid out of the public treasury.
Sec. 30. That this act be in force from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER VIII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Texas Dry Dock Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That George H. Delesdernier, Daniel A. Sullivan, W. W. Upham, George Sealey, R. H. Wynne, Charles Fowler, Henry G. Briggs and Henry B. Andrews, with such others as they may as-
sociate with them from time to time, their successors or assigns, be and they are hereby created a body politic and corporate under the name and style of “The Texas Dry Dock Company,” with a capital stock of one hundred thousand dollars, to be increased to two hun-
dred and fifty thousand dollars, to be divided into shares of one hundred dollars each, for the purpose of erecting, or causing to be erected, a dry dock or docks at or near the city of Galveston, at a point to be selected by said company.

Sec. 2. That said company, under the name and style of the Texas Dry Dock Company, shall be capable to contract, to buy and to receive all kinds of property, moveable or immoveable, real or personal, that may be necessary for said corporation to construct said dry dock and appurtenances, and to make such other improve-
ments, as warehouses, wharves, machine shops, as may be deemed necessary to promote the interest of said company; and they may lease, sell and dispose of any such property; may borrow money on the faith of this charter, and also pledge any property, real or personal, they may have acquired for the payment of the same. They may sue and be sued, and have a common seal.

Sec. 3. That the parties above named as corporators are hereby constituted commissioners to open the books for subscription to the capital stock; to close them and to reopen them, if necessary, at such time and places as they may select, until fifty thousand dol-
lars of the stock is subscribed, when they shall call a meeting of the stockholders, and a plurality being present holding a majority of shares, they shall proceed to organize by electing a board of direc-
tors, of not less than five or more than ten, who shall select from their number a president, vice president, and secretary and treas-
urer, and such other officers as may be provided for in their by-laws; and they establish such ordinances, rules, by-laws and regulations as they may think necessary for the protection, use and government of said company, not contrary to the Constitution and laws of Texas or of the United States.

Sec. 4. That said corporation shall have, use and exercise all
Laws of the State of Texas.the powers necessary for the purpose of its creation, and may also use its steam power for any and all purposes that the same may be applicable to, and for that purpose may erect such wharves, ware-
houses and machinery as may be deemed requisite; and they shall be entitled to ask, demand, levy, collect, sue for and recover such toll, fees or compensation for labor performed or services rendered, or for use of property, as may be in accordance with any special agreement, or the rates established by the board of directors.

Sec. 5. That the election of directors shall be annual, at such time and place as may be designated in the by-laws, and all vacan-
cies shall be filled by the directors until the next regular annual election, and the directors shall hold their offices until their suc-
cessors are elected and qualified.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted, That the grant heretofore made by the State of Texas to the “Galveston Dry Dock Company,” and which was forfeited by a non-compliance with the terms and conditions attached thereto, be and they are hereby rented and leased to the “Texas Dry Dock Company” for the term of ninety-
nine years, at the annual rent of five dollars a year; provided, they shall erect, or cause to be built, a dry dock within two years from the passage of this act, or the lease hereby granted and made shall be null and void.
Sec. 7. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

The foregoing act, received in the office of the Secretary of State the thirtieth day of March, one thousand eight hundred and sev-
enty-one, having been presented to the Governor of Texas for his approval, and not having been returned by him to the house in which it originated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has become a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER IX.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Gonzales Agricultural and Industrial Association.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That there is hereby created a body politic and corporate to be styled the “Gonzales Agricultural and Industrial Associa-
tion.” Said corporation shall be capable of sueing and being sued in any and all courts whatsoever, to use a common seal, to contract and make and enforce the necessary by-laws, rules and regulations to carry into effect the object of this charter, the same not be in-
consistent with the Constitution and laws of the United States or of the State of Texas.

Sec. 2. That said corporation shall be enabled to purchase and hold such real and personal property as may be necessary to effectuate and sustain the objects of its creation, which are hereby declared to be to encourage and promote the development of the ag-
ricultural and industrial interests of the State.

Sec. 3. That the officers of the Gonzales Agricultural and in-
dustrial Association, G. W. L. Fly, President, R. T. Knox, Vice President, W. O. S. Cook, Corresponding Secretary, J. P. Miller, Secretary, and T. J. Pilgrim, Sr., Treasurer, be, and are hereby authorized, to open books at the town of Gonzales for subscriptions to the capital stock of said corporation, in such amounts as may be necessary, for the legitimate objects of said association, to be de-
termined by them, the said capital stock to be divided into shares of five dollars each. In the election by stockholders, each share shall be entitled to one vote, provided no stockholder shall be entitled to more than twenty-five votes.

Sec. 4. That said corporators shall give notice by publication in the newspapers published in Gonzales county, of the opening of said books, which shall be kept open for thirty days, or longer, if necessary, to obtain the required amount of stock.

Sec. 5. That at the time of subscribing the whole amount of such stock, subscription shall be paid in. Such stock shall be deemed personal assets, and shall be transferred only on the books of said corporation, by the person owning the same, or his legally constituted agent, attorney, legal representative, trustee or guardian, and said stock shall ever be held subject to any demand due from the stockholder to said corporation before or at the date of the transfer.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p:
Sec. 6. On the subscription and payment of the stock adver-
tised for by said corporation, they shall proceed to an organization. The affairs and business of the company shall be managed by a board of directors, not less than five nor more than seven in number, who shall be elected annually by the stockholders, the day of elec-
tion to be fixed by said corporators. They shall hold their offices for the term of twelve months, or until their successors are elected and qualified. Thirty days notice shall be given of all elections for di-
rectors. No person shall be eligible as a director, secretary or treas-
urer, unless he owns at least two shares of the capital stock of said company. The said board shall elect a president and vice president from their number, fill vacancies, appoint corresponding secretary, recording secretary and treasurer, and such other officers as they may deem necessary, and require bond and security for the faith-
ful performance of their duties, if they see fit, and do all other things that they may deem necessary in conducting the business of said association not in contravention of the Constitution and laws of the United States or of this State. A majority of the board of di-
rectors shall constitute a quorum to transact business.

Sec. 7. Instruments or contracts in writing authorized by the association shall be signed by the president and countersigned by the Secretary, with the seal of the association affixed, and said asso-
ciation shall be bound by the parol contracts made by their author-
ized agents within the scope of their authority, confirmed by reso-
lution of the board of directors.

Sec. 8. That the stockholders in said corporation shall be liable, in a just ratio or proportion, to the amount of their stock held or subscribed, for all debts incurred or created during their said own-
ership of said stock to the extent of their stock subscribed.

Sec. 9. That the said corporation may receive and hold, by gift, grant or bequest, for the benefit of the same, any bonds, money, labor, material, or other property, but the whole amount of prop-
erty held by said association, shall not exceed fifty thousand dollars.

Sec. 10. That said president and board of directors shall have power to make all necessary rules and regulations for the holding of their fairs and for the preservation of order, and the protection of the fair grounds from imposition.
Sec. 11. That this act shall be in force for the period of thirty years, and take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER X.

opener.salute: An act to incorporate the Powell Bridge Company, in Navarro County.

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That Henry L. Malloy, Alfred Brooks, and their associates and successors, be and are hereby constituted and declared to be a body politic and corporate, under the name and style of the “Powell Bridge Company.”

Sec. 2. That the said persons, their associates and successors, under the name and style aforesaid, may sue, and be sued, plead and be impleaded, defend and be defended in all the courts of this State, and may have a common seal.

Sec. 3. That said persons, their associates and successors, under the name and style aforesaid, shall be authorized to construct and keep up a toll bridge over Chambers creek, on the road from Cor-
sicana to Tyler, by way of Springs’ ferry, on the Trinity river, and Athens; and to build, construct and keep up causeways, or mud bridges, through the bottom or low lands, to the high lands on either side of said Chambers creek.

Sec. 4. That said bridge company shall complete said bridge, causeway, or mud bridges, and shall open a road through the bot-
tom or low lands, to the high lands on either side of said Chambers creek, at least thirty feet wide, within one year from and after the passage of this act; otherwise this charter shall be null and void.

Sec. 5. That the privileges herein granted to said bridge com-
pany shall continue for twenty years, and no longer, from the pas-
sage of this act, unless said bridge company shall sooner wilfully or negligently fail or refuse to comply with the conditions of this act, in which case this charter shall be deemed to be forfeited.

Sec. 6. That said bridge company be and is hereby authorized to charge and collect tolls, not to exceed the following rates, to wit: For every wagon with six horses or oxen, one dollar; for every wagon with four horses or oxen, seventy-five cents; for every wagon with two horses or oxen, fifty cents; for every buggy and two horses, fifty cents; for every buggy and one horse, twenty-five cents; for every man and horse, ten cents; for loose stock, horses or cattle, per head three cents; for sheep or hogs, per head, two cents. Provided, the following named persons shall at all times pass over free of charge, to wit: Ministers of the gospel in going to and from church; persons going to and from church; jurors going to
Laws of the State of Texas.and from court; mill boys on horseback; officers on official busi-
ness; provided, that no person or persons shall erect a toll bridge across said creek within three miles of said bridge.

Sec. 7. That said bridge company and their successors are hereby required to keep said bridge, and the causeways or mud bridges through said bottom or low lands, in good repair; and should any accident or damage occur to person or property in crossing the same, caused by the negligence of said corporation, then said cor-
poration shall be responsible in damages for the same to the person or persons so injured, or to the owner or owners of the property so damaged.
Sec. 8. That this act be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER XI.

opener.salute: An Act incorporating the Texas Coal and Mining Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That James H. Raymond, C. W. Whitis, James P. Mc-
Kinney, W. C. Phillips, A. W. Terrell, D. A. Wray, Thomas R. Patton and C. Harbert, and such other persons as they may asso-
ciate with themselves, be and they are hereby created a body cor-
porate and politic by the name and style of the “Texas Coal and Mining Company,” with authority to make contracts; to have suc-
cession and a common seal; to make by-laws for its government; and in its said corporate name to sue and be sued; to grant and receive, to purchase and hold real and personal estate; to borrow money and contract debts, and generally to do and perform all such acts and things as may be necessary and proper for, or incident to the fulfillment of its obligations and the maintenance of its rights under this charter, and consistent with the Constitution and laws of this State.

Sec. 2. The capital stock of said corporation shall not exceed the sum of five hundred thousand dollars, which shall be divided into shares of one hundred dollars each, and each share shall entitle the owner thereof to one vote, in person or by proxy, at all meetings of the company; which meetings may be held at such times and places as may be named by the persons herein named as corporators, or by the directors after the company is organized. The shares
Laws of the State of Texas.shall be deemed personal estate, and may be transferred by convey-
ance recorded in the books of the company at its principal office, or in books kept at such other places as the directors may appoint; and any transfer recorded at any other place than the principal office of the company, shall be communicated to the principal office and recorded there within thirty days after the same were made.

Sec. 3. The immediate control, government and direction of the affairs of the company shall be vested in a board of not less than five directors, to be elected by the stockholders, and the directors shall elect one of their number to be president of the company. No person shall be eligible to the office of director unless he shall own at least five shares of the stock of the company. The directors shall have power to fill any vacancy that may occur in the board, and may appoint such officers and agents as they may consider necessary for the management of the affairs of the company, and prescribe and require bonds and security from such officers or agents for the faithful performance of their duties. The said directors shall cause to be kept correct records of all meetings of the direc-
tors and company, and accounts, books and accounts of the receipts and expenditures of the company. A majority of the board shall have the power of a full board, and all conveyances and contracts executed in writing, signed by the president and attested by the seal of the company, and in pursuance of a vote of the directors, shall be valid and binding upon the company. The first board of directors shall be chosen by the corporators named in this act, and such persons as they may associate with them, at such time and place as a majority of them may name; and all subsequent elections for directors shall be made by the vote of a majority of the stockholders at the principal office of the company, and at such time as may be appointed by the company or a majority of the board of directors.

Sec. 4. The board of directors may acquire, by purchase or in payment for stock of the company, such real estate as they may think desirable for the mining of coal, iron, lead or any other minerals; and the said company shall have full power and authority to carry on the business of mining coal, iron, lead or any other minerals, upon any lands they may acquire in this State, and to smelt, refine or manufacture any minerals, with the right of acting, owning and operating any buildings, works or machinery that may be necessary for their object, and also with the right of building, owning and operating any vehicles that may be needed for the transportation of their products to market.
Sec. 5. This act shall take effect from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER XII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Galveston Seamen’s Home.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That John S. Sellers, G. H. Sherwood, B. F. Dunklin, A. W. Wakelie and J. S. Beers, who represent the Galveston Port Society, are, together with their associates, created a body corporate under the name of “The Galveston Seamen’s Home,” and by said corpor-
ate name may sue and be sued, and do all things necessary or advisa-
ble in the opinion of said body corporate, not inconsistent with the Constitution and laws of the State, for carrying out the objects per-
taining thereto.

Sec. 2. This incorporate body may purchase and hold land, ex-
clusive of improvements, to the value of fifty thousand dollars at date of acquisition of same; and also personal property to the amount of fifty thousand dollars, and may sell and convey and re-
purchase property, and use and dispose of the same to the best in-
terest of said “Home.”
Sec. 3. These incorporators, or a majority of them, shall adopt a constitution and by-laws for the government of said corporation, and elect officers according to such constitution and by-laws.

Sec. 4. This corporation has power to receive all bequests and donations that may have been intended therefor, or that may be hereafter made to it, and may appropriate any means or money it has or may have in any manner that may be deemed advisable to such corporation; and lots and other means donated to “Galveston Port Society” is vested, so far as the last mentioned society may or can dispose of, in this body corporate. That the property held by this society is for the sole benefit of seamen under the provisions of the aforesaid constitution and by-laws.
Sec. 5. This incorporation is made for the term of fifty years, and takes effect from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER XIII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate Paris Commercial College, Paris, Texas.

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That J. M. Santler, S. B. Maxey, J. D. Wathan, J. W. Broad, J. M. Fort, T. D. Wooten, A. S. Johnson, S. E. Clement, H. S. Bennett, E. D. Dohoney, J. B Bennett, J. K. R. Campbell, Wm. Brenstelle, C. R. Thebo and J. R. Jones, trustees of Paris Commercial College, situate in the city of Paris, county of Lamar, Texas, be and are hereby created a body corporate, under the name and style of the Trustees of the Paris Commercial College, and by that name and style may sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, enact by-laws, rules and regulations, purchase, take, hold and enjoy all property of every and all kinds for the benefit of said college; and by that name and style aforesaid to convert said property into money, and dispose of the same; and shall have a common seal for the transaction of its business.

Sec. 2. That the rights and privileges herein granted shall ex-
tend to the trustees named in the preceding section and their suc-
cessors, and to no other persons. In the event of the death of one or more of said trustees, all the rights and privileges by the pro-
visions of this act shall be taken, exercised and enjoyed by their successors; and on the death of all of said trustees, then the corpora-
tion herein created shall be extinct.

Sec. 3. That the board of trustees shall have power, upon the recommendation of the faculty, to confer diplomas in the commer-
cial department, and degrees in arts and sciences upon the gradu-
ates of said commercial college, and upon such persons as they may deem worthy, and give diplomas of the same by the proper signa-
tures and endorsements of the president and faculty of said com-
mercial college, and by the board of trustees, or a majority of said board of trustees.

Sec. 4. That all donations and bequests to said commercial col-
lege shall be good and binding, although the corporate name may not have been properly used or stated by the person or persons mak-
ing such donations or bequests.

Sec. 5. The board of trustees may elect from their own num-
ber, under such rules and regulations as they may adopt, and for such terms and times as they may see proper, a president, secretary and treasurer, or any other officer or agent necessary in the board.
Laws of the State of Texas.They shall also have the power to contract, enlarge, alter or remove all things necessary to the proper conduct and management of said commercial college not contrary to law or inconsistent with this charter.
Sec. 6. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER XIV.

opener.salute: An Act for the relief of F. H. Arlitt.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the Comptroller of said State be and is hereby au-
thorized and required to issue his warrant in favor of F. H. Arlitt for the sum of eight hundred and thirty-three dollars and seventy-
two cents due to said F. H. Arlitt for services rendered by him to the State, of Texas as assessor and collector of taxes during the years 1865 and 1866.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That the State Treasurer is hereby authorized to pay the said draft out of any moneys in the Treasury not otherwise appropriated, the said F. R. Arlitt receipting for the same.

Sec. 3. That this act take effect and be in force from and after-
its passage.

The foregoing act, received in the office of Secretary of State March thirty, one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one, having been presented to the Governor of Texas for his approval, and not having been returned by him to the house in which it originated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has become a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER XV.

opener.salute: An Act for the relief of the Eastern Texas Railroad Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the Eastern Texas Railroad Company shall have, two years from and after the passage of this act, to construct and put in good running order, fifty miles of said road, and have two years thereafter, for the like construction of every additional section of fifty miles of line of said road; provided, however, that if said com-
pany shall fail to construct and put in good running condition fifty miles of said road within two years from the passage of this act, or shall thereafter fail to construct, as aforesaid, fifty additional miles of said road during each and every succeeding period of two years, until said road shall be finally completed, then in either event said company shall forfeit all rights, privileges, and immunities granted by this act and the original act for the incorporation of said com-
pany, save and except such rights, privileges and immunities as said company may be entitled to claim, if any part of said road shall have been fully constructed and in running order at or previous to the date of such forfeiture, in respect to such part of said road so completed.
Sec. 2. That said company shall have the right to commence and prosecute the further construction of said road at and from such point or points on the line of the same as it may deem best.

Sec. 3. That the time between the second day of March, (1861,) eighteen hundred and sixty-one, and the thirtieth day of March, (1870,) eighteen hundred and seventy, the date of the acceptance of the present Constitution of the State of Texas by Congress, shall not be reckoned against said company, but it shall now have the same time for the performance of anything required of it in its char-
ter (subject to such modification thereof as is made by this act) as it had on said second day of March, (1861,) eighteen hundred and six-
ty-one; provided, however, that this section shall not be construed to revive any grant or grants to lands in favor of said company, if such grants are prohibited by the Constitution of the State, but it shall be entitled to such grants as are provided for in its charter, if it shall be decided judicially that the same are constitutional.

Sec. 4. That said company may borrow money on lands secured by mortgage or deed of trust, with power of sale, including
Laws of the State of Texas.its franchises as well as roadway, and all other property; and such mortgage or deed of trust may be enforced according to its terms; and the franchises, as well as the roadway, and other property con-
veyed at any legal sale under such mortgage or deed of trust, to be fully used and enjoyed by the purchaser or purchasers thereof as the same could have been done by said company if such sale had not been made.

Sec. 5. That said company shall be entitled to take and receive either personal or real property donated or conveyed to it for the purpose of securing or expediting the construction of said road upon such terms and conditions as may be agreed upon between said com-
pany and the party making the same. And said company may lawfully receive aid from the counties through which its road is to pass, in pursuance of section thirty-two of the general provisions of the Constitution of the State.

Sec. 6. That said company shall have the right to construct its road in such gauge as it may deem best, and it shall be entitled to the benefit of all such general laws as are now in force or as may be hereafter enacted, in aid of or for the encouragement of the con-
struction of railroads; provided, said road shall run through or within one-half mile of the town of Homer in Angelina county.
Sec. 7. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

The foregoing act, received in the office of Secretary of State March thirty, one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one, having been presented to the Governor of Texas for his approval, and not having been returned by him to the house in which it originated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has become a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div3.head: CHAPTER XVI.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the city of Calvert, in Robertson county.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That all the inhabitants of the city of Calvert in Robertson county, be and they are hereby declared, a body politic and corpor-
Laws of the State of Texas.ate under the name and style of the “Mayor, Aldermen and Inhab-
itants of the City of Calvert,” and by that name they and their successors shall be known in law, and shall have power to sue and be sued, plead and be inpleaded in all courts, and in all actions and matters whatever, and may have a common seal, and by the same name shall have power to acquire, hold and dispose of any estate, real and personal for the benefit of said corporation; provided, such real estate be within the limits of said city.

Sec. 2. That the bounds and limits of said city shall be as fol-
lows: commencing at a point one mile north of the centre of the court house square in the city of Calvert; thence east one mile; thence south two miles; thence west, two miles; thence north two miles; thence east, one mile, to the place of beginning.

Sec. 3. That no person shall vote at any election in said city, un-
less he be a qualified voter under the laws of this State, and a resi-
dent within the limits of said city for six months next preceding an election; and no person shall be eligible to any office in said city, unless he be a qualified elector thereof, under the provisions of this act, and shall have been a resident within the limits of said city for twelve months next preceding his election or appointment; pro-
vided, that all officers of said city shall take and subscribe the oath prescribed by the Constitution, which oath may be administered by any officer by law authorized to administer oaths.

Sec. 4. That at the next general State election, to wit: on the second Tuesday in November, A. D. 1872, and every two years thereafter, the qualified voters of said city shall elect a mayor, a city marshal, and five aldermen, which said officers shall hold their offices for two years, and until their successors shall be elected and qualified; that the city marshal shall be, ex officio, chief of police, and assessor and collector of taxes for said city, that the other officers of said city shall be a secretary and treasurer, to be selected by the aldermen from their own number; a city attorney, to be elected by the aldermen, and such other inferior officers and agents as the city council may from time to time direct and appoint, who shall hold their offices for two years and until their successors are elected and qualified; provided, that any officer of said city may be removed by a vote of two thirds of the aldermen present at any regular meeting of the council, for any neglect of duty, malfeas-
ance, or default in office.

Sec. 5. That the mayor and aldermen shall constitute the city council, over which the mayor, when present, shall preside; pro-
vided, that any three of the aldermen, either with or without the mayor, shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business.

Sec. 6. That a regular meeting of the city council shall be held
Laws of the State of Texas.once in each month, at such time and place as they may direct, and the mayor, upon his own motion, or upon the application of three aldermen, may call special meetings of the city council; provided, no compensation shall be allowed the mayor and aldermen for any special meeting of the city council.

Sec. 7. That no officer of said city shall be allowed in his own name, or in the name of any other person, to be in anywise inter-
ested in any lease, sale or contract for any work, or undertaking, whatsoever, made by said city, or wherein said city may be a party.

Sec. 8. That in the event of a vacancy in the office of mayor the aldermen of said city shall elect one of their own number to fill such vacancy for the unexpired term, and until his successor shall be elected and qualified; and in case of the temporary absence of the mayor, the aldermen shall select one of their own number to act as mayor for the time being, and such person so selected is hereby vest-
ed with all the privileges and powders of the mayor elect; and should there be a vacancy in the office of aldermen, then the city council is hereby empowered to fill such vacancy by election, and such per-
son so elected shall exercise all the duties and privileges of alder-
man until Iris successor be elected and qualified; and all the vacan-
cies in the other offices of said city shall be filled by election by the city council, and the persons so elected shall continue in office for the unexpired term to which they shall be so elected, and until their successors be elected and qualified.

Sec. 9. That the aldermen shall require the mayor, city marshal, and treasurer, each to enter into bond, with two good and sufficient securities to be approved of by the aldermen, in such sum as they may deem proper, conditionel for the faithful and impartial dis-
