charge of their duties, which bond shall not be void upon the first recovery.
Sec. 10. That until the first election, as provided for in this act, the mayor, aldermen, treasurer, marshal and attorney of said city shall be appointed by the Governor.

Sec. 11. That the mayor is hereby vested with all the powers and jurisdiction, civil and criminal, within the limits of said city, which may, by law, be exercised by justices of the peace; and in prosecu-
tions, trials and proceedings before him, had under the provisions of this act, and under the by-laws and ordinances of said city, he shall be governed by the laws regulating proceedings in justices’ courts, in force at the time, and he shall be entitled to such fees as may he, by law, allowed to justices of the peace for similar services, or such as may be fixed by resolution of the city council.

Sec. 12. That the city marshal, in addition to his powers and privileges as such, is hereby vested with all the powers and privi-
Laws of the State of Texas.leges of a constable of said county of Robertson, and as such may execute process, civil and criminal, within the limits of said county, and shall receive such fees as may, by law, be allowed to other con-
stables, or such fees as may be prescribed by the city council, by resolution or ordinance.

Sec. 13. That the city council shall cause the secretary and treas-
urer, on the first Monday in April of each year, to publish an accu-
rate and just statement of all the receipts and expenditures of the treasurer of said city for the fiscal year ending on said day, and a just and true statement of the condition of said treasury, which statements shall be subscribed and sworn to before the judge of the district court or clerk of the district court of said county, and the same shall be published for four successive weeks in some news-
paper published in said city.

Sec. 14. That should the secretary and treasurer fail to account, as provided for in this act, he shall be subject to a fine of five hun-
dred dollars, to be recovered on motion of the district attorney, be-
fore the district court of said county, after ten days previous notice of such motion shall have first been given; and it is hereby made the duty of the district attorney to see that the provisions of this act are faithfully complied with. Said secretary and treasurer shall also be liable in a civil action upon his bond.
Sec. 15. That all revenue arising from fines and taxes shall be paid into the city treasury, and shall not be paid out except upon warrant of the mayor, approved by the city council.

Sec. 16. That the salaries and fees of the officers of said city shall be fixed by the city council, and shall in no case exceed the amounts named in this section, to wit: the salary of mayor shall not exceed one thousand dollars for any one year and his fees of office; the salary of the city marshal shall not exceed six hundred dollars for any one year and his fees of office, together with such per cent-
age upon the amount of taxes collected by him, as the city council may allow, not to exceed that by law allowed to sheriffs for similar services; the salary of the city attorney shall not exceed five hundred dollars per annum, and such fees as may be allowed him by the city council, not to exceed two dollars and fifty cents for each conviction before the mayor, for any violation of any of the by-laws and ordi-
nances of said city, to be taxed in the bill of costs against the de-
fendant; the salary of secretary and treasurer shall not exceed five hundred dollars for any one year, and five per centum of all sums of money received and paid out by him, to be fixed by order of the city council; the salaries and fees of such other inferior officers and agents of said city as may be provided for by the city council, shall be fixed by the city council; provided, that warrants for the pay of the salaries of all the officers shall issue monthly.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p:
Sec. 17. That the city council shall have power and authority to make and pass such by-laws and ordinances as they shall deem neces-
sary, to maintain the cleanliness and health of said city; to se-
cure the safety and convenience of persons passing in the streets, sidewalks, squares, and public highways of said city; to maintain and repair pavements in said streets at the cost of the proprietors of lands, houses, and lots fronting thereon, and to prevent any encroachments upon the public streets, highways and alleys of said city; to inspect premises and cause the abatement of anything what-
ever that may endanger the health and comfort of the inhabitants of said city; to organize an efficient police force, and establish rules for the government of the same; to determine in what part of said city the erection of wooden buildings shall be prohibited; to pro-
vide proper safeguards to prevent injury by fire; to cause theatres, play-houses, and other places for showsor exhibitions to be closed, whenever preservation of order may require it; to close dram shops and drinking saloons when deemed expedient; to establish markets, and regulate the same, to define and suppress nuisances; to regulate and fix the compensation of draymen, and other common carriers in said city; to require railroad companies to keep in repair the streets through which their track may run, and to construct and keep in repair safe crossings at the intersections of streets; to require rail-
road companies to cut ditches, and provide all means necessary to thoroughly drain the streets through which their track may run; to regulate the speed of locomotives; and to establish all such rules and regulations as they may deem useful and necessary to preserve the peace and promote the general welfare and happiness of the in-
habitants of said city; provided, that no by-law, ordinance or regu-
lation, inconsistent with the Constitution and laws of this State shall have any force and effect.

Sec. 18. That the city council, by a vote of two-thirds present at any regular meeting taken by “yeas” and “nays” and en-
tered upon the journals, shall have power to assess, license and tax hawkers, peddlers, auctioneers, theatrical and other exhibitions, shows and amusements, billiard tables, nine and ten pin alleys, pub-
lic drays and wagons, dram shops and drinking saloons, beer saloons, and, such other trades and occupations as may be taxed by any gen-
eral law of this State, in no case to exceed one-half the State tax allowed upon such occupations; and may, in like manner, assess and collect a direct annual tax upon all property real and personal, sit-
uate within the limits of said city, not to exceed one-half the State tax allowed in any one year; and may also collect a poll tax of one dollar upon all male persons residing within said city, over the age of twenty-one years, and under the age of fifty years.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p:
Sec. 19. That every person on whom or on whose vocation, an occupation tax may have been assessed, shall, before engaging in such vocation, pay to the city treasurer the amount of said tax, taking his receipt therefor, which receipt shall entitle him to a cor-
responding license, to be issued by the mayor. If any person or persons shall engage in any vocation within the limits of said city, on which a license tax may have been assessed, without first having obtained a license therefor from the mayor, such person or persons shall be liable to an additional assessment of fifty per centum of the amount so due, to be recovered by suit in any court having juris-
diction. All assessments and collections of taxes in said city shall be made in accordance with the laws of this State regulating the as-
sessment and collection of taxes, and the mayor and aldermen are hereby empowered to enforce the payment of all taxes due said city, under such rules and regulations and penalties as they may pre-
scribe, in accordance with the laws of this State.

Sec. 20. That the city council shall have power to suppress all gaming and gambling houses, and houses of prostitution, and dis-
orderly houses of every character, and shall adopt summary meas-
ures to enforce the same.

Sec. 21. That, the city council shall have power to prescribe pen-
alties for the violation of the by-laws and ordinances of said city not to exceed a fine of one hundred dollars in any one case, or imprison-
ment for three months.

Sec. 22. That all general laws of the State relating to the in-
corporation of cities and towns, and not inconsistent with this char-
ter, shall be taken and construed as a part thereof.
Sec. 23. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER XVII.

opener.salute: An Act to authorize James A. Nelms and Preston Owens to erect a toll bridge over Chambers creek, in the county of Navarro, Texas.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That James A. If elms and Preston Owens be and they are hereby authorized and empowered to erect a toll bridge over Cham-
Laws of the State of Texas.bers Creek, in the county of Navarro, where the public road from Corsicana to Tyler crosses the same; and that they be authorized and empowered to charge, receive and collect toll for crossing on said bridge at the following rates, to wit: For every footman, three cents; for man and horse, ten cents; for every one horse vehicle, twenty cents; for every two horse vehicle, twenty-five cents; for every ox wagon, and two yoke of oxen, thirty cents; for every ox wagon, and four to six yoke of oxen, fifty cents; for every two horse wagon, twenty-five cents; for every four to six horse wagon, fifty cents; for every loose horse, five cents; for cattle, sheep, goats and hogs, per head, one cent.

Sec. 2. That the right and privilege herein granted shall inure to the benefit of the said James A. Nelms and Preston Owens, their heirs and assigns, for twenty years; provided, however, that in order to secure the privileges conferred herein, they shall, within twelve months, from the passage of this act, erect and construct a good, safe and substantial bridge over the said Chambers creek, at the crossing aforesaid, and shall keep the same in good repair; and in the event of any accident or casualty destroying said bridge, the said James A. Nelms and Preston Owens shall reconstruct the same from the date of such accident or casualty; otherwise the franchise herein-granted shall abate.

Sec. 3. That no bridge shall be permitted or allowed to collect toll, or be erected, with the right so to do, for three miles above and below said Anderson’s crossing of the Tyler and Corsicana road on Chambers creek.
Sec. 4. This act shall take effect, and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER XVIII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the “San Antonio Jockey Club.”

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That R. W. Peay, W. B. Knox, W. R. Story, John With-
ers, John G. Ward, W. H. Bennett, James R. Marmion and others, who are or may hereafter become stockholders in said company, and their successors and assigns be, and they are hereby constituted a
Laws of the State of Texas.body corporate and politic, under the name and style of the “San Antonio Jockey Club,” and by that name shall have succession, and be capable in law to sue and be sued; plead and be impleaded; to enact by-laws, rules and regulations, not in conflict with the laws of the State, for the proper management, prosecution and preservation of the property and business of the said company.

Sec. 2. The said corporation is hereby authorized and empow-
ered to purchase, hold, possess and acquire all such real and per-
sonal estate as shall be necessary for the transaction of its business, and the same to sell and convey, and for such purposes, may have and use a common seal.

Sec. 3. Said corporation shall have a right to demand and re-
ceive such compensation as it may deem proper, for admission to its enclosures and lands.
Sec. 4. The capital stock of said company shall be ten thousand dollars, with the privilege of increasing the same to fifty thousand dollars, lawful currency of the United States.

Sec. 5. The shares of said company shall be one hundred dol-
lars each, and the company may determine at any time, to what extent the non-payment of shares upon stock shall operate as a for-
feiture of the same.

Sec. 6. The business and affairs of said company shall be con-
ducted by a president, four vice presidents, a secretary and treas-
urer, and they shall constitute the executive board during their term of office.
Sec. 7. In the elections held by this corporation for officers or otherwise, each share of stock shall be entitled to one vote.

Sec. 8. The officers of the company shall be elected as the by-
laws of the corporation may direct, and the officers chosen must each hold at least one share of the capital stock in his own proper right.

Sec. 9. The books of the company shall be open at all times to the inspection of any stockholder, and no share of stock shall be transferred, by the secretary except upon said company’s books, when a new certificate shall issue to the assignee.
Sec. 10. This act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage, and continue in force for ninety-nine (99) years.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER XIX.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Corpus Christi Navigation Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That Perry Doddridge, Thomas Kearny, Lewis G. Brown, John B. Mitchell, George F. Evans, N. Gussett, U. Lott, R. Hol-
bein, John Woessner, B. Jordan, W. L. Rogers, B. King, Ed. Buck-
ley, L. D. Brewster, John Babb, Hines Clark, W. W. Wright, W. N. Staples, and their associates, successors and assigns, be and they are hereby constituted and created a body corporate, in law and in fact, under the name and style of the “Corpus Christi Navigation Com-
pany,” and under that name shall have capacity to make contracts, may sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, have and use a com-
mon seal, buy, hold, lease, mortgage, or sell and convey, real and personal property for the uses of said company; may make and en-
force all necessary by-laws and rules for its general government, and the management of its business, not inconsistent with the Con-
stitution of this State and of the United States.

Sec. 2. The objects of said company are hereby declared to be the construction, use and maintenance of a ship channel from Cor-
pus Christi Bay, either by way of and through Turtle Cove, in the direction of the United States light house, into Aransas Bay, or by the route of a canal to be excavated and constructed through Mus-
tang Island, or by a channel to be opened directly from Corpus Christi Bay to and through Corpus Christi Pass, so as to connect Corpus Christi, by safe and practicable navigation with the Gulf of Mexico. Said company shall have authority, if deemed expedient or necessary for the fulfillment of their object, to construct an embank-
ment or levee across the mouth of the Laguna del Madre, in order to prevent the waters of Corpus Christi Bay from passing into said Laguna, and for the confining said waters to the excavated chan-
nel as an outlet; to build or purchase, own and hold, any dredge boats, steam tugs, or vessels that may be useful or necessary in the construction of said canal, or convenient or a help to the navigation thereof; to build or purchase, own and hold such piers or wharves, with railways or tramways thereon, at Corpus Christi, for the re-
ception and unloading thereupon of ships or steamers coming to said port—with warehouses thereon for the protection and storing of the goods and merchandise brought to said port, and to levy and collect against said ships, steamers, or the goods or merchandise
Laws of the State of Texas.transported thereon, the charges and tolls usual and customary for the use of such wharves or warehouses.

Sec. 3. That the capital stock of the corporation shall be sev-
enty-five thousand dollars, with liberty to increase the same when-
ever the holders or representatives of one half of the stock shall so desire, to an amount not to exceed two hundred and fifty thousand dollars. Said stock shall be divided into shares of one hundred dollars each, each share entitling the holder to one vote, in person or by proxy at any meeting of the company, and to be transferrable in such manner as the by-laws of the company shall direct. Whenever the minimum amount of said stock shall have been subscribed, and thirty-three and one-third per cent. thereon actually paid in, the corporation may commence business.

Sec. 4. That the affairs of the company shall be managed and controlled by a board of directors, not less than seven (7) in number, a majority of whom shall constitute a quorum to do business, and said directors shall be elected from and by the stockholders. No person shall be eligible as a member of said board, unless he be the bona fide owner of ten (10) shares of the stock of said company. Said directors shall hold their offices for and during one year, or until their successors are elected. The board shall choose one of their number for president, who shall act as such during the term of said board, and the board may fill all vacancies therein, arising, from death or any cause, by appointment until the next election for directors. The first election for directors shall take place on the first Monday in June, A. D. 1871, and on that day in each year thereafter, in the city of Corpus Christi, at which place the prin-
cipal office and legal domicil of the corporation shall be located.

Sec. 5. That the board of directors shall have power to make all necessary by-laws for the carrying out of the provisions of this act, and the management of the business of the company, said by-laws to be approved by a majority of the stockholders; to manage the business of the corporation in all its departments; to appoint, pay and remove a secretary, treasurer, superintendent and engineer, and all such other officers, agents and employes as may be necessary from time to time, and to establish and enforce rules and regulations for the guidance of all such officers, agents and employes. They shall cause to be kept accurate records of their proceedings and those of the company, and accurate books and accounts of the receipts and expenditures of the company, which shall be open to inspection by the stockholders. They shall, annually, divide among the stockholders so much of the profits of the company as in their dis-
cretion they shall deem safe; but no dividend of any of the
Laws of the State of Texas.profits shall be made, unless the capital paid in remain unimpaired. They shall, annually, during the month of May, cause a full and accurate statements of the affairs of the company to be made out, sworn to by the president and secretary, and submitted to the in-
spection of the stockholders at their first subsequent meeting. They shall cause a book to the kept by the secretary, containing the names of all persons who are stockholders in said corporation, their place of residence, the number of shares of stock held by them respec-
tively, and the time when they became respectively the owners of such shares, which book shall at all times be open to the inspection of the creditors and stockholders, at the place of business or office of said corporation, and shall be evidence of the right of any person to vote at any election of directors. Proof of ownership to entitle a person to register as a stockholder shall be the exhibit of the origi-
nal certificate of stock, and if not in the hands of the first holder, then by exhibit of legal assignment thereof, or proof of ownership according to law. Any action of the holders of two-thirds of the issued stock shall be binding upon the remaining stockholders of the company.

Sec. 6. That a vote of the stockholders representing two-thirds of the stock, shall be sufficient at any time to remove any board of di-
rectors, and to appoint others in their stead; provided, that any meeting for such purpose shall only be convened by a notice to that effect, published for four weeks in one newspaper published in the city of Corpus Christi, and for two weeks previous to said meeting, in a newspaper published in the city of New Orleans, and which notice shall be signed by the owners of said two-thirds or by their legal representatives.

Sec. 7. That said corporation shall have the right to locate the route of the channel or canal herein designated, in such manner as upon actual survey by competent engineers, may appear most judi-
cious and conducive to the public interest, and for such objects may appropriate, use and hold so much of the public lands as may be required for the constructing of said channel or canal, and also so much as may be necessary for the work and embankments on either side of said channel or canal, not to exceed one hundred yards on each side thereof, and that private lands may be appropriated in like manner as is done by railroads.

Sec. 8. That said corporation shall have power to levy, receive and collect toll upon all freight passing through said channel or canal, not to exceed five (5) cents for every five (5) cubic feet of freight carried through the same, or at the rate of one-half of one cent for each and every mile of channel or canal on each one hun-
dred pounds of freight so carried, at the option of the corporation;
Laws of the State of Texas.provided, that all charges of tolls shall be made upon terms of equal-
ity to all persons navigating said canal; and the channel or canal mentioned in the first section of this act, shall be by said corpora-
tion excavated and maintained throughout its entire length, dur-
ing the continuance of this charter, to a depth of eight (8) feet large in ordinary tides, and with a width of at least one hundred (100) feet, and no tolls for the use of said canal shall be charged or levied until after due survey by three disinterested and competent seamen, or ship owners, for such purpose appointed by the District Judgo for Neuces county, and the mayor of the city of Corpus Christi, and after a report of such survey by said appointees, certi-
fied as true by them, or a majority of them, shall have been filed with said judge, certifying that said channel or canal has been com-
pleted by the company to the width and of the depth above men-
tioned. Said corporation shall also have power, if they shall deem advisable, to excavate and complete said canal to a depth of twelve (12) feet, and a width of two hundred (200) feet, but shall not be authorized, on account of such further extension, to make or collect any other or higher tolls than above mentioned.

Sec. 9. Any steamer, vessel or craft using said canal and refus-
ing to pay the toll established, and which is properly chargeable upon the freight carried under the provisions of this charter, on each refusal shall be held liable to double the amount of the current rate of toll which should have been paid to said corporation; and the same shall operate as a line [lien] and charge upon any such steamer, vessel or craft, and upon their freight, until the full pay-
ment thereof is made, to be enforced before any court of competent jurisdiction.

Sec. 10. That said company shall commence said channel or canal prior to the first day of June, 1872, and complete the same by the first day of June, 1875, and failing to do so shall forfeit all rights conferred by this act.

Sec. 11. That the board of directors, under such regulations as they may adopt, may appoint commissioners to receive subscriptions to the capital stock of said company, at such points and places as they may select. The said commissioners, at the time of receiving a subscription to the stock, shall demand and receive from each sub-
scriber at least five (5) per centum on the amount of his or her sub-
scription; and any agreement in writing, whereby any one shall be-
come a subscriber to stock, may be enforced against him or her, ac-
cording to the terms of said agreement. The balance of subscrip-
tions remaining due the corporation shall be paid by the subscribers from time to time, as the same may be assessed and required by the board of directors, in accordance with the provisions of the by-laws in force. If any subscriber shall fail to pay any such assessment
Laws of the State of Texas.or balance when required, his or her stock may be sold and con-
veyed by the corporation, under such rules and in such manner as may be prescribed by the by-laws; and all payments made shall be forfeited to the corporation.

Sec. 12. The contemplated canal, with all works or improvements appertaining thereto, shall be at all times subject, by the order of the Governor, to the inspection of the State engineer, or of such of-
ficer as the Governor may designate for such purpose.

Sec. 13. All laws and parts of laws in conflict with the provisions of this act are hereby repealed; and this act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage, and shall remain in force for and during the period of thirty (30) years from and after its pas-
sage.

div3.head: CHAPTER XX.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Citizens’ Sayings Bank of Jefferson.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That P. T. Norwood, James W. Russell, V. H. Claiborne, F. A. Schluter, W. C. Towers, John C. Kolster, B. D. Foscue, A. A. Terhune, W. H. Nichols, L. H. Norwood, R. E. Rowell, John V. Ford, and their associates and successors, and all such persons as shall become stockholders in the corporation hereby created, shall be a body politic and corporate, by the name and style of the “Citi-
zens’ Savings Bank of Jefferson,” and shall have succession, a com-
mon seal, with power to plead and be impleaded, to sue and be sued, to appoint all necessary assistants, and may have, enjoy and exercise all the powers necessary to carry out and execute all the purposes and intents of a savings bank and trust corporation.

Sec. 2. The general business and object of this corporation shall be to receive on deposit or in trust such sum or sums of money as may, from time to time, be offered therefor by tradesmen, mer-
chants, clerks, laborers, servants and others, to be repaid to such depositors when demanded, at such times, with such interest and under such regulations as the board of directors may from time to time prescribe, which regulations shall be posted up in some con-
Laws of the State of Texas.spicuous place in the room where the business of said corporation shall be transacted.

Sec. 3. The business of the corporation shall be managed by twelve directors, and the persons named in section one shall be the first directors thereof, and shall so continue for one year from the date of the organization of the company; and any vacancy which may occur from resignation or other cause may be filled by a ma-
jority of directors remaining.

Sec. 4. The capital stock of said corporation shall be fifty thou-
sand dollars, divided into shares of one hundred dollars each, pay-
able in such installments as the directors may from time to time elect, under such penalties as they may in their discretion adopt; and the directors are hereby appointed and authorized to superin-
tend the subscriptions to the capital stock of the corporation; and it will be competent for said directors to commence the business of the corporation when the full amount of stock shall have been sub-
scribed and (at least ten per cent. of it) paid into the treasury.

Sec. 5. This corporation may loan money according to the con-
stitution and laws of the State, or may discount in accordance with bank usages, taking such security therefor, either real or personal, as the directors may deem sufficient. Said corporation shall have power to borrow money, buy and sell exchange, bullion, bank notes, Government stocks and other securities; but nothing in this act contained shall confer on said corporation the privilege of issuing notes similar to bank notes for the purpose of a circulating medium, unless the same be done in conformity with the laws of the United States in such case made and provided.

Sec. 6. It shall be lawful for this corporation to purchase and hold such real estate as may be convenient and necessary for the transaction of its business, and to take and hold any real estate in trust, or otherwise, as security for or in payment of any debt or debts due, or to become due, to the said corporation, to purchase real estate at any sale made by virtue of any loan, debt or mortgage made to or held by said corporation, and to receive and take, in whole or in part, satisfaction of any such loan or debt any real estate, and to bold and convey the same.

Sec. 7. The stockholders of this corporation shall meet at such time, not exceeding one year from the date of organization, as the directors may fix upon, and annually thereafter, and elect by ballot, from their own number, twelve (12) directors, to serve for the term of one year, or until their successors are chosen. Each stockholder shall be entitled to one vote for every share of stock standing in his or her name on the books of the corporation, and they may vote in person or by proxy; the name of the stockholder so voting shall be
Laws of the State of Texas.endorsed on the ballot, and a plurality of votes shall elect, The di-
rectors shall elect annually, from their number, a president and vice president. The cashier may be selected from the stockholders by the directors. The directors shall make and execute such by-laws as may be necessary and convenient for the proper prosecution of the business of the corporation, not inconsistent with this act or with the laws of this State, or of the United States.

Sec. 8. At any time after the full payment of the original stock of fifty thousand dollars, as hereinbefore provided the directors may increase the capital stock of said corporation to any amount not exceeding five hundred thousand dollars, in shares of one hundred dollars each, and said increased stock shall be subject to all the lia-
bilities, immunities and privileges of the original stock; stockhold-
ers shall have the option of subscribing to such additional stock, pro rata, within such time as the directors may limit.

Sec. 9. When any deposit is made to said corporation by a minor, or by a female, being or thereafter becoming a married woman, the said corporation may pay such depositors any sums of money due to them, which they themselves have deposited; and their receipt or acquittance shall be a legal discharge to said corporation there-
for.

Sec. 10. The stock of this corporation shall be deemed personal property, transferrable only on the books of the company; and no transfer shall be valid while the stockholder is indebted to the com-
pany.

Sec. 11. This corporation shall exist for the term of fifty years next succeeding the first day of May, A. D. 1871. This act shall be void unless said company shall organize and proceed to business within three years after the passage hereof. The said company shall be subject to the provisions of any general law hereafter passed on the subject of banking, trust or deposit companies.
Sec. 12. This act shall be deemed a public act, of which all courts and magistrates shall officially take notice, and shall take effect on and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER XXI.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Navasota, Washington and Brazos Bridge Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That C. D. Harn, C. J. Stockbridge, John S. Mills, and such other persons as they may associate with themselves, are hereby in-
corporated under the name and style of the “Navasota, Washington and Brazos Bridge Company,” and under such name shall sue and be sued, and have succession for fifty years.

Sec. 2. Said company shall have the right to construct a bridge of iron or wood across the Brazos river, at or near where the road from Navasota crosses the Brazos river to the town of Washington, in Washington county, Texas.

Sec. 3. Said company, shall construct said bridge in a good, sub-
stantial manner within five years from the first day of January, A. D. 1872, and shall keep the same in good repair for the term of fifty years from the completion thereof; and to be ready at all times to pass passengers, carriages, wagons, teams and stock that may wish to cross on said bridge, and be responsible as common carriers, un-
der the law, for any loss of property in trust over said bridge.

Sec. 4. That said company shall be entitled to charge and re-
ceive from the completion of said bridge, for the term of fifty years, the following tolls from all persons who may cross themselves or their property, viz: Four-horse or ox stage or wagon, loaded, seventy-
five cents; for each additional pair of horses, mules or oxen attached to said wagons, twenty-five cents; for man and horse, fifteen cents; single horse and buggy, thirty cents; two-horse buggies, two-horse or ox wagon, fifty cents; other vehicles in proportion; footman, five cents; cattle, five cents per head; hogs, sheep and goats, two cents per head; and all other property not mentioned, in proportion to the above rates.

Sec. 5. That no bridge shall be constructed across the Brazos river for fifty years, within three miles on a straight line up and down said Brazos river from said bridge, which said Navasota, Washington and Brazos Bridge Company may construct.
Sec. 5. That this act shall take effect from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER XXII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Bank of Texas.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, and it is enacted by the same, That J. W. Lawrence, R. W. Satham, A. W. Thompson, J. T. Flint, H. K. White, J. M. Tryon, K. M. Vanzandt, S. S. Nichols, J. E. Bouldin, and their associates, successors and assigns, are hereby created a body corporate and po-
litic under the name and style of the Bank of Texas, and by such name and title shall have succession, and shall have and possess all the powers and privileges necessary or incident to a corporation having for its object the loaning of money, transmitting funds from place to place, dealing in exchange, executing trusts, receiving on deposit money and valuables for safe keeping, investment or profit therefor as shall be agreed; representing of deposits, trusts, transmissions, negotiations and exchange by certificates, bills, re-
ceipts or vouchers, with, or without interest, in such forms and sums as shall be required and agreed upon by parties in interest therein, and especially to aid farmers, merchants, mechanics and others by loans of money, or certified representations of real property or of satisfactory personal or other security available for use.

Sec. 2. The capital stock of said bank shall not exceed two millions dollars, represented by shares of one hundred dollars each, and the same shall be located in the city of Austin, with authority to place an agency in any city or town in the State, or in any other locality where trade can be promoted and business facilitated.

Sec. 3. The officers of said bank shall consist, of a president, vice president, cashier and assistant cashiers, and such other clerks and messengers as may be necessary to conduct the business. The board of directors shall consist of not less than seven, shall elect its officers and regulate the admission of members, and make the by-
laws for the management of the bank.

Sec. 4. No stockholder shall be eligible as a director unless he shall own, absolutely in his own right, at least ten shares of the capital stock. The annual meeting of the stockholders shall be provided by the by-laws. Any five persons named in this act of incorporation shall constitute a committee to organize the bank, to appoint directors for one year, and to receive subscriptions to the capital stock. When five hundred thousand dollars shall have been
Laws of the State of Texas.subscribed of the capital stock, and ten per cent. thereon shall have been paid up, the bank shall proceed to the transaction of business.

Sec. 5. Should any subscriber to the stock of this bank be unable, from misfortune or any other cause, to pay the future in-
stallments as the same may be called for by the board of directors, he or she shall not forfeit the same, and the amount paid in shall be returned to the subscriber or to his or her assigns by said bank in twelve months from the date of default.
Sec. 6. This act shall be in force from its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER XXIII.

opener.salute:
An Act to incorporate the Central Texas Agricultural and Mechan-
ical Association of Bryan, Texas.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That Harvey Mitchel, as president; Spencer Ford, as vice president; E. E. Blandford, secretary; and Horatio M. Moore, as treasurer; with J. S. Fawlks, O. P. Bowles, B. H. Davis, C. A. Sterne, C. F. Moore, Wm. B. Forman, M. W. McCraw and H. A. Moore as directors, and their successors, be and are hereby created a body corporate, under the name and style of the “Central Texas Agricultural and Mechanical Association of Bryan, Texas,” with the capacity, in said corporate name, to make contracts; to have succession and a common seal; to make by-laws for their govern-
ment and regulation; to sue and be sued; to plead and be im-
pleaded; to grant and receive; and, generally, to do and perform all such acts and things as may be necessary and proper for the ful-
fillment of its obligations, or maintenance of its rights, consistent with the Constitution, of the State.

Sec. 2. Said association is hereby empowered to purchase and hold such real estate as may be necessary (not to exceed one thou-
sand acres) to carry out the purposes of said association.

Sec. 3. The capital stock of said association shall consist of all its real and personal property, and shall be divided into shares of twenty-five dollars each, each share entitling the owner thereof to one vote, by himself or proxy, at all meetings of said association; said shares to be deemed personal estate, and as such subject to levy and sale for the individual debt of the owner, and shall be transfer-
Laws of the State of Texas.able by any conveyance in writing, recorded by the secretary in the-
books of the association in such manner as the by-laws may pre-
scribe; and no sale of such stock shall be deemed valid, so as to en-
title the purchaser to the title as against any subsequent purchaser, unless the same is recorded or presented for record with the secre-
tary within thirty days from the purchase.

Sec. 4. The immediate government and direction of the affairs of said association shall be vested in a board of not less than five directors, a president, and vice president, who shall be ex officio members of the board of directors; the president and vice president, secretary and treasurer, together with the directors, to be chosen annually at the regular meeting of the stockholders; and other necessary officers to be chosen by the board of said directors.

Sec. 5. Said association shall hold at least one fair in the city of Bryan in each year, at such time as they may select, and shall publish in at least one official journal of that city a list of pre-
miums to be offered, at least one month before the holding of said-
meeting or fair.

Sec. 6. All medals or tokens awarded at such fair shall be en-
graved as follows: “First premium for............., C. T. A. and M. A. of Bryan, Texas;” provided, however, that said association may pay its premiums in money.
Sec. 7. Not exceeding twenty-five per cent. of the value of the premiums offered shall be exacted by said association from owners, for the privilege of competing.

Sec. 8. Said association shall have power, at any regular meet-
ing of the stockholders, to adopt such by-laws, rules and regulations for its government, as they may deem advisable.
Sec. 9. Said association shall keep a seal engraved thus: “C. T. A. and M. A. of Bryan, Texas.”
Sec. 10. The capital stock of said association shall not exceed the sum of thirty thousand dollars.
Sec. 11. The domicil of said association to be in the city of Bryan.
Sec. 12. This act to take effect and be in force for fifty years from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER XXIV.

opener.salute: An Act to organize and incorporate the East Line and Red River Railroad Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That Alexander Caldwell, Lem T. Smith, T. A. Osborne, T. B. Mills, W. W. H. Lawrence, of Kansas, B. B. Dawes, and W. P. Cutler, of Ohio, P. M. Graham, W. C. Battle, H. J. Avinger, E. W. Taylor, W. P. Williams, S. B. Allen, Wm. A. Evans, Z. G. Mathews, Alexander Cameron, Samuel F. Mosely, George W. Newcome, James P. Dumas, J. C. D. Blackburn, Anthony Bryant, Richard D. King, James Davidson, James M. Lindsay, J. L. Ken-
nedy, W. T. Blythe, F. M. Rogers, Joshua F. Johnson, J. M. Ur-
quhart and W. Thompson, of Texas, D. H. Zachery and T. J. Campbell, of Texas, and their associates and successors be, and they are hereby constituted a body corporate and politic, by the name and style of the “East Line and Red River Railroad Company,” and by said name shall have succession and a common seal, with ca-
pacity to make contracts, and in its said corporate name to sue and be sued, to make by-laws for its general government and manage-
ment, and generally to do and perform all such acts and things as may be necessary and proper for or incidental to the fulfillment of its obligations, or to the maintenance of its rights under this act consistent with the Constitution of this State and of the United States; and the said above named corporators, or a majority of them, shall meet in the city of Jefferson, Texas, within ninety days from the passage of this act, and elect such officers as may by them seem best to further the objects of the incorporation, and shall forthwith thereafter open books for the subscription of stock in the counties along the line of said contemplated road, which said books for sub-
scription shall remain open for the subscription of stock for a period of not less than two weeks.

Sec. 2. Said company is hereby authorized to construct, own and maintain and to equip and operate a continuous line of railway, with either a single or double track, of such gauge as said company may deem best, as well as a telegraph line, from the city of Jeffer-
son, in Marion county, Texas, to the city of Sherman, in Grayson county, at which point a depot shall be established; thence in a westerly or northwesterly direction to the western limits of the State of Texas. Said road shall be constructed on the most practicable and expedient route via Mount Pleasant, in Titus county, and Sul-
Laws of the State of Texas.phur Springs, in Hopkins county, and Kentucky Town, in Grayson county, and depots be established therein.

Sec. 3. That to effect the objects of this corporation, the said company shall have the right, in their corporate name, to purchase, own, use and sell lands or other property, real and personal, and to accept donations of lands or any other species of property whatso-
ever, or to receive the same in payment for subscriptions of stock, and to issue stock therefor, as the contracting parties may agree upon, to use such weight of iron per lineal yard as may be deemed best; to fix the capital stock of said company at ten millions of dol-
lars, but may, upon a two-thirds vote of stockholders, increase the same to fifteen millions of dollars, which shall consist of shares of one hundred dollars each, transferable as the by-laws of said com-
pany may direct. In the election of officers, each share shall entitle the owner thereof to one vote, which may be given by himself or by proxy, authorized by a written instrument. The board of directors shall have the right and power to require payment of stock sub-
scribed in such installments, and at such times and places as the by-
laws of the company may provide; and shall be required at each meeting to report all action taken and proceedings held by them during the previous year.

Sec. 4. The persons named in the first section of this act, or a majority of them, shall meet in the city of Jefferson, Texas, within ninety days after the passage of this act, and temporarily organize the company hereby incorporated, by electing a president, vice president, from the incorporators of this act, and a secretary and treasurer, who shall be required to report at each annual meeting; and a board of directors, which said board of directors shall consist of not less than seven nor more than nine persons. The president shall be ex officio a member of the board of directors. The presi-
dent shall have the power to appoint or discharge the engineer, subject to and by and with the consent of the executive committee. The said officers elected as aforesaid, shall continue in office for the period of not more than six months, within which time they shall permanently organize by calling together the stockholders in said company and holding an election for a like number of directors, as is named for the temporary organization. The said election may be called by the president, or on his failure to do so, by any three directors. The directors shall have the power to appoint an execu-
tive committee, and confer on it such powers as they may deem necessary, and such other officers and agents of the company as may be deemed necessary, or may authorize the president to do the same.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted, That the right of way through
Laws of the State of Texas.the public lands of the State along the line of said road, be and the same is hereby granted to said company, and the authority is hereby conferred on said company to take from the public lands adjacent to said road, stone, earth, timber and other material for the con-
struction thereof; and the right of way is hereby granted to said company to the extent of two hundred feet in width where it passes over public lands, including all lands necessary for stations, work-
shops, switches, side tracks, turn-tables and water stations at any point along said main line, and when the same shall pass through the lands of private persons, the right of way is hereby secured in accordance with the general laws of the State now in force. Said company is authorized, and the right is hereby granted them, to cross ox connect with any other railway, to join stocks, or consoli-
date with any other railway company running in the same general direction.

Sec. 6. That the capital stock and other property of said com-
pany shall be exempt from the payment of all taxes within this State, of whatever nature, including State, county and corporation, for a period of five years after the passage of this act.

Sec. 7. The said company may locate its principal office at any point along the line of said road, as to them may be deemed best, but this shall not prevent the establishment of a branch office at such other points said company may deem best for the transaction of its business. All suits by the company may be prosecuted by the president, vice president or secretary of the company, and suits may be maintained against said company by service of process being had on the president thereof; and in case of his absence from the State, service of process may be had on the vice president or secretary of the same, and shall be prosecuted in the county where their princi-
pal office is established.

Sec. 8. The said company shall have completed and in running order at least twenty miles of their said road, commencing at the city of Jefferson, in eighteen months after the permanent organiza-
tion thereof, and complete said main trunk to Sherman within four years thereafter, and the western division shall be completed in ten years thereafter; and in default thereof shall forfeit all the fran-
chises hereby granted, except as to the part in running order.

Sec. 9. Provided, that should war, epidemic, revolution or in-
ternal strife ensue so as to hinder or delay the construction of said road thereby, the time the company may be thus hindered or de-
layed shall be excepted out of the limitation named in a previous section of this act.
Sec. 10. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER XXV.

opener.salute: An Act for the relief of George W. G. Browne, late clerk of the Supreme Court.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the Comptroller be and he is hereby authorized and re-
quired to draw his warrant on the Treasurer of the State, in favor of George W. G. Browne, for the sum of one hundred and fifty dol-
lars, as pay for services as clerk of the Supreme Court, which amount is hereby appropriated out of any unappropriated funds in the Treasury.
Sec. 2. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER XXVI.

opener.salute:
An Act to establish a ferry across the Neches river, at the old Wil-
liams ferry crossing, county of Cherokee.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That A. B. Cole be and he is hereby authorized to establish a ferry across the Neches river, at the old Williams ferry crossing, in the county of Cherokee, and that he shall have the right to make his landing on any point on the opposite bank of said river, in An-
derson county.

Sec. 2. That it shall be the duty of the said A. B. Cole to pro-
vide and keep in good repair all necessary and sufficient boats for the transportation across said river of all passengers, wagons and other wheel carriages, horses, oxen, and stock of every description, and that upon the providing and keeping such boats in good repair he shall have the right to use and enjoy said ferry within the limits aforesaid for and during the term of twenty years.

Sec. 3. That the said A. B. Cole shall have, for and during said term of twenty years, the right to charge the following rates of toll for crossing passengers, carriages, wagons or stock at said ferry, to-wit: For one man and horse, ten cents; for buggy or wagon
Laws of the State of Texas.and one horse, twenty-five cents; for carriage or wagon and two horses, thirty-five cents; for four horses or oxen and wagon, fifty cents; for foot passengers, five cents each; and for live stock, five cents per head; provided, that the said A. B. Cole may charge double these rates when the waters of the said river are overflowing its banks.

Sec. 4. That the said A. B. Cole shall enter into bond of one thousand dollars, with sufficient security, payable to the district clerk of Cherokee county, or to his successor in office, for all dam-
ages that may accrue from neglect of duty; and shall pay to each or said counties of Cherokee and Anderson an annual tax, not to ex-
ceed twenty-five dollars.
Sec. 5. That this act shall take effect from and after its passage.

The foregoing act, received in the office of Secretary of State May thirty-one, one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one, hav-
ing been presented to the Governor of Texas for his approval, and not having been returned by him to the house in which it originated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has become a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div3.head: CHAPTER XXVII.

opener.salute: An Act for the relief of John M’Donald.

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the pension of one hundred dollars per annum, now given by law to John McDonald, be and the same is hereby increased to the sum of two hundred and fifty dollars per annum for the term of his natural life, payable in like manner as his present pension.
Sec. 2. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

The foregoing act, received in the office of Secretary of State April ten, one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one, having
Laws of the State of Texas.been presented to the Governor of Texas for his approval, and not having been returned by him to the house in which it originated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has become a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div3.head: CHAPTER XXVIII.

opener.salute: An Act to authorize Alexander Inglish to erect a toll bridge over Bois D’Arc Creek, in the county of Fannin, Texas.

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That a charter be hereby granted to Alexander Inglish, his assigns and successors, authorizing and empowering him to erect a toll bridge across Bois D’Arc creek, two miles east of the town of Bonham, in Tannin county, on the road leading from Bonham to Paris, known as the Bonham and Paris road; said bridge to be of the following description: eight hundred yards long, ten feet wide, and three feet above high water mark, with good banisters along each side, and a passway in the centre, the whole to be constructed of good material and in a substantial and workmanlike manner, and that he be authorized and empowered to charge, receive and collect toll for crossing on the same at the rates to be fixed by the Police Court of Fannin county.

Sec. 2. That as soon as said bridge is completed the Police Court of Fannin county shall appoint three skilled workmen whose duty it shall be to examine said bridge, and report to said court whether or not the bridge is completed according to the require-
ments of this charter, and if so, said police court shall issue a cer-
tificate to the builder authorizing him to receive and collect such toll as it may authorize in said certificate.

Sec. 3. The builder of said bridge shall enjoy and exercise the privilege granted to him in this charter for the term of fifteen years from and after the completion of said bridge; and the builder, his assigns and successors shall be responsible for all losses sustained or injuries received by a failure, on his or their part, to comply with the provisions of this charter; such damages to be recovered by suit as in other suits for damages.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p: Sec. 4. The builder of said bridge shall have power to collect the rates of toll fixed by the Police Court of Fannin county, and also power to collect damages from all persons crossing said bridge and refusing to pay said toll; such suits to be the same as the law directs in other cases for damages.
Sec. 5. This charter shall be void unless the work be completed within one year after the granting of this, charter.
Sec. 6. This act to take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER XXIX.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Galveston Building Association.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That Charles De Blanc, George Sealy, Thomas Reed, M. B. Mott, A. P. Boot and J. M. Haden and their present and future associates, successors and assigns be and they are hereby incorpo-
rated and created a body politic and corporate by the name and style of the “Galveston Building Association,” and by said name and style shall be capable of suing and being sued, and maintaining any action to final judgment and execution, and shall be in law capable of purchasing, holding, improving, selling and conveying any estate, real, personal or mixed, of loaning money or otherwise investing their funds in such safe and judicious manner as the directors here-
inafter provided for, shall determine. Said corporation shall have a common seal, and shall have the power to ordain, establish and put in execution such by-laws, ordinances and regulations as shall be necessary for the government thereof; and it shall be lawful for the said corporation, after the expiration of its term of incorporation, to use the corporate name, style and capacity, for the purpose of suits for the final settlement and liquidation of the affairs and accounts of the corporation, and for the sale and disposition of their estate, real, personal and mixed—but not for any other purpose—and for a pe-
riod not exceeding three years after the expiration of the term of in-
corporation.

Sec. 2. All the corporate powers of the association shall be ex-
eacised by a board of seven directors, who shall be elected from among the stockholders annnally. The board of directors shall elect
Laws of the State of Texas.a president and vice president from among their own number, and such other officers as shall be provided for in the by-laws, from the body of the stockholders.

Sec. 3. The capital stock of the association, shall be one hundred and twenty thousand dollars, to be divided into one hundred shares of twelve hundred dollars each, and payable as follows: twenty dol-
lars for the first installment and ten dollars between the first and fifth of each month thereafter until the capital stock shall be paid.

Sec. 4. If any stockholder shall fail or neglect to pay any monthly installment as provided for in the foregoing section, the board of directors shall have the power to sell his share of stock in such mode as shall be provided for in the by-laws, and out of the proceeds of such sale shall pay, first, the expenses of sale and the amount due the association, and second, the surplus (if any) to the delinquent stockholder.

Sec. 5. In all elections of the directors of the association the vote shall be by ballot, and each shareholder shall be entitled to one vote for each share of stock he may own; and each absent stock-
holder may vote by proxy.

Sec. 6. The board of directors shall have the power to make all the by-laws which they shall deem necessary and expedient for the well-being and good management of the association; and such by-
laws when not inconsistent with the provisions of this act, and the laws of the State, shall be binding on all the members of the asso-
ciation.
Sec. 7. The charter granted by this act shall continue in full force and effect for the term of twenty-five years from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER XXX.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Star State Savings Association.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That Joseph Harrell, B. H. Thompson, J. A. Bowers, W. G. Thomas, T. F. Mitchell, J. E. Rector and E. T. Moore, and their associates and successors, be and they are hereby created and appointed a body politic and corporate, under the name and style of
Laws of the State of Texas.the “Star State Savings Association,” and by that name shall have succession for ninety-nine years, and a common seal, with capacity to sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, contract and be con-
tracted with; buy, hold, sell and convey real, personal and mixed property; to rent and lease, execute deeds, mortgages and deeds of trust; to loan, borrow, discount or take on deposit money, exchange, bullion, bank notes, Government securities or stocks, and other val-
uables in accordance with bank usages, to make divisions of prop-
erty, declare dividends, and to do and perform all such acts, includ-
ing the making and enforcing of by-laws, rules and regulations for their government as may be necessary and consistent with law and a constitution; provided, that nothing in this act shall be construed to authorize the issuance of notes for a circulating medium.

Sec. 2. The capital stock of the said association shall be thirty thousand dollars, with the power in the association to increase the same to three hundred thousand dollars, and shall be divided into sixty shares of five hundred dollars each, payable, in United States currency, in monthly installments of ten dollars—each share en-
titling the owner thereof to one vote.

Sec. 3. Whenever stock to the amount of fifteen thousand dol-
lars has been subscribed, and two per cent. on the same paid in, the association shall be deemed organized, and competent to transact business, and entitled to all the provisions of this act.

Sec. 4. When any deposit is made, or any transaction had, by or with a minor, or female being or hereafter becoming a married woman, said association may pay to said party any sums of money due them, and their receipt shall be a legal discharge therefor.

Sec. 5. Service of all legal process against said association shall be made on the president or secretary. All stock of the association shall be deemed personal property, transferable only on the books of the association, an-d no transfer shall be valid while the stock-
holder is indebted to the association. In making deeds or other in-
struments for the conveyance of property, or other matters of im-
portance, the same shall be signed by the president, attested by the secretary, and sealed with the seal of the assosciation.

Sec. 6. The association may, when the provisions of section three have been complied with, adopt a constitution, by-laws and rules, but the above written incorporators shall be the first board of directors, and shall hold office until their successors, have been elected, which shall not be before the whole amount of shares shall have been taken up, and two per cent. thereon paid in.
Sec. 7. The domicile of sand association shall be in the city of Austin, Texas.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p: Sec. 8. This act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXXXI.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Callahan Cotton Seed Oil Manufacturing Company, of Hempstead, Texas.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That William Ahrenbeck and brothers, their associates and succes-
sors, be and they are hereby created a body corporate and politic, under the name and style of “The Callahan Cotton Seed Oil Manu-
facturing Company, of Hempstead, Texas,” and in their corporate name and capacity to own, build, purchase and erect buildings and machinery of all kinds necessary for manufacturing purposes, in-
cident to their legitimate business as a cotton seed oil manufactur-
ing company, and to own, receive and purchase any real or per-
sonal estate necessary for the erection of buildings, etc., for the manufacture of cotton seed oil, oil cake, or other uses for which cot-
ton seed may be used: to make contracts; to have succession and a common seal; establish by-laws for their government, and in their corporate name to sue and be sued, to plead and be impleaded, to grant and receive, and to do all and any such acts and things as may be necessary and proper for the performance of the objects of the corporation, and the maintenance of their rights under this act, and as may not be inconsistent with this act, and the Constitution and laws of the United States and of this State.

Sec. 2. The capital stock of said company shall not exceed three hundred thousand dollars, to be divided into shares of one hundred dollars each, which said shares shall be deemed personal property, and the holders thereof to constitute the said company. Said stock shall be transferable in such manner as may be provided by the by-
laws of said company.

Sec. 3. The business of said company shall be vested in a board of directors, to be elected by the stockholders annually, of not less than three nor more than seven, one of whom shall be, by said board of directors or managers, elected president. Until further organized, William Ahrenbeck shall be the first president, and shall
Laws of the State of Texas.call a meeting of the stockholders at such time and place as he may deem proper for the further organization of the company.

Sec. 4. The board of directors may elect such other officers as they may deem necessary, and give them such powers and duties as they may deem necessary; provided, that no person shall be a direc-
tor unless he be a stockholder in said company; and provided fur-
ther, that the powers and duties of such officers shall not be incon-
sistent with this act. A majority of the board of directors shall con-
stitute a quorum to do business.

Sec. 5. Said corporation shall be entitled to any bonus, loan or exemption from taxation or other benefit granted to any individual or corporation for similar purposes by any general law of the State of Texas now in force, or that may be hereafter enacted.
Sec. 6. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER XXXII.

opener.salute: An Act in relation to the Atlantic and Pacific Railroad Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the Atlantic and Pacific Railroad Company, a corporation in-
corporated and duly authorized by the Congress of the United States of America on the twenty-seventh day of July, A. D. 1866, to con-
struct a railway from the town of Springfield, in the State of Mis-
souri, to the Pacific Ocean, shall have the right, and is hereby autho-
rized and empowered to locate, build, construct and maintain a branch of its railroad, with its present gauge, together with its tele-
graph lines, into and across the State of Texas, entering said State at some point on Red River, where its branch road, from the main line, shall cross from the Indian Territory into Texas, from thence to Paris, in Lamar county, or within one mile of the public square of said city; thence to Sulphur Springs, in Hopkins county, or within one mile thereof; thence to Tyler, or within one mile of the centre of said town; thence to a crossing on the Neches river that shall not be below the mouth of Bowles creek, in Cherokee county, and thence, by direct line, on the west side of the Neches river, to Beaumont, or within one mile thereof; thence to Sabine
Laws of the State of Texas.Pass; and that the following persons are hereby incorporated with said company and made a part of the incorporators of said branch railroad, to-wit; J. T. Means, of Missouri, William M. Cravens, of Fort Smith, Arkansas, Marshal Marsh, of Newark, Ohio, and Alfred S. Johnson, Owen S. Davis, W. C. Holland, John M. Wiggins, Christopher C. Francis and William T. Simmons, all of the State of Texas; and said branch shall be known by the corporate name of the Saint Louis and Mexican Gulf branch of the Atlantic and Pacific Railroad.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That said branch road of said At-
lantic and Pacific Railroad shall have the right of way, two hundred feet in width, through all the public lands, with the right to take such rock, timber, earth and other material as may be needed in con-
structing its said branch railroad, and all necessary grounds for sta-
tion buildings, workshops, depots, machine shops, switches, side tracks, turn tables and water stations.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, That said branch railroad, in con-
structing and operating its road, shall have and exercise, and is hereby vested with all the rights, powers, privileges and immunities granted by the act of Congress aforesaid, incorporating the said At-
lantic and Pacific Railway Company, as far as the same may be applicable to this State, and not inconsistent with this act and the Constitution and laws of the State of Texas, together with all the rights, powers, privileges, benefits and immunities conferred by all general laws now existing or that hereafter may be passed by the Legislature of the State of Texas, in relation to railroad corpora-
tions, in same manner and to same extent as if incorporated by the laws of this State.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, That said branch of said Atlantic and Pacific Railroad Company shall have the right to purchase, lease, join stock unto or consolidate with any railroad company, by and with the approval and consent of a majority in interest of the stockholders in each company, and to acquire and merge into itself all or any part of the property, rights and privileges and franchises of such other company, upon such terms and conditions as may be agreed upon by the respective boards of directors; provided, that this power to consolidate will apply only to railroads running in the same general direction with the branch herein authorized.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted, That any person or persons whose lands shall be taken for the purposes of said road, where there has been no agreement between said road and owner or owners; and in case the owners and said road cannot agree on the amount of compensation, owner or owners may apply to the district court of the county in which said land is situated for the
Laws of the State of Texas.appointment of appraisers, and said court shall thereupon appoint three disinterested freeholders of said county who shall appoint a time and place to hear the applicant; and said company, to whom shall be given, by said freeholders, reasonable notice of the time and place of said hearing; and said freeholders shall, after being duly sworn, and after due hearing of the parties, determine the amount of compensation, if any, to which the applicant may be entitled, and make return of their award at the next succeeding term of said court, and said award, if not rejected by said court for sufficient cause then shown, shall be entered up as the judgment of said court. In determining the question of compensation said freeholders shall be governed by the actual value of said land at the time it was taken, taking into consideration the benefits or injuries done to other lands or property by the establishment of said railway. And if the amount of compensation awarded by said freeholders shall not ex-
ceed the amount offered by said company to the owner, prior to said application to the court, the applicant shall pay the cost of the proceedings, otherwise the company shall pay the same. During the inquiry as to the value of said land, or the damage done to the estate of the owner, said company shall in no manner be molested or hindered in the prosecution of their work thereon, or occupation of the same, by any writ or process of any court of this State; but all officers of the State are authorized and required to render prompt assistance to the company in the premises.
Sec. 6. Be it further enacted, That the capital stock of said branch railroad shall not exceed fifteen million dollars, into shares of one hundred dollars each.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted, That the stock taken by citizens, corporations or counties, and all aid granted by the State, citizens, counties or corporations, in said State of Texas, shall be applied, to the constructing of said branch railroad in the State of Texas, and no part thereof shall be expended outside of said State.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted, That there shall be books for subscription opened at such points in the State of Texas as the Texas directors may direct; and that the citizens of the said State of Texas shall have the refusal, for two years from the date of the passage of this act, of taking five million dollars of the stock of said railroad, unless work shall be commenced in the State of Texas sooner than that time, and, in that event, until the work begins in said State, that if at the expiration of two years from the date of the passage of this act the citizens of the State of Texas shall have not taken said amount reserved as aforesaid, or before work commences in said State as aforesaid, then the same may be taken, or any part thereof not taken, by any person or persons desiring to take the same.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p: Sec. 9. Be it further enacted, That the State of Texas shall not be deprived of representation in the directory of said railroad, but shall have three directors in said railroad, to be chosen by the stockholders; and said company shall keep an office in this State.

Sec. 10. Be it further enacted, That work shall commence on said branch railroad, in the State of Texas, in two years from the passage of this act, and be completed in five years from the date thereof.

Sec. 11. Be it further enacted, That Francis B. Hays, of the city of Boston, in the State of Massachuseets, is hereby appointed president of said branch railroad, and shall hold his office until his successor is elected and qualified. That Alfred S. Johnson, of the State of Texas, is hereby appointed vice president, who shall hold said office until his successor is elected and qualified. That William H. Coffin, of Clyde, N. Y.; Andrew Peirce, jr., of the city of Saint Louis; Frederick Billings, of New York; George S. Curtis, of Boston, Massachusetts; and Jacob Sleeper, of Boston, Massachu-
setts; and Charles J. Merrill, of Boston, Massachusetts; Alfred S. Johnson, of Paris, Texas; and John M. Wiggins, and William T. Simmons, of the State of Texas, are hereby appointed directors until the first day of January, A. D. 1872; and the directors of the State of Texas are hereby authorized to appoint a treasurer and secretary for the State of Teaxs, who shall hold their office until the first day of January, A. D. 1872.

Sec. 12. Be it further enacted, That before the treasurer shall enter upon his duties, he shall execute a bond to the Saint Louis and Gulf branch of the Atlantic and Pacific Railroad Company in the penal sum of one hundred thousand dollars, conditioned that he will faithfully discharge his duties as such treasurer, pay over all moneys and deliver up all property that has come into his hands as such treasurer of said branch railroad company, to his successor in office, who may be elected by the stockholders of such company.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, That this act shall be taken notice of as if it were a public and general statute; shall take effect from its passage, and shall be and continue in force for ninety-nine years.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER XXXIII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Pine Island Bayou Bridge Company.

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That George W. O’Brien, of the county of Jefferson, in this State, and such other persons as he may associate with him and his or their successors, are hereby constituted and declared to be a body corporate and politic under the name and style of the “Pine Island Bayou Bridge Company,” and under and by that name and style may sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, in all the courts of the State of Texas, and may have a common seal, and alter the same at pleasure.

Sec. 2. That the said company, under the name and style afore-
said, shall be and is hereby authorized to construct a bridge across Pine Island bayou, a stream constituting the boundary line between Jefferson and Hardin counties, at such point as may be, in the opinion of said company, most eligible at or within three miles above the town of Concord on said bayou, and to acquire by pur-
chase and donation, or either, property, real, personal or mixed, and to hold or sell the same in any amount necessary to construct and maintain said bridge; and to do all other works and perform all other acts that may be necessary for that purpose not contrary to the constitution of this State.
Sec. 3. That said bridge shall be completed within three years from and after the passage of this act, otherwise this charter shall be void.

Sec. 4. That said company may demand and receive for the use of said bridge tolls which shall not exceed the following rates: For a loaded wagon and four to six yoke of oxen, one dollar; for an un-
loaded wagon and four to six yoke of oxen, seventy five cents; for a loaded wagon and three yoke of oxen, seventy-five cents; for an empty wagon and three yoke of oxen, fifty cents; for a loaded wogon with two or less yoke of oxen, fifty cents; if unloaded, twen-
ty-five cents; for carts loaded or empty, fifty cents; for a four-horse coach or other vehicle, fifty cents; for a two-horse wagon, carriage, or other vehicle, fifty cents; for a double buggy, fifty cents; for a single buggy, thirty cents: for horses, mules or cattle, per head, three cents; for horse and rider, ten cents; for sheep, goats and hogs, per head, one cent; for footmen, each, five cents; and for other things not herein enumerated rates proportioned to those herein fixed.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p:
Sec. 5. That said company be and it is hereby required to keep said bridge and its abutments in good repair, and to keep in attend-
ance at the toll gate of the same a sufficient number of persons, or keepers, to admit persons and property to cross said bridge at any time by day or night.

Sec. 6. That the privileges and rights granted in this charter shall and do hereby authorize the said company to take possession of and use any vacant lands lying contiguous to the points on each bank of said bayou where they may determine to construct said bridge, together with any timber, stones, rock and other material upon said lands necessary for the proper construction and keeping in use and repair said bridge; provided, that the owner or owners of said lands and material shall be paid a fair remuneration for such lands and the use thereof, and for said material the amount of damage or value of the use of said lands and material, to be de-
termined by three commissioners, one to be chosen by said com-
pany, one by the owner or owners of the lands and material in question, and the third by the two that may be so selected, and that their decree shall have the force and effect of a judgment in law; provided, that either party aggrieved by the award of said, commissioners shall have the right of appeal to any court of com-
netent jurisdiction.

Sec. 7. That the privileges granted by this charter shall cease and determine at the expiration of twenty-five years from the date of the passage of this act, and that this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER XXXIV.

opener.salute: An Act granting to John M. Beard the privilege of constructing and keeping a toll bridge across the Neches river at the place known as Beards’ bridge on said river.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the privilege is hereby granted to John M. Beard, and he is hereby authorized, to construct and keep a toll bridge across the Neches river at the place known as “Beards’ bridge,” on said river, on the road leading from the town of Rusk in the county of Cherokee to the town of Palestine in the county of Anderson, to
Laws of the State of Texas.extend across the bottom as well as the stream from hill to hill above high water mark, making the way passable at all times in safety.

Sec. 2. That the bridge now constructed and owned by John M. Beard, across the Neches river at the point mentioned in the first section of this act; that the Police Court of Cherokee county, upon application of John M. Beard, shall appoint two commissioners, citizens of said county of Cherokee whose duty it shall be to exam-
ine the said bridge, and if they find upon examination that it is such a bridge as referred to in the first section of this act, and they re-
port to the police court of said county, that said bridge is in good order and safe for the passage of travelers; then the said proprie-
