tor shall have the right to erect a toll gate at some convenient place in the immediate vicinity of said bridge and demand and receive at said gate from all and every person passing over said bridge, toll according to the following rates: For buggies fifty cents, carriages seventy-five cents, wagons twenty cents per wheel and five cents per head for the team attached thereto, for a horse or mule and rider twenty cents, for a footman five cents, for loose horses and mules five cents per head, cattle per head two and half cents, hogs, sheep and goats one cent per head.

Sec. 3. That the Police Court of Cherokee county shall appoint two commissioners on the application of the proprietor of said toll bridge—citizens of said county—whose duty it shall be to examine and approve the bridge now constructed across said river, or to be constructed under this act, and report their action, fully describ-
ing the bridge, its length, width, height and its condition as to safety to the traveling public. This report to be made at a regular term of the court, and they shall hold their office as commissioners for the term of two years from the time of their appointment, and until their successors shall have been appointed, and it shall be the duty of the Police Court of Cherokee county to appoint two com-
missioners bi-ennially to examine and report at least twice in each and every year the condition of said bridge, constructed or author-
ized to be constructed by John M. Beard, for which service the said commisisoners shall each receive two dollars per day for the time they may be necessarily employed in the discharge of the duties hereby imposed upon them, to be paid by the proprietor of said bridge.

Sec. 4. That the bridge constructed, or to be constructed across the Neches river at the place designated in this charter, by John M. Beard, that the privilege hereby granted to John M. Beard, shall inure to the said John M. Beard, his heirs and assigns for a period of twenty-five years from and after the passage of this act.

Sec. 5. That whenever the bridge now constructed, or an-
Laws of the State of Texas.thorized to be constructed, shall be found out of repair, or in bad order, the toll gate shall be set open until such bridge shall have been repaired and examined as herein provided.

Sec. 6. That the owner and proprietor of said toll bridge shall be liable by action for damages, to any person who may sustain in-
jury to person or property by reason of negligence, or failure to keep in repair said bridge, before any court having jurisdiction, of the amount of damages claimed.

Sec. 7. That when any person shall report in writing under oath to the Police court of Cherokee county that the bridge con-
structed or authorized to be constructed under the provisions of this act is out of repair and not safe for the public travel, then it shall be the duty of the chairman of said court to inform the pro-
prietor of said bridge of the fact, and it shall not be lawful after such information for such proprietor to demand and receive toll from any person crossing over said bridge, until the commissioners appointed under the provisions of this act shall report to the court that the bridge is in good repair and safe for public travel.

Sec. 8. That An act granting to Jesse Gibson, guardian ox George W. Cannon, the privilege of constructing a toll bridge across the Neches river at the place known as Cannon’s ferry on said river,” passed February the 7, A. D. 1854, be and the same is hereby repealed.
Sec. 9. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER XXXV.

opener.salute: An Act for the relief of John G. Boyle.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the Comptroller of Public Accounts be and he is hereby directed to draw his warrant on the Treasurer of the State of Texas in favor of John G. Boyle, for the sum of seventeen hun-
dred and fifty dollars.
Sec. 2. That this act take effect and be in force from and alter its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER XXXVI.

opener.salute: An Act to repeal an act entitled “An Act to prevent the sale of vinous, spirituous, or other intoxicating liquor, within one mile of the centre of the town of Alto, in Cherokee, county, in the State of Texas,” approved December 11, 1861.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That an act entitled “An act to prevent the sale of vinous, spirituous, or other intoxicating liquor within one mile of the cen-
tre of the town of Alto, in Cherokee county, in the State of Texas,” approved December 11, 1861, be and the same is hereby repealed.
Sec. 2. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXXXVII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Richland Bridge Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That S. J. T. Johnson, R. H. Matthews, T. P. Sparks, George Rogers, J. G. Berry, N. T. Jones, James Smith, D. C. Sum-
mers, J. T. Summers, W. S. Robinson and J. C. Sparks, and their successors, be and are hereby constituted and declared to be a body politic and corporate, under the name and style of the “Richland Bridge Company.”

Sec. 2. That said persons and their successors, under the name and style aforesaid, may sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, defend and be defended, in all the courts of this State; they may contract and be contracted with, may hold property, real and per-
sonal, and may transfer, alienate and dispose of their joint or un-
divided interest therein at pleasure. They may have a common seal.

Sec. 3. That said persons and their successors shall select one or more, not to exceed three, out of the stockholders of the company, who shall constitute a board of managers or directors, whose duty it
Laws of the State of Texas.shall be to manage and control the business of said company ac-
cording to and under the directions of a majority of the stock-
holders.

Sec. 4. That said persons and their successors shall be and they are hereby authorized to build, construct and keep up, a toll bridge across Richland creek, at or near the place where the road leading from Dresden, Navarro county, to Spring Hill, of said county, crosses said creek; and said company shall have the right of way to and from said bridge, and it is hereby made the duty of said com-
pany to open a road at least thirty feet wide through the flats or low lands to the high lands on both sides of said creek; and it is also made the duty of said company to construct such bridge or causeways over the sloughs and bayous to said high lands as may be necessary to make a good and substantial road, and so as to make the same passable at all seasons of the year, except in cases of very high waters.

Sec. 5. That said company shall complete said bridge and cause-
ways within one year from the passage of this act, and the privi-
leges herein granted shall not cease until after the expiration of twenty years from date hereof; provided, said company shall keep the same in good repair, and shall be ready at all times to pass all passengers, carriages, wagons, teams and stock that may wish to cross the same.

Sec. 6. That said company shall be and they are hereby author-
ized to charge and collect tolls of all passengers, carriages, wagons, teams and stock that pass over said bridge; provided, the charges do not exceed the following, to wit: For wagon with six or more horses or oxen, one dollar; for a wagon with four horses or oxen, seventy-five cents; for a carriage or wagon with two horses or oxen, fifty cents; for a buggy and one horse, twenty-five cents; man and horse, ten cents; loose stock, cattle or horses, three cents per head; hogs, sheep or goats, two cents per head; provided, that the fol-
lowing persons shall at all times pass free of charge, to wit: min-
isters of the gospel in going to and from church; persons in going to and from church; jurors and State witnesses going to and from court; persons going to and from mill, and officers on official busi-
ness.

Sec. 7. That no other person or persons shall erect a toll bridge across said creek within three miles of said bridge; provided, said company shall keep said bridge and causeways in good repair; and should any accident or damage occur to person or property in cross-
ing the same, caused by the insufficiency of said bridge or cause-
ways, or the negligence of said company in not keeping the same in good condition, said company shall be responsible in damages to the
Laws of the State of Texas.person or persons so injured, and to the owner or owners of the property damaged.

Sec. 8. That if any person shall wilfully fail or refuse to pay toll after crossing said bridge, he shall be liable to forfeit to said company five dollars and costs of suit, to be recovered before any justice of the peace, as in other cases.

Sec. 9. That said company shall post up in a conspicuous place near the bridge, a printed notice, containing the rates of toll, and should said company, or any of its employes, exact and receive a greater amount of toll than herein allowed, said company shall be liable to pay, at the suit of the party from whom such amount was received, the sum of twenty dollars and all costs, to be recovered before any justice of the peace as in other cases

Sec. 10. That this act take effect and be in force from its pas-
sage.

The foregoing act, received in the office of the Secretary of State the twenty-eighth day of April, one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one, having been presented to the Governor of Texas for his approval, and not having been returned by him to the house in which it originated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has become a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div3.head: CHAPTER XXXVIII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Central Bank.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That T. I. Hall, I. A. Semones, Spencer Ford, J. J. Adams, J. S. Proctor, and S. A. Shaw, and their associates and successors, be and they are hereby created a body politic and corporate by the name of the “Central Bank,” with capacity to sue, and be sued, to make contracts, to hold, buy and sell property, both real and per-
sonal; to receive and execute notes, bonds, bills, deeds, mortgages and deeds of trust, and other instruments of writing; to receive de-
posits, make collections, borrow money and make loans, and may provide for receiving the interest or discount in advance. Said
Laws of the State of Texas.company may buy and sell coin and uncurrent bills, drafts, bills of exchange and stocks, and also the bonds and other obligations of any county, city or State. It may negotiate loans and execute orders for others on commission, and may lease and improve such real es-
tate as it may acquire. It may receive in pledge for loans or debts owing it, bonds, notes, stocks or other obligations in writing, pro-
duce and merchandise, or any other character of property or se-
curity whatever, and sell the same on the non-payment of the debt on demand at the stipulated time of payment, according to any agreement made between the parties for the payment of the same, and pass a good title to the purchaser; and any power given for that purpose shall be irrevocable until the debt or demand is paid; and the promissory notes made payable and negotiable at the office, of said company, and inland bills which may be discounted or pur-
chased prior to maturity, shall be put upon the footing of foreign bills of exchange, and like remedy may be had thereon. It shall have succession and a common seal; may pass by-laws and resolu-
tions for the government of its affairs, and may do all acts neces-
sary for performing its obligations or maintaining its rights under this act.

Sec. 2. The managers and officers of the company shall consist of a board of directors, composed of such a number as the by-laws may designate, to be selected from the stockholders, and their num-
ber may be increased after organization by resolution of the board; and said board shall select from their number a president, They shall hold their offices for one year and until their successors are elected; provided, the first board elected and its presiding officer shall hold their offices for such time not exceeding two years, as the by-laws may designate. They shall be subject to removal in such-
manner, and receive such compensation as the by-laws may direct. And said board may employ such agents, clerks and other employes as it may deem necessary to transact its business, and may provide for filling vacancies in the board of directors and other officers.

Sec. 3. The capital stock of the company shall not exceed five hundred thousand dollars, which shall be divided into shares of one hundred dollars each, and said shares shall represent all the prop-
erty, real and personal of the company, and shall be deemed per-
sonal property, and shall be transferable on the books of the com-
pany according to the by-laws; but the company shall hold a lien on the shares of any stockholder who may be indebted to it, and said shares shall not be transferred without the consent of the board of directors until such debt shall be paid or discharged.

Sec. 4. When forty thousand, dollars of the capital stock are subscribed, and twenty-five dollars per share paid thereon, the com-
Laws of the State of Texas.pany shall organize, and the balance of the capital stock shall be paid in such installments as the board of directors may provide, and any stockholder failing or refusing to pay such installments, shall after twenty days notice given in such manner as the by-laws pro-
vide, forfeit such stock.
Sec. 5. Said company shall be responsible to the extent of its property, and the stockholders for the amount of their respective stock not paid for, for all liabilities of the corporation.
Sec. 6. That this act take effect from its passage, and be in force for twenty-five years.

The foregoing act, received in the office of Secretary of State April twenty-eighth one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one, having been presented to the Governor of Texas for his approval, and not having been returned by him to the house in which it or-
iginated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has be-
come a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div3.head: CHAPTER XXXIX.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Rusk and Harrison County Railway Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That J. W. Flanagan, A. D. Tinsley, W. W. Morris, Aleck Pope, J. A. Vinson, Ed. S. Graham, Jiles S. Boggess, jr., and C. B. Kilgore, and assigns, be and they are hereby constituted a body corporate and politic, by the name and style of the Rusk and Har-
rison County Railway Company, with the power to sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, contract and be contracted with, and to adopt and have a corporate seal, and to alter the same at discre-
tion.

Sec. 2. That the object of the railway company hereby incor-
porated is to construct, maintain and operate, a railway, beginning at the town of Henderson, in Rusk county, running north to inter-
sect with the Southern Pacific Railroad at such point as may be most convenient; and it shall have power to purchase or accept any dona-
Laws of the State of Texas.tion or grants of lands, and any other property whatsoever; the said company shall also have the right to connect their road with any other road or roads that it may intersect or cross.

Sec. 3. That the capital stock of the said company shall be fixed by the board of directors, not to exceed five hundred thousand dollars, to be divided into shares of twenty-five dollars each, which shares shall be transferable in such manner as the by-laws of the company may provide, and in all elections of officers of said com-
pany each share of stock shall entitle the holder to one vote. No right shall vest until one hundred thousand dollars of stock shall have been subscribed, and five per cent. thereon paid; the board of directors may require payment of all subscriptions to the capital stock of the company on such terms and in such manner as they shall prescribe.

Sec. 4. The persons named in the first section of this act, or any three of them, shall meet in the town of Henderson, within ninety days after the passage of this act, and temporarily organize said company by electing a president, secretary and treasurer. The said persons shall at the same time make: by-laws, rules and regula-
tions, for the government and regulation of the business and affairs of such company, not inconsistent with the laws of this State or of the United States. The said persons shall at the same time provide for the opening of books of subscription to the capital stock of the company, and when two hundred thousand dollars of stock shall have been subscribed and ten per cent. paid thereon, the president of said company shall notify the stockholders to meet at the town of Henderson, Rusk county, where a permanent organization shall be had by electing a board of not less than five directors, a majority of whom shall constitute a quorum, who hold their offices for one year and until their successors are duly elected and qualified; and the said directors shall elect a president from their number, also a secre-
tary and treasurer, and such other officers as may be necessary; and further provided, that due notice of time and place for permanent organization herein provided for shall be given, by publication for at least thirty days in one newspaper published in Marshall, Harri-
son county, and one in Henderson, Rusk county, Texas.

Sec. 5. That the right of way through the public lands of the State, along the line of this road, be and the same is hereby granted said company, to the extent of two hundred feet in width. Where the lines of said road shall pass through the lands of private persons the right of way is hereby secured to said company, in accordance with the laws of this State, and the said company is also empowered to bridge all streams on its route, so as not to impede the navigation thereof.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p:
Sec. 6. That the said company hereby incorporated shall con-
struct at least twelve miles of road within three years after the passage of this act, and have their whole line completed within five years thereafter, and in default thereof shall forfeit all rights under the provisions of this act.

Sec. 7. That the said company shall have the right, and are hereby empowered, to mortgage its road, franchise rights, privileges and property, and issue bonds secured thereby in aid for the con-
struction and equipment of their said road.

Sec. 8. That the said railway company shall enjoy and be sub-
ject to all the rights, powers, privileges and exemptions under all general laws of this State in reference to railroad companies, with-
out regard to length of road.
Sec. 9. That this act take effect and be in, force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER XL.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Indianola, San Antonio and El Paso Railroad Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That W. H. Fant, M. Kreisle, Wm. Kohler, R. W. Davis, E. Seeligson, of Goliad, Henry Seeligson, Wm. Westhoff, Sam. R. Johnson, of Indianola, F. E. Grothaus, of De Witt county, H. H. McLean, L. S. Lawhon, of Karnes county, Joseph Deutz, Charles Elmendorf, A. Siemering, W. A. Bennett, W. J. Locke and David Bell, of San Antonio, John M. Mathis, of Rockport, Richard King, of Corpus Christi, and A. J. Fountain, of El Paso, together with their associates and successors, are hereby created a body corporate and politic, under the name and style of the “Indianola, San An-
tonio and El Paso Railroad Company,” and under that name may have succession and a common seal, elect officers, enact by-laws and own property, real, personal and mixed, and hypothecate or other-
wise dispose of the same at pleasure, may grant and receive, sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, contract and be contracted with, and may do all the acts and exercise all the powers incident or per-
taining by law to private corporations, and shall have, exercise and use all the rights, privileges and immunities, and be entitled to all
Laws of the State of Texas.the benefits secured to other railroad companies by the general laws of this State.

Sec. 2. The objects for which this company is incorporated are to construct, own, maintain and operate a first class double or sin-
gle track railroad from the city of Indianola, in Calhoun county, across the Guadalupe river, at or near Kemper’s Bluff, thence to and up the San Antonio river in its general course to the city of San Antonio, and thence by the most eligible route to El Paso, on the Rio Grande; to construct, own and operate such branch roads as may be necessary to furnish the main road with material or freight, or to form connections with other roads or important points of business, and to construct, own and operate telegraph lines along the roads and routes of the company, and said company are en-
dowed with all the powers necessary to carry out these objects.

Sec. 3. This company shall have the right to cross any other railroad track or any thoroughfare, and may form junctions with, or may consolidate with any other railroad company, whereby any of the objects hereinbefore declared shall be attained; and the at-
tainment of any portion of the objects of the company under the provisions of this section shall be deemed a compliance with the terms thereof as to such objects, and in case the company shall form connection with any railroad company at or beyond San An-
tonio, whereby the free transit of trade and travel shall be obtained to El Paso, this company shall be thereby relieved from construct-
ing that portion of the road.

Sec. 4. The capital stock of the company shall be ten millions of dollars, with the privilege of increasing the same to twenty mil-
lions, whenever the same may be deemed necessary to carry out the legitimate objects of the company. The stock shall be subscribed and held in shares of one hundred dollars each, gold valuation, which shall be personal property, and shall be represented by cer-
tificates of stock to be issued by the president and board of direc-
tors. Each share of stock shall entitle the holder to one vote in all elections of the company, to be cast in person or by proxy, and the stock subscribed shall be paid in such installments or by such assess-
ments as the board of directors may direct, and shall be subject to sale or forfeiture under such regulations as the board of directors may establish for failure to pay the assessments or installments as they become due. The board of directors may establish such regu-
lations for the transfer of stock as the interest of the company shall demand, and they may also establish suitable offices and agencies out of the State for the transfer and negotiation, or for otherwise facilitating the business of the company, as they may in their judg-
ment from time to time determine.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p:
Sec. 5. The business of the company shall be conducted and managed by a president, vice president and board of directors, to-
gether with such subordinate officers and agents as the board of di-
rectors shall from time to time deem necessary. The board of di-
rectors shall consist of not less than seven, nor more than thirteen stockholders, owning not less than ten shares of stock each, who shall be elected by the company on the first Monday of December in each year, at the office of the company. The board shall elect the president and vice president from their own number, and in case of a vacancy in the board, or in the office of president or vice president, they shall be authorized to fill the same by appointment until the next general election of the company. A majority of the board of directors shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of any busi-
ness, and they shall be authorized to establish all needful and proper rules, regulations and by-laws, for the interest of the company, con-
sistent with law and with the objects of the company, and shall also be authorized, either with or without the consent of the president to appoint all subordinate officers and agents required by the company.

Sec. 6. The president, or in case of his absence or inability to act, the vice president, shall have authority to convene the board to temporarily appoint officers, and under the rules established by the board, to execute all contracts and writings, and generally to trans-
act the business of the company.

Sec. 7. The incorporators herein named shall be authorized to act as a board of directors until the first election of the company herein provided for, and to transact all the business of the company, and W. N. Fant shall be authorized to act as commissioner of or-
ganization.

Sec. 8. The company may receive as eubscriptions to stock as donations or otherwise, any lands or other property, and may hold and use or hypothecate the same in any manner that may be neces-
sary to carry out the objects of the company.

Sec. 9. The principal office of the company shall be fixed by the board of directors at some point on its main trunk line within this State, and all elections and meetings of the company shall be held at said office, and the board of directors may establish such subordinate offices as may be necessary.

Sec. 10. The company may fix upon and determine the gauge of the road or roads to be constructed by them, and may alter the same at pleasure, and may discontinue any branch road constructed by them whenever they shall find the same unprofitable or un-
necessary.

Sec. 11. The company may receive subscriptions or donations of land, money or securities from any county or corporation through
Laws of the State of Texas.or near which any road constructed by them shall pass, and they may locate the road and branches herein, provided for on such route or routes, consistent with the outline points herein enumerated, as they may deem most advantageous to the interest of the company.

Sec. 12. The right of way is hereby granted to the company through any of the public domain, to the extent of one hundred feet wide on each side of the track of any road herein provided for, and also to such additional extent as may be necessary for all and any switches, side tracks, turn outs, turn tables, stations, machine shops, water tanks, wells, cisterns, depots or stock yards which the com-
pany may deem necessary for the proper operation of the roads.

Sec. 13. The company shall have the right to take from any public land in the vicinity of the roads to be constructed by them any timber, stone or other material which may be necessary or desirable for the road, and shall have the right to cut down and re-
move any tree or other obstruction which might injure the road, although standing more than one hundred feet from the road.

Sec. 14. The company shall have the right to enter upon any titled or appropriated land and appropriate the same for the road or its appurtenances to the same extent that said right is secured through and upon, the public domain; provided, that the company shall be subject to the payment of the actual damages to the owner of any such land, to be assessed and determined by appraisers to be appointed on application of either party, by the district judge, with proper notice to the opposite party.

Sec. 15. Whenever the owner or claimant of any occupied lands entered upon by or conveyed to the company, is unknown, the president shall be authorized to bring suit for the company, and have service, by publication, upon the unknown owner or owners and shall have such proceedings for the adjudication of the title as the law or equity demands

Sec. 16. The company shall have the right to select such point for the bay terminus of the road as they may find most eligible on Matagorda Bay, at or in the vicinity of Indianola, and at such point shall have the right of wharfage; provided, that no prior right shall thereby be interfered with.

Sec. 17. The company hereby incorporated shall organize and secure the capital stock necessary to construct the road from its bay terminus to and across the Guadulupe river, within six months from the passage of this act, and construct the first section of their road to and across the Guadalupe river within two years after the passage of this act, or on failure thereof shall forfeit the rights herein granted; and the company shall, within three years after the passage of this act, complete the road to San Antonio, and within five years
Laws of the State of Texas.thereafter to El Paso; provided, that a failure to comply with any of these provisions shall forfeit the right to the same to such an extent as herein provided.

Sec. 18. The company may commence work at any point or points upon the road, and shall have the right to construct any bridge or ferry that may be necessary for the road or its branches, and may construct any such bridges, ferries or other thoroughfares, for ordinary travel in the vicinity of the road, for facilitating its operations or construction, and shall have the right to contract with any county or municipal corporation for any such construction.

Sec. 19. In case the company should fail to comply with and carry out the provisions of this act, and such failure should be caused by war, revolution or epidemic diseases, the time which the company has been obstructed in their operations by these causes or any of them, shall not be counted in the time given them to carry cut and accomplish the works herein provided for.

Sec. 20. That this act shall take effect and be in force for ninety-
nine years from and after its passage.

The foregoing act received in the office of Secretary of State April twelfth, one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one, hav-
ing been presented to the Governor of Texas for his approval, and not having been returned by him to the house in which it origi-
nated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has become a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div3.head: CHAPTER XLI.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Huntsville Branch Railway Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That Sandford Gibbs, W. A. Oliphant, W. A. Rawlings, J. H. Banton, J. H. Thomason, Michael Butler, M. H. Goddin, R. M. Bankhead, Strother Green, John Gourtade, H. C. Oliphant, I. P. Nixon and G. W. Grant, be and they are hereby appointed commissioners to open books and receive subscriptions to a capital
Laws of the State of Texas.stock of a corporation to be styled the “Huntsville Branch Railway Company.” A majority of said commissioners shall constitute a quorum to do business, and shall meet in the town of Huntsville within twenty days after the approval of this act, or as soon there-
after as a majority thereof may agree upon; and they may appoint one or more of their own body, and such, other agents as they may select, to open books at such places as they may direct, to receive subscriptions for the stock of said company; and the said commis-
sioners shall hold meetings from time to time as their business may require, until directors shall be selected as hereinafter provided for. In receiving subscriptions for said capital stock they shall require five per centum thereof to be paid at the time of subscribing, whether to one of their own number or an agent appointed by them; and any subscription to said stock upon which the amount of five per centum is not paid shall be void, and the party receiving the same on the part of the company shall be responsible to it for said five per cent. upon said stock; provided, that certificates of said stock shall not be assignable until after the organization of said company.

Sec. 2. That the subscribers to said capital stock, whenever they shall have selected directors, are hereby created and established a body corporate and politic, under the name and style of the “Hunts-
ville Branch Railway Company,” with capacity in said corporate name to sue and be sued; to plead and be impleaded; to have suc-
cession and a common seal; to make contracts; to grant and receive; to make by-laws for its government, and generally to do and per-
form all things necessary or proper to the maintenance of its rights under this act, not inconsistent with the Constitution of this State and of the United States.

Sec. 3. The capital stock of said company shall not exceed one million of dollars, to be divided into shares of fifty dollars each; each share to entitle the owner thereof to one vote, either in person or by proxy, in all elections and meetings when the stockholders are called upon to vote, and a majority of the votes shall govern in all cases not otherwise provided by law; the said shares of stock shall be deemed personal estate, transferable only on the books of the company by person or by proxy.

Sec. 4. The direction and control of the affairs of said corpora-
tion shall be vested in a board of not less than five nor more than nine directors, as the by-laws may provide: they shall be chosen by the stockholders at their annual meetings, the first of which shall be bolden within one year after the passage of this act, at such time and place as the corporators herein named shall designate: said directors shall select one of their own body to be president of said company; shall fill vacancies in their board; appoint a secretary.
Laws of the State of Texas.treasurer, and such other officers and agents as they may deem proper, and require bond for the prompt and honest discharge of their duties, and make all proper rules for the holding of their meetings, and all other rules not inconsistent with the general laws, which they may deem necessary to protect the interests of the com-
pany; they shall cause to be kept accurate books of accounts ex-
hibiting the receipts and expenditures of the company. A majority of the directors shall constitute a quorum to do business, and shall have the power of a full board, and all conveyances and contracts in writing, signed by the president and contersigned by the secretary or any other officer, duly authorized by the board of directors, under the seal of the company, when the same is in execution of an order of the board, shall be binding and valid.

Sec. 5. That so soon as ten thousand dollars of the capital stock of said company is subscribed and five per cent. thereof paid to the commissioners, they shall cause the first election to be held for directors, first giving notice of the time and place of such elec-
tion by publication in all the newspapers printed in the town of Huntsville, in Walker county, Texas; and when said directors so elected shall have organized, the said commissioners shall pay over to the treasurer of the company all the moneys they have received upon subscriptions to the stock of the company, and deliver to the said directors all the books and papers belonging to the company.

Sec. 6. That said company, when it shall be organized under the provisions of this act, shall be and is hereby invested with the right of locating, constructing, owning, operating and maintaining a railroad, commencing at a convenient point oil the Houston and Great northern Railroad, and running thence by the most eligible route to the town of Huntsville, in Walker county, Texas; provided, that this road shall not intersect at a point nearer than ten miles from the point of intersection of the Hempstead E. and W. Trunk Railroad; and provided further, that the said railroad shall make its connection with the Houston and Great Northern Railroad be-
fore said branch road shall be commenced.

Sec. 7. That said company, after its organization in pursuance of this act, under the board of directors, shall have power to receive further subscriptions to the capital stock of said company, until the whole amount shall have been subscribed: but five per cent. of its subscription shall be paid at the time of subscribing, and the direc-
tors shall be personally liable to said company for five per cent. of all such subscription as they may receive without such payment; provided, however, that said company may, by a vote of a majority of the votes of the stockholders, issue certificates of stock to be issued in payment of any debt contracted for the construction or
Laws of the State of Texas.equipment of said road. Any agreement in writing to subscribe for-
stock may be enforced according to its terms, and if any subscriber shall fail to pay any amount due upon shares subscribed for by him, according to the terms of his subscription, the directors may sell at auction, after giving thirty days’ notice, as required at sheriff’s sales, and transfer the shares of such delinquent to the purchaser; and if the proceeds of such sale shall not be sufficient to pay the amount due with interest and charges, said delinquent shall be liable to the company for such deficiency; but if the proceeds shall exceed the amount due with interest and charges, he shall be enti-
tled to the excess, such sale to be made in the town of Huntsville.

Sec. 8. It shall be lawful for said company to enter upon and purchase, or otherwise take and hold, any land necessary for the purpose of locating, constructing and maintaining said railway, with all the necessary depots and other buildings connected with, said railway; and if they shall not be able to obtain such lands by agreement with the owners thereof, they shall pay such compensa-
tion as shall be determined, in the manner provided in the follow-
ing section. The land so taken for the road bed shall not exceed fifty yards in width, and for depots and other buildings, only such, width as shall be absolutely necessary.

Sec. 9. Any person, whose land has been taken as aforesaid, may apply to the chief magistrate of the county where the land is situated, for the appointment of three freeholders, and said magis-
trate shall thereupon appoint a time and place to hear the applicant and the company, to whom shall be given reasonable notice of such, time and place, and said freeholders shall, after being sworn, and having heard the parties, determine the compensation to be paid to the applicant, and make return of their award to the next regular term of the district court of said county, and said award may be confirmed, or for any sufficient reason it may be set aside by said court, and if it be confirmed, judgment shall be rendered thereon as in other cases. In determining the compensation to be paid as aforesaid, the said freeholders shall be governed by the actual value of the land at the time it was taken, and shall consider the injury and benefit which would result to the adjoining land of the appli-
cant by the establishment of the railroad; and if the benefit shall exceed the injury, the applicant shall receive nothing, but shall pay the cost.

Sec. 10. The said company, in its charges for freight, and pas-
sengers, shall be governed by the general railroad law; it shall have the right to cross all public highways, and streets of towns and cities, that it may be necessary to cross to establish said railway.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p: Sec. 11. That said company shall have the right to connect their road with the Houston and Great Northern Railroad at such point as they may elect; provided, that the road be compelled to make a full stop before crossing the Houston and Great Northern Railroad or any other road.

Sec. 12. That said company shall have power to borrow money, and issue its bonds with or without mortgage; provided, that the same be done in conformity to the laws of the State, this act of in-
corporation, and the by-laws of the company.

Sec. 13. The annual meeting of the stockholders of this com-
pany shall be held at such time and place as may be designated in the by-laws, which shall be a day for the transaction of business by the stockholders, at which time the annual election for directors shall take place. Should the stockholders owning a majority of the stock fail to meet on that day, the directors may appoint another day for such election, and an election held on the day appointed shall be valid. Directors elected under the provisions hereof shall hold office until the next annual meeting and until their successors are chosen and qualified.

Sec. 14. This company shall be subject to all general laws now in force, or which may hereafter be in force, in regard to running over the road of one company by another, when the public interests or the interests of commerce require it, and may form a junction and connect with another road in such manner as may best and mose certainly secure the construction of their railway.

Sec. 15. This charter shall remain in force for the period of fifty years from the date of completing said road; provided, the conditions set forth are fully complied with; and provided further, that the Branch road shall be completed in one year after the Great Northern reaches a point opposite Huntsville.

Sec. 16. The subscriptions for stock may be paid in land; pro-
vided, that the owner of land who desires to pay for his stock with the same, shall pay the full amount of his subscription in lands at the time of subscribing, at such price as may be agreed upon by the subscriber and the person receiving such subscription; provided, the title shall not vest in the company till the road is completed from its junction to the town of Huntsville.

Sec. 17. That said company shall have the right of extension under this charter from the Houston and Great Northern Railway, either eastwardly or westwardly, or both, to make connections with railroads first reached in those directions.
Sec. 18. This act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER XLII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the town of San Eleceario in El Paso county.

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the citizens of the town of San Eleceario, in the county of El Paso, be and are hereby declared a body corporate, by the name and style of the town of San Eleceario; and by that name may sue and be sued; may have and use a corporate seal; may hold real and personal estate, and may dispose of real estate in the manner hereinafter provided, and in no other manner.

Sec. 2. That the corporate limits of said town shall include all within the following boundaries: Commencing on the Rio Grande at a point where the established line of division between the towns of Socorro and San Eleceario strikes said river for the northern boundary, and following to the hills bordering on the eastern bank of the river Viejo; thence running southeast along with said hills down the river Viejo to the point at which said river Viejo empties into the Rio Grande; thence up said Rio Grande from the mouth of said river Viejo to the place of beginning.

Sec. 3. That no person shall be a qualified voter in said cor-
poration unless he be a registered voter in the State, and shall have resided in said corporation six months.

Sec. 4. That no person shall be eligible to office in said cor-
poration unless he be a qualified voter therein.

Sec. 5. That the corporate affairs of said town shall be admin-
istered by a mayor and nine aldermen, who shall be styled the Town Council of the Town of San Eleceario.

Sec. 6. The justice of the peace of the precinct in which said town is situated shall be ex officio mayor of the town. He shall preside over the town council, and shall have no vote except in case of a tie, when he shall give the casting vote.
Sec. 7. Two-thirds of the aldermen elected shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business; but a less number may, at a regular meeting, enforce the attendance of absent members.

Sec. 8. That at the first and each subsequent general election for State or county officers there shall be nine aldermen elected by the qualified, voters of said town. Said aldermen shall hold their office for two years, and until their successors shall have been elected and qualified; and said election shall be conducted in conformity with the laws regulating elections in this State.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p: Sec. 9. That should the election of any one of the aldermen be contested, said contest shall be tried by the town council, and shall be determined by a majority of those present when the contest is tried.
Sec. 10. That there shall be a constable, secretary, treasurer, assessor and collector, and alcalde of acequias for said town.
Sec. 11. The constable of the precinct in which said town is situated, shall be ex officio constable of the town.

Sec. 12. That all officers of said corporation, before entering upon the duties of their office, shall take and subscribe the oath prescribed by the Constitution; and the mayor, constable, assessor and collector, and treasurer shall enter into bond, with two good securities, to be approved by the town council, for the faithful per-
formance of the duties of their office, payable to said corporation, in such sum as the town council may require; which said bond shall not be void on the first recovery, but may be sued on from time to time, in the name of any person injured by a breach thereof, until the whole of the penalty is recovered.

Sec. 13. That the secretary, treasurer, assessor and collector and alcalde of acequias shall be elected by the town council, and shall hold their office for two years, and until their successors shall have been elected and qualified; said officers shall be elected by a ma-
jority of the aldermen present; said election shall be at a regular meeting of the town council, as soon as possible after the aldermen have received their certificates of election; and any of said officers may be removed at any regular meeting of the town council, by a vote of two-thirds of the aldermen elected.
Sec. 14. The town council may, from time to time, provide by ordinance for the election or appointment of such other officers as they may deem necessary.

Sec. 15. The town council shall have and exercise control over the public square, streets and roads within said corporation. They shall have power to license, tax and regulate hawkers, peddlers, auc-
tioneers, theatrical and other exhibitions, shows and amusements, billiard tables, nine or ten pin alleys, tippling houses, dram shops and groceries, and to determine the amount of tax on the same; and to suppress gaming or gambling houses, by whatever name or de-
scription known, and all disorderly houses; to establish and regulate public pounds, and to regulate the running at large of horses, mules, cattle and sheep, and to regulate, restrain and prohibit the running at large of swine and other animals, and to authorize the distraining, impounding and sale of the same, for the cost of the proceeding and the penalty incurred, and to impose penalties on the owners thereof for a violation of any ordinance in relation thereto; to tax, regulate
Laws of the State of Texas.restrain and prohibit the running at large of dogs, and to authorize their destruction when at large contrary to ordinance, and to impose penalties on the owners or keepers thereof; to provide by ordinance for the distribution of water for irrigating purposes; and generally to do such other acts, and to pass such ordinances not inconsistent with the Constitution and laws of this State or of the United States, as may conduce to the interest and welfare of said town; provided, that any ordinance, law or by-law passed in pursuance of this act shall not go into effect unless the same be approved by the mayor, or being disapproved by him it be passed by a vote of two-thirds of the whole council; nor until five days after the same shall have been published by posting copies thereof in three public places in said town, unless, in the opinion of said council, the emergency may be such as to require a departure from this rule.

Sec. 16. To defray the expenses of said town the said council are hereby fully authorized and empowered to impose a direct prop-
erty and license tax upon all such persons, property and employ-
ments as are liable to taxation under the Constitution and laws of this State, and to make and execute all laws necessary to enforce the collection of the same; provided, nevertheless, that no property tax (unless for special purposes, and specially provided for by act of the Legislature) shall for any one year exceed the one-half of one per cent. of the value of the property, nor any license tax the sum of one hundred dollars; nor shall any tax be levied without the con-
currence of three-fourths of the whole council in its favor. And in order the more effectually to enforce the ordinances of the said town the said town council shall impose, upon the violation thereof, such fines and penalties, not exceeding one hundred dollars, and such im-
prisonment, not exceeding fifteen days, to be collected and inflicted through the mayor’s court, as they may deem necessary and proper.

Sec. 17. The stated meetings of the town council shall be on the second and fourth Saturdays of each month, and the mayor may, whenever he considers it necessary, call special meetings by notice to each of the members of said council, served personally or left at their usual places of abode; and the mayor shall, on the application of any three members of the council, call a special meeting.

Sec. 18. The council shall determine the rules for its own pro-
ceedings, and be the judge of the election and qualification of its own members, and shall have power to compel the attendance of absent members and punish them for disorderly conduct, and with the concurrence of two-thirds of the council may expel a member.

Sec. 19. It shall be the duty of the secretary of said town to keep a correct record of the proceedings of the town council, in a book kept for that purpose; to take charge of and keep safely all
Laws of the State of Texas.books, papers and accounts of the council. He shall keep the seal and use it in the attestation of all documents signed by him by direction of the mayor or council; he shall receive and receipt for all moneys paid into the mayor’s court on account of tines imposed by said court, and shall pay the same to the treasurer, taking his receipt therefor, and shall generally perform such other duties as the town council may lawfully require of him. He shall receive for his services such compensation as the town council may deter-
mine, not to be changed during the term of service of the incum-
bent.

Sec. 20. That the treasurer of said town shall receive and keep securely all moneys belonging to the said town, and make all pay-
ments for the same, upon the order of the mayor, attested by the secretary, and the seal of the town. He shall keep regular and correct accounts of their real, personal and mixed property, and shall render a correct statement of his receipts and payments to the town council at their first regular meeting in each quarter, and whensoever at other times he be required by them to do so; and at the end of every half year shall cause to be published, at the ex-
pense of the town, a statement showing the amount of receipts and expenditures for the six months next preceding, and the general condition of the treasury, and shall do and perform such other acts and duties as the town council may lawfully require of him as the treasurer of the town; and for his services the said treasurer shall receive such compensation as the town council may deem sufficient, not to be changed during the term of service of any incumbent.

Sec. 21. That the assessor and collector of the town shall make up the assessment of all the property taxed by the town, and collect the taxes of every kind as they shall become due and owing, and generally perform all the duties in relation to town taxes as are required of the justices of the peace and sheriffs in regard to the State and county taxes, under such forms and regulations as the town council may prescribe, and shall pay over to the treasurer every month the moneys he shall have received, and make a report thereof to the town council at their first regular meeting in every quarter. All assessments of property shall be made under oath by the party returning the same; if the appraisement be unsatisfactory to the assessor, it shall be referred to a board of three commissioners, being owners of real estate in the town to the value of five hundred dollars each, and entirely disconnected with the administration of the town, who shall be appointed by the town council, and whose decision shall be final. The same commissioners shall assess the value of all property whose owners are unknown, or which may not
Laws of the State of Texas.have been returned, and receive for their services such remunera-
tion, not being a per centage, as the town council shall deem proper.

Sec. 22. The alcalde of acequias shall supervise all work under-
taken by the town council on the acequias; he shall see that the acequias are kept clean and in good condition, and shall supervise-
the partition of water for irrigation purposes.

Sec. 23. That whenever a vacancy shall occur in the town, coun-
cil or any other office in said town by death, resignation, removal or otherwise, or whenever from any cause the regular election shall not be held at the proper time, the town council may and shall, as soon as practicable thereafter, order an election to fill such vacancy, or to supply the place of such omitted election, and the said election so ordered, shall be conducted in all things in the same manner as here-
inbefore prescribed for the regular elections; and in case of the sick-
ness of any officer, and until the vacancy shall be filled by such elec-
tion the town council are hereby fully authorized and empowered to appoint other persons (if it be the office of the mayor, from their own, and if any other office, from without their body,) to fill such office until such sick person shall recover, or such vacancy be filled by election by the people, or by the town council, and the person so appointed shall have the same powers, perform the same duties, be subject to the same penalties, and receive the same com-
pensation for the time being as if he had been duly elected to said office.

Sec. 24. That the town council shall have the power, in the manner hereinafter specified, to grant or sell portions of real estate, the property of the said town of San Eleceario, to any of the follow-
ing person or persons, and to no others: First, to actual settlers on said lands, who are citizens of the town of San Eleceario. Second, to any person or company for the erection of buildings to be used for mechanical or manufacturing purposes, or for the building of railroad depots or workshops; provided, that the land granted or sold shall not exceed the quantity to be actually covered by the erection of such buildings. Third, to any person or persons who may desire to become citizens of said town, and who shall become actual settlers on the lands sold or granted.

Sec. 25. That, whenever any person shall desire to purchase or obtain a grant of land for the purposes specified in the foregoing section, he or they shall make application to the town, council at a regular meeting thereof, said application to be in writing and in duplicate in the following form: “To the town council of the town of San Eleceario, Texas: Your petitioner (or petitioners) respect-
fully prays that the following described tract of land, situated within the corporate limits of the town of San Eleceario, be sold (or
Laws of the State of Texas.granted) to him by your honorable body. [Here must follow a correct description of the land.] Your petitioner desires to use said land for the following purposes. [Here follows the purposes for which the petitioner desires the land.] (Signed.).............” Said petition shall be read in open meeting of the council when it is received, but no further action shall be had thereon at that time. At least ten days before the next regular meeting of the town coun-
cil, the secretary shall publish the duplicate copy of the petition by posting it in a conspicuous place near the door of the town council hall, and shall post underneath a notice advising all parties inter-
ested that said petition will be acted on at the next regular meeting of the council. At the next regular meeting of the council the pe-
tition shall be taken up and read, and the presiding officer shall ask if there is any person present who has anything to say in favor of or against the granting of this petition, and any citizen of said town may appear in person or by attorney before the council, and speak in favor of or against the granting of the petition. When argument has been finished, the council shall proceed to vote by ayes and noes, which shall be entered upon the journal, and if two-thirds of the council elected shall vote in favor of the petitioner, the petition shall be considered as granted. If the petition is for the purchase of lands, the council shall then proceed by a two-thirds vote, to fix the price to be paid by the petitioner.

Sec. 26. When a petition has been granted in the manner speci-
fied in the foregoing section, the secretary shall furnish the mayor with a correct copy of the petition, on which shall be endorsed the action of the council in the premises, and state the consideration, if any. When the said consideration shall have been paid, or the considerations of the sale or grant shall have been complied with to the satisfaction of the mayor, he shall issue to the petitioner a deed to the said real estate, which deed shall be signed by the mayor and attested by the secretary, and shall be in words and form as follows: “Whereas,.............. has fully complied with the provisions of section twenty-five of an act entitled, ‘An act to incorporate the town of San Eleceario;’ and whereas, the town council of said town, at a regular meeting thereof, held on the....... day of............, did, by a two-thirds vote, authorize me to sell (or grant) to the said petitioner, the hereinafter described parcel of land, situated within the corporate limits of said town of San Eleceario, in the county of El Paso, State of Texas, on condition that the petitioner shall have complied with certain considerations herein set fouth, to-
wit: [here follows the consideration;] and whereas, said consid-
eration has been fully complied with to my satisfaction; blow, therefore, know all men by these presents, that I,........, mayor
Laws of the State of Texas.of the town of San Eleceario, by and in virtue of the authority in me vested by the act hereinbefore recited, have granted, bar-
gained, sold and released, and by these presents do grant, bargain, sell and release unto the said.........., all that, (here describe the land) together with all and singular, the rights, members, heredita-
ments and appurtenances to the same, belonging or in anywise inci-
dent or appertaining, to have and to hold all and singular the lands and premises above mentioned unto........., his heirs and as-
signs forever.

“Witness my hand and the corporate seal of the town of San Ele-
ceario, this the.... day of...... in the year of......
[L. S.]“Signed................, “Mayor of the town of San Eleceario.
“Attest:
“Signed.............., “Secretary.”
And the foregoing deed shall be considered in law and equity, a good and sufficient conveyance of all the right, title and interest which the said town of San Eleceario may have in the premises.
Sec. 27. That this act be in force and take effect from and after its passage.

The foregoing act, received in the office of Secretary of State April twenty-two, one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one, having been presented to the Governor of Texas for his approval, and not having been returned by him to the house in which it or-
iginated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has be-
come a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div3.head: CHAPTER XLIII.

opener.salute: An Act authorizing Julius N. Garret to erect a toll bridge over the Flat Fork of Tennaha, in the county of Shelby.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That Julius N. Garret be and he is hereby authorized to erect a toll bridge over the Flat Fork of Tennaha, in the county
Laws of the State of Texas.of Shelby, where the public road from Shreveport to San Augus-
tine crosses the same, and that the rates of toll shall be regulated by the county court of said county.

Sec. 2. That the rights and privileges herein granted shall inure to the benefit of the said Julius N. Garret, his heirs and assigns, for twenty years from the passage of this act; provided, however, that in order to secure the privileges herein granted, he shall, within twelve months from the passage of this act, erect a good, safe and substantial bridge over the said Flat Fork of Tennaha, at the cross-
ing aforesaid, and shall keep the same in repair; and in the event of any accident or casualty destroying said bridge, the said Julius N. Garret shall reconstruct the same within four months from date of such accident or casualty, otherwise the rights and privileges herein granted shall abate.

Sec. 3. That no bridge shall be allowed to collect toll, or be erected with the right so to do, for three miles above and below said crossing of the Flat Fork of Tennaha, on the Shreveport and San Augustine road.
Sec. 4. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

The foregoing act, received in the office of Secretary of State, April twenty-two, one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one, having been presented to the Governor of Texas for his approval, and not having been returned by him to the house in which it origi-
nated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has become a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div3.head: CHAPTER XLIV.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Henderson Male and Female College, in Rusk county.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted toy the Legislature of the State of Texas, That for the management and control of an institution of learning located in the town of Henderson, Rusk county, to be styled “The Henderson Male and Female College,” G. H. Gould, Thompson Camp, A. B. Collins, A. D. Stroud and Giles S. Boggess,
Laws of the State of Texas.jr., are hereby constituted a board of trustees for said college, and that they and their successors in office are made a body corporate, capable in law of suing and being sued, holding or alienating prop-
erty, real or personal.

Sec. 2. That said board of trustees shall have succession, may have a common seal, may hold property to the amount of three hun-
dred thousand dollars, may establish a course of studies, employ teachers, grant diplomas or certificates of scholarship, and do all other things necessary and incident to the maintenance and promo-
tion of good morals and sound learning, not inconsistent with the Constitution and laws of the United States and of this State.

Sec. 3. Said board of trustees shall be elected annually by the stockholders of said college, at such times and under such regula-
tions as may be prescribed by said stockholders.
Sec. 4. This act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER XLV.

opener.salute:
An Act to incorporate the Tyler Real Estate and Banking Asso-
ciation.

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That A. W. Ferguson, John C. Robertson, W. S. Herndon, F. N. Gary, Samuel L. Earle, B. G. Duval, G. W. Whitmore, J. H. Brown, M. L. Flushel, and such other persons as they may associate with them, and their successors, be and they are hereby created a body politic and corporate, under the name and style of the “Tyler Real Estate and Banking Association,” and by said corporate name are hereby empowered to have succession, to sue and be sued, to make contracts, to hold, buy and sell property of every description, to contract and execute leases, to take grants and gifts, to execute deeds, mortgages and deeds of trust, to have a common seal, to make a constitution and by-laws for the government and regulation of its affairs, to deal in foreign and domestic exchange, discount paper, and generally to do and perform every act that may be necessary for, or incidental to, the carrying out the objects of the association, and not inconsistent with the laws of this State.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p: Sec. 2. The legal domicil of this association shall be in the town of Tyler, Smith county, Texas.

Sec. 3. The capital stock of this association shall be one hundred thousand dollars, with power to increase the same to two hundred and fifty thousand dollars; said capital stock shall consist of shares of one hundred dollars each, and shall be transferable in such man-
ner as the by-laws of said company shall prescribe.

Sec. 4. The management of said association shall consist of a board of directors not less than three nor more than seven in num-
ber, to be elected annually by the stockholders; and said board of directors shall elect from their own number one president and one vice president, who shall hold their offices, for the period of one year, or until their successors qualify. All other officers, clerks or employes of said association shall be chosen or appointed in such manner as the by-laws may direct.

Sec. 5. Whenever stock to the amount of fifty thousand dollars has been subscribed and fifty per centum on the same paid in, the association shall be deemed organized and competent to transact business, and be entitled to all the grants and privileges conferred by this enactment.

Sec. 6. Service of any and all legal process in any suit or pro-
ceeding against the association shall be sufficient if made upon the president or cashier of the association.
Sec. 7. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER XLVI.
div3.p: An Act granting to Robert Fitzhugh and others authority to build a bridge across the east fork of the Trinity river.

Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That a charter is hereby granted Robert Fitzhugh, and any others whom he may associate with him, to build a toll bridge across the East Fork of the Trinity river, within two miles of the cross-
ing of the McKinney and Greenville road, over said stream, where good foundation for the abutments may be obtained; the said bridge to be above high water mark; and that he bridge all sloughs
Laws of the State of Texas.in the river bottom, and keep them constantly in good order, and keep the highway open and in good condition through said river bottom, from the high ground on one side to the same on the other, in order that coaches, wagons and pleasure carriages may pass with safety at all seasons of the year.

Sec. 2. As soon as such bridge and road shall have been com-
pleted, on intimation of the builders the County Court of Collin county shall appoint two justices of the peace of said county, whose duty is shall be to examine said bridge and road, and report to said court whether or not said bridge and road are completed ac-
cording to the requirements of the charter, and if so, said county court shall authorize the clerk of said county to issue his certificatae to the builders, authorizing him or them to receive and collect the following tolls, viz: Sheep, per head, two cents; stock or beef cattle, going to or from market, three cents per head; stock horses, five cents per head; a man and horse, ten cents; a man on foot, five cents; one horse and buggy, twenty-five cents; two horse buggy or wagon, or pleasure carriage, forty cents; four horse wagon, or three yoke of oxen and wagon, fifty cents; and all other charges in pro-
portion.

Sec. 3. The builders of said road and bridge shall enjoy and exercise full control over the said East Fork, for a distance of three miles up and down the same from the location of the bridge, and the privilege granted to them in this charter, for the term of fif-
teen years from the passage of this act; and the builders, their as-
signs or successors, shall always be responsible for all losses sus-
tained, or injuries received, by failure on their part to comply with this charter, such damages to be recovered as other suits for dam-
ages.

Sec. 4. The builders of said road and bridge shall have, power to erect a toll gate and collect the rates of toll, and collect damages from all persons crossing and refusing to pay the same, as the law directs in other cases of damages.
Sec. 5. This charter shall be void unless the bridge and road be completed by the first day of January, A. D. 1872, and this act shall be in force from and after its passage.

The foregoing act, received in the office of the Secretary of State April twenty-five, one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one having been presented to the Governor of Texas for his approval, and not having been returned by him to the house in which it orig-
inated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has become a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER XLVII.

opener.salute:
An Act to incorporate the Excelsior Bridge and Turnpike Com-
pany.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That John D. Dillard, John Watson, and such other per-
sons as they may associate with them, are hereby incorporated, under the name and style of the “Excelsior Bridge and Turnpike Company.” That, said Dillard and Watson, their associates and successors, shall constitute a body corporate and politic for the period of twenty years; that under that name the said Dillard and Watson, their associates and successors, shall have power to contract for, buy, receive, hold and possess all kinds of property that may be necessary for the purposes for which said corporation is created; to sue and be sued, to bind themselves without using a seal, and make any by-laws, rules or regulations that may be necessary for the welfare of said corporation, not in conflict with the provisions of this act, nor with the Constitution and laws of this State.

Sec. 2. That the entire interest of any member of said corpora-
tion may be sold, transferred or assigned in the same manner that real estate is now sold and transferred.

Sec. 3. That said company shall have the right to construct, own and keep a good and substantial bridge across Tankersly’s Bayou, at the crossing of said bayou, by the Quitman and Mount Pleasant road, and shall construct, own and keep a good and sub-
stantial bridge across the bottom adjacent to said bayou; to be built so as, at all times, to be above high water mark.

Sec. 4. That said company are required to have said bridge and turnpike bridge completed within six months from the passage of this act, and shall execute a bond in the sum of one thousand dollars, to the presiding justice of the County Court of Titus county, conditioned that said bridge and turnpike shall be at all Times kept in good order, and that said company shall be liable for all accidents resulting from neglect to keep said bridge and turn-
pike in good order. Said bond shall be signed by the members of said company, with two good and sufficient sureties, to be approved by the county court of said county.

Sec. 5. That whenever said company shall have complied with the provisions of this act, by having said bridge and turnpike com-
pleted and in good order, they shall be entitled to demand and en-
force the collection of toll at the following rates, to-wit: For one
Laws of the State of Texas.man and horse, ten cents; for one and two-horse vehicles, of every kind, tewnty-five cents; for four-horse wagons, fifty cents; for six-
horse wagons, sixty cents; for wagons drawn by one yoke of oxen, twenty-five cents; for wagons drawn by two yoke of oxen, fifty cents; for wagons drawn by three or more yoke of oxen, sixty cents; for stock or beef cattle and horses five cents per head; for sheep and hogs, per head, two cents.

Sec.6. That said company, or one or more of them, shall be required to own the land upon which said bridge and turnpike is situated, and shall have the exclusive right to own and construct bridges to the extent of said land so owned by them, and no further, which privileges shall never be construed to extend to a greater amount of land than six hundred and forty acres, said land to be in a square survey.
Sec. 7. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

The foregoing act, received in the office of the Secretary of State April eighteenth, one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one, having been presented to the Governor of Texas for his approval, and not having been returned by him to the house in which it origi-
nated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has become a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div3.head: CHAPTER XLVIII.

opener.salute: An Act to authorize Thomas C. Reedy to erect a toll bridge over the Cowbeach Fork of Sabine River, in the county of Hunt and State of Texas.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas. That Thomas C. Reedy,” of the county of Hunt and State of Texas, be and he is hereby authorized and empowered to erect a toll bridge over the Cowbeach Fork of the Sabine river, where the public road leading from the town of Greenville, in Hunt county, to the town of Sulphur Springs, in Hopkins county, crosses said river,
Laws of the State of Texas.at what is known as the “Wall Crossing,” and that he be authorized and empowered to charge, receive and collect toll for crossing on the same at the following rates, to wit: For each head of stock cattle, three cents; for each head of beef cattle or loose horses, four cents; for each man and horse, ten cents; for each led horse, five cents; for each footman, five cents; for each horse and buggy, twenty-five cents; for two horse carriage or buggy, thirty-five cents; for a wagon and two horses or one yoke of oxen, twenty-five cents; for each additional pair of horses, fifteen cents; for each additional yoke of oxen, ten cents.

Sec. 2. That the right and privilege herein granted shall inure to the said Thomas C. Reedy and his heirs and assigns for twenty years; provided, however, that in order to secure the privileges of this act, he shall, within twelve months from the passage of this act, erect and construct a good, safe and substantial bridge over said Cowbeach Fork of Sabine river, at the place aforesaid in the first section of this act specified, and shall keep the same in good repair, and shall keep the public road through the bottom of said river in good order and repair, under the supervision of the honorable Police Court of Hunt county; and provided further, that no person or per-
sons shall be permitted to build a bridge across said river between said bridge herein specified and the road as now located, leading from said town of Greenville to Paris, in Lamar county, Texas, nor within three miles of said bridge on said river below the loca-
tion thereof; and provided further, that all citizens of Hunt county shall be exempt from the payment of all tolls or charges for cross-
ing said bridge.

Sec. 3. That if any person shall willfully fail or refuse to pay toll after crossing said bridge, he shall be liable to forfeit and to pay to the said Thomas C. Reedy, his heirs or assigns, the sum of five dollars and costs of suit, recoverable before any justice of the peace, as in other cases.

Sec. 4. That as soon as said bridge shall have been constructed as aforesaid, the said Thomas C. Reedy, his heirs or assigns, shall have power to charge, receive and collect tolls, according to the rates hereinbefore set forth in section one of this act.
Sec. 5. This act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

The foregoing act received in the office of Secretary of State April twenty-eight, one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one, having been presented to the Governor of Texas for his approval, and
Laws of the State of Texas.not having been returned by him to the house in which it origi-
nated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has become a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div3.head: CHAPTER XLIX.

opener.salute:
An Act to amend An Act granting to James L. Tarver the privil-
ege of constructing a ferry across Big Cypress, approved October 1, 1866.

div3.p: Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the eighth section of the above recited act shall be so amended as to read as follows: Section 8. It shall not be lawful for any person or persons to erect any toll bridge or ferry within five miles, measured by the stream, of the location of this ferry in Upshur county, unless authorized by the police court of said county.

The foregoing act, received in the office of the Secretary of State April seventeenth, one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one, having been presented to the Governor of Texas for his approval, and not having been returned by him to the house in which it origi-
nated within the time prescribed by the Constituton, has become-
a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div3.head: CHAPTER L.

opener.salute:
An Act to incorporate the Mission Valley Pontoon Bridge Com-
pany.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That B. H. Coleman, C. Carsner and such others as they may associate with them, be created a body corporate and politic by
Laws of the State of Texas.the name of the “Mission Valley Pontoon Bridge Company,” and by that title may sue and be sued, may own real estate and personal or mixed property, sufficient to carry out the objects of this charter; may sell and convey the rights and privileges as herein provided for, and all property owned by them; may do and perform all acts necessary and proper for the benefit of the corporation, and make by-laws and regulations not inconsistent with the laws or Constitu-
tion of this State or the United States.

Sec. 2. That the corporation shall have the right to construct a pontoon bridge across the Guadalupe river at any place on said river below the Stapp league or survey, and above the F. De Leon league, about twelve miles above the town of Victoria, in Victoria county; provided, they obtain a right of way from the owners of the land and banks on said stream, and they be authorized to de-
mand and receive such tolls as may be allowed by the Police Court of Victoria county.
Sec. 3. That this charter shall continue for twenty-five years from the passage of this act, and shall be forfeited unless the bridge be completed within two years from the passage of this act.

Sec. 4. That no ferry or bridge shall be established within three miles of said bridge, and that in case of high water, or when the bridge may become impassable, the said company be and are re-
