quired to keep a ferry boat for the purpose of crossing the public, until said bridge shall become passable.

Sec. 5. That this act shall be in force from and after its pas-
sage.

The foregoing act, received in the office of the Secretary of State the twenty-fifth day of April, one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one, having been presented to the Governor of Texas for his approval, and not having been returned by him to the house in which it originated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has become a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER LI.

opener.salute: An Act for the relief of Henry Koontz.

div3.p:
Whereas, On the twenty-second day of May, A. D. 1854, there was issued from the Adjutant General’s Office, a bounty land cer-
tificate, in favor of Henry Kloontz, for three hundred and twenty acres of land for his services in the army of the Republic in the year 1836-7, as set forth in said certificate; and

Whereas, Said certificate was never located, but was lost, as ap-
pears from the evidence adduced; and
Whereas, The said certificate rightfully belongs to, and is the property of Henry Koontz, the son and only heir of Henry Koontz, deceased, the grantee of said certificate; therefore,

Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the Commissioner of the General Land Office issue a duplicate certificate in favor of said Henry Koontz, the son and only heir of Henry Koontz, deceased, and in the preamble to this act first above named, for three hundred and twenty acres of land; and that this act be in force and effect from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER LII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate Austin Hook and Ladder Company No. 1, of the city of Austin.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That H. Thompson, H. M. Metz, A. Ziller and H. Me-
lasky, and their associates and successors, are hereby constituted a body politic and corporate, under the name and style of “Austin Hook and Ladder Company, No. 1,” with power to sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, contract and be contracted with; to have succession; to have a corporate seal, buy, sell, hold and convey property, both real and personal, and to make all rules, and by-laws that may be deemed necessary for the government of the company, and to have and exercise all the powers and privileges generally in-
cident to, and exercised by such companies.

Sec. 2. Said company shall have the right in its constitution
Laws of the State of Texas.and by-laws, to impose fines upon its members for neglect of duty; provided, the fine shall not exceed, in any one instance, the sum of ten dollars, which said fines may be collected in the name of said, company by suit before any justice of the peace within Travis county, and which fines, when collected, are to be appropriated to the use and benefit of said company.

Sec. 3. That the officers of said company shall consist of one foreman, one assistant foreman, one treasurer and one secretary, to be elected at the time and in the manner prescribed by the constitu-
tion and by-laws of said company.

Sec. 4. That said company shall never consist of less than twenty nor more than forty members, and that the officers of said company shall be exempt from all jury service, and that the actual members of said company who shall have served therein for the period of six months or longer, shall be exempt as long as they re-
main members of said company, from duty in the militia and from service as jurymen, except in capital cases.

Sec. 5. That any and all property of the company shall be ex-
empt from taxation for State or county purposes; that all suits in-
stituted by this company may be brought either by the foreman or the secretary, and that service may be had in all suits against the company, either upon the foreman or secretary of the company.

Sec. 6. That neither the company nor the members thereof shall be liable in damages or otherwise, for property destroyed or injured by the company, or by the members thereof, while in the discharge of their duty as a hook and ladder company, or as the members of such company.
Sec. 7. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

The foregoing act, received in the office of Secretary of State April twentieth, one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one, hav-
ing been presented to the Governor of Texas for Ms approval, and not having been returned by him to the house in which it origi-
nated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has become a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER LIII.

opener.salute:
An Act to authorize Car Forrest to erect a toll bridge over Cham-
bers Creek, in Ellis County, Texas.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That Car Forrest, of Ellis county, State of Texas, be and he is hereby authorized and empowered to erect a toll bridge over Chambers creek, in Ellis county, where the public stage road from Milford to Waxahachie crosses the same, and that he be empowered to charge, receive and collect toll for crossing the same, at the fol-
lowing rates, to wit: For footman, five cents; for man and horse, ten cents; for one horse and vehicle, twenty-five cents; two horse vehicle or wagon, thirty-five cents; wagon and one yoke of oxen, twenty-five cents; wagon and two yoke of oxen, thirty-five cents; wagon and three or four horses, or wagon and three yoke of oxen, fifty cents; wagon and any greater number of horses or oxen, sev-
enty-five cents; loose stock, horses or cattle, per head, five cents; sheep, goats or hogs, per head, two cents; provided, that ministers of the gospel, persons going to and from church, jurors and State witnesses, going to and from court, officers on official business, and persons going to and from mill, shall have the right to pass free of charge.

Sec. 2. That the rights and privileges herein granted shall in-
ure to said Car Forrest, his heirs and assignees, for twenty years; provided, however, that in order to secure the privileges herein granted, he shall, within twelve months from the passage of this act, erect and construct a good, safe and substantial bridge over the said Chambers creek, at the place aforesaid in the first section of this act, and shall keep the same in good repair; and in the event of any accident or casualty, destroying said bridge, the said Forrest shall reconstruct the same within six months therefrom, otherwise the rights and privileges herein granted shall abate.

Sec. 3. That when said bridge shall have been completed, the said Car Forrest shall have the right to charge and receive toll according to the rates set forth in section one; provided, he shall keep the same in good repair; and provided further, that he shall be responsible for all accidents and damages occurring to persons or property in crossing the same, caused by negligence or failure to keep the same in good repair.

Sec. 4. That no person or persons shall be authorized to build
Laws of the State of Texas.a toll bridge across said creek within three miles of said bridge as long as said Forrest complies with the conditions herein imposed.

Sec. 5. That said Forrest, his heirs or assignees, shall have the right to bring suit against any person or persons, in any court hav-
ing jurisdiction, to recover the tolls herein allowed, who may re-
fuse to pay the same, and the court may award exemplary damages against the party or parties refusing to pay, not to exceed five times the amount of the toll allowed in such cases; and should said For-
rest charge and receive from any person or persons any greater amount for toll than is herein allowed, he shall be liable to pay to said person or persons from whom the same was received, five times the amount thereof, together with costs of suit.
Sec. 6. That this act take effect from and after its passage..

div3.head: CHAPTER LIV.

opener.salute:
An Act for the relief of William Scanlan, late Assessor and Collec-
tor, Cameron County, Texas.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That William Scanlan, late assessor and collector of Cam-
eron county, Texas, and his sureties on his official bond, be and they are hereby relieved of any obligation to the State of Texas for the amount of one hundred and ninety-four dollars and fifty cents, collected in State tax in Cameron county, Texas, in the year 1870, and of which amount one Julian Raye, deputy collector of said county, was robbed.

Sec. 2. That the Comptroller of Public Accounts is hereby in-
structed and authorized, in his settlement with the late assessor and collector of Cameron county, Texas, for the year 1870, to allow a credit of one hundred and ninety-four dollars and fifty cents, due the State by the said William Scanlan.
Sec. 3. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

The foregoing act, received in the office of Secretary of State April twenty-two, one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one, having been presented to the Governor of Texas for his approval,
Laws of the State of Texas.and not having been returned by him to the house in which it origi-
nated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has become a law wthout his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div3.head: CHAPTER LV.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Indianola City Railroad Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That H. Seeligson, Cassimer Villeneuve, B. E. Hunt, D. H. Began, J. E. Mitchell and V. Weldon, of the city of Indianola, in the county of Calhoun, and their associates and successors, are hereby declared a body corporate and politic, under the name and style of the “Indianola City Railroad Company,” by which name they may contract and be contracted with, sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded; shall have and use a common seal; may issue bonds and borrow money for the construction, equipment and main-
tenance of their road, buy and sell real and personal estate, and generally do all acts necessary to carry out the objects and designs of said company.
Sec. 2. The legal domicil of said company shall be in the city of Indianola.

Sec. 3. The object of said company is declared to be to build, equip, own and operate street railroads in the streets of the city of Indianola, and this company under this act is authorized to build such roads on any street within the corporate limits of the city of Indianola, as may be agreed upon by the mayor and aldermen of the city of Indianola and the said Indianola City Railroad Com-
pany, with the right to use such motive power as may be agreed upon between this company and the common council of Indianola.

Sec. 4. The capital stock of said company shall be not less than fifty thousand dollars nor more than two hnudred and fifty thou-
sand dollars, divided into shares of one hundred dollars each. Said shares to be transferable on the books of the company in person or by attorney.

Sec. 5. Subscription, for shares to the capital stock of this company shall be paid in such sums and at such times as may be
Laws of the State of Texas.agreed upon by the by-laws of said company. When any stock-
holder shall make default in the payment of the assessment of his stock it shall be sold by the president of said company after thirty days public notice, published in some newspaper in the city of In-
dianola, which sale shall be an absolute conveyance in fee simple of such stock to its purchaser, he also paying the remaining install-
ments which may be due.

Sec. 6. The company shall, at its first meeting, make by-laws for its government not inconsistent with the Constitution and laws of this State or this act of incorporation; no by-law shall take effect until approved by a majority of the stockholders.

Sec. 7. That the parties named in this act, or a majority of them, are hereby declared commissioners, whose duty it shall be, within twelve months after the passage of this act, to organize said company, and begin their work, and complete one road within three (3) years. The stockholders shall elect a board of not less than five nor more than seven directors, who shall elect from their number a president, and they shall also elect such other officers as the by-laws may require.

Sec. 8. That all contracts made or entered into by and between the mayor and aldermen of the city of Indianola and the said com-
pany, or any privileges or rights granted by the said mayor and aldermen of the city of Indianola to the said company, shall be in all respects legal and binding on the aforesaid contracting parties.
Sec. 9. This charter shall remain in full force and effect for the period of fifty years.
Sec. 10. This act shall take effect from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER LVI.

opener.salute: An Act for the relief of Moses L. Patton.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the Commissioner of the General Land Office is au-
thorized and required to issue to Moses L. Patton of Nacogdoches county, a certificate for one-fourth of a league of land, subject to be located upon any of the public land of the State of Texas not other-
wise appropriated, which certificate is in lieu of a certificate for the same quantity of land issued by George Antonio Nixon, Commis-
Laws of the State of Texas.sioner for Vehlein’s Colony, to the said Moses L. Patton, as an im-
migrant to Texas, as a single man, in the spring of one thousand eight hundred and thirty-five, which location and survey under the certificate of said Nixon was not perfected until a little before the closing of the General Land Office of the State in 1835, and hence all proceedings under and by said certificate became null and void.
Sec. 2. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

The foregoing act, received in the office of Secretary of State April twenty-two, one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one, having been presented to the Governor of Texas for his approval, and not having been returned by him to the house in which it origi-
nated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has become a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div3.head: CHAPTER LVII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the City of Hearne.

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted Toy the Legislature of the State of Texas, That all the inhabitants of the city of Hearne be and they are hereby declared to be a body politic and corporate, to be known by the name and style of the city of Hearne, and by that name may sue and be sued, and may defend in all courts, and all actions and matters whatever; and may purchase, hold and convey real and personal estate within the limits of said town for the use of said corporation, and may have a common seal, and may alter and change the same at their pleasure.

Sec. 2. That the limits of said city corporation shall extend to the present limits of said city, or including the town plots of the Houston, Texas, Central Railroad Company and of the Internation-
al Railroad Company.

Sec. 3. That no person shall be a qualified voter at any election for officers of said corporation, unless he is constitutionally a quali-
fied elector of this State, and has resided within the chartered lim-
its of the corporation two months next preceding the election.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p:
Sec. 4. That no person shall be eligible as an officer of said city who at the time of his election does not possess the qualifica-
tions of an elector in accordance with the requirements of the Con-
stitution and laws of this State.

Sec. 5. That the qualified electors of said corporation shall, as-
soon as authorized by law, elect a mayor, recorder, assessor and collector, marshal, street commissioner, city sexton, a secretary and treasurer, and one city attorney, and one alderman for each ward of said town, which said officers shall hold their offices for the term, of two years from date of their election and until their successors shall be elected and qualified. No office of the city shall be deemed a lucrative State office.
Sec. 6. That the city authorities are authorized to divide the city into a convenient number of wards, not exceeding six, and to fix and define the boundaries thereof.

Sec. 7. That the mayor and aldermen shall constitute the coun-
cil of said corporation, over which the mayor, when present, shall preside, and in case of his absence, they shall elect an alderman to preside pro tempore, and in case of a tie in the vote of the board he shall give the casting vote.

Sec. 8. That the officers of said corporation, before entering upon the discharge of their duties, shall take and subscribe the oath of office required by the Constitution of the State, before any officer legally authorized to administer oaths.

Sec. 9. That the major, in addition to his powers and juris-
diction as such, is hereby vested with all the power and jurisdiction, civil and criminal, within the limits of said corporation which may be by law exercised by justices of the peace under the laws of the State, and he shall be entitled to have and receive such fees as are or may be by law allowed to justices of the peace for similar ser-
vices and no more.

Sec. 10. That all the officers of said corporation may be re-
moved from office for any neglect of duty, misdemeanor or malfeas-
ance in office by a vote of two-thirds of the aldermen at a regular meeting of the board.

Sec. 11. That the mayor and aldermen shall have the power to enact such by-laws and ordinances for the government of said cor-
poration, and for the quiet, peace, good order and happiness of the citizens of the same, not inconsistent with the laws of the State, as may be deemed proper, and may impose fines and penalties for the violation of the same not to exceed on hundred dollars in any one case.

Sec. 12. That the mayor and aldermen shall have and exercise
Laws of the State of Texas.control over the public square, streets, sidewalks and roads within said corporation.

Sec. 18. That the board of aldermen shall have power to levy and provide for the collection of an ad valorem tax on property situated in said corporation taxable by the general law of the State, and also the power to levy and collect a poll tax, not to exceed one dollar each, on all male persons of said corporation over the age of twenty-one years and under fifty-five years, which tax shall be col-
lected in such manner as may be provided by the by-laws of said corporation; provided, said ad valorem tax shall not exceed one-
half of one per centum on the value of the property taxed, and that it shall require the vote of two thirds of the members of the city council to levy such tax, and the same shall be done at a regular meeting of the board.

Sec. 14. That the board of aldermen shall have the power to license, tax and regulate peddlers, auctions, hawkers, theatricals, and other exhibitions, shows and amusements, billiard tables, nine and ten pin alleys, groceries, tippling houses and dram shops, and to determine the amount of tax upon the same, and to suppress gaming or gambling houses by whatever description known, and all disorderly houses.

Sec. 15. That the mayor, recorder, city assessor and collector, and secretary and treasurer, shall each enter into a bond with two good securities, to be approved by the board of aldermen, for the faithful performance of their duties, payable to the said corporation in such sum as the board of aldermen may require; which bonds shall not be void on first recovery, and which bonds shall be entered into before entering upon the duties of their office.

Sec. 16. That the fees of aldermen shall not be more than three dollars for each and every regular meeting of the board at which they may be in attendance; provided, they shall not be entitled to charge for more than twelve meetings in any one year; that the fees of the recorder shall not be more than two dollars for each and every meeting of the board at which he may be in attendance; the fees of the treasurer shall not be more than five per centum upon all moneys received and paid out by him; the city attorney shall be en-
titled to have and receive a tax fee of two dollars and fifty cents on each and every conviction; provided, that when any person shall have committed any offense against the laws of said corporation; which fee the mayor shall include and tax in the bill of costs on said conviction; provided, that when any person shall have committed any offense against the laws of said corporation, and shall plead guil-
ty of the same said tax shall not be allowed nor taxed; and the board of aldermen shall have the power to regulate the compensation of
Laws of the State of Texas.the officers of said corporation not definitely fixed and provided for in this act.

Sec. 17. Thai in all prosecutions, trials and proceedings under this act and the by-laws of said corporation, the mayor and marshal Shall be governed by the laws regulating proceedings in justices’ courts, in force at the time of said proceedings, prosecutions and trials, and shall be entitled to the same fees as the justices of the peace and marshals for similar services.

Sec. 18. That the first election, as provided for in the fifth sec-
tion of this act, for officers, shall be held as may be provided by law; that, for the present, the Governor be requested to appoint the officers for said corpoation.
Sec. 19. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER LVIII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the city of Groesbeck, in Limestone County.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the citizens of the city of Groesbeck, in Limestone county, be and they are hereby declared a body corporate and poli-
tic, and under the style of the City of Groesbeck, may sue and be sued in all courts whatever, and may purchase, hold and convey any real and personal estate within the limits of said city, and may have a corporate seal.

Sec. 2. That the limits of said city corporation shall be two miles square, including the city of Groesbeck, as laid out by the Central Texas Railway Company, and the Isaiah Medlock, Elijah McCullough, John Bradley, Haywood Trammell and York Jack-
son, are hereby appointed commissioners to lay off and define the limits of said city.

Sec. 3. The city council shall consist of a mayor and five alder-
men, and the mayor and board of aldermen of said city shall be ap-
pointed by the Governor, and they shall hold their offices until the next general election, when the qualified electors of said corporation shall elect their successors, who shall hold their offices for the term of two years.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p: Sec. 4. That all persons who are qualified voters under the Constitution of the State, and who have been citizens of said city six months preceding an election, shall be authorized to vote in elections held in said corporation.

Sec. 5. That there shall be a marshal, treasurer, recorder and attorney of said corporation, who shall hold their offices for the term of one year, and until their successors be appointed and quali-
fied; said officers shall be appointed at a regular meeting of the board of aldermen, by a vote of two-thirds of the aldermen present; said appointments shall be made as soon as practicable after the aldermen shall have received their certificates of election or ap-
pointment, and as soon as practicable after any vacancies from resignation, death, expiration of term of office, or other cause, may occur.

Sec. 6. That at all elections held under this act, the board of aldermen shall appoint judges of said elections, who shall take an oath, faithfully and impartially to discharge their duties; they shall open the polls at ten o’clock A. M., and close the same at four o’clock P. M. on the day of election, and shall within twenty-
four hours thereafter, make returns of said election to the mayor, or in case of his absence or inability to act, or of a vacancy in his office, then the recorder and board of aldermen shall open such returns and determine the results of the election, and immediately issue certificates thereof to the persons elected.
Sec. 7. That when an election for mayor shall be contested, the board of aldermen shall determine such contest.

Sec. 8. That in case of vacancy in the office of mayor, the board of aldermen shall order an election to fill such vacancy; such election as provided in this act for regular elections; and in case of vacancy in the office of aldermen, such vacancy shall be filled at a regular meeting of the board of aldermen by a vote of two-thirds of the aldermen present, and the person so appointed shall hold his office for the unexpired term.

Sec. 9. In case of the temporary absence of the mayor, the board of aldermen shall have the power to appoint one of their number to act as mayor pro tempore, who shall have the same powers and privileges as the mayor elect, and such appointment shall expire on the return of the mayor.

Sec. 10. That the mayor when present, shall preside over the board of aldermen, and in case of a tie in the vote of the board, shall give the casting vote; that three members of said board in-
cluding the mayor, shall constitute a quorum to transact business.

Sec. 11. That the mayor in addition to his powers and jurisdic-
tion as such, is hereby Tested with all the powers and jurisdiction, civil and criminal, within the limits of said corporation, which may
Laws of the State of Texas.be by law exercised by justices of the peace under the laws of the State; and he shall be entitled to have and receive such fees as are or may be by law allowed to justices of the peace for similar ser-
vices.

Sec. 12. That the mayor and aldermen shall have the power to enact such by-laws and ordinances for the government of said cor-
poration and for the quiet, peace, good order and happiness of the citizens of the same, not inconsistent with the laws of the State, as may be deemed proper; and may impose fines and penalties for the violation of the same, not to exceed one hundred dollars in any one case.

Sec. 13. That the mayor and aldermen shall have and exercise control over the streets, sidewalks and roads, within said corpora-
tion.

Sec. 14. That the board of aldermen shall have power to levy and provide for the collection of an ad valorem tax on property situated in said corporation taxable by the general law of the State, which tax shall be collected in such manner as may be provided by the by-laws of said corporation; provided, said ad valorem tax shall not exceed one-half of one per centum on the value of the property taxed, and that it shall require the vote of two-thirds of the members of the board of aldermen to levy such tax, and the same shall be done at a regular meeting of the board.

Sec. 15. That the board of aldermen shall have the power to license, tax and regulate hawkers, peddlers, auctions, theatricals and other exhibitions, shows and amusements, billiard tables, nine and ten pin alleys, groceries, tippling houses and dram shops, and to determine the amount of tax upon the same, and to suppress gaming or gambling houses by whatever description known, and all disorderly houses.
Sec. 16. That the board of aldermen also have the power to license, tax and regulate drays, carts and wagons running within said corporation, and prescribe the bond of owners of same.

Sec. 17. That the board of aldermen shall have power to ap-
point such additional officers as may be necessary, and to regulate their duties and compensation, and may require of them bond and security to the mayor in such penalty as may be deemed requisite to compel the efficient discharge of such duties as may be assigned them.

Sec. 18. That the marshal, in addition to his powers and privi-
leges as such, be and is hereby vested with all the powers and privi-
leges which are now or may be by law exercised by the constable of the beat in which said corporation is situated, and for all services which may be rendered by him he shall have the same fees which
Laws of the State of Texas.are or may be by law allowed to constables of the beat for similar services.

Sec. 19. That the fees of the aldermen shall not be more than three dollars for each and every regular meeting of the board at which they may be in attendance; the fees of the recorder shall not be more than three dollars for each and every meeting of the board at which he may be in attendance; the fees of the treasurer shall not be more than five per centum upon all moneys received and paid out by him; the corporation attorney shall be entitled to have and receive a tax fee of two dollars and fifty cents on each and every conviction under this act and the by-laws of said corporation, which fee the mayor shall include and tax in the bill of costs on said con-
viction; and the board of aldermen shall have the power to regulate the compensation of the officers of said corporation not definitely fixed and provided for in this act.

Sec. 20. The board of aldermen shall fix the amount of bond required of the marshal and treasurer; and, after approval, said, bonds shall be recorded in the office of the district clerk of Lime-
stone county.

Sec. 21. That in all prosecutions, trials and proceedings under this act and the by-laws of said corporation, the mayor and marshal shall be governed by the laws regulating proceedings in justices courts in force at the time of said proceedings, prosecutions and trials, and shall be entitled to the same fees as justices of the peace and constables for similar services.

Sec. 22. That it shall be the duty of the district judge when-
ever complaint is made to him under oath by any person or persons, accusing the mayor, marshal, or any member of the board of aldermen, or any other officer appointed by them, of malfeasance or neglect of duty in any manner in office, to immediately examine into the truth of said charges, and, if true, he shall remove the person or persons from office at once.
Sec. 23. That this act shall be in force from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER LIX.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the San Antonio Shooting Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That R. Hermann, E. Dosch, B. Manermann, A. Altmann, A. Hanreich, together with their associates and successors, be and are hereby constituted a body corporate, for the purpose of rifle practice and target shooting, under the name of “San Antonio Shooting Company,” and by that name shall have succession and be capable of suing and being sued, of defending and being defend-
ed, in any courts of this State; to acquire and hold estate, real, per-
sonal and mixed; to encumber, sell or otherwise alienate the same; provided, the amount of property held by said corporation shall at no time exceed five thousand dollars.

Sec. 2. That said company shall have power to enact rules and regulations for its government, and to alter the same, not incon-
sistent with the laws of the State.
Sec. 3. That this act shall take effect from and after its passage, and remain in force ten years.

The foregoing act, received in the office of Secretary of State April twenty-two, one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one, having been presented to the Governor of Texas for his approval, and not having been returned by him to the house in which it origi-
nated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has become a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div3.head: CHAPTER LX.

opener.salute: An Act granting a charter to James A. Mitcham to create, keep, and run, a ferry boat at the Bazette Landing or Crossing on the Trinity River, in Henderson County and Navarro County.

div3.p: Section. 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That James A. Mitcham, of the county of Henderson, is hereby authorized to keep and run a ferry boat at or near the town of Bazette, in Navarro county.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p: Sec. 2. That the said James A. Mitcham shall be subject to the general laws of the State of Texas governing the establishment of ferries.

Sec. 3. That there shall not be established any other ferry, or other ferry boat kept or run for public use, within three miles above or below said ferry established by this act, except for private use, after said ferry boat shall be in running order; and the said Mitcham shall establish and have a good and substantial ferry boat completed and in running order within twelve months from the pas-
sage of this act and shall then be ready at all times, to convey pas-
sengers and property of all description, and shall be responsible, as common carriers, for the same; except at such stages of water in said Trinity river as in the opinion of the ferryman in charge it would be hazardous to cross the said river, and in such event he shall not be compelled to cross or run his ferry boat.

Sec. 4. That the said James A. Mitcham, his agent or attorney, shall be entitled to collect and receive the following tolls, to wit: For wagon or any other vehicle drawn by four horses, or mules, or oxen, seventy-five cents, and ten cents for each pair of horses, mules or oxen, in said team over the first number named; for each two horse wagon or vehicle drawn by two horses, mules, oxen or other animals, the sum of fifty cents; for one horse wagon, buggy or cart, the sum of thirty cents; for each man and horse, the sum of fifteen cents; for each footman, five cents; for each loose horse, mule, jack, jennet, ox or cow, the sum of five cents each; for ani-
mals in drove or herd, of the stock kind, the sum of three cents each; for hogs, sheep and goats, the sum of two cents per head. Any other species of stock or property crossed at this ferry and not enumerated above, a ferriage fee in proportion as above.

Sec. 5. Any person willfully damaging said ferry boat, its tackle, paraphernalia, or anything appertaining to the said boat, its landing banks or crossways, shall be fined in double the amount of the damages proven, upon conviction, and same recoverable before any court of competent jurisdiction, and the same be due and pay-
able to the party injured, and said fine and costs to be collected as other fines are.

Sec. 6. This charter shall be in force for the period of fifteen years from and after the passage of this act; provided, said ferry shall be kept in good repair and condition to serve and answer for public rise, otherwise this charter to be null and void.
Sec. 7. This act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER LXI.

opener.salute: An Act to amend An Act entitled “An Act to incorporate the Caddo Lake Manufacturing Company,” approved 1st November, 1866.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the first section of the above entitled act be amended so as to read as follows: That Sam F. Moseley, C. D. Morris, Don Campbell, M. J. Hall, M. D. K. Taylor, W. T. Scott, J. K. P. Record, W. H. Parsons, Wm. H. Johnson, and such other persons as they may associate with them, are hereby created a body corpo-
rate and politic, under the corporate name of the “Texas Manufac-
turing Company,” and in this name they may sue and be sued, make and enter into contracts, have a corporate seal, make by-laws, rules and regulations in this name and under the corporate seal, create an agent or agents, of the company with the power to act for the company in accordance with the by-laws and rules. Said company may receive subscriptions of stock, or donations in land or money, may issue their bonds as hereinafter provided, shall have perpetual succession, and shall have all the powers incident to private corporations at common law, not in conflict with the Con-
stitution and laws of this State or of the United States, so that the object of this act may be carried into effect.

Sec. 2. The said company is hereby invested with the right and power to purchase lands and machinery, and erect buildings for the use of said company, and for the purpose of manufacturing or in-
cident thereto, as may be necessary, as hereinafter provided. Said company shall have the right to manufacture any article made of wood, iron or other minerals, of cotton, wool, hides or leather; said company may also engage in packing beef and pork, and grinding wheat or corn and putting up the same for market or shipment, or any of the products of the country may be manufactured, shipped or sold by the said company. Said company may also engage in digging and shipping coal, or in smelting and manufacturing iron, copper or other metals, and hammering or rolling the same. Said company may have establishments for the manufacturing of any of the articles aforesaid, at as many places as may be deemed necessary by said company for the manufacture of any or all the articles herein named, with power to erect tan yards or any other works, so as to prepare the raw material for market or manufacture. Said company may have a capital stock of one million of dollars, which
Laws of the State of Texas.may be used in the purchase of lands and machinery, and the erec-
tion of buildings for manufacturing purposes.
Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, That section nine of said act is hereby repealed.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, That said company may issue its bonds in such sums and for an amount equal to three-fourths of the cash value of the lands and landed stock of the company, re-
deemable in not less than ten years, with interest not to exceed eight per cent. per annum, payable semi-annually; provided, that a lien shall exist, and is hereby created on the land and landed stock, the buildings and machinery of said company, to secure the payment of said bonds so issued.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted, That in any suit by or against said company, it shall not be necessary to specially plead this act, but the same is declared to be one of the public statutes of the State.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted, That when said company shall, issue any bonds as provided in section four of this act, the proviso to said section four shall be incorporated into said bonds, and after any of said bonds have been negotiated all persons shall be deemed to have conclusive notice of the lien created.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted, That in any county where said company shall manufacture there may be organized a special board of directors under the direction of the principal organization, which shall be in the county of Marion, in the State of Texas; said special board of directors shall exercise such powers as may be conferred by the rules and regulations of the company. The assets, stock, mon-
eys, lands, etc., of such organization, organized beyond Marion county, shall be plainly designated and recorded from time to time, and shall be placed, also, as an archive with the general office of the company at Jefferson, in the county of Marion, in the State of Texas; shall only create liabilities in accordance with law, and the general by-laws, rules and regulations of the company.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted, That the machinery introduced into this State for the purpose of manufacturing, as contemplated by this act, and actually used in manufacturing, shall not be subject to taxation for the period of five years from the date of intro-
duction; nor shall fifty acres of land, in each tract on which build-
ings may be erected for manufacturing purposes, be taxed for a like period.
Sec. 9. Be it further enacted, That the corporators herein named, or any three of them, shall, within four months after the passage of this act, organize as contemplated.
Sec. 10. This act shall be in force from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER LXII.

opener.salute: An Act to authorize T. S. Garrison to erect a Toll Bridge over Atoyac River, in Rusk County, Texas.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the Stare of Texas, That T. S. Garrison be and he is hereby authorized and em-
powered to erect a toll bridge over Atoyac river, in Rusk county, Texas, where the public road from Henderson to Shelbyville crosses the same, and that lie is authorized and empowered to charge, re-
ceive and collect toll for crossing on said bridge at the following rates, to-wit: For every footman, three cents; for man and horse, ten cents; for one-horse vehicle, twenty cents; for two-horse vehicle, twenty-five cents; for ox wagon and two yoke of oxen, thirty cents; for ox wagon and four to six yoke of oxen, fifty cents; for two-horse wagon, twenty-five cents; for four to six-horse wagon, fifty cents; for loose horses, five cents each: for cattle, sheep, goats and hogs, per head, one cent.

Sec. 2. That the right and privilege herein granted, shall inure to the benefit of said T. S. Garrison, his heirs and assigns for ten years; provided, however, that in order to secure the privileges secured by this bill, he shall, within twelve months from the passage of this act, erect and construct a good, safe and substantial bridge over said Atoyac river at the crossing of the public road from Hen-
derson to Shelbyville aforesaid, and shall keep the same in good re-
pair; and in the event of any accident or casualty destroying said bridge, the said Garrison shall reconstruct the same within twelve months from the date of such accident or casualty, otherwise the franchise herein granted shall abate.
Sec. 3. That no bridge shall be permitted or allowed to collect toll, or be erected, with the right to do so, for two miles above and below said bridge.
Sec. 4. That this act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER LXIII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the “Indianola Hook and Ladder Company No. 1,” of the City of Indianola.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That John Eglington, C. B. Burbank, V. Weldon, H. Iken, H. Seeligson and Marx Rouff, and their associates and successors, shall be and are hereby constituted a body politic and corporate as a fire department for the city of Indianola, under the name of the “Indianola Hook and Ladder Company No. 1,” with power to sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded; to appear and prosecute to final judgment, in any and all courts of this State; to have a common seal, with such device as they may adopt; to elect, in the manner by them adopted, the officers necessary to command them; to establish by-laws for the government and regulation of their affairs, not inconsistent with the Constitution and laws of this State, and the same to alter or amend at pleasure; and to hold real and personal property, and to dispose of the same; provided, how-
ever, such real estate and personal property shall at no time exceed ten thousand dollars in value, and that the Indianola Hook and Ladder Company No. 1 shall never exceed forty members rank and file.

Sec. 2. The actual active members of the company shall be exempt from service as jurymen, except in criminal cases, and they shall also, one year after their actual and complete organization, be exempt from militia duty.

Sec. 3. That said company shall have power by their constitu-
tion and by-laws, to try all violations of their own ordinances, agreed upon by a majority of the members of said company; to suspend, expel or fine, not exceeding ten dollars, those violating the constitution and by-laws of said company.
Sec. 4. That this act of incorporation shall be and continue in force for and during the term of twenty-five years from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER LXIV.
div3.p: An Act to incorporate the Falls County Turnpike Road and Bridge Company.

Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That S. S. Ward, A. Bledsoe, A. M. Attoway, S. J. Parker, B. T. Scogin, L. Cf. Scogin, Robert Alexander, J. P. Haley. James Stuart, E. C. Stuart, William Killebrew, W. W. Lang, W. B. Ford, D. Y. Gaines, Leonard McGhee, B. G. Shields and B. F. Gassaway, and such other persons as they may associate with them, and their successors in office, be and they are hereby created a corporation under the name and style of the “Falls County Turnpike Road and Bridge Company,” and as such may sue and be sued; may have a separate seal, and may hold and own such property, both real and personal, as may be necessary to carry out the objects of this charter, not to exceed three hundred thousand dollars in value.

Sec. 2. That it shall be the duty of said company to make from the town of Marlin, in Falls county, to the east bank of the Brazos river, at or within five miles of the mouth of Deer creek, a good graded turnpike road, on a level, as near as may he, of one foot above the highest water mark. The said road to be cut out thirty-
six feet wide, to be graded twenty-four feet in the center, with six feet open space on each side of the grade, and sixteen feet in the center of said grade to be covered four inches deep in gravel. At the terminus of said road upon the river, it shall be their duty to build a good, safe and substantial bridge across the said Brazos river, the said road or the said bridge to be commenced within three years from and after the passage of this act.

Sec. 3. That when said bridge shall be completed the said com-
pany are authorized to demand and receive from each and every non-resident of Falls county crossing said bridge, or crossing their property over the same, a toll not exceeding the following rates, to wit: For each wagon, cart, carriage or other vehicle drawn by more than two horses or other animals, twenty cents per wheel, and five cents for each animal by which the same is drawn, and when the same is drawn by two animals or less, ten cents per wheel, and five cents for each animal by which the same is drawn; for each animal and rider, ten cents; for each loose animal of the cattle kind, five cents; for each loose horse, mule, jack, or jennet, five cents; for each foot passenger, five cents, and for each sheep, hog or goat, three cents,
Laws of the State of Texas.and from citizens of Falls county, one-half of the above rates; provided, that all voters who reside in the said county of Falls, going to and returning from any election in said county, shall be permitted to pass, either on foot or on horseback, over said bridge and turnpike road free of charge; and any violation of this proviso-
shall forfeit the charter.

Sec. 4. When said turnpike road shall be completed, said com-
pany are authorized to demand and receive, for each and every resi-
dent and non-resident of Falls county, traveling or passing their property over said road, a toll not to exceed one-half of the rates for crossing the said bridge, and for the purpose of collecting the same are authorized to erect at any suitable point on said road a toll gate.

Sec. 5. That no person shall be authorized or allowed to erect any bridge, except such as are to be used by railroads, or keep any public ferry across the said Brazos river at or within five (5) miles of the said company’s bridge, after the said bridge herein author-
ized is completed; provided, that in case said bridge should get out of repair said company may keep a ferry boat until the said bridge is put in repair.

Sec. 6. That it shall be the duty of the Police Court of Falls county, from time to time, to cause the said bridge and road to be examined, and whenever they shall consider the same not to be in a good and safe condition for using, they may cause the gates thereof to be opened for the free passage of the public and so to remain until said company shall place them in good repair.
Sec. 7. That questions relating to the right of way for the said turnpike road may be adjusted and determined under and according to the general laws governing railroad companies in such cases.

Sec. 8. That the gates of said road and bridge shall at all times, night and day, be open for the passage of persons, and property, and said company shall be responsible, in damages, for unreasonable delays and for injuries to persons and property resulting from the bad condition of said bridge or turnpike road.

Sec. 9. That this charter of incorporation continue and remain in force fifty (50) years from and after the completion of said bridge and road; and that this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER LXV.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Kemper City Bridge Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That John G. Coller and such others as may associate with him, be and are hereby created a body corporate and politic, to be known by the name and style of the Kemper City Pontoon Bridge Company, with capacity in said corporate name to make contracts; to have succession and a common seal; to sue and be sued, and generally to do any and all other acts common to corporate bodies; to have a seal for such title corporate; may own real, personal or mixed property, to an amount necessary to carry out and complete the purposes of this charter, and may sell and convey the same, and may make by-laws and regulations for their government, not incon-
sistent with the laws of this State.

Sec. 2. That the corporation shall have the right to construct a pontoon bridge across the Guadalupe river, at or near the place in Victoria county known as Kemper City; provided, they obtain a right of way from the owners and proprietors of the lands on the banks of said Guadalupe river at the place where said bridge may be constructed, and that they be authorized to demand and receive such tolls at said bridge, when constructed, as may be allowed and established by ordinance of the Police Court of Victoria county

Sec. 3. This franchise shall continue for twenty-five years from the first day of January, A. D. (1871) eighteen hundred and sev-
enty-one, and shall be forfeited unless said bridge be completed and in good and safe crossing order within one year from the pas-
sage of this act.

Sec. 4. No other person or persons, or booty corporate, shall have the right to construct a bridge or ferry across said river with-
in three miles on a straight line, either above or below said bridge, during the existence of said charter.
Sec. 5. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER LXVI.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Collin County, Texas, Agricultural, Horticultural and Mechanical Association.

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That Isaac F. Graves, James T. Coleman, William M. Bush, William H. Andrews, William H. Bush, G. A. Foote, W. A. Rheoa and John Huffman, and their associates and successors, be and they are hereby declared a body politic, under the name and style of the “Collin County, Texas, Agricultural, Horticultural and Mechanical Association,” and by said corporate name shall be capable of suing and being sued, pleading and being impleaded, contracting and being contracted with, and of doing and performing all things necessary to carry into effect the objects of this act; they shall also have and use a common seal.

Sec. 2. That said association is hereby empowered to purchase and hold such real estate as may be necessary and proper, not to exceed three hundred acres of land, to carry out the purposes of said association. The cash capital of said association shall not ex-
ceed seventy-five thousand dollars, and shall be divided into shares of twenty dollars each; each share entitling the owner thereof to one vote, by himself or proxy, at all meetings of said association.

Sec. 3. That the immediate government and direction of said association shall be vested in a board of not less than five directors, a president, and two vice presidents, who shall be ex officio members of the board of directors; a secretary, treasurer, and such other officers as shall be necessary to the transaction of its business; the president, vice presidents and directors to be chosen annually, at the regular meeting of the stockholders, and the other officers to be chosen by the board of directors.

Sec. 4. That said association shall have power, at any regular meeting of the stockholders, to adopt such by-laws, rules and regu-
lations, for its government, as they may deem advisable; provided, that no by-laws shall be in conflict with the Constitution or laws of the State of Texas.
Sec. 5. That this association shall have its fairs at its grounds at the town of McKinney, annually, at such time as the directory may adopt.
Sec. 6. That this act shall be in force for the period of thirty years, and shall take effect from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER LXVII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Austin Gymnastic Association.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That H. O. Heftier, Herm. Lungkwitz, Max. Maas, Wm. Besserer, Louis Maas, Jacob Kuechler and C. Runge, together with their associates, be and they are hereby constituted a body politic and corporate, for gymnastic, social and other purposes, under the name and style of “Austin Turn Verein,” and by that name shall have succession, and be capable of suing and being sued, of defend-
ing being defended, in any of the courts of this State; of acquir-
in and holding estate, real, personal and mixed, and of encumber-
ing, selling, or otherwise alienating the same, as said association may deem expedient; provided, the amount of property held by said association shall at no time exceed fifty thousand dollars.
Sec. 2. That, the said corporation shall not be liable to pay any occupation tax, either State, county or municipal.

Sec. 3. That said association shall have power to enact rules and regulations for its government, not inconsistent with the laws of this State, and to alter the same; and shall have a seal for the authentication of its acts.
Sec. 4. That this act take effect from and after its passage, and remain in force thirty years.

div3.head: CHAPTER LXVIII.

opener.salute:
An Act to authorize Matthew Armstrong, his associates and suc-
cessors, to construct over and keep a Toll Bridge on Whiteoak Creek, in Hopkins County.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That Matthew Armstrong, and such other persons as he may associate with him and their successors, be, and they are here-
by authorized to construct, own and keep a toll bridge across White-
oak creek, in Hopkins county, to be known by the name of Arm-
strong’s Bridge, at a crossing on said stream.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p:
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That said Matthew Armstrong and his associates, shall, within two years from and after the pas-
sage of this act, construct a good and substantial bridge across said stream, at said crossing, on the road leading from Bonham to Mount Pleasant, in Titus county, and shall also within said time of two years construct safe and substantial bridges across all sloughs in the bottom adjacent to said stream that obstruct travel, and shall be required to keep said bridge in good order under penalty of forfeiture of all rights conferred by this act.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, That said Matthew Armstrong, his associates and successors shall, when said bridges are completed, notify the County Court of Hopkins county, of such fact, and it shall be the duty of said court to appoint three commissioners, whose duty it shall be to visit and inspect said bridges, and certify under oath to said court at its next term the condition and char-
acter of said bridges, and whether the same are substantial and safe for public use, and upon a favorable certificate under oath of said commissioners, the County Court shall require a bond in the sum of one thousand dollars, conditioned that said Armstrong and asso-
ciates shall be liable in damages for all injuries caused by neglect in keeping in good repair said bridges; said bond to be given and signed by said Matthew Armstrong and associates’ or successors, with two or more sureties, to be approved by the County Court.

Sec. 4. Said Armstrong and associates and their successors, when said bridges are completed and received and bond is approved, shall have the right to demand, receive and collect the following rates of toll, viz: For each wagon with six horses or oxen, seventy-
five cents (75cts.); for each wagon or other vehicle drawn by four horses or oxen, fifty cents (50cts.); for each wagon or other vehicle drawn by two horses or oxen, thirty cents (30cts.); and for each carriage, twenty-five cents (25cts.); for each person on horseback, ten cents (10cts.); for each footman, five cents (5cts.); for each horse and head of cattle, five cents (5cts.); for each head of hogs or sheep, three cents (3cts.); said tolls shall be collected in the vicinity of the bridges, and no person shall have the right to erect a public crossing within four miles above or below.
Sec. 5. That this act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage for the term of thirty years.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER LXIX.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the East Texas Cotton, Woolen and Cotton Seed Oil Manufacturing Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That William C. Swanson, Carney McClure, W. T. Scott, M. J. Hall, A. M. Burnham, James Turner, Albert D. Lister, R. H. Motley, T. W. Winston, Ormond Knox, H. P. Perry, Benjamin Long, B. H. Martin, D. H. James, J. H. Calloway, G. B. Adkins, B. Smalley, J. H. Van Hook, E. B. Blalock, Henry Hargrove, James F. Taylor, Roland Green, T. A. Bell, A. Akin, A. Page, S. B. Hendricks, S. F. Perry, W. L. Wheat, W. W. Nesbitt, J. F. Wo-
mack, A. Shoat, J. H. Starr and William Umbdenstrek, and their associates and successors, are hereby established a body corporate and politic under the name and style of the East Texas Cotton, Woolen and Cotton seed Oil Manufacturing Company, with the capacity in said corporate name to make contracts, to have succes-
sion and a common seal, to make by-laws for its government and the regulation of its affairs, to sue and be sued, to plead and be im-
pleaded, to grant and receive, and generally to do and perform all such acts and things as may be necessary and proper to the fulfill-
ment of its obligations or the maintenance of its rights under this act and consistent with the Constitution of the State.

Sec. 2. Said company is hereby invested with the right to lo-
cate, construct, own and maintain all such buildings as shall be necessary to carry on the business of manufacturing cotton and woolen fabrics, and of extracting the oil from cotton seeds, and to this end may purchase and own a tract of land, not exceeding six hundred and forty acres in extent, upon which their buildings and factories shall be erected.

Sec. 3. The operations of said company shall be confined to the manufacture of cotton and woolen fabrics and of cotton and woolen yarns, and extracting the oil from cotton seed; provided, however, that at any regular or called meeting of the stockholders, in which two-thirds of the stock is represented, said company may by a majority of stock engage in the manufacture of other articles.

Sec. 4. The domicil of said company shall be at Marshall, Har-
rison county, Texas, and their factories erected within three miles of that point, and within one mile from the line of the Southern Pacific Railroad.

Sec. 5. The name of said company shall be “The East Texas
Laws of the State of Texas.Cotton and Woolen and Cotton Seed Oil Manufacturing Company, but a two-thirds vote of the stockholders at any regular or called meeting may change the name, and notice of such change shall be published for one month in the nearest newspaper published in the State.

Sec. 6. The capital stock of said company shall at no time he less than fifty thousand dollars, and may be increased to five hun-
dred thousand dollars, to be divided into shares of one hundred dol-
lars each, and said company may organize as soon as one thousand shares are subscribed and ten per cent. thereon paid in; and the first meeting under this act shall be held within twelve months from the date of its passage, or the right to organize thereunder shall be considered forfeited, and the first meeting shall be held at the town of Marshall.
Sec. 7. No stockholder or director shall be individually bound for the debts of said company further than to the amount of stock owned by him or her.

Sec. 8. The government, and control of the affairs of said com-
pany shall be vested in a board of not exceeding nine directors, and shall choose from their own number a president and vice president.

Sec. 9. The directors shall be chosen by the stockholders at their annual meetings, which, after the first annual meeting, shall be held on the first Monday in May of each year, at the domicil of the company, and all votings at such meetings shall be by stock, each share entitling the holder to one vote.
Sec. 10. The stockholders at their first regular meeting shall agree upon the by-laws for the government of the company, and upon the number, and duties and compensation of its officers and employes.

div3.head: CHAPTER LXX.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Washington County Fair Association.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That L. N. Halbert, A. Kavanaugh, J. B. Robinson, Geo. W. Gentry, James E. Gray, A. H. Rippetoe, J. D. Giddings, J. H. Gatlin, John Sayles. S. A. Hackworth, Edward T. Randall, and
Laws of the State of Texas.their associates, stockholders in an unincorporated association in the county of Washington, known as the “Washington County Fair Association,” and their successors, be and are hereby declared a body corporate and politic, under the name and style of the “Wash-
ington County Fair Association,” and as such capable of suing and being sued, pleading and being impleaded, contracting, doing and performing all things necessary to carry into effect the objects of this act.

Sec. 2. That the objects of said association are declared to be the improvement of the breed of domestic animals and the encour-
agement of agriculture and mechanical improvements, and for that purpose said association is authorized to purchase, import, breed, exhibit and sell any kind of domestic animals; to purchase, import, manufacture, exhibit and sell such improved machinery and imple-
ments as will promote the mechanical, agricultural and manufactur-
ing interests of the people of this State, and to own the necessary real estate for fair grounds, pastures, race track and training grounds, and to erect upon the same such improvements as may be necessary to carry out the objects of this association.

Sec. 3. That the capital stock of this association shall not ex-
ceed one hundred thousand dollars, divided into shares of ten dol-
lars each, and that the affairs of said association shall be managed by a board of directors of not less than nine persons, elected by and from the stockholders of said association; said board shall elect one of their number president, and shall make such by-laws, rules and regulations, and appoint such other officers and agents as may be necessary for the government and conduct of said association; pro-
vided, that the persons named in this act as corporators shall be the board of directors of this association until an election is held under this charter.
Sec. 4. That this act shall be in force for the period of thirty years, and shall take effect from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER LXXI.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Belton Bridge Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That W. A. Miller, Elisha Ernbree, Silas Baggett, of Bell county, and John T. Flint, of the county of McLennan, and such
Laws of the State of Texas.other persons as they may associate with them, and their successors in office, be and they are hereby created a corporation under the name and style of the “Belton Bridge Company,” and in that cor-
porate name may sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, may have a corporate seal, and may hold and own such real and personal property as may be necessary to carry out the objects of this char-
ter, not to exceed in value fifty thousand dollars.

Sec. 2. That it shall be the duty of said company to build and maintain a good, safe and substantial bridge across the Leon river, in Bell county, at or within one mile of the crossing of said river, known as the Hill crossing, near Belton.

Sec. 3. That said bridge shall be commenced within one year, and completed within two years from the passage of this act, other-
wise this charter will be forfeited. And when completed, it shall be the duty of said company to keep the said bridge and the approaches to the same in good repair, and to keep in constant attendance at the toll gate of the same a person to admit persons and property to cross at all times, by day and night; and the said company shall be responsible in damages to any person or persons injured or damaged in person or property, or unreasonably delayed by its failure to com-
ply with the requirements of this section.

Sec. 4. That whenever the Police Court of Bell county, upon examination, shall consider said bridge be not in a good and safe condition for crossing, they may cause the gates thereof to be thrown open, and for the free crossing of the public, and so to re-
main until said company shall place said bridge in good repair.

Sec. 5. That the said company is hereby authorized and em-
powered to demand and receive from each and every person crossing said bridge, or crossing their property over the same after its com-
pletion, a toll not to exceed the following rates, to wit: For each wagon, cart, carriage or other vehicle drawn by more than two horses or other animals, ten cents per wheel, and two and one-half cents for each animal by which the same is drawn; and when the same is drawn by two animals, five cents per wheel, and two and one-half cents for each animal; and if drawn by one animal, five cents per wheel; for each animal and rider, ten cents; for each horse, animal of the cattle kind, and for each loose horse, mule, jack or jennet, three cents; for each sheep, hog or goat, two cents; for each foot passenger, five cents.

Sec. 6. That no person shall be authorized or allowed to erect any bridge, or to keep any ferry across said Leon river at or within three miles of the point at which the bridge herein authorized shall be located, after the same is completed. The present fords of the river shall not be obstructed.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p:
Sec. 7. That this charter of incorporation continue and remain-
in force for twenty-five years from and after the completion of said bridge; and that this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER LXXII.

opener.salute: An Act to authorize A. R. Parsons and J. A. Helms to erect a toll bridge over Richland creek, in the county of Navarro, Texas.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That A. R. Parsons and J. A. Helms be and they are hereby authorized and empowered to erect a toll bridge over Rich-
land creek at a crossing known as the Burleson Crossing, in the county of Navarro, where the public road from Corsicana to Spring-
field crosses the same, and that they be authorized and empowered to charge, receive and collect toll for crossing on said bridge at the following rates, to wit: For every footman, three cents; for every man and horse, ten cents; for every two horse vehicle, twenty-five cents; for every one horse vehicle, twenty cents; for every ox wagon and two yoke of oxen, thirty cents; for every ox wagon and four to six yoke of oxen, fifty cents; for every two horse wagon, twenty-five cents; for every four to six horse wagon, fifty cents; for every loose horse, five cents; for cattle, sheep, goats and hogs, per head, one cent.

Sec. 2. That the right and privilege herein granted shall inure to the benefit of the said A. R. Parsons and J. A. Helms, their heirs and assigns for twenty years; provided, however, that in order to secure the privileges conferred by this bill, they shall, within twelve months from the passage of this act, erect and construct a good, safe and substantial bridge over the said Richland creek at the Burleson crossing of the Springfield and Corsicana road aforesaid, and shall keep the same in good repair; and in the event of any accident or casualty destroying said bridge, the said A. R. Parsons and J. A. Helms shall reconstruct the same within twelve months from the date of such accident or casualty, otherwise the franchise herein granted shall abate.

Sec. 3. That no bridge shall be permitted or allowed to collect.
Laws of the State of Texas.toll, or be erected with the right so to do, for three miles above and below said Burleson crossing, on the Corsicana and Springfield road crossing on said Richland creek.
Sec. 4. This act shall take effect and be in force from its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER LXXIII.

opener.salute: An Act to authorize James A. Nelms and John W. Irwin to erect a toll bridge over Rush creek, in the county of Navarro, Texas.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That James A. Nelms and John W. Irwin be and they are hereby authorized and empowered to erect a toll bridge over Rush creek, in the county of Navarro, where the public road from Corsi-
cana to Waco crosses the same, and that they are authorized and empowered to charge, receive and collect toll for crossing on said bridge at the following rates, to wit: For every footman, three cents; for man and horse, ten cents; for one horse vehicle, twenty cents, for two horse vehicle, twenty-five cents; for ox wagon and two yoke of oxen, thirty cents; for ox wagon and four to six yoke of oxen, fifty cents: for two horse wagon, twenty-five cents; for four to six horse wagon, fifty cents; for every loose horse, five cents; for cattle, sheep, goats and hogs, per head, one cent.

Sec. 2. That the right and privilege herein granted shall inure to the benefit of said James A. Nelms and John W. Irwin, their heirs and assigns for twenty years; provided, however, that in order to secure the privileges secured by this bill they shall, within twelve months from the passage of this act, erect and construct a good, safe and substantial bridge over said Rush creek, at the crossing of the public road from Corsicana to Waco aforesaid, and shall keep the same in good repair; and in the event of aim accident or casualty destroying said bridge, the said Nelms and Irwin shall reconstruct the same within twelve months from the date of such accident or casualty, otherwise the franchise herein granted shall abate.
Sec. 3. That no bridge shall be permitted or allowed to collect toll, or be erected with the right so to do, for three miles above and below said Corsicana and Waco crossing on said Rush creek.
Sec. 4. This act shall take effect and be in force from its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER LXXIV.

opener.salute: An Act to authorize G. W. B. T. Davis to erect a toll bridge over Pin Oak creek, in Navarro county.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That G. W. B. T. Davis be and he is hereby authorized to erect a toll bridge over Pm Oak creek, in the county of Navarro, near where the public road from Spring Hill to the Comanche Cross-
ing on the Navasota crosses the same; and that he be authorized and empowered to charge, receive and collect toll for crossing the same, at the following rates, to wit: For man and horse, ten cents: footman, fire cents; one horse vehicle, fifteen cents; two horse ve-
hicle, twenty-five cents; two horse or ox wagon, twenty-five cents; four horse wagon, or wagon and and two yoke of oxen, thirty-five cents; more than four horses and wagon, or wagon and more than two yoke of oxen, fifty cents; loose stock, three cents per head. Provided, that all persons traveling said road may cross at the ford on said creek, if they desire, without paying toll.

Sec. 2. That the right and privilege herein granted shall inure to the said G. W. B. T. Davis, his heirs and assigns, for ten years; provided, however, that in order to secure the privileges herein granted, he shall, within twelve months from the passage of this act, erect and construct a good, safe and substantial bridge over said Pin Oak creek, at the place aforesaid, and shall keep the same in re-
pair; and in the event of any accident or casualty destroying said bridge, he shall reconstruct the same within four months from the date of said accident or casualty; otherwise the right and privilege herein granted shall abate.

Sec. 3. That when said bridge shall have been constructed as aforesaid, the said Davis, his heirs or assignees, shall have the right to charge, receive and collect toll, according to the rates herein set forth in section one of this act, and shall have the right to sue in any court having jurisdiction, to enforce the payment of the same.
Sec. 4. That no person or persons shall have the right to erect or construct a toll bridge over said Pin Oak creek, within three miles of the bridge herein authorized to be built.
Sec. 5. That this act take effect and be in force from its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER LXXV.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Liberty County, Texas, Agricultural and Mechanical Association.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That James Wrigley, Thomas J. Ridley, L. C. Chambers, Y. L. Ridley, B. F. Ellis, J. C. Day, S. P. Baillio, Jerome De Blanc, Beasley Prewett, A. Lutldewiez, J. M. C. Lacour, T. J. Chambers, W. F. Hardin, J. G. Minter, Ab. McMurtry, and others, their asso-
ciates and successors, be and they are hereby declared a body cor-
porate and politic, under the name and style of the “Liberty Coun-
ty, Texas, Agricultural and Mechanical Association,” and by said corporate name shall be capable of suing and being sued, pleading and being impleaded, contracting and being contracted with, and of doing and performing all things necessary to carry into effect the objects of this act. They shall also have and use a common seal.

Sec. 2. That the persons named in the first section of this act shall act as commissioners to obtain by subscription the capital stock of said association, and that the stockholders shall organize the same in the manner hereinafter provided.

Sec. 3. That the objects of said association are declared to be the improvement of the breed of domestic animals, and the encour-
agement of agricultural and mechanical improvements, and for these purposes said association is authorized to purchase, import, breed, exhibit and sell any kind of domestic animals; to purchase, import, manufacture, exhibit and sell such improved machinery and imple-
ments as will promote the mechanical, agricultural and manufactur-
ing interests of the people of this State; provided, nothing herein contained shall infringe upon the rights of patentees. For the fur-
ther purpose of carrying out the objects and purposes above de-
clared, said association is hereby authorized to own the necessary real estate for fair grounds, pastures and farming grounds, not to exceed five hundred acres, and to erect upon the same such improve-
ments as may be necessary to carry out the objects of this associa-
tion. That the fair grounds and other improvements of said asso-
ciation shall be located in the county of Liberty, in this State.

Sec. 4. That the capital stock of said association shall not ex-
ceed fifty thousand dollars, to be divided into shares of twenty dol-
lars each; and that the affairs of said association shall be conducted by a board of directors to be elected by and from the stockholders of
Laws of the State of Texas.said association, and that said board shall consist of not more than twelve, and a president and vice president, secretary and treasurer, who shall be elected from and by the stockholders of this associa-
tion. These officers and the board of directors shall make such by-
laws, rules and regulations and appoint such other officers and agents as may be necessary for the government and conduct of said association.

Sec. 5. That this act shall take effect and be in force for twenty-
five years from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER LXXVI.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Agricultural, Mechanical and Blood Stock Association of Jasper, Texas.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That W. H. Bendy, Wm. H. Kyle, James Lee, Geo. W. Smyth, J. W. Sanders, L. Seale, E. L. Armstrong, E. I. Kelley, Ben Powell, and Seymour White, their successors and associates, he and are hereby declared a body corporate and politic, under the name and style of the “Agricultural, Mechanical and Blood Stock Association of Jasper, Texas,” and as such shall be capable of suing and being sued, pleading and being impleaded, contracting and be-
ing contracted with, and doing and performing all things necessary to carry into effect the objects of this act. They shall have a common seal. That the parties named in this act shall act as commissioners to obtain by subscription, the capital stock of said company, and that the stockholders shall organize the same in the manner here-
inafter provided.

Sec. 2. That the objects of said association are declared to be the improvement of the breed of domestic animals and the encour-
agement of agricultural and mechanical improvements, and for these purposes said association is authorized to purchase, import, breed, exhibit and sell any kind of domestic animals, and to purchase, im-
port, manufacture, exhibit and sell such improved machinery and implements, as will promote the mechanical, agricultural and manu-
facturing interest of the people of said county of Jasper, or of this State; provided, nothing herein contained shall infringe upon the rights of patentees; and for the further purpose of carrying out the
Laws of the State of Texas.objects and purposes of this association as above declared, said asso-
ciation is hereby authorized to own the necessary real estate for fair grounds, pastures, race tracts and training grounds, not to exceed five hundred acres, and to erect upon the same such improvements as may be necessary to carry out the objects of this association. That the fair grounds and other improvements of said association shall be located in the county of Jasper, in this State.

Sec. 3. That the capital stock of said association shall not ex-
ceed seventy-five thousand dollars, divided into shares of twenty-five dollars each, and that the affairs of said association shall be con-
