ducted by a board of directors elected by and from the stockholders of said association; and that said board shall consist of not more than five, who shall elect one of their number president, and shall make such by-laws, rules and regulations, and appoint such other officers and agents as may be necessary for the government and conduct of said company.

Sec. 4. That this act shall take effect and be in force for twenty-
five years from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER LXXVII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Bryan Bridge Company, and allow them certain privileges therein named.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That W. L. Sanders, president, and P. R. Smith, secretary, and J. S. McLendon, T. T. Smothers, H. T. Downard, J. S. Fowlks, C. H. Randolph and J. N. Cole, directors of the Bryan Bridge Com-
pany, and their successors in office, be and the same are hereby de-
clared a body corporate, under the corporate name and style of the “Bryan Bridge Company,” with the right and privileges of an ag-
gregate corporation at common law, to sue and be sued, to implead and be impleaded in their corporate name and capacity; to have a corporate seal to verify their official acts, which shall not be changed unless by special act of this Legislature.
Sec. 2. That said corporate body shall have the right to hold and own property, to alien and convey the same in their corporate name and capacity.

Sec. 3. That said corporation shall have the right to own, hold
Laws of the State of Texas.and control the bridge now built by them across the Navasota river, about twenty miles northeast of Bryan, in Brazos county, by any by-law, rule or regulation made by them, that is not in conflict with any general law of this State or the United States.

Sec. 4. That no person or persons shall construct a bridge or ferry within a distance of three miles; provided, the gates of this bridge shall be kept closed when undergoing repairs, and a ferry boat provided to transport passengers and stock during such in-
tervals.

Sec. 5. That the following rates of tollage over said bridge shall be established: For every vehicle drawn by one-animal, twenty-
five cents; for every vehicle drawn by two animals, fifty cents; for every vehicle drawn by four animals, seventy-five cents; for, every vehicle drawn by six animals, one dollar; for every footman, ten cents; for every horseman, ten cents; for loose cattle, each, five cents; for loose horses, each, five cents; for sheep and hogs, each, two cents.
Sec. 6. That this act shall continue and be in force for twenty years from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER LXXVIII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Kaufman County Bridge Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That A. B. Nash and James Potter, of the county of Kauf-
man, and such other persons as they may associate with them, and their successors, be and they are hereby constituted, created and de-
clared to be a body politic and corporate, under the name, style and designation of the “Kaufman County Bridge Company,” and in the name aforesaid may sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, defend and be defended in all courts in this State.

Sec. 2. That said persons, their associates and successors under the name and style aforesaid, shall be and they are hereby authorized to establish, erect, construct and maintain a toll bridge over King’s Fork, a tributary of the Trinity river, within said county, on the public road leading from the town of Kaufman, in said county, to Porter’s Bluff, in Navarro county; and to acquire and bold such
Laws of the State of Texas.property, personal, real and mixed, as may be necessary or useful for the construction and maintenance of said bridge, and to do all other acts, and perform all other works, that may be necessary for the purposes aforesaid, not inconsistent with the Constitution and laws of this State; and that no toll bridge be allowed within three miles of said bridge.

Sec. 3. That said corporation shall be authorized to charge, de-
mand, receive and collect toll, not to exceed the following rates, to wit: For each wagon with two horses, mules or one yoke of oxen, fifty cents; for each additional pair of horses, mules or oxen, ten cents; for each one horse buggy or other carriage, twenty-five cents; for each additional horse or mule to same, five cents; for each man and horse, ten cents; for each loose horse, mule, jack or other animal, three cents; for each sheep, goat or hog, two cents; for each footman, five cents; for each head of neat cattle, three cents.

Sec. 4. That said company be and they are hereby required to keep said bridge in good repair, and to keep in constant attendance at the toll gate thereof some person, so as to admit passengers and property to cross at any and all times.

Sec. 5. That the rights and privileges hereby granted to said company shall cease and determine at the expiration of twenty years from the passage of this act; provided, however, that before said company shall charge or receive any toll at said bridge, they shall cause the police court, or a majority of its members, within and for Kaufman county, to inspect said bridge; and if on such inspection said bridge shall be found to be well and substantially built and fin-
ished, and perfectly safe for passengers and property, said court shall thereupon make a report to that effect, which shall be entered upon the records of said court; and provided further, if said police court, or a majority thereof, shall find upon inspection of the pres-
ent bridge erected by said parties in the condition contemplated by this act, and shall so report, the same shall be thereafter kept in good repair and used by said company, with all the rights and priv-
ileges of this act.
Sec. 6. That this act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER LXXIX.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Widows’, Orphans’ and Superannuated Preachers’ Aid Society, of the West Texas Conference of the M. E. Church, South.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That R. H. Belvin, J. G. Walker, Dan. A. P. Woods and W. H. H. Carpenter, and their associates and successors in office, are hereby created and constituted a body politic and corporate under the name and style of the “Widows’, Orphans’ and Superan-
nuated Preachers’ Aid Society of the West Texas Conference of the M. E. Church, South.”

Sec. 2. Said society shall have the right and power in their corporate name to make contracts, to hold, buy and sell property, to make and execute leases; to take grants and gifts; to execute deeds, mortgages and deeds of trust; to have succession and a common seal; to make a constitution and by-laws for the regulation and government of its officers, to sue and be sued, plead and be im-
pleaded, to defend and be defended, and to do and perform all such things as may be necessary and proper for and incident to the ful-
fillment of its obligations and the maintenance of its rights under this act, consistent with the Constitution and laws of the United States and of this State.

Sec. 3. The officers of this society shall consist of a president and vice president, treasurer and secretary, who shall be selected annually by the members of the society, as may be prescribed by the by-laws of the Society, and at such time as may be determined by the corporation named in the first section of this act.

Sec. 4. The members of said society shall be all such persons friendly to the objects of this organization, as may be selected by the corporation hereinbefore named, till the first regular meeting, and thereafter the members shall be selected on such terms and con-
ditions as may be prescribed by the by-laws of the society.
Sec. 5. In any suit or proceedings against the society, service of legal process on the president or secretary of the same shall be sufficient.

Sec. 6. The annual meeting of said society shall be held at the place and time of holding the West Texas conference of the Metho-
dist Episcopal Church South, and the other meetings at such place or places as may be determined by the society, and all questions
Laws of the State of Texas.shall be determined by a vote of the members in such manner as may be fixed by the by-laws.

Sec. 7. That the powers, rights and duties of the officers of said society shall be such as may be established and determined by the by-laws, and said society shall be and remain as a corporate body for and during the term of fifty years.
Sec. 8. That this act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER LXXX.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Alamo Literary Society of the city of San Antonio.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That Thomas H. Stribbling, Geo. M. Maverick, H. Mac-
Cormack, Theo. Baldus, Stanley Welch, H. C. Thompson, W. W. Gamble, Geo. Kalteyer, B. Mauermann, I. N. Everett, John J. Stevens, Samuel Maverick, G. W. Bartholomew, Thomas M. Pas-
chal, and others, of the Alamo Literary Society, as they are now or-
ganized, be and they are hereby constituted a body corporate and politic under the name and style of “The Alamo Literary Society of the city of San Antonio,” and by that name they and their suc-
cessors and associates shall be capable in law of suing and being sued; of making contracts; of holding property, real, personal and mixed; provided, that the value of real estate held by said society at any one time shall not exceed in value the sum of fifty thousand dollars. They shall have all the ordinary privileges of a corpora-
tion, of doing and performing whatever may be necessary and proper to carry out the designs of the society, which are hereby declared to be for the promotion of their own moral and intellectual culture, and that of the community at large.
Sec. 2. That the officers of said society may enact such by-laws for their government not inconsistent with the laws of this State, as they from time to time may deem necessary and proper.
Sec. 3. That this act shall take effect from and after its passage and continue in force for twenty-five years.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER LXXXI.

opener.salute: An Act for the relief of W. H. Dangerfield.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the Commissioner of the General Land Office be and he is hereby authorized and required to issue unto W. H. Danger-
field an unconditional headright certificate for six hundred and forty acres of land in lieu of the conditional certificate No. 11, issued to said W. H. Dangerfield by the board of land commissioners of Bexar county, and dated on the eleventh day of May, A. D. 1838.
Sec. 2. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER LXXXII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Cuero Bridge Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That J. C. French, J. M. Brownson, B. J. Jones, and such other parties as they may associate with them, are hereby consti-
tuted a body corporate and politic, under the name and style of the “Cuero Bridge Company,” and as such may sue and be sued, may have a corporate seal, and may hold and own such property, both real and personal, as may be necessary to carry out the objects of this charter.

Sec. 2. That it shall be the duty of said corporation to build a good, safe and substantial bridge of wood or iron, across the Guada-
lupe river, near the confluence of the Sandies creek and said river, in DeWitt county; said bridge to be completed within two years from and after the passage of this act

Sec. 3. That it shall be the duty of said company to open and construct a roadway, with necessary Culverts, in the approaches to said bridge from the highlands, as shall render transit safe and easy, and to keep the same in good repair.

Sec. 4. That when said bridge shall be completed, said company may demand and receive tolls which shall not exceed the following
Laws of the State of Texas.rates, to wit: For a loaded wagon or cart and two or three yoke of oxen, fifty cents; for each additional yoke, ten cents; for an un-
loaded wagon or cart, one-half of the above rates; for a loaded wagon or cart and eight to ten horses or mules, eighty cents; for a loaded wagon or cart and four to six horses or mules, sixty cents; for a loaded wagon or cart and two to three horses or mules, forty cents; if unloaded one-half of the above rates; for a coach or am-
bulance with four horses or mules, seventy-five cents; for a coach or ambulance with two horses or mules, fifty cents; for a carriage or other light vehicle with two horses or mules, forty cents; for a car-
nage or other light vehicle with one horse or mule, twenty-five cents; for a single horse or mule and rider, ten cents; for horses, mules or cattle, per head, five cents; for sheep, goats and hogs, per head, two cents; for a footman, five cents.

Sec. 5. That no other person or corporation shall be authorized or allowed to construct any bridge across the said Gaudalupe river, during the term of this charter, within two miles, in a straight line up and down said river, from said bridge herein authorized to be made; and that this act of incorporation take effect and remain in force for twenty-five years from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER LXXXIII.

opener.salute: An Act to authorize Henry W. Jones, his associates and successors, to construct, own and keep a toll bridge on Sulphur Fork of Red river.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That Henry W. Jones, and such other persons as he may associate with him, and their successors, be and they are hereby authorized to construct, own and keep a toll bridge across Sulphur Pork of Red River, at the crossing known as Becknell’s or Mc-
Creery’s Crossing of said stream.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That Henry W. Jones and his associates shall, within two years from and after the passage of this act, construct a good and substantial bridge across said stream; at said crossing, and shall also, within said term of two years, con-
struct safe and substantial bridges across all sloughs in the bottom adjacent to said stream, that obstruct travel, and shall be required
Laws of the State of Texas.to keep said bridges in good order, under the penalty of forfeiture of all rights conferred by this act.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, That said Henry W. Jones, his-
associates and successors shall, when said bridges are completed, notify the County Court of Titus county of such fact, and it shall be the duty of said court to appoint three commissioners whose duty it shall be to visit and inspect said bridges, and certify under oath to said court, at its next term, the condition and character of said bridges, and whether the same are substantial and safe for public use; and upon a favorable certificate, under oath, of said commis-
sioners, the county court shall require a bond in the sum of one thousand dollars, conditioned that said Jones and associates shall be liable in damages for all injuries caused by neglect in keeping in good repair said bridges; said bond to be given and signed by said Henry W. Jones and associates or successors, with two or more sureties to be approved by the county court.

Sec. 4. Said Jones and associates, and their successors, when, said bridges are completed and reviewed, and bond is approved, shall have the right to demand, receive and collect the following rates of toll, viz: For each wagon with six horses or oxen, one dollar ($1); for each wagon or other vehicle drawn by four horses or oxen, seventy-five cents (75 cts.); for each wagon or other vehicle drawn by two horses or oxen, fifty cents (50 cts.); for each wagon or other vehicle drawn by one horse or ox, twenty-five (25 cts.); for each person on horseback, ten cents (10 cts.); for each footman, five cents (5 cts.); for each loose horse and each head of cattle, five cents (5 cts.); for each head of bogs or sheep, three cents (3 cts.);, said tolls shall be collected at the bridge over the main stream.
Sec. 5. That this act take effect and be in force twenty-five years from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER LXXXIV.

opener.salute:
An Act to establish a ferry across the Sabine river, at or near Fre-
donia, Rusk county, Texas.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That J. H. Jones and Henry Miller, be and they are hereby authorized to establish a ferry across the Sabine river, from or near
Laws of the State of Texas.to Fredonia, in the county of Rusk, and that they shall have the right to make their landing on any point on the opposite bank of the said river in Upshur county.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That it shall be the duty of said J. H. Jones and Henry Miller, to provide and keep in good repair all necessary and sufficient boats for the transportation across said river of all passengers, wagons, carriages, horses, oxen and stock of every description; and that upon the providing and keeping such boats in good repair, they shall have the right and enjoy said ferry within the limits aforesaid, for and during the term of twenty years.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, That said J. H. Jones and Henry Miller, shall have for and during said term of twenty years, the right to charge rates of tolls for crossing passengers, carriages, wagons or stock in said ferry, to be fixed by the County Court of Rusk county.

Sec. 4. That no person or persons shall be authorized to con-
struct or keep a ferry within one mile in a straight line above or below said ferry.
Sec. 5. That this act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER LXXXV.

opener.salute: An Act to amend an act entitled “An Act to incorporate the Alamo Fire Association.”

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That section one of “An act to incorporate the Alamo Fire Association” shall hereafter read as follows: That Peter Gallagher, W. A. Menger, Steph. Daunbauer and Don L. McGary, of the city of San Antonio and county of Bexar, and their associates and suc-
cessors, be and are hereby created a body corporate and politic, un-
der the name and style of the Alamo Tire Association, and by that name shall have succession, may sue and be sued, plead and be im-
pleaded, have a corporate seal; hold property, real, personal and mixed, to the value of thirty thousand dollars; make contracts, and all rules and by-laws not inconsistent with this act, that may be deemed proper for the government of said association, and have and
Laws of the State of Texas.exercise all such, other rights and privileges usually incident to cor-
porations of that character.

Sec. 2. Be it enacted, etc., That section three of said act shall hereafter read as follows, to wit: That the members of said asso-
ciation shall be exempted from liability to serve on all juries, except in capital cases.

The foregoing act, received in the office of Secretary of State April twenty, one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one, having been presented to the Governor of Texas for his approval, and not having been returned by him to the house in which it originated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has become a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div3.head: CHAPTER LXXXVI.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Tyler Cemetery Association.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That J. T. Hand, J. J. Flynne, E. H. Wells, H. V. Ham-
ilton, E. D. K. Walters, S. D. Wood, Stephen Reams, and such other persons as they may associate with them, are hereby created a body politic and corporate, under the name and style of “The Tyler Cemetery Association,” with power to sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, acquire real estate and to convey the same, to contract and be contracted with, have succession and a common seal, to make all necessary rules and regulations, and do all other things neces-
sary to carry out the objects of this incorporation.

Sec. 2. This association may, with the consent and upon such terms as the town of Tyler, by ordinance of its town council, may prescribe, acquire control of the cemetery grounds now in use in the town of Tyler, and may, by purchase or otherwise, make additions to said grounds not to exceed twenty-five acres, which shall be sub-
divided into lots, with drives, walks and alleys; and said associa-
tion shall cause a map thereof to be made, a copy of which shall be deposited in the office of the district clerk of Smith county, and all sales of lots shall be made with reference to said map, and the
Laws of the State of Texas.said association may sell said lots at public or private sale; provided, they shall be sacredly dedicated to burial purposes.

Sec. 3. All moneys arising from the sale of lots by this asso-
ciation, after paying the purchase money of the same and all other expenses incident to the purchase and sale of said lots, and after de-
ducting all necessary expenses, incident to conducting the business of said association, shall be used in protecting, improving and or-
namenting the grounds, and any violation of this provision shall operate a forfeiture of the rights herein granted.

Sec. 4. All property, real or personal, belonging to this asso-
ciation, and all lots sold by this association and dedicated to burial purposes, shall be exempted from taxation, State, county or munici-
pal, nor shall any lots so set apart and dedicated be subject to forced sale.

Sec. 5. One twentieth part of the grounds acquired by said as-
sociation shall be set apart as a burial ground for the poor; pro-
vided, that the right to use such ground shall only be enjoyed after the party applying for such right shall have received the certificate of one of the justices of the peace of the county of Smith, or the mayor of the town of Tyler, given upon the affidavit of some re-
spectable person, that the deceased did not leave sufficient estate to defray his or her burial expenses.

Sec. 6. This association shall have all actions at law against any person or persons who may commit a trespass upon said cemetery grounds or property, or who may desecrate any grave, or injure or deface any slab, tombstone, or other monument or structure within or around said grounds, or who shall wantonly injure any tree, shruib, or flower, intended as an ornament to said grounds.
Sec. 7. This act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER LXXXVII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Casino Society of Indianola.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That W. Westhoff, Julius Wagener, L. Preuss, and their as-
sociates and successors, be and they are hereby constituted a body corporate and politic, for the promotion of education and science, as
Laws of the State of Texas.well as social intercourse and amusement, under the name and style of “The Casino Society of Indianola,” and by that name may re-
ceive, hold, enjoy, sell, convey and alienate property, real and per-
sonal, and by the aforesaid name may sue and be sued, defend and be defended, plead and be impleaded, in any court of law or equity within this State; provided, nothing herein contained shall be so construed as to authorize the purchase and sale of lands for specu-
lative purposes, or to hold any more real estate than may be neces-
sary to carry into effect the purposes set forth in this act.

Sec. 2. That said Casino Society shall have power to make such a constitution and by-laws as they may deem necessary for their own government, not contrary to the Constitution and laws of this State, and may elect from their own body the officers necessary for conducting the business of said society.

Sec. 3. That said corporation shall have a common seal, and may alter or change the same as they may deem proper, and in general have and exercise all such rights, privileges and immunities, as by law are incident to and necessary for corporations of a similar character.
Sec. 4. That the privileges, immunities and franchises of this corporation shall expire, unless renewed within thirty years.
Sec. 5. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER LXXXVIII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the town of Burnet, in Burnet county.

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the citizens of the town of Burnet, in Burnet county, he and they are hereby declared a body politic and corporate, under the name and style of the “Corporation of the Town of Burnet,” and by that name shall have power to sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, and to hold and dispose of property real and personal; provided, such real property is situated within the limits of said corporation.
Sec. 2. That the limits of said corporation shall extend one mile, in a square so laid off as to leave the public square in the center of said corporation.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p:
Sec. 3. That it shall be the duty of the citizens of said corpora-
tion to elect a mayor, five aldermen and a constable, who shall be also ex officio assessor and collector of taxes; and a treasurer and secretary shall be elected by said mayor and aldermen. The treas-
urer and assessor and collector of taxes shall be required to give bond, with security to be approved by the presiding officer, for the faithful performance of their duties, and to make reports when re-
quired by the mayor or board of aldermen; land the mayor shall have power, when necessary, to suppress riots and disturbances, and to call out the citizens of said corporation for the purpose of restoring order.

Sec. 4. The mayor, aldermen and constable shall, for the pres-
ent time, and until the next general election, be appointed as pro-
vided for in an act entitled “An act to authorize the Governor to appoint certain officers to fill vacancies,” and upon the expiration of their term of office there shall be an election held under the direc-
tion of the mayor, who shall give at least ten days’ notice of such election before his term of office shall expire, and said elections for the offices as aforesaid shall be held every two years thereafter; and all male inhabitants who have resided within its limits for the space of four months preceding, and who are qualified voters under the Constitution and laws of this State, shall be deemed qualified elec-
tors of said corporation.

Sec. 5. That the mayor and board of aldermen of said corpora-
tion shall have power to pass such rules, regulations and ordinances as may be necessary for the regulation of the police, and the pre-
servation of order within the corporate limits; for the levying of taxes: for the removal of nuisances and keeping the streets in good order; for building a market house; for improving and ornamenting public property within said corporate limits and for any and all other purposes tending to promote good order and government, and they shall have power to prescribe and enforce the collection of penalties for the violation of the ordinances of the corporation; provided, no tax shall ever be levied exceeding one-half of the State tax allowed by law; and provided further, that they shall in no case prescribe penalties to exceed one hundred dollars, or imprison-
ment for more than one week.

Sec. 6. That the mayor, with a majority of the board of alder-
men, shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business, and in the absence of the mayor, the board of aldermen shall elect one of their number mayor pro tempore.
Sec. 7. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage, and that all acts and parts of acts in conflict herewith are hereby repealed.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER LXXXIX.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the officers and members of Weatherford Lodge, No. 77, I. O. O. F.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the officers and members of Weatherford Lodge, No. 77, I. O. O. F., and their successors and associates, be and they are hereby created a body politic and corporate, by the name and style of “Weatherford Lodge No. 77, I. O. O. F.” and by that name shall be capable of acquiring, holding, selling, and conveying property, both real, personal and mixed; provided, the same shall not ex-
ceed the sum of twenty thousand dollars at any one time; and they shall have the right to establish and conduct an institution of learn-
ing in the town of Weatherford, Parker county, in said corporate name, and have the right to make all necessary by-laws for the gov-
ernment of same, not inconsistent with the Constitution and laws of the State, and the United States.

Sec. 2. That said corporation, by the name and style aforesaid, shall have the right to sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, in said corporate name, answer and be answered, defend and be de-
fended in all suits in law or equity within this State.
Sec. 3. That said corporation may have a common seal, and affix the same to all documents requiring it.

Sec. 4. That in any suit in law or equity within this State, where said corporation may be a party plaintiff or defendant, service of any papers or notices shall be sufficient, when made on any officer of said corporation, and the return of the officer making said service shall be the same as returns of officers in civil suits.

Sec. 5. That any deed of conveyance duly signed and executed by the officers of said corporation in pursuance of a resolution au-
thorizing the same, shall be deemed valid, and have the same force and validity as any other similar conveyance.
Sec. 6. That this act shall be in force for fifty years from date of passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER XC.

opener.salute: An Act to amend “An act to incorporate the town of Clarksville, Red River county,” approved January 31, 1852.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That section five of an act entitled “An act to incorporate the town of Clarksville, Bed River county,” approved January 31, 1852, be so amended as to read as follows: Section 5. That the board of aldermen shall have power to enact such by-laws and ordi-
nances as they may deem proper for the government of the town, may appoint such officers as they may consider necessary, subject to removal at the pleasure of the board, and regulate their compensa-
tion; may levy and collect taxes for the building of bridges, and working and keeping in order the streets and alleys, within the limits of said town, and for the support of said corporation and the improvement of said town; provided, no ad valorem tax shall exceed one per cent. They shall also have power to collect a license tax upon all tippling houses, billiard tables, bowling alleys and all mercantile and grocery establishments in said town for the same purposes, and may levy a tax upon all dogs kept within the limits of said corporation; and they shall have power to prescribe the mode of collecting taxes due said corporation, not contrary to the Consti-
tution of the State, and shall exercise a general control over the financial affairs of said corporation, the alleys, streets, and public works and buildings within the limits of said town.
Sec. 2. That section six of the above recited act, of which this act is amendatory, be so amended as to read hereafter as follows:
Section 6. That it shall be the duty of the board of aldermen of said town to keep in order the bridges, streets and public roads within the limits of said corporation.
Sec. 3. This act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER XCI.

opener.salute:
An Act to incorporate the Washington County Banking and In-
surance Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That G. W. Gentry, W. G. Wilkins, H. E. Lockett, F. Bussey, J. B. Wilkins, E. H. Norton, W. H. Thacker, C. C. Hem-
ming, J. T. Norris, James V. Matson, E. F. Ewing, Boulds Baker, A. H. Rippetoe, Edward T. Randall, and their associates, succes-
sors and assigns, are hereby declared to be a body politic and corpo-
rate, by the name of the Washington County Banking and Insur-
ance Company, and in said corporate name they and their succes-
sors and assigns may sue and be sued, plead, and be impleaded, and shall be in law capable of purchasing, holding, improving, and con-
veying any estate, real, personal or mixed, essential for the use of said corporation. The said corporation shall have a common seal, and shall have power to make by-laws and regulations for the gov-
ernment thereof; but said by-laws or regulations must be approved before binding by two-thirds of the stock. For the transaction of ordinary business a majority of stock shall constitute a quorum.

Sec. 2. That the capital stock of said corporation shall not be less than one hundred thousand dollars, divided into shares of one hundred dollars each, with the privilege of increasing the same, at the discretion of two-thirds of the issued stock, to a sum not exceed-
ing five hundred thousand dollars; provided, that after the organi-
zation of this company by the election of directors, there shall be no further increase of stock until after the first day of January, 1872. Notice of any increase of stock shall be made in one news-
paper published in Washington county, Texas, for thirty days, stat-
ing intended amount of increase. The subscription, sale or dis-
tribution of said increased stock shall be in such a manner as may be provided in the by-laws of the company.

Sec. 3. That the affairs of this company shall be managed by seven directors, who shall be stockholders in said corporation, four of whom shall be residents of Washington county. The said directors shall be elected annually by the stockholders at their annual meet-
ing, to be held on the first Monday in January of each year, and shall elect from their number a president and vice president. Each share of stock shall entitle the holder thereof to one vote either in person or by attorney, and all voting shall be by ballot; provided, that after the first election no stockholder shall be entitled to vote
Laws of the State of Texas.on any share or shares which he or she may represent, unless the stock so represented shall have been standing on the books of the company in his or her name, or the name of the attorney, for at least ninety days previous to the day of the election.

Sec. 4. That the directors of said corporation, for the time be-
ing, five of whom shall constitute a quorum, shall have power to appoint such officers, clerks, agents and other persons as shall be necessary to conduct the business of said corporation, and to allow said persons such compensation for their services as they shall deem proper, and generally to exercise all other powers and privileges which are given by law to corporations, or contained in this act.

Sec. 5. That it shall be lawful for said corporation to employ the funds thereof in establishing and sustaining the business of marine and fire insurance, to insure sea going vessels of all kinds, both in port and at sea, steamboats and other craft engaged in coast or other navigation, and all merchandise in transit, buildings and merchandise, and all perishable property on land or sea, against loss or damage by fire; to make all and every insurance appertaining to or connected with marine, inland or transportation risks, and to charge and collect and receive for the same such premiums of insur-
ance as the president and directors of said corporation may deem just and reasonable. It shall be further lawful for said company to buy and sell exchange, and to loan money at interest on securities, both real and personal; to receive deposits, both special and gen-
eral, and issue their certificates for the same, and generally to do all such business as pertains to a banking, exchange and insurance business.
Sec. 6. That the shares of said corporation shall be assignable and transferable upon the books of said company, according to such regulations as the by-laws may provide.

Sec. 7. That the president and directors shall render to the stockholders an annual statement of the liabilities, assets and busi-
ness of said corporation, which statement shall be verified under such provisions as the by-laws may require. One-fourth of the net profits of said company shall be divided pro rata among the depos-
itors, the remaining three-fourths to the stockholders; but if at any time the amount of deposits should bear the proportion to the capi-
tal stock, of three to one, then one-third of the net profits shall be divided among the depositors, and two-thirds among the stockhold-
ers; and if the average deposits should reach the proportion to the capital stock, of four to one, then one-half of the net profits shall be divided among the depositors and one-half among the stockholders.

Sec. 8. That at any time after the passage of this act, and within twelve months after the date thereof, it shall be the duty of the commissioners named in the first section of this act, or a major-
Laws of the State of Texas.ity of them, to assemble the subscribers to the capital stock, by giving due notice of time by publication in all the papers of Wash-
ington county, or by written notice served upon every stockholder, at least fifteen days previous to such meeting. One of said commis-
sioners, to be selected by a majority of the others, shall ex officio preside at the meeting thus assembled, and lie shall proceed to effect the organization of the company by the election of directors, as hereinbefore provided, exacting that five per cent. of the stock rep-
resented shall be paid down before any vote is cast. The meeting shall then proceed to elect a directory, which directory shall imme-
diately select a temporary treasurer, who shall take charge of the five per cent. paid in. The directory, at their discretion, shall within thirty days perfect their organization by the election of pres-
ident and vice president, as heretofore provided. And when the president and directors, as herein elected, shall have established, to the satisfaction of any notary public of Washington county, by the oath or affirmation of the president, that the amount of subscription on stock has been paid in full on not less than one hundred shares, and that the terms of the charter have been complied with, then said notary public shall give his certificate thereof, which shall be their warrant to commence business operations under the authority vested by this act; and it is herein provided that the duties of the commissioners named shall cease to exist from the date of the elec-
tion of this directory.

Sec. 9. That when the directory shall have perfected their or-
ganization, as provided for in section eight, and when they shall have made a demand through their president for the remaining ninety-five per cent., or any portion thereof due on the capital stock, any stockholder failing to pay up the amount due on his stock shall forfeit the five per cent. paid in; provided, that ten days notice of the call for ninety-five per cent. of such payment, or any part thereof, be given by publication in one or more newspapers pub-
lished in Washington county.
Sec. 10. That the legal domicile of this company shall be in the city of Brenham, in Washington county, Texas, and that there its books of record and transfer shall be kept.
Sec. 11. That this act shall continue for fifty years, and be in force from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER XCII.

opener.salute:
An Act to incorporate the Houston Real Estate and Banking Com-
pany.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That A. J. Burk, A. McGowen, W. J. Hutchins, T. W. House, Rowland Allen, E. H. Cushing and R. B. Baer are hereby ap-
pointed commissioners to open books and receive subscriptions to the capital stock of a corporation to be styled the Houston Real Estate and Banking Company. A majority of said commissioners shall constitute a quorum to do business. In receiving subscrip-
tions to said capital stock they shall require five per cent. to be paid in cash, and the balance to be paid in real estate, which said real es-
tate shall be valued and conveyed to the company as they may elect.

Sec. 2. That as soon after the passage of this act as the sum of five hundred thousand dollars is subscribed, it shall be the duty of said commissioners to call a meeting of the stockholders, who shall organize the company by electing seven directors, and said direc-
tors shall elect from their own body a president, and vice president, and such other officers and agents as shall be necessary for the proper transaction of the business of the company.

Sec. 3. The capital stock of the company shall not be less than five hundred thousand dollars, and may be increased to five millions of dollars. The principal office thereof shall be domiciliated in the city of Houston. The president and directors shall have power to ordain, establish, and put in execution such by-laws, ordinances and regulations for the government thereof as may by them be deemed for the best interest of the company.

Sec. 4. That said company, as a body politic and corporate, may sue and be sued, and maintain any action to final judgment, and exe-
cution, and shall be in law capable of purchasing, holding, improv-
ing and conveying any estate, real, personal or mixed; may buy and sell exchange, discount notes, loan its money at such rates of in-
terest as shall be recognized by the laws of this State, and exercise banking privileges generally, not inconsistent with the Constitu-
tion and laws of this State.

Sec. 5. That the capital stock of the company shall be divided into shares of one hundred dollars each, and each share shall entitle the holder to one vote, and shall be transferable by assignment; but no stockholder shall be entitled to vote thereon unless the stock
Laws of the State of Texas.shall appear on the books of the company in his or her name, who claims the same, for thirty clays previous to the election. The vote shall be by ballot, and may be in person or by proxy. The annual election after the first organization shall be on the first Monday in December of each year.

Sec. 6. That the charter granted by this act shall continue in force and effect for the term of twenty-five years from and after the passage of this act, and three years thereafter for the purpose of clos-
ing the business of the company.

div3.head: CHAPTER XCIII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the German Casino of Columbus, Texas.

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That Theo. Harde, Robert P. Tendick, George Whitting, Charles Schmidt, Theo. Oswald, Simon Thulmeyer and William Beethe, of the city of Columbus, county of Colorado, and State of Texas, together with their associates, be and are hereby incorporated as a body politic and corporate, under the name and style of the “German Casino” of the city of Columbus.

Sec. 2. That said incorporation shall be invested with perpetual rights and succession, and as such may have and use a common seal, subscribe, hold and buy real estate within the corporate limits of the city of Columbus, under such rules and regulations as the members of said association shall agree upon and make, not incon-
sistent with the terms of this charter and the Constitution and laws of the State of Texas.

Sec. 3. The members of their association, or a majority of them, may make by-laws for the government of the said association, and may at any time expel a member for a violation of the rules of said association.

Sec. 4. The object of said association being for the social recrea-
tion of the members of said association, their families and friends, the same shall never be used or devoted to any other purpose.

Sec. 5. Said association by their corporate name may sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, and generally may do all other acts necessary to preserve the property and protect the rights of the
Laws of the State of Texas.association as such; provided, that said association and their suc-
cessors shall never own at any time a greater amount of real estate than is of the just value of twenty-five thousand dollars, exclusive of improvements.
Sec. 6. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER XCIV.

opener.salute:
An Act to incorporate the San Antonio Hebrew Benevolent Asso-
ciation.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That Louis Zork, L. Moke and A. Morris, and their suc-
cessors in office, be and they are hereby constituted a board of trus-
tees of an association for the relief of the poor and indigent of the Jewish persuasion, established in the city of San Antonio, which said association is hereby declared a body politic and corporate, by the name of “The San Antonio Hebrew Benevolent Association,” by which name it shall have succession and be capable of sueing and being sued, of defending and being defended, in any of the courts of the State of Texas; to acquire and hold estate, real, personal and mixed, to encumber, sell or otherwise alienate the same as said asso-
ciation may deem expedient.
Sec. 2. The amount of property held by said association shall at no time exceed in value the sum of twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000).

Sec. 3. The said corporation shall have power to enact such by-
laws, rules and regulations for its government, and generally to do any and all things that may seem proper to its members, for the pro-
motion and interest of the association, not repugnant to the Consti-
tution and laws of the United States, and of the State of Texas.
Sec. 4. This associaion shall have a common seal, which, with the signature of the president and secretary of the board of trustees, shall be evidence of their acts.
Sec. 4. This act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage, and shall continue in fall force for twenty years and no longer.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER XCV.

opener.salute:
An Act to incorporate the Hebrew Benevolent Association of Jef-
ferson, Texas.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That Moses Steinline, E. Marx, A. Rosenthal, Julius Ney, J. Sherk, M. Levy, E. Hernstadt, and their associates and succes-
sors, be and they are hereby constituted a board of trustees of an as-
sociation for the relief of the poor and indigent of the Jewish per-
suasion, established in the city of Jefferson, Texas, which said asso-
ciation is hereby declared a body politic and corporate by the name and style of the “Hebrew Benevolent Association of Jefferson, Texas,” by which name it shall have succession; be capable of suing and being sued, of pleading and being impleaded in any of the courts of the State of Texas; may acquire estate, real, personal and mixed; and encumber, sell or otherwise alienate the same, as said association may deem to be expedient.
Sec. 2. The amount of property held by said association shall at no time exceed one hundred thousand dollars.

Sec. 3. The said corporation shall have power to enact such by-
laws, rules and regulations for its government, and generally to do any and all things that may seem proper to its members for the promotion of the interests of the association not incompatible with the Constitution and laws of the United States and this State, and shall have a common seal, which, with the signatures of the presi-
dent and secretary of the board of trustees, shall be evidence of their acts.
Sec. 4. That this act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER XCVI.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Houston “Gewerbe Verein,” city of Houston, Harris county, for benevolent purposes.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That F. Kredel, F. A. Michels, T. R. Neurath, F. A. Breitling, Henry Peterson, P. Ackerman, T. Hornberger, Gus.
Laws of the State of Texas.Dryling, George F. Bock, John H. Meyer, Arnold F. Riemann, Henry Stein, C. F. Schmidt, Chas. Hermann, T. Japliet, Chas. Reiber, Gust. Erbenmeyer, Chas. Eggert, Jacob Zorne, G. Schulte, Chas. W. Stappel, Otto Beyer, P. W. Schwauder, T. E. Miller, J. Zimmer, Louis Ernst, Max. Stubenrauch, Wm. Disen, Wm. Rumpel, Dr. F. Hadra, A. Hoffman, Dr. F. Hassenberg, H. Black, George Kerner, Andrew Bartels, F. Gieseke, H. Ott. D. Hecht, P. Vogel, Alex. Diot, F. Sachs, L. Kaiser, A. Kroner, and all other persons that are now or may hereafter become associated with them, be and they are hereby constituted, from and after the passage of this act, for space of twenty-five years, a body corporate for benevolent pur-
poses, under the name and style of Houston Gewerbe Verein, and by virtue of this act to hold and dispose of all manner of property; to sue or to be sued; to have a common seal, and to use, exercise and enjoy all rights and privileges of a body corporate, under the Constitution and laws of the United States and the State of Texas, for the purposes above expressed.

Sec. 2. That this corporation have power to establish such by-
laws, for their internal regulation and organization, as they may see proper, that shall not be in conflict with the Constitution and laws of the State of Texas and the United States.
Sec. 3. This act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER XCVII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the San Antonio Turners Hook and Ladder Company No. 1.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That E. Pentenrieder, Gust. Mueller, P. Haberick, G. Duerler, Hans Degener, P. C. Haueisen, and their associates, are hereby constituted a body politic and corporate for the purpose of render-
ing assistance in case of fire, under the name and style of “The San Antonio Turners Hook and Ladder Company No. 1,” and by that name shall have succession, and be capable of suing and being sued; of defending and being defended in any of the courts of this State; to acquire and hold estate, real, personal and mixed, to encumber, sell or otherwise alienate the same as said company may
Laws of the State of Texas.deem expedient; provided, the amount of property held by said cor-
poration shall at no time exceed twenty-five thousand dollars in value.

Sec. 2. That said company shall have power to enact rules and regulations for its government and the administration of its affairs, and to alter the same, not inconsistent with the laws of this State.
Sec. 3. That members of this company shall be exempt from jury duties in justices’ and mayors’ courts.
Sec. 4. That neither, said company nor any of its members, shall be made liable for damages done to property or otherwise whilst in the legitimate discharge of their dirties.

Sec. 5. That all machinery and implements owned by said com-
pany for the extinguishment of fires, together with one building, used exclusively for the protection of the same, shall be exempt from. State, county and city taxes.
Sec. 6. That this act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

The foregoing act, received in the office of the Secretary of State the sixteenth day of May, one thousand eight hundred and seventy-
one, having been presented to the Governor of Texas for his ap-
proval, and not having been returned by him to the house in which it originated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has become a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div3.head: CHAPTER XCVIII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the city of Dallas, in Dallas county, Texas.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That all the inhabitants of the city of Dallas shall be a body politic and corporate, by the name and style of the “City of Dallas,” and as such by that name they and their successors shall be known in law, and be capable of contracting and being contracted with, of suing and being sued, and defending in all courts and all actions and matters whatsoever; may purchase and hold real and personal prop-
Laws of the State of Texas.erty, and dispose of the same for the benefit of the said city; and may have and use a corporate seal, and alter and change the same at pleasure.

Sec. 2. That the hounds and limits of the said corporation shall be as follows, to wit: Beginning at a point on the east bank of the Trinity river, at low water mark, directly opposite (westward) from the centre of the courthouse square; running thence east parallel with Main street one and one-half miles; thence north parallel with Jefferson street three-fourths of one mile; thence west parallel with Main street to said Trinity river; thence down said river, with the meanderings thereof, to the place of beginning; thence east along the line first described one and one-half miles; thence south parallel with Jefferson street three-fourths of one mile; thence west parallel with Main street to said Trinity river; thence up said river, with the meanderings thereof, to the place of beginning; provided, that the said limits of said corporation may be hereafter extended by adding additional territory to the same, whensoever the majority of the inhabitants of said territory shall indicate a desire to be included within the limits of said corporation.

Sec. 3. That no person shall be a qualified voter at any election for officers of said corporation, unless he possess the qualifications of a citizen of this State, and have resided within the chartered limits of the corporation of said city six months next preceding the elec-
tion.

Sec. 4. That no person shall be eligible to the office of alderman of the said city who at the time of his election does not possess the qualifications of an elector, and has not resided in the said city twelve months next preceding.
Sec. 5. That no person shall be eligible to the office of mayor of said city, unless he posses the qualifications of an alderman.
Sec. 6. That the city authorities are authorized to divide the city into a convenient number of wards, not exceeding eight, and to fix and define the boundaries thereof.

Sec. 7. That the officers heretofore appointed by the Governor as mayor and aldermen for the said city of Dallas, and who are now acting as such, shall continue to hold their offices, respectively, until the next general election in this State, at which election the quali-
fied voters of said corporation shall elect a mayor, marshal, and as-
sessor and collector, who shall hold their offices for the term of one year, and until their successors shall be elected and qualified.

Sec. 8. That at the said election mentioned in the preceding section, there shall also be elected as therein provided two aldermen from each ward, one of whom shall hold the office for the term of one year, and the other for the term of two years; and immediately
Laws of the State of Texas.after their being qualified the aldermen so elected from each ward shall determine, by lot, who shall hold for the long term; and at every annual election thereafter one alderman shall be elected from each ward, who shall hold the office for the term of two years.
Sec. 9. That the mayor and aldermen shall constitute the city council, over which the mayor shall preside, when present, and in case of a tie in the vote of the board he shall give the Casting vote.

Sec. 10. That the city council shall have power to regulate the manner and time of holding and conducting elections, not incon-
sistent with the laws and Constitution of the State, and shall be the indge of the elections of the officers of said corporation.

Sec. 11. That the officers of said corporation, before they enter upon the discharge of their duties, shall take and subscribe the oath of office required by the Constitution of the State, which may be taken before any officer legally authorized to adminsiter oaths.

Sec. 12. That the council shall determine the time of their stated meetings, and they may meet at any other time that the mayor shall, in his discretion, call them together, or any three members of the board of aldermen shall deem necessary. A majority of the whole number of aldermen elected and qualified, and such a number with or without the mayor, shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. Each member of Said board shall receive, for each regu-
lar meeting he shall attend, the sum of two dollars, and fifty cents for each called meeting, and any member of said council who shall fail to attend a regular meeting, shall for each and every such failure be fined two dollars, unless prevented from attending by sickness of himself or in his family, or absence out of the county.

Sec. 13. That in future the sittings or assemblings of the city council of Dallas shall be public, except when at the request of two thirds of the members present in said council, the said council shall deem it necessary to deliberate with closed doors.

Sec. 14. That in future neither the mayor, marshal, nor any of the aldermen then in office shall be allowed, either in his or her own name or through the medium of other persons, to become the lessee or bidder for any branch of the revenue of the city, nor for any work or undertaking whatsoever which may be authorized or or-
dered by the corporation of said city.

Sec. 15. That in case of the inability of the mayor of the city of Dallas to perform his duties, by reason of absence, refusal, or other causes, or in the event of a vacancy in said office occasioned by death, resignation or otherwise, the board of aldermen of said city may be and they are hereby authorized and empowered to ap-
point from their own body a presiding officer, who shall be mayor
Laws of the State of Texas.pro tempore, and shall have and may exercise all the powers con-
ferred by law on the mayor, and shall perform all the duties of mayor until his return, or the removal of such inability, or until a successor is elected and qualified; provided, that in case of a, vacancy in said office, the city council may order an election upon ten days notice, to fill such vacancy for the unexpired term.

Sec. 16. That whenever any order, resolution, by-law or ordi-
nance may be passed by the council, and is disagreed to by the mayor, it shall be inoperative, unless the same shall be passed by a vote of a majority of the whole number of aldermen, taken by yeas and nays, and recorded upon the journal of their proceedings.

Sec. 17. That in case of vacancy in the office of alderman, asses-
sor and collector, marshal, or other subordinate office, the mayor may order an election to fill the same, first giving ten days’ notice thereof, and the person so elected shall hold his office for the un-
expired term.

Sec. 18. That the city council shall elect a secretary and treas-
urer and city attorney, and such other subordinate officers as may be necessary for preserving the peace and well ordering of the affairs of the said corporation, and shall prescribe their duties, fees and term of office.

Sec. 19. That the city council shall have power to remove any officer of the said corporation for any neglect, misdemeanor or mal-
feasance in office, by a vote of three-fourths of the whole number of aldermen elected and qualified.

Sec. 20. That the city council shall require such officers as they may see proper, to execute bonds payable to the corporation, for the faithful discharge of the duties and trusts incumbent upon them, in such amounts as it may deem necessary, with security to be ap-
proved by the council.

Sec. 21. That the mayor of the said city shall be chief executive magistrate thereof, and as such shall be vigilant and active in caus-
ing the laws, ordinances and regulations of the city, not inconsistent with the laws of the land, to be executed and enforced. He shall take instant measures for the quelling of all riots and disorders, and the dispersion of all unlawful assemblages of persons in said city. He shall also be the chief judicial magistrate thereof, and as such shall constitute a court vested with all the powers and jurisdiction, civil and criminal, within the said corporate limits, that are con-
ferred upon justices of the peace; shall have power to punish all con-
tempts, and shall have cognizance of all misdemeanors, breaches of the peace, infractions of the ordinances, and all other oases arising under the laws of said city, and shall be deemed always open for the trial of said causes; and in prosecutions, trials and proceedings had
Laws of the State of Texas.before him under this act, he shall be governed by the laws regu-
lating the proceedings in justices’ courts in force at the time, and shall be entitled to the same fees that justices of the peace are allowed for similar services; and to such additional compensation as may be allowed by the by-laws and ordinances of the corporation.

Sec. 22. That all process from the mayor may be directed to and executed by the sheriff or any constable of the county, or the city marshal, in the same manner that similar process from justices of the peace is executed.

Sec. 23. That it shall be the duty of the city council to cause the secretary and treasurer thereof to make out under oath, and return to the council, semi-annually or oftener, if deemed by the council to be for the best interest of the city, an accurate, detailed and just statement of the receipts and expenditures, and condition of the treasury of said body politic, which shall be published in some news-
paper published in the city of Dallas.

Sec. 24. That should the secretary or treasurer of said corpora-
tion refuse to account as directed by this act, he shall pay a fine of five hundred dollars; said fine to be recovered on motion before the district court by the district attorney or his assistant, ten days’ notice of which shall be given to the said treasurer or secretary, as the case may be; and it is hereby made the duty of the district attor-
ney to enquire and see that the provisions of this act are faithfully fulfilled, and proceed as the case may require.

Sec. 25. That in order the more effectually to enforce the ordi-
nances of the said city, the said council shall, upon the violation thereof, impose such fines and penalties, not exceeding one hundred dollars, to be appropriated to the use and benefit of said city, and such imprisonment, not exceeding fifteen days, to be collected and inflicted through the city court hereinbefore provided, as they may deem necessary and proper, and all prosecutions therefor shall be in the name of the “City of Dallas,” and upon conviction the defendant shall stand committed until the fine and costs of said prosecution be paid or replevied.

Sec. 26. That the city council of Dallas shall have power to ap-
propriate so much of the revenues of the city, emanating from whatever source, to the improvement of the public market and streets within the limits of the corporation, as they in their wisdom may, from time to time, deem expedient.

Sec. 27. That the city council of the said city of Dallas shall have full power and authority to make and pass such by-laws or ordinances as they shall deem necessary for their own government, and to preserve the peace, cleanliness, comfort and salubrity of said city; to secure the safety and convenience of passing in the streets,
Laws of the State of Texas.alleys, squares and other public ways; to determine the width of and to open streets, and to prevent any encroachment or other undertaking on the said streets or ways; to direct the construction, maintenance and repairs of sidewalks in the said streets, at the cost of the proprietors of neighboring houses and lots, and to determine the dimensions thereof; to establish rules and regulations in rela-
tion to partition walls and fences; to organize a tire department and to regulate the same, and to pass such other laws as may be deemed necessary for the prevention and extinguishment of tires, to estab-
lish a city police and to regulate the same; to provide for the light-
ing of streets; to establish one or more market places, and to provide for the inspection of all comestibles offered for sale therein or else-
where, and otherwise to regulate the same; to prevent forestalling and regrating and to punish the same; to establish and enforce by suitable penalties, the proper weights and measures; to regulate every thing which relates to bakers, butchers, tavern-keepers and other persons keeping public houses, beer saloons, or grog shops, draymen, hack drivers, horse drivers, water carriers, and persons employed as day laborers; to prevent the establishment within the said city of houses of ill fame, or any other place of resort fox gambling or other vicious purposes; to permit or forbid theatres, balls and other public amusements, to cause the playhouses and other places for shows or exhibitions to be closed whenever the preservation of order, tran-
qillity, or public safety shall require it; also to close dram-shops and drinking saloons, whenever necessary or expedient; to define and suppress nuisances; to establish hospitals for the accommodation of destitute sick persons, poor houses for the infirm and indigent, and work houses for the confinement of common beggars, vagrants, and other idle and vicious persons; and to pass such laws, and appoint such officers as they may deem necessary for the due management thereof; to provide places for the storing of powder, and the burying of the dead; and generally to do all such other acts, and to pass such ordinances, not inconsistent with the Constitution and laws of this State or of the United States, as may conduce to the welfare of said city; provided, that no ordinance, law, or by-law, passed in pursuance of this act shall go into effect until ten days after the same shall have been published in one of the newspapers of the city, unless in the opinion of two-thirds of said board the emergency may be such as to require a departure from this rule; provided also, that said council shall not have the power of fixing the price of any article sold in the market or other places.

Sec. 28. That the city council, by a vote of a majority of the whole number of aldermen taken by yeas and nays and entered upon their journal, shall have power to assess, tax and license hawkers,
Laws of the State of Texas.peddlers, shows and amusements, billiard tables, nine and ten pin alleys, public drays and wagons, omnibuses and carriages, grog shops, tippling houses and dram shops, beer saloons, whether for the sale of domestic beers and liquors, and occupations not specially mentioned herein, as may be taxed by the laws of the State, and to suppress all gaming houses and all disorderly houses by whatever name or description known.

Sec. 29. That the city council, by a vote of a majority of the whole number of the aldermen, taken by yeas and nays, and entered upon their journal, may levy, assess and collect an annual direct tax upon all property, real and personal, situate and being within the limits of the corporation, not exceeding four-tenths of one per centum ad valorem; and upon all merchants, traders and fabricators, who purchase and introduce stocks of goods for sale, or material to be converted into articles of trade or sale not exceeding three-tenths of one per cent. upon the actual cost of such goods or articles at the time of their receipt; and it shall be the duty of the assessor and col-
lector of taxes to call upon all such merchants, traders and me-
chanics, at least, once in three months, for a list of said stocks; also a poll tax of one dollar upon each and every male person within the limits of the corporation over the age of twenty-one years.

Sec. 30. That every person or persons on whom or whose voca-
tion a license tax may have been assessed, shall, before engaging in such vocation, pay to the city assessor and collector the amount of such tax, taking his receipt therefor, which receipt shall entitle him, her or them to a corresponding license, to be issued by the mayor. If any person or persons shall engage in any vocation within the limits of the city, on whom or on whose vocation a license tax had been assessed by the city council, without having first obtained a license therefor from the mayor, such person or persons shall be liable to pay one-fourth of the amount of such annual license tax for each week he, she or they, may be so engaged, and in the same proportion for each day, which may be recovered by action before the mayor or any justice of the peace, or the district court, accord-
ing to the amount, for the benefit of the city.

Sec. 31. That the assessor and collector of the city shall make up the assessments of all property taxed by the city, and collect the taxes of every kind as they shall become due and owing, and gener-
ally perform all such duties in relation to city taxes as are required of the State assessor and collector in regard to the State and county taxes, under such forms and regulations, and shall receive such com-
pensation as the council may prescribe, and shall pay over to the treasurer every month the moneys which he shall have received and make a report” thereof to the board of aldermen at their first regular
Laws of the State of Texas.meeting in every quarter. All assessments of property shall be made under oath by the party returning the same. If the appraise-
ment be unsatisfactory to the assessor, it shall be referred to a board of three commissioners, being owners of real estate in the city to the value of two thousand dollars, and entirely disconnected with the administration of the city, who shall be appointed by the council, and whose decision shall be final; the same commissioners shall assess the value of all property whose owners are unknown, or which may not have been returned, and shall receive for their services such remuneration, not being a per centage, as the council shall think proper.

Sec. 32. That the marshal shall be the chief constable of the said city, and shall, either in person or by one of his deputies, at-
tend upon the court of the mayor while the said court may be in session, and shall faithfully execute all process issued from the said court, and directed to him. He shall be active in quelling riots, dis-
orders and disturbances of the peace, within the limits of said city, and shall take into custody all persons so offending against the peace of the community, and him, her or them, have, before the court of the mayor, if in session; if the said court be not then in ses-
sion, the said marshal shall commit the person or persons so offend-
ing to the city jail, there to be securely kept in custody until the said court shall be in session, when he, she or they, shall forthwith be taken before the said court, there to be fined and punished ac-
cording to the laws of the city and the sound discretion of the court; provided, that said marshal may, at his discretion, take suit-
able and sufficient bail for the appearance before the said court of the mayor, of any person charged with an offense against the ordi-
nances or laws of the city, being himself responsible for the appear-
ance of said accused. The said marshal, for the more efficient dis-
charge of his duties, may appoint one or more deputies, who shall have the same powers and perform the same duties as the marshal has or should perform, the said marshal being responsible for the faithful performance of their duties by his said deputies; and for his services the marshal shall receive the same fees as the sheriff of the county does by law receive for like services, and such other com-
pensation, if necessary, as the council may deem sufficient.

Sec. 33. That after the expiration of the time prescribed by law for the payment of city taxes, the assessor and collector for the city, or such officer as the city council may charge therewith, may pro-
ceed to seize upon any property, real or personal, the tax of which has not been paid, or that belongs to a delinquent tax payer, and after advertising the same in some newspaper published in the city of Dallas, or by posting at three public places in said city if
Laws of the State of Texas.there be no newspaper published as aforesaid, for twenty days, specifying the time and place of sale, may sell at the court house door of Dallas county, to the highest bidder for cash, so much of said property as will pay the taxes thereon or may be due from such delinquent, as the case may be, together with the costs of advertis-
ing and selling, unless the taxes and costs be paid before the day of sale; provided, that all sales of real estate shall be made at the court house door, and in the second Tuesday of the month, as other lands are sold under execution; and should the property so sold bring a greater amount than shall be necessary to pay the said taxes and costs, the overplus shall be deposited in the treasury, subject to the order of such delinquent. If such sales should not be com-
pleted on the day appointed, the assessor and collector may adjourn the sales from day to day until they are all completed.

Sec. 34. That at the conclusion of the sales, and on compliance with the terms thereof by a purchaser, the assessor and collector shall give to such purchaser a certificate of purchase, stating the amount of tax and costs paid, and describing the property sold, which shall entitle the purchaser to a deed for said property, at the expiration of twelve months, from the mayor of the city; but such certificate may be redeemed within one year from the day of sale by the owner of the property sold, or some person for him, by payment of double the amount of tax and costs paid by the holder, which payment may be made either to the city treasurer, for the use of the holder of such certificate, or to the holder of such certificate.

Sec. 35. That if any certificate of purchase given as before pro-
vided be not redeemed within one year from the day of sale, then the holder may demand, and it shall be the dirty of the mayor of the city to give a deed to such holder, conveying all the right and inter-
est of the person in whose name the property is sold, and of the owner in case of unknown or non-resident owners, in and to the property specified in the certificate, and on the production and de-
livery of the certificate to him, such deed shall be signed by the mayor in his official capacity, and countersigned by the secretary of the council under the city seal.

Sec. 36. That the city of Dallas shall not be held responsible on any implied warranty or for any damages under any deed or sale made for taxes, but the person injured by any neglect or mal-
feasance of any officer shall have recourse against him for any dam-
age sustained in consequence thereof.

Sec. 37. That any tax made as required by this act shall be prima facie evidence that all the prerequisites of the law have been com-
plied with, and shall pass all the right of the person owning the property conveyed, unless it can be proven that the tax thereon had
Laws of the State of Texas.been paid before the sale or the certificate of sale redeemed within the year aforesaid.

Sec. 38. That the assessor and collector shall, after his sales, make returns to the council of all property sold, and the names of the purchasers of each parcel of property to whom certificates of purchase may be issued, which returns shall be preserved among the archives of the city.

Sec. 39. That the said mayor and marshal and his deputies are hereby fully authorized and empowered to call to their aid the as-
sistance of any person resident in the said city whenever in the dis-
charge of their several duties, in cases of riot, disorder, breach of the peace or resistance to their lawful authority, they may need the same; and any person or persons who shall, when so called upon, neglect or refuse to render his assistance shall, on conviction thereof in the court of the mayor, be liable to such fine, not exceeding one hundred dollars, and such imprisonment, not exceeding ten days, as the said court shall, in its sound discretion, impose.

Sec. 40. That all laws and parts of laws conflicting with the provisions of the foregoing charter be and the same are hereby re-
pealed; and that this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER XCIX.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the “Hebrew Benevolent Society of Bryan, Texas.”

div3.p: Whereas, Divers Israelites of the city of Bryan are desirous of being enabled in a corporate body and capacity to afford relief to the indigent sick and destitute; therefore,

Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That Isaac Cahn, D. Wolf, L. Sanger, Prank Moore, M. Levine and M. Mayman, and such other persons as they may asso-
ciate with them, and their successors, be and are hereby created a body corporate, under the name and style of the “Hebrew Benevo-
lent Society of Bryan, Texas,” and by that name and style shall have succession, subject to the limits fixed by this act, and be capa-
ble in law of suing and being sued, of defending and being de-
fended, of pleading and being impleaded; to have a common seal,
Laws of the State of Texas.and the same not to be changed; to have, acquire and hold real and personal estate, and to buy and sell exchange, to buy and sell mortgages; to transfer, pledge or otherwise encumber or alienate as said association may deem expedient, and said association shall be capable in law of receiving by donation, bequest, desire, or in any manner of form, from any person or persons, or body corporate in or out of this State; provided, that the value of real estate or per-
sonal property held by said association at any one time shall not exceed in value fifty thousand dollars.

Sec. 2. That said association shall make a constitution and by-
laws for its government, and shall have the power to alter and amend the same at pleasure.

Sec. 3. That no individual who may be a member of said asso-
ciation shall receive any compensation or donation from said associ-
ation for his personal services rendered to the same; and the busi-
ness of said association shall be confined to the object stated in the preamble of this act.

Sec. 4. That this act shall expire ten years from and after its passage, and in case of the expiration thereof all the funds and property of said association shall vest in and belong to the corpora-
tion of the city of Bryan, and shall be applied to and constitute a part of the hospital fund of said city.
Sec. 5. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER C.

opener.salute:
An Act to amend an act entitled “An Act to incorporate the Gal-
veston City Company,” approved February 5, 1841.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the second section of the above recited act be so amended as to read as follows to-wit: That the management of the affairs of said company shall be conducted by a board of five direc-
