tors, each of whom shall own at least two shares of the capital stock of said company, and three of said directors shall constitute a quo-
rum to do and perform all the business necessary to the successful operation of said company. A majority of said directors shall appoint a president from their own number, and fill such vacancies as may
Laws of the State of Texas.from time to time take place from death, resignation or otherwise; the election of directors shall take place in the city of Galveston, on the fourth Monday of January of each and every year; and in case of failure to so elect said directors, the corporation shall not be dis-
solved for that cause, but the president and directors for the time being shall continue in office until there shall be an election; pro-
vided also, that it shall be the duty of said directors to call a meet-
ing of the stockholders at an early day to elect the directory so omitted to be done at the regular period.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That this act take effect from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CI.
div3.p: An Act to incorporate the “Little Brazos River Bridge Company."

Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That B. L. Givens, G. W. Miller, and such others as they may asso-
ciate with them, be and they are hereby incorporated under the name and title of the “Little Brazos River Bridge Company,” and under such name may sue and be sued, and have succession for thirty years.

Sec. 2. Said company shall have the right to construct a bridge of iron or wood across the “Little Brazos river,” in Falls county, on the banks they may deem most suitable, at a point where a good road at all seasons can be had, to and connecting with the public road leading from Waco and Marlin, to Bremond, in Robertson county.

Sec. 3. Said company shall construct said bridge in a good and substantial manner, within one year from the passage of this act, and shall keep the same in good repair for the term of thirty years from the completion thereof, and shall be ready at all times, night and day, to pass all passengers, carriages, wagons, teams and stock that may wish to cross on said bridge, and shall be responsible as common carriers under the, law, for any loss of property in transit over said bridge; and the said bridge shall be subject to inspection at least twice per year by a committee appointed by the County Court of Falls county, and if said committee declare the said bridge unsafe or out of repair, the said bridge company shall put the same
Laws of the State of Texas.in complete repair in ninety days, and a failure to put the same in thorough repair in six months, shall work a forfeiture of this char-
ter.

Sec. 4. That no person or persons shall be authorized or allowed to erect any bridge, or keep any ferry across said “Little Brazos river,” at or within (5) miles on a straight line above or below the said bridge herein authorized, when completed; provided, that in case said bridge shall get out of repair, said company may keep a ferry boat to cross persons and property, until the said bridge is put in order.

Sec. 5. That the said company shall have the right to establish said bridge at any point (as in section second) and have the right of way over any land on either side of the “Little Brazos River,” where the said company conclude to place the said bridge (as in section second) which may interpose or lie between the termination of said roads, (as in section second) and said bridge, if any there be, and may enter upon and take possession of said land, provided the same shall not exceed the width of (50) fifty feet, by paying the owner or owners thereof whatever price may be agreed upon; and should the said owner or owners of said land not be able to agree as to the price, the said company may petition the presiding justice of the police court of said county, giving a description of the land which they require, with the names of the owner or owners thereof; and the presiding justice shall summons a jury of six freeholders, not in any manner interested, who shall on oath, make a report of the value of the land so required, and upon payment thereof by the company to the owner or owners or his or their agents, a good bona fide title shall be granted by said presiding justice of said company, a copy of which shall be recorded in the office of the district clerk of the county aforesaid.

Sec. 6. That when said bridge shall be completed, said com-
pany are authorized to demand and receive from each and every person crossing said bridge, or crossing their property over the same, a toll not to exceed the following rates, to-wit; For every footman (6) five cents; for every man and horse (10) ten cents; for every one horse vehicle (25) twenty-five cents; for every two-horse ve-
hicle (50) fifty cents; for every ox wagon and two yoke of oxen (30) thirty cents; for every ox wagon and four to six yoke of oxen (50) fifty cents; for every two-horse wagon (25) twenty-five cents; for every four to six horse wagon (50) fifty cents; for every loose horse (5) five cents; for sheep, goats, hogs and cattle per head (3) three cents.

Sec. 7. That this charter of incorporation continue and remain in force for thirty years from and after the completion of said bridge,
Laws of the State of Texas.and that this act take effect and be in force from and after its pass-
age.

The foregoing act, received in the office of Secretary of State May first, one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one, having been presented to the Governor of Texas for his approval, and not having been returned by him to the house in which it originated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has become a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div3.head: CHAPTER CII.
div3.p: An Act to organize and incorporate the Sherman and Red River Railroad Company.

Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That C. C. Binkley, J. C. Richards, J. S. Porter, J. C. D. Blackburn, Silas Hare, Joseph Gunter, James M. Wilson, B. A. King, and George C. Dugan, of Texas, be and they are hereby con-
stituted a body politic and corporate, under the name and style of the “Sherman and Red River Railroad Company,” by and under which name they and their assigns and successors shall have suc-
cession for the term of ninety-nine years, and are hereby granted all the rights and privileges conferred upon the East Line and Red River Railroad Company, excepting only the exemption from taxa-
tion. And said Sherman and Red River Railroad Company is hereby authorized to construct, operate, equip and own a railroad and telegraph line from the city of Sherman, in Grayson county, to any point on Red River, to connect with the Missouri, Kansas and Texas Railroad, now being built through the Indian Territory, and said road shall be fully completed within eighteen months after the completion of the Missouri, Kansas and Texas Railroad to the Red River. And the capital stock of said company shall be one million of dollars, with the right to increase it to three millions of dollars by a vote of two-thirds of the stockholders at any regular meeting thereof.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p: Sec. 2. This act to take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

The foregoing act, received in the office of the Secretary of State May fourth, one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one, having been presented to the Governor of Texas for his approval, and not having been returned by him to the house in which it originated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has become a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div3.head: CHAPTER CIII.

opener.salute: An Act to authorize C. E. Goodwin to erect a toll bridge over Chambers creek where the road leading from Waxahachie to Dresden crosses the same.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That C. R. Goodwin be and he is hereby authorized and empowered to erect a toll bridge over Chambers creek, on or near the road leading from Waxahachie, in Ellis county, to the town of Dresden, in Navarro county, which bridge may be built at any point within two and one-half miles above or below the regular crossing or public road on said creek, and that he be authorized and empowered to charge, receive and collect toll for crossing on said bridge at the following rates, viz: For every footman, five cents; for every man and horse, ten cents; for every one-horse ve-
hicle, twenty-five cents; for every two-horse vehicle, fifty cents; for every ox wagon and two yoke of oxen, fifty cents; for every ox wagon and four yoke of oxen and upwards, seventy-five cents; for every two-horse wagon, twenty-five cents; for every four-horse wagon and upwards, seventy-five cents; for loose stock, five cents per head.

Sec. 2. That the right and privilege herein granted shall inure to the benefit of the said C. E. Goodwin, his heirs and assigns, for twenty years: provided, however, that in order to secure the privil-
eges conferred by this act he, the said C. E. Goodwin shall, within twelve months from the passage of this act, erect and construct a good, safe and substantial bridge over the said Chambers creek, at
Laws of the State of Texas.the place aforesaid, and shall keep the same in good repair; and in the event of an accident or casualty destroying said bridge, the said Goodwin shall reconstruct the same within twelve months from the date of such accident or casualty, otherwise the franchise herein granted shall be and become void and of no effect.
Sec. 3. That no bridge nor ferry shall be permitted or allowed to collect toll within a distance of two and one-half miles above or below the toll bridge herein specified and chartered.
Sec. 4. That this act shall take effect and be in force from its passage.

The foregoing act, received in the office of Secretary of State May eleventh, one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one, having been presented to the Governor of Texas for his approval, and not having been returned by him to the house in which it originated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has become a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div3.head: CHAPTER CIV.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Galveston Bank and Trust Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That there may be established in the city of Galveston, for the purposes hereinafter mentioned, a company, which shall be called and known by the name of the “Galveston Bank and Trust Company,” and the stockholders and their successors shall have continuous succession, and by that name shall be capable of suing and being sued in all the courts of the State, and shall be capable of receiving, purchasing, conveying, holding, in fee or in trust, for themselves or others, property of all descriptions, of alienating, con-
veying, mortgaging, or in any other manner disposing of the same as a natural person might dispose of similar property; to make, have and use a common seal, and the same to alter and renew at pleas-
ure, and generally to do any act necessary to carry into effect the objects of the corporation not inconsistent with the laws of this State or of the United States.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p:
Sec. 2. That the capital stock of this company shall not be less than five hundred thousand dollars, to be divided into shares of one hundred dollars each, one-half of which shall be paid at the time of subscription, which capital stock may be increased to one million of dollars at the discretion of the president and directors of this corporation. The said stock shall be held and deemed as personal property, and be represented by certificates under the seal of the company, signed by the president and countersigned by the treas-
urer or cashier. All subscriptions for stock over and above fifty per cent. required to be paid before the organization of the company, shall be binding on the subscribers respectively, their heirs and legal representatives, and be payable in such installments and at such times as the board of directors may prescribe; and upon the failure or refusal of any of the subscribers to pay said installments when so called on, the stock of such delinquent may, by resolution of the board of directors, be sold, in which case all portions previously paid in shall be forfeited to the company.

Sec. 3. That the books of subscription to said capital stock shall be opened in the city of Galveston, under the supervision of Gardiner S. Stafford, of New York, Edmund Ketchum, of Savan-
nah, Georgia; George F. Alford, J. E. McKeen, A. C. McKeen, Martin V. McMahan, D. The Ayres, Francis C. Jeffrey and James H. McCormick, of Galveston, or any two or more of them, and at such place and time as they, or any two or more of them, may di-
rect; advertisement of the time and place of opening such books to be made for one week in some newspaper published in the said city of Galveston, and shall be kept open until the sum of five hundred thousand dollars shall be subscribed; and the said commissioners, or any two or more of them, shall, as soon as may be after the books of subscription are closed, call a meeting of the subscribers, and shall proceed to the election of five directors to be chosen by ballot from the stockholders, and no person shall be a director of said com-
pany who shall not be a stockholder, to the extent of ten shares or upwards; and all stockholders, at all elections of the company, and in all matters pertaining to the interests of the company acted on in convention, shall be entitled to one vote for each share of stock owned, and may vote in person or by proxy in writing. Es-
tates may be represented by the executor or administrators, and minors by their guardians, in all meetings of the stockholders. All votes shall be by ballot, and in all elections a majority of the votes present and voting shall elect. The commissioners above named, or any two or more of them, shall conduct the first election for direc-
tors, shall receive and count the votes, and certify accordingly; and the certificate of two or more of said commissioners who may act
Laws of the State of Texas.shall be sufficient evidence of the election of persons declared by them to be elected. After the election of said directors, the said commissioners shall deliver to the board of directors so chosen all moneys and credits in their hands, the subscription books of the stock, and an account of all their acts and doings as such commis-
sioners, whereupon their functions shall cease.

Sec. 4. That the first and all subsequent boards of directors shall be elected to serve one year and until their successors are elected and qualified, and shall have power to choose a president, from their own number, to appoint a vice president, cashier, and other officers, define their duties, require bonds of them and fix the penalty thereof, dismiss said officers or any of them at pleasure, and appoint others to fill their places, and exercise all such powers as shall be necessary to carry on a banking and trust business by dis-
counting and negotiating promissory notes, drafts, bills of exchange and other evidences of debt; by receiving money or property on de-
posit or in trust; by buying and selling exchange, coin or bullion; by loaning money on personal or other security; by obtaining and circulating its own national bank notes. And its board of directors shall also have power to define and regulate by by-laws the man-
ner in which its stock shall be transferred, its directors elected or appointed, its officers appointed, its property transferred, its gen-
eral business conducted, and all the privileges granted by this act shall be organized and enjoyed; provided always, that the stock-
holders in convention shall have power to regulate and limit the dis-
cretionary powers conferred on the board of directors, and repeal, alter or amend by-laws or regulations which may be established by the board of directors.

Sec. 5. There shall be an annual meeting of the stockholders held on the first Monday in June of each and every year, the time and place to be designated by the board of directors by advertisement for at least ten days in one or more of the daily papers published in the city of Galveston, at which time an election for directors shall take place to serve during the ensuing year, and until their succes-
sors are qualified; provided, that the directors first elected shall hold their offices until the first Monday in June, 1872.

Sec. 6. The board of directors, or any number of stockholders, together representing not less than one fourth of the capital stock of the company, may at any time call a special meeting of the stock-
holders, by advertisement for ten days previous in one or more of the city papers of Galveston, and when the stockholders shall so assemble they shall have all power, and may adopt any rules or regulations they might adopt in a regular meeting; pro-
vided, a majority of the stock shall be represented to constitute a
Laws of the State of Texas.quorum for any business, except to elect directors, or to adjourn from day to day until a quorum may assemble; and power is hereby expressly given, at the second or any subsequent annual meeting of stockholders, to increase the number of any future board of direc-
tors to serve, if the stockholders shall deem it expedient.

Sec. 7. That the said “Galveston Bank and Trust Company” shall have power and authority to receive deposits and issue certifi-
cates for the same, paying such rates and interest as may be agreed upon, and under such rules and regulations as said corporation may establish; and the said corporation shall and are hereby authorized to act as trustees by appointment of any court of the State, or by the selection of any executor or executors, or individual or individ-
uals, for themselves or for the benefit of any minor or minors for whom they may be acting, and funds in litigation in the various courts of the State may be deposited in said “Galveston Bank and Trust Company” pending said litigation, bearing the same interest as other deposits.

Sec. 8. That all special trusts for permanent investment shall only be invested by them in bonds of the United States or bonds, of the State of Texas, or bonds endorsed or guaranteed by the State of Texas, or in bonds or stocks of State, citizens or companies, whose bonds or stocks at the time of such investment shall, in the market, be at par or over.

Sec. 9. The said “Galveston Bank and Trust Company" shall make, annually, to the Governor of the State, through their presi-
dent, a correct and sworn statement of their affairs.

Sec. 10. That said corporation shall have power to receive money on deposit, paying therefor such interest as may be agreed upon; to loan and borrow money; to take and give therefor such securities as may be considered best; to invest its funds upon such terms as it may deem best, and transfer its property at pleasure, and to do all other acts it may deem advisable for the safe keeping and secure and profitable investment of its funds, and may charge and receive, in addition to interest, such a commission or advance of money for negotiating loans, as may be agreed upon between said company and the party or parties buying or selling bonds, bills of exchange, promissory notes, or borrowing money from said company.

Sec. 11. That the said company shall be responsible to its credi-
tors to the extent of its property, and the stockholders shall be liable to the extent of the full amount of their respective inpaid stock sub-
scribed for by them, for the debts of the company, in proportion to the number of shares held by them.

Sec. 12. That this act and all the privileges and powers herein guaranteed shall continue in force for the term of fifty years from
Laws of the State of Texas.and after the organization of the company which may be organized under said act, and the property, funds and business transactions of said company, during it existence, shall be subject to the same rate of taxation as is or may be imposed by law on money or property of the same kind, and similar business transactions of individuals, like corporations or citizens of this State.

Sec. 13. That if the sum of five hundred thousand dollars be not subscribed and actually paid in within three years after the passage of this act, then all the privileges hereby and herein granted shall be forfeited.
Sec. 14. That this act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CV.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the officers and members of the Grapevine Lodge No. 288, Free and Accepted Masons.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the officers and members of Grapevine Lodge No. 288, Free and Accepted Masons, their successors and future asso-
ciates, be and they are hereby created a body politic and corporate, by the name and style of Grapevine Lodge No. 288, Free and Ac-
ceptd Masons, and by that name shall be capable of acquiring, holding, selling and conveying property, real, personal or mixed; provided, the same shall not exceed in value at any one time the sum of twenty-five thousand dollars; and they may establish and manage institutions of learning in the usual manner of conducting colleges or seminaries, and under such regulations as they may make, not inconsistent with the Constitution and laws of the State of Texas.

Sec. 2. That said corporation may, by the name and style afore-
said, sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, answer and be answered, defend and be defended in all suits, actions, demands, pleas or complaints of any character in any court of law or equity within the State.

Sec. 3. That the said corporation may have a common seal, may make, repeal or change a constitution and by-laws for their government not inconsistent with the laws of the State, and shall in general have and exercise all rights, privileges and immunities by
Laws of the State of Texas.law incident to and commonly enjoyed by corporations of like kind, for and during the term of twenty-five years.

Sec. 4. That in any suit or other proceeding against the said corporation, service of process or of notice, or of any other papers may be made by delivering to any officer of the corporation a copy thereof duly certified, and the officer or other serving the same shall state in his return the officer of the corporation upon whom it was served, naming him.

Sec. 5. That any deed of conveyance duly signed and executed by the officers of said corporation in pursuance of a resolution au-
thorizing the same, shall be deemed valid in law, and shall in law have the same force and effect as any other deed of conveyance.
Sec. 6. That this act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CVI.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the town of Socorro, in El Paso county.

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the citizens of the town of Socorro, in the county of El Paso, be and are hereby declared a body corporate, by the name and style of “The Town of Socorro,” and by that name may sue and be sued, and may have and use a corporate seal, may hold real and personal estate, and may dispose of real estate in the manner hereinafter provided, and in no other manner.

Sec. 2. That the corporate limits of said town shall include all within the following boundaries: Beginning at a stake and mound on the bank of the Rio Grande set for the lower corner of survey No. 42 (no trees near); thence north twenty-one and three-fourths degrees east, two thousand six hundred and seventy varas, along the southeast boundary of survey No. 42, to a stake in a mound; thence north forty-eight and one-half degrees east, fourteen hundred and fifty varas, to a stake in mound on the bank of an acequia; thence north thirty-seven degrees east, three thousand and twenty varas, to a stake in mound on a sandhill called “La Loma de la, Cruz de Juan Antonio Suterhills”; thence north seventy and three-fourths degrees east, nine hundred and forty varas, to a stake in mound set for the
Laws of the State of Texas.northeast corner of survey No. 42; thence south thirty degrees east, ten thousand eight hundred and ten varas, along the sandhills to a stake in mound one hundred and forty varas from edge of valley; thence south seventy-three and one-half degrees west, seven thou-
sand seven hundred and forty varas, along the north boundary of the San Eleceario grant, to a stake and mound on the bank of the Rio Grande (no trees near), it being the upper corner of the San Eleceario grant and lower corner of this survey; thence up the river with its meanderings to the place of beginning.

Sec. 3. That no person shall be a qualified voter in said corpo-
ration, unless he be a registered voter in the State, and shall have resided in said corporation six months.

Sec. 4. That no person shall be eligible to office in said corpora-
tion unless he be a qualified voter therein.

Sec. 5. That the corporate affairs of said town shall be admin-
istered by a mayor and nine aldermen, who shall be styled the “Town Council of the town of Socorro.”

Sec. 6. The justice of the peace of the precinct in which said town is situated shall be ex officio mayor of the town; he shall pre-
side over the town council, and shall have no vote except in case of tie, when he shall give the casting vote.
Sec. 7. Two-thirds of the aldermen elected shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business, but a less number may at a regular meeting enforce the attendance of absent members.

Sec. 8. That at the first and each subsequent general election for State or county officers there shall be nine aldermen elected by the qualified voters of said town. Said aldermen shall hold their office for two years, and until their successors shall be elected and qualified. Said election shall be conducted in conformity with the laws regulating elections in this State.

Sec. 9. That should the election of any one of the aldermen be contested, said contest shall be tried by the town council, and shall be determined by a majority vote of those present when the contest is tried.
Sec. 10. That there shall be a constable, secretary, treasurer, assessor and collector and alcalde of acequias for said town.
Sec. 11. The constable of the precinct in which the town is situated shall be ex officio constable of the town.

Sec. 12. That all officers of said corporation, before entering upon the duties of their office, shall take and subscribe the oath prescribed by the Constitution; and the mayor, constable, assessor and collector, and treasurer, shall also enter into bond with two good securities, to be approved by the town council, for the faithful performance of the duties of their office, payable to said corporation
Laws of the State of Texas.in such sum as the town council shall require, which said bond shall not be void on the first recovery, but may be sued on from time to time in the name of any person injured by a breach thereof until the whole of the penalty is recovered.

Sec. 13. That the secretary, treasurer, assessor and collector and alcalde of acequias, shall be elected by the town council and shall hold their office for two years and until their successors are elected and qualified; said officers shall be elected by a majority of aldermen present. Said election shall be at a regular meeting of the town council as soon as possible after the aldermen have re-
ceived their certificates of election; and any of said officers may be removed at any regular meeting of the town council by a vote of two-thirds of the aldermen elected.
Sec. 14. The town council may, from time to time, provide by ordinance for the election or appointment of such other officers as they may deem necessary.

Sec. 15. The town council shall have and exercise control over the public square, streets and roads within said corporation; they shall have power to license, tax and regulate hawkers, peddlers, auctioneers, theatrical and other exhibitions, shows and amuse-
ments, billiard tables, nine or ten pin alleyes, tippling houses, dram shops, groceries, and to determine the amount of tax on the same, and to suppress gaming or gambling houses, by whatever name or description known, and all disorderly houses; to establish and regu-
late public pounds, and to regulate the running at large of horses, mules, cattle and sheep; to regulate, restrain and prohibit the run-
ning at large of swine or other animals, and to authorize the distrain-
ing, impounding and sale of the same for the costs of the proceed-
ing and the penalty incurred, and to impose penalties on the owners thereof for a violation of any ordinance in relation thereto; to tax, regulate and restrain and prohibit the running at large of dogs, and to authorize their destruction when at large, contrary to ordinance, and to impose penalties on the owners or keepers thereof; to provide by ordinance for the opening, widening and cleaning of acequias, (or irrigating canals,) and to regulate the manner of working thereon; to provide by ordinance for the distribution of water for irrigating purposes, and generally to do such other acts, and to pass such ordi-
nances, not inconsistent with the Constitution and laws of the State or of the United States, as may conduce to the interest and welfare of said town; provided, that any ordinance, law or by-law, passed in pursuance of this act, shall not go into effect unless the same be approved by the mayor, or, being disapproved by him, it be passed by a vote of two-thirds of the whole council; nor until five days after the same shall have been published by posting copies thereof in
Laws of the State of Texas.three public places in said town, unless, in the opinion of three-
fourths of said council, the emergency may be such as to require a departure from this rule.

Sec. 16. To defray the expenses of said town the said council are hereby fully authorized and empowered to impose a direct property and license tax upon all such persons, property and em-
ployments as are liable to taxation under the Constitution and laws of the State, and to make and execute all laws necessary to enforce the collection of the same; provided, nevertheless, that no property tax (unless for special purposes, and specially provided for by act of the Legislature,) shall for any one year exceed the one-half of one per cent. of the value of the property, nor any license tax the sum of one hundred dollars, nor shall any tax be levied without the con-
currence of three-fourths of the whole council in its favor. And in order the more effectually to enforce the ordinances of the said town the said town council shall impose upon the violation thereof such fines and penalties, not exceeding one hundred dollars, and such imprisonment, not exceeding fifteen days, to be collected and inflicted through the mayor’s court, as they may deem necessary and proper.

Sec. 17. The stated meetings of the town council shall be on the second and fourth Saturdays of each month, and the mayor may, whenever he considers it necessary, call special meetings by notice to each of the members of said council, served personally or left at their usual place of abode; and the mayor shall, on the application of any three members of the council, call a special meeting.

Sec. 18. The council shall determine the rules of its own pro-
ceedings, and be the judge of the election and qualification of its own members, and shall have power to compel the attendance of absent members, and punish them for disorderly conduct, and with the concurrence of two-thirds of the council may expel a member.

Sec. 19. It shall be the duty of the secretary of said town to keep a correct record of the proceedings of the town council in a book kept for that purpose; to take charge of and keep safely all books, papers and accounts of the council. He shall keep the town seal, and use it in the attestation of all documents signed by him by direction of the mayor or council. He shall receive and receipt for all moneys paid into the mayor’s court on account of fines im-
posed by said court, and shall pay the same to the treasurer, taking his receipt therefor, and shall generally perform such other duties as the town council may lawfully require of him. He shall receive for his services such compensation as the town council may determ-
ine, not to be changed during the term of service of the incum-
bent.

Sec. 20. That the treasurer of said town shall receive, and keep
Laws of the State of Texas.securely, all moneys belonging to the said town, and make all pay-
ments for the same upon the order of the mayor, attested by the sec-
retary and the seal of the town; he shall keep regular and correct accounts of their real, personal and mixed property; and shall ren-
der a correct statement of his receipts and payments to the town council at their first regular meeting in each quarter, and whenso-
ever at other times he be required by them to do so; and at the end of every half year shall cause to be published at the expense of the town a statement, showing the amount of receipts and expenditures for the six months next preceding, and the general condition of the treasury; and shall do and perform such other acts and duties as the town council may lawfully require of him as the treasurer of the town. And for his services the said treasurer shall receive such compensation as the town council may deem sufficient, the said compensation not to be changed during the term of service of any incumbent.

Sec. 21. That the assessor and collector of the town shall make up the assessment of all the property taxed by the town, and collect the taxes of every kind as they shall become due and owing, and generally perform all the duties in relation to town taxes as are re-
quired of the justices of the peace and sheriffs in regard to the State and county taxes, under such forms and regulations as the town council may. prescribe, and shall pay over to the treasurer every month the moneys he shall have received, and make a report there-
of to the town council at their first regular meeting in every quar-
ter. All assessments of property shall be made under oath by the party returning the same; if the appraisement be unsatisfactory to the assessor it shall be referred to a board of three commissioners, being owners of real estate in the town to the value of five hundred dollars, and entirely disconnected with the administration of the town, who shall be appointed by the town council, and whose de-
cision shall be final. The same commissioners shall assess the value of all property whose owners are unknown, or which may not have been returned, and receive for their services such remuneration, not being a per centage, as the town council shall think proper.

Sec. 22. The alcalde of acequias shall supervise all work un-
dertaken by the town council on the acequias; he shall see that the acequias are kept clean and in good condition, and shall supervise the partition of water for irrigating purposes.

Sec. 23. That whenever a vacancy occurs in the town council or any other office in said town by death, resignation, removal or otherwise, or whenever from any cause the regular election shall not be held at the proper time, the town council may and shall as soon as practicable thereafter, order an election to fill such va-
cancy, or to supply the place of such omitted election, and the said
Laws of the State of Texas.election so ordered shall be conducted in all things in the same manner as hereinbefore prescribed for the regular election; and in case of the sickness of any officer, and until the vacancy shall be filled by such election, the town council are hereby fully authorized and empowered to appoint other persons (if it be the office of the mayor, from their own, and if any other officer, from without their body) to fill such office until such sick person shall recover, or such vacancy be filled by election by the people, or by the town council, and the person so appointed shall have the same powers, perform the same duties, be subject to the same penalties and receive the same compensation for the time being, as if he had been duly elected to said office.

Sec. 24. That the town council shall have the power, in the manner hereinafter specified, to grant or sell portions of real estate, the property of the said town of Socorro, to any of the following person or persons, and to no other: First, to actual settlers on said lands who are citizens of the town of Socorro; second, to any per-
son or company for the erection of buildings to be used for mechani-
cal or manufacturing purposes, or for the building of railroad de-
pots or workshops; provided, that the land granted or sold shall not exceed the quantity to be actually covered by the erection of said buildings; third, to any person or persons who may desire to become citizens of Socorro, and who shall become actual settlers on the land sold or granted.

Sec. 2. That whenever any person shall desire to purchase or obtain a grant of land for the purpose specified in the foregoing section, he or they shall make an application to the town council, at a regular meeting thereof; said application shall be in writing, and in duplicate, and shall be in the following form: To the town coun-
cil of the town of Socorro: Your petitioner (or petitioners) respect-
fully prays that the following described tract of land, situated with-
in the corporate limits of Socorro, be sold (or granted) to him by your honorable body. (Here must follow a correct description of the land.) Your petitioner desires to use said land for the following purposes: (Here follow the purposes for which the petitioner de-
sires the lands.)

Said petition shall be read in open meeting of the council when it is received, but no further action shall be had thereon at that time. At least ten days before the next regular meeting of the town coun-
cil, the secretary shall publish the duplicate copy of the petition by posting it in a conspicuous place near the door of the town council hall, and shall post underneath a notice advising all parties interested that said petition will be acted on at the next regular meeting of the
Laws of the State of Texas.council. At the next regular meeting the petition shall be taken up and read, and the presiding officer shall ask if there is any person present who has anything to say in favor of or against the granting of this petition; and any citizen of Socorro may appear in person or by attorney, before the council and speak in favor of or against the granting of the petition. When argument has been finished, the council shall proceed to vote by ayes and noes, which shall be entered upon the journal, and if two-thirds of the council elected shall vote in favor of the petitioner, the petition shall be considered as granted. If the petition is for the purchase of lauds, the council shall then proceed by a two-third vote, to fix the price to be paid by the petitioner.

Sec. 26. When a petition has been granted in the manner speci-
fied in the foregoing section, the secretary shall furnish the mayor with a correct copy of the petition, on which shall be endorsed the action of the council in the premises, and state the consideration, if any; when the said consideration shall have been paid, or the con-
ditions of the sale or grant shall have been complied with to the satisfaction of the mayor, he shall issue to the petitioner a deed to the said real estate, which deed shall be signed by the mayor and attested by the secretary, and shall be in words and form as follows: Whereas,..................... has fully complied with the provisions of section.... of an act entitled “An act to incorporate the town of Socorro;” and whereas, the town council of the town of Socorro, at a regular meeting thereof held on the........ day of.............., did, by a two-thirds vote, authorize me to sell (or grant) to the said petitioner the hereinafter described parcel of land situated within the corporate limits of the town of Socorro, in the county of El Paso, on condition that the petitioner shall have com-
plied with certain considerations herein set forth, to wit: (Here follows the consideration.) And whereas, said consideration has been fully complied with to my satisfaction; now, therefore, know all men by these presents that I,........................., mayor of the town of Socorro, by and in virtue of the authority in me vested by the act hereinbefore recited, have granted, bargained, sold and re-
leased, and by these presents do grant, bargain, sell and release un-
to the said......................... all that—(here describe the land) together with all and singular the rights, members heredita-
ments and appurtenaces to the same belonging, or in any wise inci-
dent or appertaining; to have and to hold, all and singular, the lands and premises above mentioned unto the said................ his heirs and assigns forever.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p: Witness my hand and the corporate seal of the town of Socorro, this the.......... day of.......... in the year of.........
[Town Seal.] Mayor of the Town of Socorro.
Attest:
Secretary.
And the foregoing deed shall be considered in law and equity a good and sufficient conveyance of all the right, title and interest which the said town of Socorro may have in the premises.
Sec. 27. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CVII.

opener.salute: An Act for the relief of Thomas G. Davidson.

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the Comptroller of Public Accounts be and he is hereby authorized to draw his warrant upon the State Treasurer in favor of Thomas G. Davidson, for services rendered during months of July and August, A. D. 1870, from the date of his qualification as District Attorney, Twenty-ninth Judicial District, State of Texas.
Sec. 2. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CVIII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Jamestown high school.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That M. D. Leverett, W. J. Dupree, John P. Gipson, J. A. Beall, R. A. Pelton and C. B. Bacon, and their successors in
Laws of the State of Texas.office, are hereby created a body corporate and politic, under the name and style of “The Trustees of the Jamestown High School,” by which name they may sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, buy and sell property, real, personal and mixed, have a common seal, and do and perform all such acts and things as may be neces-
sary for the purpose of maintaining a seminary of learning at Jamestown, Smith county, Texas.
Sec. 5. This act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CIX.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Dallas Gas Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That T. G. T. Kendall, H. Mordecai, J. S. Chord and John T. Barton, their associates and successors, be and are hereby con-
stituted and declared to be a body politic and corporate, under the name and style of the Dallas Gas Company, with capacity to make contracts, to have succession and a common seal, to make by-laws for its government, and in its corporate name to sue and be sued, to grant and receive, and generally to do and perform such acts and things as may be necessary and proper for or incidental to the ful-
fillment of its objects or maintenance of its rights under this act, and consistent with the provisions of the State Constitution.

Sec. 2. That the said company be and is hereby established, with the right of erecting, owning and maintaining works for the generation of gas, and laying down in the streets, lanes and alleys, and other public grounds within the town of Dallas and the sub-
urbs thereof, pipes for the conveyance of gas in and through said town and its suburbs.

Sec. 3. That the capital stock of said company shall be divided into shares of one hundred dollars each, and the holders of such shares shall constitute said company, and each member shall be en-
titled to one vote, in person or by proxy, for each and every share he, she or they may own, and such share of stock shall be transfer-
able alone upon the books of the company.

Sec. 4. That the affairs and business of said company shall be conducted and managed by a board of directors, not less than three
Laws of the State of Texas.nor more than seven, who shall be elected by the company at such time as the stockholders may appoint, and annually thereafter; pro-
vided, that in case of failure to elect at the stated time, the board of directors incumbent shall continue in office until there be an election; the time for which may be fixed by said board, whereof rea-
sonable notice shall be given.

Sec. 5. That no person shall be eligible as a director unless he be the owner of five shares of the capital stock. The said board shall elect a president from their number, fill vacancies, and appoint such other officers and agents as they may deem necessary, and re-
quire securities for the faithful performance of their duties; also prescribe the time for the payment of installments or assessments upon the capital stock, and the amount of such installments or as-
sessments; to declare the forfeiture of such stock for non-payment, and to do or cause to be done all other lawful acts or things which they may deem necessary or proper in conducting the business of said company. A majority of said board of directors shall constitute a quorum for doing business. All instruments in writing executed by the president and secretary, under the seal of the company, with the consent of the board of directors, shall be valid and binding.

Sec. 6. That the board shall have power to elect an agent or agents, who shall be members of said company, and whose names shall be made known to the public, and by whom the business of the corporation may be conducted, under the powers given him by the board.
Sec. 7. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CX.

opener.salute: An Act to prohibit the sale of intoxicating or spirituous liquors in the immediate vicinity of the town of Circleville, Williamson County, Texas.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That it shall not be lawful for any person, with or without license, to sell, give away or in any manner dispose of, any intoxicat-
ing or spirituous liquors, except for medicinal or sacramental pur-
poses, within the distance of two miles of Circleville Seminary, an
Laws of the State of Texas.institute of learning located in the town of Circleville, Williamson county, Texas.

Sec. 2. That any person violating this act shall, upon convic-
tion thereof before any justice of the peace in said county, be fined not less than ten dollars nor more than one hundred dollars, for each and every offense.
Sec. 3. That the one half of any fine thus collected shall be paid to the informer, and the other half to be paid into the treasury of the county, for the benefit of the school fund of said county.

Sec. 4. That this act shall remain in full force and effect while said Cireleville Seminary shall maintain a school organization dur-
ing the accustomed months of any one scholastic year.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXI.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate a Gymnastic Association at New Braunfels, under the name and style of “Turn Verein New Braunfels.”

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That Edgar Gohramm, Rudolph Wippreeht, F. Hampe, August Groos and Charles Wetzel be and they are hereby, with their associates, constituted a body politic and corporate for gym-
nastic purposes, for the encouragement of bodily exercise and mental improvement, under the name and style of the “Turn Verein New Braunfels,” at the city of New Braunfels, in the county of Comal, and by that name shall have succession, and be capable of suing and being sued, of defending and being defended in any of the courts of this State; of acquiring and holding estate, both real, personal and mixed; and of selling, alienating, or otherwise dispos-
ing of the same, as said association may deem expedient; provided, the amount of property held by said corporation shall, at no time, exceed fifty thousand dollars; and provided further, that nothing herein contained shall be so construed as to authorize said company to engage in any business or occupation for profit.

Sec. 2. That said corporation shall not be liable to pay any oc-
cupation, tax, State, county or municipal.

Sec. 3. That the said association shall be governed and con-
trolled by a president, vice president, secretary and treasurer, to-
Laws of the State of Texas.gether with a board of trustees, and shall have power to enact by-
laws, rules and regulations fox its government, not inconsistent with the laws of this State, and to alter and amend the same. The said association shall have a seal for the authentication of its acts.
Sec. 4. That this act shall take effect from and after its passage and remain in force thirty years.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXII

opener.salute: An Act for the relief of T. F. Steudebach, late sheriff of Kendall County.

div3.p:
Whereas, T. F. Steudebach, late sheriff of Kendall county, Texas, did, under an attachment issued by the Criminal Court of the city of San Antonio, in the case of the State vs. John F. Giles et al., ar-
rest certain prisoners in the county of Kendall, and convey the same, nine in number, from the said county to the city of San Antonio, a distance of four hundred and fifty traveled miles; and,

Whereas, Said prisoners were under special orders of General J. J. Reynolds, commanding the district, examined before Judge T. P. Van Antwerp, and the account for said services having been approved by the judge; therefore,

Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the sum of one hundred and twenty-three dollars and twenty-two cents, or so much thereof as may be necessary, be and the same is hereby appropriated, out of any moneys in the Treasury not otherwise appropriated, for the payment of said claim.

Sec. 2. That the Comptroller of Public Accounts be and he is hereby instructed and directed to audit and pay the said T. F. Steudebach for the said services, on his filing the accounts approved by the said judge of the Criminal Court of San Antonio.
Sec. 3. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXIII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the City of Waco.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That all that district of country contained within the fol-
lowing limits, to-wit: In McLennan county, beginning at a cotton-
wood on the west bank of the Brazos river (about seven or eight hundred yards below the mouth of Waco creek) marked with a blaze on three sides and three hacks on the other; thence south thirty-
eight degrees west, passing to the left of Dr. Owens’ brick house at eight hundred and fifty varas, continued in all thirty-two hundred varas, to a stake in the prairie; thence north forty-three degrees west, passing to the right of a cluster of live oaks at fifteen hundred varas, also passing to the right of Captain N. Snead’s brick house at seventeen hundred and fifty varas, continued in all forty-five hun-
dred varas, to a stake; thence north thirty-eight degrees east, pass-
ing to the left of R. Burleson’s house at six hundred varas, con-
tinued in all two thousand and fifty varas, to an elm and cotton-
wood on the west bank of the Brazos, both marked with a blaze on three sides, and three hacks on the other; thence north forty-five degrees east, crossing the Brazos to a stake in division line between Judge Davis and Captain Selman, in all three hundred and eighty varas; thence with said line, north sixty degrees east, passing at twenty-one hundred and sixty varas, a post oak ten inches in di-
ameter marked W. A. & +, continued in all twenty-four hundred and sixty varas, to a stake; thence south forty-three degrees east, passing to the left of Robert S. Lyons’ house at six hundred and forty varas, continued in all thirty-five hundred and forty varas, to a stake; thence south thirty-eight degrees west, seventeen hundred and fifty varas, recrossing the Brazos river to the place of beginning, is hereby erected into a city by the name of the “City of Waco.”

Sec. 2. That the inhabitants of the city of Waco, as the same extends and is laid out above, be and they and their successors, are hereby constituted a corporation and body politic in fact and in law, by the name and style of the “City of Waco,” and by the same name shall have succession, shall sue and be sued, implead and be impleaded, defend and be defended, in all courts of law and equity, and in all actions whatsoever; may purchase, receive and hold property, real and personal, within said city, and may sell, lease or dispose of the same for the benefit of the city, and may purchase, re-
ceive and hold property, real and personal, beyond the limits of the-
Laws of the State of Texas.city, to be used for the burial of the dead of the city; also for the erection of water works to supply the city with water, and also for the establishment of a hospital for the reception of persons in-
fected with contagious and other diseases; and may sell, lease or dis-
pose of such property, for the benefit of the city, and may do all other acts as natural persons. They shall have and use one common seal, and may break, change, alter and make a new seal at pleasure.

Sec. 3. That the city of Waco shall be divided into eight wards; the boundaries thereof shall be fixed by the city council, and may be, by the council, changed from time to time, as they shall see fit, having regard to the number of male inhabitants, so that each ward shall contain, as near as may be, the same number of male in-
habitants.

Sec. 4. That there shall be a city council, to consist of a mayor and board of aldermen; that the board of aldermen shall consist of one member front each ward, to be chosen by the qualified voters of said city for one year; and no person shall be an alderman unless he be a citizen of the State of Texas, and shall have resided within the city limits for six months preceding his election, and be a bona fide resident of the ward for which he is elected. That if any al-
derman shall after his election remove from the ward from which he is chosen, his office shall thereby be vacated. The city council shall judge of the election returns and qualifications of its own members, and shall determine contested elections. The majority of the city council shall constitute a quorum to do business, but a smaller num-
ber may adjourn from day to day, and may compel the attendance of absent members, in such manner and under such penalties as they may prescribe. The city council may determine the rules of its proceedings, punish its members for disorderly behavior, and, with the concurrence of two-thirds of the members elected, expel a member, but not a second time for the same offense. The city coun-
cil shall keep a journal of its proceedings, and the yeas and nays of the members on any question shall, at the desire of any two of those present, be entered on the journal. No alderman shall, during the time for which he was elected, be appointed to any office under the city. All vacancies that shall occur in the board shall be filled by election in suck manner as shall be provided for by ordinance. Each alderman shall, before entering upon the duties of his office, take the oath prescribed by the Constitution of the State for mem-
bers of the Legislature, and that he will faithfully discharge the duties of his office. Whenever there shall be a tie in the election of aldermen, the judges of the election shall certify the same to the mayor, who shall immediately thereupon issue his proclamation, stating such facts and ordering a new election.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p:
Sec. 5. There shall be stated sessions of the city council, and they shall be held at such time and place as shall be prescribed by ordinance. Upon the passage of all ordinances appropriating money, of ordinances imposing taxes, increasing, lessening or abol-
ishing licenses, the yeas and nays shall be entered on the journal. All ordinances shall be read in council on three several days, unless two-thirds of the members elected, of the board, shall dispense therewith. A majority of the members of the city council shall be necessary to pass an ordinance appropriating for any purpose the sum of five hundred dollars or upwards, or an ordinance in any wise diminishing or increasing the city revenue.

Sec. 6. That the appropriations of the city council for payment of moneys for improvements and city expenses during any one fiscal year shall not exceed the income for said fiscal year; but it shall be lawful for said board to appropriate any surplus moneys in the treas-
ury to the extinguishment of the city debts.

Sec. 7. The mayor and city council shall have power within the city, by ordinance: First, to levy and collect taxes, not exceed-
ing one-half of one per centum, upon all property made taxable by law, for State and county purposes. Second, to appropriate money, and to provide for the payment of the debt and expenses of the city. Third, to make regulations to prevent the introduction of contagious diseases into the city. Fourth, to establish hospitals and make regu-
lations for the government thereof. Fifth, to make regulations to secure the general health of the inhabitants, and to prevent and re-
move nuisances. Sixth, to provide the city with water, and to erect hydrants, fire plugs and pumps in the streets, within or beyond the limits of the city, for the convenience of the inhabitants of the city and environs. Seventh, to open, alter, abolish, widen, extend, es-
tablish, grade, pave, or otherwise improve, clean and keep in repair, streets, lanes, avenues or alleys. Eighth, to establish, erect and keep in repair bridges, culverts and sewers, and regulate the use of the same; provided, that nothing herein shall be so construed as to give any power over the Waco suspension bridge, across the Brazos river, or to interfere with the chartered rights of the Waco Bridge Company in any respect whatever; in all other respects, however, leaving the jurisdiction the same over said bridgeway as in other portions of the corporation. Ninth, to provide for the lighting of the streets and erecting lamps thereon. Tenth, to establish, sup-
port and regulate night watch and patrols. Eleventh, to erect market houses, establish markets and market places, and pro-
vide for the government and regulation thereof. Twelfth, to provide for the erection of all needful buildings for the use of the city. Thirteenth, to provide for the inclosing, im-
Laws of the State of Texas.proving and regulating all public grounds belonging to the city, and for regulating the use of the river and banks thereof, and the commons adjacent thereto. Fourteenth, to license, tax and reg-
ulate auctions, grocers, merchants, retailers and taverns; and to license, tax, regulate and suppress ordinaries, hawkers, peddlers, brokers, pawnbrokers, moneychangers, and bakeries; provided, that the tax imposed under this clause shall not exceed one-half of that imposed by State law for the benefit of the State, on the same occu-
pations. Fifteenth, to license, tax and regulate hackney carriages, omnibuses, wagons, carts and drays, and fix the rates to be charged for the carriage of persons, and of wagonage, cartage and drayage of property. Sixteenth, to license and regulate porters, and fix the rate of porterage. Seventeenth, to license, tax, regulate and sup-
press theatrical and other exhibitions, shows and amusements. Eighteenth, to license, tax and regulate billiard tables, tippling houses and dram shops, and to suppress gaming and gambling houses and other disorderly houses, or to suppress bawdy houses or license the same. Nineteenth, to provide for the prevention and extinguishment of fires, and organizing and establishing fire com-
panies; also to regulate, restrain and prohibit the erection of wooden buildings in any part of the city; to regulate and prevent the carry-
ing on of manufactories dangerous in causing or producing fires; to appoint fire wardens and property guards, with power to re-
move and keep away from the vicinity of any fire, all idle and sus-
picions persons lurking near the same; and to compel any person or persons present to aid in extinguishing such fire, or in the preser-
vation of property exposed to the danger of the same, and in pre-
venting goods from being purloined thereat, and with such other powers and duties as may be prescribed by ordinance; to compel the owners of houses and other buildings to have scuttles upon the roof of any such houses and buildings, and stairs and ladders lead-
ing to the same. Twentieth, to regulate and order the cleaning of chimneys, and to fix the fees thereof. Twenty-first, to regulate the storage of gunpowder, tar, pitch, rosin, hemp, cotton, and all combustible material, and the use of lights and candles in all stables, shops and other places; to remove and prevent the con-
struction of any fireplace, hearth, chimneys, stoves, ovens, boilers, kettles or apparatus used in any house, building, manufactory or business which may be dangerous in causing or promoting fires; to direct the safe construction of deposit for ashes, and severally to enter into, or to appoint one or more officers, at rea-
sonable times, to enter into and examine all dwellings, houses, lots, yards, inclosures and buildings of every description, in order to dis-
cover whether any of them are in a dangerous state, and to cause
Laws of the State of Texas.such as may be dangerous to be put in a safe and secure condition. Twenty-second, to regulate and prescribe the manner and order of the building of partition and parapet walls, and of partition fences. Twenty-third, to establish standard weights and measures, and to regulate the weights and measures to be used in the city in all cases not otherwise provided by law. Twenty-fourth, to provide for the inspection and measuring of lumber and other building material. Twenty-fifth, to provide for the inspection and weighing of hay, the measuring of charcoal, firewood and all other fuel to be used in the city. Twenty-sixth, to regulate the inspection of butter, lard and other provisions; to regulate the vending of meat, poultry and vegetables; to restrain and punish the forestalling of poultry, butter, eggs and fruit, and to suppress hucksters. Twenty-seventh, to regulate the weight, quality and price of bread to be sold and used in the city. Twenty-eighth, to regulate the size of brick made or sold in the city; provided, no ordinance shall prevent the sale of brick made before its passage. Twenty-ninth, to provide for the taking an enumeration of the inhabitants of the city. Thirtieth, to provide for the removing from office any person holding an office created by an ordinance of the city council. Thirty-first, to pro-
vide for the appointment of all officers, servants and agents of the corporation not otherwise provided for, and to provide what officers of the corporation shall give bonds and the amount and condition of the same. Thirty-second, to fix the compensation of the city officers not otherwise provided for, and regulate the fees of all jurors, witnesses and others for services rendered under this act or any ordinance. Thirty-third, to regulate the police of the city; to impose fines, forfeitures and penalties for the breach of any ordinance, and provide for the recovery and appropriation of such fines and forfeitures, and the enforcement of such penalties; pro-
vided, that no fine shall exceed one hundred dollars, and imprison-
ment not exceeding fifteen days for any one offense. Thirty-fourth, to remove all obstructions from the sidewalks, and to provide for the construction and repair of all sidewalks and curb stones, and for the cleaning of the same, and of the gutters, at the expense of the owners of the ground fronting thereon. Thirty-fifth, to prevent the assembly of idle persons at store house doors, whereby the trade of such house is interrupted, also to prevent or restrain any riot, row, disturbance, or disorderly assemblage, in any street, house or place in the city. Thirty-sixth, to prevent and remove all encroach-
ment in and upon all streets, lanes, avenues and alleys, established by law or ordinance. Thirty-seventh, to exercise complete and per-
fect control over the common, and all the property belonging to the city, real and personal, whether lying within or beyond the limits
Laws of the State of Texas.of the corporation created by this act, and the same to lease, sell, transfer and dispose of, either absolutely or within limitation, sub-
ject only to the conditions, if any, on which the property is held, to any person or persons whatsoever, and generally to make such rules, regulations, by-laws and ordinances, for the purpose of maintaining the peace, good government and order of the city of Waco, and the trade, commerce and manufactures thereof, as the city council may deem expedient, not repugnant to the laws and Constitution of this State, and also to enforce the observance thereof by inflicting penal-
ties upon any inhabitant thereof, or other person or persons for the violation of any ordinance, not exceeding one hundred dollars for any one offense, recoverable with costs in an action of debt, by and in the name of the city of Waco, for the use of the city, before any court having cognizance of the same. Thirty-eighth, that the mayor and city council shall have power to subscribe for the city of Waco to the capital stock of such railroad company or companies as may seem best for the advancement of the interest of said city, not to ex-
ceed in all one hundred thousand dollars, and may issue bonds to raise the money therefor; provided, that before said subscription or subscriptions are made, the questions whether the same shall be made or not, shall be submitted to the vote of the qualified voters of the city, at an election to be held at the time and in the mode to be prescribed in an ordinance to be enacted for the purpose, and that two-thirds of the votes cast at such election are in favor of such subscription or subscriptions; and provided further, that no bonds shall be issued under this clause until the city council shall first have provided by an ordinance for the levy of a special tax on all property taxable according to the laws of the State, situated within the limits of the city, sufficient to pay the interest and not more than one twentieth nor less than one thirtieth of the principal yearly, of the bonds proposed to be issued; which ordinance shall not be repealed or suspended until the bonds are fully paid off and discharged. The fund arising from this special tax shall not be di-
verted to any other purpose than that of paying off the interest and principal of the bonds issued by virtue of this clause, and any officer of the corporation who by vote or otherwise shall be instrumental in diverting said fund, or any part of it, to any other purpose, shall be liable therefor out of his own estate. Bonds issued by virtue hereof shall not run longer than thirty years, nor a shorter time than twenty years, nor bear more than eight per centum interest, to be paid semi-annually in gold in the city of Waco, Galveston, or New York, as may be fixed upon, and shall have interest coupons attached and shall be so made that the city of Waco may, at any time before maturity, at option, pay the whole or any part of the principal
Laws of the State of Texas.thereof; and the sinking fund herein provided for shall be applied to payment of said bonds as it accrues. All bonds issued by virtue of these provisions shall be signed by the mayor, and also by the secre-
tary of the city council, and impressed with the corporate seal, and shall also be registered by said secretary in a record book to be pro-
vided for the purpose, and the date of such registry shall be endorsed on the bonds respectively, and be signed by the secretary. Full power is granted the mayor and city council, by appropriate ordi-
nances, to provide for the levy and collection of the special tax above mentioned, and generally to provide for the levy and collec-
tion of all taxes authorized by this charter to be imposed.

Sec. 8. That the city council shall have power, subject to the restriction in the preceding section, to make all ordinances which shall be necessary and proper for carrying into effect the power spec-
ified in the preceding section, and all other powers vested by this act in the corporation, the city government, or any department or officer thereof. No money shall be expended, nor shall any im-
provement be ordered, involving an expenditure of money, except by ordinance, the provisions of which shall be specific and definite. Every ordinance which shall have been passed by the city council, shall, before it becomes a law, be presented to the mayor for his ap-
probation. If he approve, he shall sign it; if not, he shall return it, with his objections, to the board, which objections shall be entered at large on the journal, and the ordinance be reconsidered. If, after such reconsideration, two-thirds of all the members of the board shall agree to pass the same, it shall be in force as an ordinance. In all such cases, the votes of the city council shall be taken by yeas and nays, and entered on the journal. If any ordinance shall not be returned by the mayor in five days (Sunday excepted) after it shall have been presented to him for his approbation, the same shall be in force as an ordinance in the same manner as if he had approved and signed it. Every resolution, except in case of adjournment, shall be presented to the mayor, and before the same shall take effect, shall be proceeded upon in the manner as in case of an ordi-
nance. The style of the ordinances of the city shall be: “Be it or-
dained by the City Council of the City of Waco.” All ordinances passed by the city council shall, within ten days after they become laws, be published in the official newspaper published in the city of Waco. All ordinances of the city may be proven by the seal of the corporation, and when printed and published by authority of the corporation, the same shall be received in evidence in all courts and places without further proof. When the office of mayor shall be va-
cant, or the mayor be absent from the city, the board of aldermen shall elect one of their members president of the board for the time being,
Laws of the State of Texas.who shall during said vacancy or absence, discharge the duties and receive the compensation of mayor.

Sec. 9. That the chief executive officer of the city shall be the mayor, who shall be elected by the qualified voters of the city, and who shall hold his office for the term of one year, whose salary shall be fixed by the aldermen of the city, but which shall not in any event exceed the sum of one thousand dollars and fees of office. No person shall be mayor who at the time of his election is not possessed of the qualifications required for an alderman, or who holds any lu-
crative office under authority of the United States. When two or more persons shall have an equal number of votes for the office of mayor, the city council shall order a new election. Whenever an election for mayor shall be contested, the city council shall determ-
ine the same by vote. Whenever any vacancy shall happen in the office of mayor, it shall be filled by election in such manner as shall be provided for by ordinance. The mayor shall have power to nomi-
nate, and by and with the consent of the board of aldermen, to ap-
point all city officers not ordered by this act to be otherwise ap-
pointed; he shall take care that the laws of the State and the ordi-
nances of the city are duly enforced, respected and observed within the city; he may remit fines, forfeitures and penalties accruing from or imposed for the violation of any ordinance in the city; he may fill all vacancies which may occur in any elective office other than that of alderman, until the same be filled by election, and in any other office, until the end of session of the board of aldermen, which shall first happen after the vacancy shall have accrued; he shall, from time to time, give the city council information relative to the state of the city, and shall recommend to their consideration such measures as he shall deem expedient for the advantage of the city. The mayor may call special sessions of the city council by notice served on them. Whenever a special session of the city council shall have been called by the mayor, he shall state to them when as-
sembled, the cause for which they have been convened.

Sec. 10. That there shall be a city treasurer, city marshal, city attorney, and a secretary of the city council, who in addition to the duties prescribed by this act shall perform such other duties as may be prescribed by ordinance; there shall be such other officers, ser-
vants and agents of the corporation as may be provided by ordi-
nance, to be appointed by the mayor, by and with the consent and advice of the board of aldermen, and to perform such duties as may be prescribed by ordinance. The city treasurer and city marshal shall be elected in the same manner as the mayor and aldermen, and the city attorney and secretary of the city council shall be appointed by the mayor, by and with the advice of the board of aldermen.
Laws of the State of Texas.They shall hold their office for one year, and until their successors are duly qualified. It shall be the duty of the city treasurer to re-
ceive and keep the money of the city, and to pay out the same on warrants drawn, as may be prescribed by ordinance. The city mar-
shal shall, within the city, in matters of a criminal nature arising under any law of the State, possess the same power, perform the same duties, and receive the same compensation as a constable of McLennan county; he shall execute and return all process issued by the mayor, recorder, any alderman or justice of the peace, under this act or ordinance of the city council. The secretary of the city council shall be present at all meetings of the council, and shall keep a correct record of all its proceedings in books to be provided for the purpose.

Sec. 11. That the mayor and all other officers of the corporation shall reside within the limits of the city during their continu-
ance in office; and if the mayor of the corporation shall cease to reside within the limits of the city, his office shall thereby be va-
cated. The mayor shall have the same jurisdiction as a justice of the peace, within the limits of the city, in all State cases; he shall have jurisdiction over all cases arising under any ordinance of the city, subject, however, to an appeal or writ of certiorari in all cases to the district court, and every such appeal shall be taken and granted in the same manner as appeals or certiorari are taken and granted by justices’ courts to the district court, under the general laws of the State. He shall charge, in all cases, the same fees which are naw allowed to justices of the peace for the same kind of services, which shall be charged and collected as other costs; and shall act as president of the board of aldermen.

Sec. 12. That a general election of all officers of the corpora-
tion, required to be elected by this act, or any ordinance of the city, shall be held on the second Monday in December in each year. At all elections for city officers the voters shall vote by ballot, and shall vote at such time and place as the council shall prescribe. Judges of elections shall be appointed by the board of aldermen; they shall take an oath to faithfully and impartially discharge their duties; they shall open the polls at nine o’clock and close them at five o’clock, when they shall forthwith proceed to ascertain and cer-
tify the result of the election, in the presence of so many of the can-
didates or other persons, of all parties indiscriminately, as can be conveniently accommodated in the room selected for the purpose; provided, that there shall never be less than ten voters present at any count, if so many desire to be present. No election shall be held in a grog shop, or other place where intoxicating liquors are vended. All persons qualified as electors under the first section of
Laws of the State of Texas.the third article of the Constitution of the State of Texas, who shall have resided six months within the city, are qualified voters under this charter; provided, that in addition thereto a residence of one month within the ward is necessary to entitle a person to vote for alderman of said ward. The election for city officers shall be but one day, and during that day the polls shall not be closed on any pretence whatever. Special elections to fill vacancies shall be held under such regulations as may be provided for by law or ordi-
nance; provided, that there shall be no election held under this act until after the next general election.

Sec. 13. That it shall not be lawful for the city council to grade, pave, macadamize, clean, water or light any street, lane or avenue not established and opened according to law and ordinance. It shall be lawful, nevertheless, for the city council to order the owner or owners of ground fronting on any private alley, to keep the same clean, and, if necessary thereto, to direct him or them to pave the same. When it is necessary to take private property for opening, widening or altering any public street, lane, avenue or al-
ley, the corporation shall make a just compensation therefor to the person whose property is so taken. If the amount of such compen-
sation cannot be agreed upon, the mayor shall cause the same to be ascertained by a jury of six disinterested persons, freeholders of the city, and the compensation fixed on shall be paid before the prop-
erty is appropriated or used. When the owner of the major part of the front of the property on the street, lane, avenue or alley, pro-
posed to be opened, widened or altered, shall petition therefor, the mayor and city council may open, widen or alter such street, lane, avenue or alley upon conditions to be prescribed by ordinance. All jurors impanelled to inquire into the amount of damages which shall happen to the owner of the property proposed to be taken for opening, widening or altering any street, lane, avenue or alley, shall first be sworn to that effect, and shall return to the mayor their in-
quest in writing and signed by each juror.

Sec. 14. That the mayor shall have the power, for good cause shown within ten days after an inquest shall have been returned to him, as mentioned in the preceding section, to set the same aside and cause a new inquest to be made. The mayor and city council shall have the power, by ordinance, to levy and collect a special tax on the holders of the lots on any streets, lanes, avenue or alley, ac-
