cording to the respective fronts owned by them, for the purpose of paving or embellishing with shade trees, or grading of such street, lane, avenue or alley; provided always, such tax shall not exceed one-
half of one per centum of the valne of said lot, nor shall the grad-
ing or paving be done at the sole and exclusive expense of the owners
Laws of the State of Texas.of the lots fronting on the street, lane, avenue or alley, unless a petition for such grading or paving, signed by the owners of a major part of the ground fronting thereon or adjoining thereto, be pre-
sented for such purpose. The city council shall have power, by ordinance, to direct the manner in which any property, real or per-
sonal, advertised for sale, or sold for taxes by authority of the cor-
poration, may be redeemed. Lands within the limits of the city, which have not been laid off into blocks or lots, shall not be as-
sessed or taxed otherwise than by the acre, as agricultural lands, and shall continue to be so assessed and taxed until laid off into blocks or lots by the owners thereof, respectively, and the owners of such lands in laying off the same into blocks or lots, shall so ar-
range the streets that they shall correspond with previously estab-
lished streets of the city.

Sec. 15. The city council shall cause to be published, within one month after the end of each fiscal year, a full and complete detailed statement of all moneys received and expended by the corporation during the preceding fiscal year, and on what account received and expended, classifying each receipt and expenditure under its proper head. All ordinances and resolutions now in force in the city of Waco, and not inconsistent with this act, shall remain in full force until altered, modified or repealed under this act. All suits, actions and prosecutions instituted, commenced, or brought by the cor-
poration hereby created, shall be instituted, commenced and prose-
cuted in the name of the city of Waco. All actions, fines, penal-
ties and forfeitures which have accrued to the city council of Waco, or the city of Waco, shall be vested in and prosecuted for by the corporation hereby created. All property, real or personal, herto-
fore belonging to the inhabitants of the city of Waco, or the trus-
tees of said town, in their corporate capacity, or to the mayor, alder-
men and citizens of the city of Waco, or to the city council of the city of Waco, or to the city of Waco, shall be and the same is hereby declared to be vested in the corporation hereby created. This charter shall not invalidate any act done by the mayor, aldermen or the citizens of Waco, the city council of the city of Waco, or the city of Waco, nor divest them of any right which may have accrued to them prior to the passage of this act. This act is declared to be a public act, and may be read in evidence in all courts of law and equity in this State without proof. The city council shall have power to provide by ordinance that any person who shall fail or neglect to pay any fine or cost imposed on him or her by any ordi-
nance of the city of Waco, for any misdemeanor or breach of any or-
dinance of said city, may, instead of being committed to the jail or calaboose, be committed to work on the streets until such fine and
Laws of the State of Texas.cost be fully paid; provided however, that no such imprisonment shall exceed the period of fifteen days for any one offense. Every person so committed to work on the streets shall be required to work for the city at such labor as his health and strength will permit, within said city, not exceeding eight hours each day, and for such work and labor, the person so employed shall be allowed exclusive of his or her board, fifty cents per day for each day’s work, which amount shall go towards paying such fines and costs.

Sec. 16. The fiscal year of this city shall terminate on the day preceding the first Monday in November in each year. Whenever any city officer, accountable as such for any money received or re-
ceivable by him, shall neglect or refuse to pay over, or account for the same, or for the balance properly due by him to the city upon the adjustment of his account, the mayor shall order suit to be com-
menced in the proper court against such delinquent officer, for such sum or balance, adding thereto commission of the delinquent, which shall be forfeited in every instance where suit is commenced and judgment obtained thereon, and interest thereon at twelve per cent. per annum, from the time of receiving the money, or when it should have been received, until it shall be paid in to the treasurer.

Sec. 17. That whenever any person or persons shall make oath before the district judge accusing the mayor, marshal, or any mem-
ber of the board of aldermen or any officer appointed by them, of a misdemeanor, malfeasance in office, or neglect of duty, it shall be the duty of said judge immediately to examine into the truth of said charges, and if true, he shall remove the person or persons from office at once.

Sec. 18. The present city council shall exercise all of the powers and functions vested in the council under this act, until su-
perseded under the same, and they shall, as soon as practicable after the passage of this act, proceed to take an enumeration of the male inhabitants of the city, and to divide the city into wards, as pre-
scribed by the same, and provide for elections conformably to the same. This act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage; and all acts conflicting in part or whole with the provis-
ions of this act be and the same are hereby repealed.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXIV.

opener.salute:
An Act to amend an act entitled “An Act to incorporate the Agri-
cultural, Stock Raising and Industrial Association of Western Texas,” approved July 8, 1870.

div3.p:
Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That sec-
tion four of an act entitled “An act to incorporate the Agricultural, Stock Raising and Industrial Association of Western Texas,” ap-
proved July 8, 1870, shall hereafter read as follows: “Section. 4. That this act continue and remain in force for ninety (90) years, and take effect and be in force from and after its passage.”

div3.head: CHAPTER CXV.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the “City of Tyler,” and to provide for the administration of its municipal affairs.

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the people residing within the territory embraced within a square league of land, the present court house in Tyler, in the county of Smith, being the centre thereof, shall be, and they are hereby declared to be a body corporate and politic, by the name and style of the “City of Tyler.”

Sec. 2. That by said corporate name they shall have the right to contract and be contracted with; to sue and to be sued; to plead and to be impleaded in all courts, and in all matters involving their corporate rights and liabilities.

Sec. 3. That they may, in said corporate name, acquire and hold real, personal and mixed property, and may dispose of the same for the use and benefit of said city; and may have and use (by the offi-
cers hereinafter provided for) a corporate seal, with such device, shape and motto as may be prescribed by the board of aldermen hereinafter provided for.
Sec. 4. That the officers of said city shall consist of a mayor and nine aldermen, who shall be styled the board of aldermen, when assembled in their official capacity.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p: Sec. 5. That there shall be an election for the officers named in the last preceding section of this act, to be held within said city, at the next general election for State and county officers, and annually thereafter.

Sec. 6. That until such election the Governor of the State be and he is hereby authorized to appoint said officers, until their suc-
cessors are duly elected and qualified.

Sec. 7. That should vacancies from any cause occur in the board of aldermen before the next general election, the Governor is author-
ized to fill the same by appointment.

Sec. 8. That the mayor and aldermen shall be selected from the citizens living within the limits of said city, and who have re-
sided therein for a period of six months, and shall be elected by the qualified voters residing within said city.

Sec. 9. That the municipal affairs of said city shall be admin-
istered by the board of aldermen, with the aid of such subordinate officers as said board may deem necessary for a proper administra-
tion of the business pertaining to the prosperity and welfare of said city.

Sec. 10. That a majority of the board of aldermen shall consti-
tute a quorum for the transaction of business.

Sec. 11. That eligibility to office and the right of suffrage at any election held for the officers provided for herein, shall be con-
trolled by the Constitution and laws of this State on those subjects, with the qualification only of section eight herein.

Sec. 12. That there shall also be a treasurer, a secretary and a city marshal, who shall be appointed by the board of aldermen, and who shall reside within the limits of said city, and perform such duties as may be prescribed by said board; and each of said officers shall give such official bond as may be prescribed by said board of aldermen, and the duties of secretary and treasurer may be per-
formed by one and the same person.
Sec. 13. That the board of aldermen shall have authority to allow and provide for the payment of such compensation to any of its officers as they may deem just and proper, and to define their duties.

Sec. 14. That said board of aldermen shall enact such ordi-
nances, rules and regulations as may be necessary, consistent with the Constitution and laws of the State, for the general interest and welfare of the city.

Sec. 15. That for the purpose of defraying the expenses that may be incurred in conducting the municipal affairs of said city, and in promoting its highest prosperity, the board of aldermen shall have the right to levy and collect a tax upon all rightful subjects of taxation within said city.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p:
Sec. 16. That the board of aldermen shall have the right, if they deem it to be for the interest of the city, to extend such aid to railroads approaching said city, and for other works of internal im-
provement as they, in their sound discretion, may think judicious and proper.

Sec. 17. That for the purpose of meeting any liability that may be incurred under the provisions of the last preceding section, said board of aldermen may, under such regulations as they may adopt, issue the bonds of said city, not to exceed one million dollars.

Sec. 18. That for the payment of the interest on said bonds, as well as for their ultimate redemption, said board of aldermen is hereby authorized to make such provisions, consistent with the Con-
stitution and laws of the State, as to them may seem right and proper.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXVI.

opener.salute: An Act for the relief of S. B. Reid.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the auditorial board, created at this session of the Legislature, are authorized to take into consideration the claim of S. B. Reid, of Travis county, for material furnished and labor per-
formed upon the State Lunatic Asylum, to an amount not exceed-
ing two thousand six hundred dollars, or so much thereof as the said board may ascertain to be justly due said Reid. The Governor is authorized to issue bonds as provided in said act for the amount found due said Reid, not exceeding said amount of two thousand six hundred dollars.
Sec. 2. That this act take effect from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXVII.

opener.salute:
An act to incorporate the town of Palestine, in the county of An-
derson.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the citizens of the town of Palestine, in Anderson county, be and they are hereby declared a body corporate and poli-
tic, and under the style of the “Town of Palestine” may sue and be sued in all courts and suits whatever; and may purchase, hold and convey any real or personal estate within the limits of said town, and may have a corporate seal.
Sec. 2. That the limits of said town corporation shall extend to the present limits of said town, or one mile square.

Sec. 3. That all persons who are qualified voters under the Con-
stitution of the State, and who have been citizens of said town six months next preceding an election, shall be authorized to vote in elections held in said corporation.

Sec. 4. That the qualified electors of said corporation shall, as soon as authorized by law to do so, elect a mayor and five aldermen, who shall hold their offices for the term of two years thereafter, and until their successors shall be elected and qualified.

Sec. 5. That there shall be a constable, treasurer, recorder, and attorney of said corporation, who shall hold their offices for the term of one year, and until their successors be appointed and quali-
fied. Said officers shall be appointed at a regular meeting of the board of aldermen, by a vote of two-thirds of the aldermen present. Said appointments shall be made as soon as practicable after the aldermen shall have received their certificates of election, and as soon as practicable after any vacancies from resignation, death, expi-
ration of term of office, or other cause, may occur.

Sec. 6. That at all elections held under this act, the board of aldermen shall appoint judges of said election, who shall take an oath faithfully and impartially to discharge their duties. They shall open the polls at ten o’clock, A. M., and close the same at four o’clock P. M., on the day of election, and shall within twenty-four hours thereafter make return of said election to the mayor, or in case of his absence or inability to act, or of a vacancy in his office, then the recorder and board of aldermen shall open such returns and determine the result of the election, and immediately issue cer-
tificates thereof to the persons elected.
Sec. 7. That when an election for mayor shall be contested, the board of aldermen shall determine such contest.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p: Sec. 8. That in case of a vacancy in the office of mayor, the board of aldermen shall order an election to fill such vacancy; such election shall be held as provided in this act for regular elections; and in case of vacancy in the office of alderman, such vacancy shall be filled at a regular meeting of the board of aldermen, by a vote of two-thirds of the aldermen present, and the person so appointed shall hold his office for the unexpired term.

Sec. 9. In case of the temporary absence of the mayor, the board of aldermen shall have the power to appoint one of their number to act as mayor pro tempore, who shall have the same powers and privileges as the mayor elect, and such appointment shall expire on the return of the mayor.

Sec. 10. That the mayor, when present, shall preside over the board of aldermen, and in case of a tie in the vote of the board, shall give the casting vote; provided, that three of the aldermen, either with or without the mayor, shall constitute a quorum to transact business.

Sec. 11. That the mayor, in addition to his powers and juris-
diction as such, is hereby vested with all the powers and jurisdiction, civil and criminal, within the limits of said corporation, which may be, by law, exercised by justices of the peace under the laws of the State, and he shall be entitled to have and receive such fees as are or may be by law allowed to justices of the peace for similar ser-
vices.

Sec. 12. The mayor, constable, recorder, treasurer and attorney of said corporation may be removed from office for neglect of duty, misdemeanor or malfeasance in office, by a vote of two-thirds of the aldermen at a regular meeting of the board.

Sec. 13. That the mayor and aldermen shall have power to en-
act such by-laws and ordinances for the government of said corpora-
tion, and for the peace, quiet, good order and happiness of the citizens of the same, not inconsistent with the laws of the State, as may be deemed proper, and may impose fines and penalties for the violation of the same, not to exceed one hundred dollars in any one case.
Sec. 14. That the mayor and aldermen shall have and exercise control over the public square, streets, sidewalks and roads within said corporation.

Sec. 15. That the board of aldermen shall have power to levy and provide for the collection of an ad valorem tax on property situated in said corporation, taxable by the general law of the State, and also the power to levy and collect a poll tax not to exceed one dollar each, on all male persons of said corporation over the age of twenty-one years and under fifty-five years, which tax shall be col-
Laws of the State of Texas.lected in such manner as may be provided by the by-laws of said corporation; provided, said ad valorem tax shall not exceed one-half of one per centum on the value of the property taxed, and that it shall require the vote of two-thirds of the members of the board of aldermen to levy such tax, and the same shall be done at a regular meeting of the board.

Sec. 16. That the board of aldermen shall have the power to license, tax and regulate hawkers, peddlers, auctions, theatricals, and other exhibitions, shows and amusements, billiard tables, nine and ten pin alleys, groceries, tippling houses and dram shops, and to determine the amount of tax upon the same, and to suppress gaming or gambling houses by whatever description known, and all disor-
derly houses.

Sec. 17. That all officers of said corporation shall, before enter-
ing upon the duties of their office, take and subscribe the oath pre-
scribed by the Constitution; and the mayor, constable, and treasurer, shall also enter into a bond with two good securities, to be approved qy the board of aldermen, for the faithful performance of their duties, payable to the said corporation, in such sum as the board of aldermen may require, which bond shall not be void on first re-
covery.

Sec. 18. That the constable, in addition to his powers and privi-
leges as such, be and he is hereby vested with all the powers and privileges which are now, or may be by law, exercised by the con-
stable of the beat in which said corporation is situated; and for all services which may be rendered by him he shall have the same fees which are, or may be by law, allowed to constables of the beat for similar services.

Sec. 19. The fees of the aldermen shall not be more than two dollars for each and every regular meeting of the board at which they may be in attendance; provided, they shall not be entitled to charge for more than twelve meetings in any one year. That the fees of the recorder shall not be more than two dollars for each and every meeting of the board at which he may be in attendance. The fees of the treasurer shall not be more than five per centum upon all moneys received and paid out by him. The corporation attor-
ney shall be entitled to have and receive a tax fee of two dollars and fifty cents on each and every conviction under this act and the by-
 laws of said corporation, which fee the mayor shall include and tax in the bill of costs on said conviction; provided, that when any person shall have committed any offense against the laws of said corporation and shall plead guilty of the same, said tax shall not be allowed nor taxed. And the board of aldermen shall have the power to regulate the compensation of the officers of said corpora-
tion, not definitely fixed and provided for in this act.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p: Sec. 20. That in all prosecutions, trials and proceedings under this act and the by-laws of said corporation, the mayor and constable shall be governed by the laws regulating proceedings in justices’ courts, in force at the time of said proceedings, prosecutions and trials, and shall be entitled to the same fees as justices of the peace and constables for similar services.

Sec. 21. That the first election, as provided for in the fourth section of this act, for corporate officers, shall be held as may be provided for by law; that, for the present, the Governor be requested to appoint the officers for said corporation.
Sec. 22. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXVIII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate Douglassville College.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That a school of learning, consisting of male and female de-
partments, be and the same is hereby established in the county of Davis to be known as Douglassville College.

Sec. 2. That W. H. D. Hunt, R. Powell, R. A. Brooks, G. P. Cook and J. A. H. Granbury, and their associates, are hereby created and declared to be a body corporate and politic, by the name and style of the trustees of Douglassville College, and by said name and style they shall have snceession, sue and be sued, plead and be im-
pleaded in all courts whatever, in like manner and as fully as nat-
ural persons; and by said corporate name and style shall be capable of contracting and being contracted with, and shall have the power of acquiring by purchase, donation or otherwise, property both real personal and mixed, and dispose of the same in any manner what-
ever for the benefit of said college; to construct all necessary build-
ings for said institution; to establish a preparatory department; to organize, establish and control a separate department and school for females, and such dependent institutions as they shall deem necessary in furtherance of the objects of this act; to have the management of the finances; the privilege of electing their own of-
ficers; of appointing all necessary committees, and to act and do all things whatsoever for the benefit of the said college, in as
Laws of the State of Texas.ample a manner as any person or body politic or corporate may or can do law.

Sec. 3. That said trustees shall have power of prescribing the course of studies to be pursued by the students, and of framing and enacting all such ordinances and by-laws as shall appear to them necessary for the good government of said college, and for their own proceedings; provided, that the same be in accordance with the Constitution of the United States and the State of Texas.

Sec. 4. The trustees shall appoint a president and the profes-
sors, who shall be styled the Faculty of Douglassville College, which faculty shall have the power of enforcing the ordinances and by-laws adopted by the trustees for the government of the students, by re-
warding or censuring them, and finally by suspending such of them as, after repeated admonitions, shall continue disobedient, or re-
fractory, until a determination of a quorum of trustees can be had; but it shall only be in the power of a quorum of the trustees to ex-
pel a student from college.

Sec. 5. That the trustees may, upon the recommendation of the faculty of said college, grant or confer such degree or degrees in the arts and sciences to the students of said college, and other persons worthy thereof, as are usually granted and conferred in other col-
leges, and to give certificates thereof or diplomas, signed by them and sealed with the common seal of the trustees of said college, (which seal they are hereby authorized and empowered to have and use) to authenticate and perpetuate the memory of such graduation.
Sec. 6. That whenever any vacancy may occur in the board of trustees, either by death, resignation or otherwise, such vacancy or vacancies shall be filled by the selection of the remaining trustees.

Sec. 7. That all necessary officers of said college shall be ap-
pointed by a majority of the board of trustees, viz: The faculty or minor officers; and that officers shall always be subject to be removed by the appointing power for cause.
Sec. 8. That the salaries of all officers connected with the college shall be fixed by a majority of the board of trustees.

Sec. 9. That Douglassville College shall be purely literary and scientific, and that he students of all religions shall enjoy equal ad-
vantages.
Sec. 10. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXIX.

opener.salute:
An Act to incorporate the Johnson’s Point Male and Female Semi-
nary.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That a school of learning, consisting of male and female de-
partments, be and the same is hereby established in the county of Kaufman, to be known as Johnson’s Point Male and Female Semi-
nary.

Sec. 2. That A. B. Johnson, Andrew Henry, J. W. Sherwood, J. W. Gillispie and J. C. McDaniel, and their associates and succes-
sors, are hereby created and declared to be a body corporate and politic, by the name and style of the trustees of Johnson’s Point Male and Female Seminary, and by said name and style they shall have succession, sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded in all courts whatever, in like manner and as fully as natural persons; and by said corporate name and style shall be capable of contracting and being contracted with, and shall have the power of acquiring by purchase, donation, or otherwise, property, both real, personal and mixed, and dispose of the same in any manner whatever for the ben-
efit of said seminary; to have the management of the finances; the privilege of electing their own officers; and to act and do all things whatsoever for the benefit of the said seminary, in as ample a man-
ner as any person or bodv politic or corporate may or can do by law.

Sec. 3. That this act of incorporation, and this charter for said seminary, shall remain in full force and effect until said trustees or their successors shall neglect or refuse to maintain in said seminary a school organization during the accustomed scholastic months of any one year.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXX.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Navasota and Washington County Ferry Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That Ed. T. Randle, C. D. Harn, and such persons as they may associate with themselves, are hereby incorporated under the
Laws of the State of Texas.name and style of the Navasota Ferry Company, and under such name may sue and be sued, and have succession for the term of thirty years; that they may have a corporate seal and the right of holding property, real, personal and mixed, for the purpose of car-
rying on the objects of the incorporation; and they may transfer, alienate and dispose of their joint or individual interest herein at pleasure.

Sec. 2. That the said persons, their associates and successors, under the name and style aforesaid, shall be authorized to establish and maintain a ferry on the Brazos river, where the public road from Navasota to the town of Washington crosses said river; said ferry shall be known hereafter by the name set forth in the first sec-
tion of this act.

Sec. 3. That the said Ed. T. Randle, C. D. Harn, and their heirs or assigns shall be bound during the term aforesaid to keep in good order a boat or flat, sufficient at all times to transport and ferry across said river all wagons, horses, cattle, persons and property, with safety and convenience; and to keep and maintain the banks on each side of said river to low water mark, so as to insure the safe embarkation of all persons and property ferried across said river at said ferry.

Sec. 4. That whenever said ferry shall have been examined and reported in good order by the commissioners appointed for that purpose, in the manner prescribed by this act, the proprietors may demand and receive from all and every person passing over said ferry, tolls according to the following rates, viz: For footmen, five cents; single horse or mule, five cents; wagon or carriage and two horses or oxen, fifty cents; wagon and four horses or oxen, seventy-
five cents; and wagon and six horses or oxen, one dollar.

Sec. 5. That the County Court of Grimes county shall appoint two commissioners, on application of the proprietor of such ferry, citizens of said county, whose duty it shall be to examine and ap-
prove of such ferry, authorized by this act.
Sec. 6. That all acts or parts of acts in conflict with this act be and the same are hereby repealed, and that this act take effect from and after its passage.

The foregoing act, received in the office of Secretary of State the nineteenth day of May, one thousand eight hundred and seventy-
one, having been presented to the Governor of Texas for his ap-
proval, and not having been returned by him to the house in
Laws of the State of Texas.which it originated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has become a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXXI.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Galveston Hibernian Society.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That Charles H. Leonard, Christopher Fox, Edward Keogh, Martin Davey, Pat Carville, Michael Cahill, N. C. White, E. Creary and B. R. Plumley, and their associates, be and they are hereby created and constituted a body corporate and politic under the name of the “Galveston Hibernian Society,” and by said name may sue and be sued in the courts of this State; may take, hold, enjoy and grant property, both real and personal; may execute and en-
force all legal contracts; may have a common seal, and shall have the right of succession for ninety-nine years; and may adopt all such rules, regulations and by-laws as may become necessary to the organization and future government of said society.
Sec. 2. That this act take effect from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXXII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Waco Insurance Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That Richard Cook, Janies E. Harrison, J. W. Speight, M. Johnson, S. A. Owens, P. McClelland, E. H. Graham, John A. Winn, D. T. Chamberlin, of McLennan county; James S. Jones, J. B. Billingsley, of Falls county; E. S. C. Robertson and W. A. Miller, of Bell county, and their present and future associates, suc-
cessors and assigns, be and they are hereby incorporated and created a body politic and corporate, by the name and style of the “Waco Insurance Company,” and by the same name and style they and
Laws of the State of Texas.their successors shall be capable of suing and being sued, and main-
taining any action to final judgment and execution, and shall be in law capable of purchasing, holding, improving and conveying any estate, real, personal or mixed, for the use of said corporation, and the said corporation shall have the power to ordain, establish and put in execution such by-laws, ordinances and regulations as shall be necessary for the government thereof; and it shall be lawful for the said corporation, after the expiration of the term of incorpora-
tion, to use the corporate name, style and capacity for the purposes of suit for the final settlement and liquidation of the affairs and ac-
counts of the corporation, and for the sale and disposition of their estate, real, personal or mixed, but not for any other purpose, nor for a period exceeding three years after the expiration of such term of incorporation.

Sec. 2. The capital stock of said company shall not be less than two hundred thousand dollars, and may be increased by said com-
pany to one million dollars, divided into shares of one hundred dol-
lars each, and the same shall be created and paid in such manner and at such times as the president and directors of said corporation shall require, of which requisition at least one month’s notice shall be given by publication in two newspapers printed in the city of Waco, and if any stockholder shall fail to pay any installment so required to be paid, he or she shall cease to be a member of said corporation, and shall forfeit his or her stock, and the share or shares so forfeited may be sold by said corporation in such manner as they may think proper; but such forfeiture and sale of stock shall not release the holder thereof, nor his or her securities on the notes contemplated to be given in sections six and eight of this act, for his or her liability on account of said notes, to any person or per-
sons having a just claim against said corporation which shall have accrued before such sale.

Sec. 3. That for the well ordering of the affairs of said corpora-
tion there shall be thirteen directors, who shall be stockholders of the corporation; they shall be elected by the stockholders at their annual meeting, to be held on the first Monday in March of each year for that purpose, and the directors, at their first meeting, shall choose one of their own number as president and another as vice president; provided, that until the first annual election the persons named in the first section of this act shall have and may exercise all the powers given to the president and directors by this act; and in all elections for directors the vote shall be by ballot, and each stock-
holder shall have one vote for each share he may hold, but no stock-
holder shall vote at any election until the share or shares upon which he may claim to vote shall have been standing in his or her
Laws of the State of Texas.name on the books of said corporation for at least three months pre-
vious to such election. In case of absence from any general meet-
ing, any stockholder may be entitled to vote by proxy.

Sec. 4. The directors of said corporation, seven of whom, in-
cluding the president or vice president, shall form a quorum to do business, shall have power to appoint such officers, clerks, agents and other persons as shall be necessary for conducting the business of said corporation, and to allow said persons so appointed such compensation for their service as they shall deem proper, and gen-
erally to exercise all such other powers and privileges as are given by law to corporations.

Sec. 5. That it shall be lawful for the said company to employ the funds thereof in establishing and sustaining the business of marine, fire and life insurance; to insure vessels in port, buildings, merchandise, produce and lives, and all other perishable property on land, against loss or damage by fire; to make all and every insurance appertaining to or connected with marine, inland and transporta-
tion risks, and to charge, collect and receive for the same such pre-
miums of insurance as the president and directors of said corpora-
tion may deem just and reasonable. It shall be lawful for the said corporation to buy and sell exchange, and to lend any surplus capital thoy may at any time possess or hold; to lend money, on bottomry and respondentia security at marine interest; but it shall not be lawful for said corporation to issue any promissory notes of the char-
acter of bank bills.

Sec. 6. The shares of said corporation shall be assignable and transferable upon the books of said company according to such rules and regulations as the president and directors thereof shall estab-
lish; and in case the assignee of any share or shares of stock shall deposit his note with securities, as contemplated and provided for in section eight of this act, then the assignor of such share or shares shall have the right to withdraw and cancel his note or notes and securities given for such share or shares of stock, otherwise the notes and securities of said assignor shall be and remain subject and liable to all the conditions and provisions contained in section nine of this act.

Sec. 7. The president and directors of said corporation shall, annually or semi-annually, make such dividends of the net profits of the company as shall appear advisable, but twenty-five per cent. of the same shall be kept as a reserve fund, and the balance shall be credited to the stockholders in proportion to the stock owned by them, and endorsed upon their notes, until such notes are paid in full, when it shall be the duty of the president and directors to issue certificates to the stockholders for full paid up shares.

Sec. 8. The main office of the company incorporated by this
Laws of the State of Texas.act shall be located in the city of Waco, and so soon as the president and directors thereof shall establish by evidence, to the satisfaction of the County Court of McLennan county, that ten per cent. of the capital stock of said corporation has been paid by the stockholders thereof, and thot the balance or residue of said capital of two hun-
dred thousand dollars has been secured, to be paid when called for, as contemplated in section second of this act, by the notes of the holders of said capital stock, secured by good and solvent security or securities, and shall also establish, to the satisfaction of said county court, that this corporation has been organized in conform-
ity with the provisions of this act, then said county court shall give said company a certificate thereof, which shall be their warrant to commence business operations under the authority vested by this act.

Sec. 9. Service of any and all legal process in any suit or pro-
ceedings against said company, shall be sufficient if made upon the president or secretary of the board of directors.
Sec. 10. That the charter granted by this act shall continue in full force and effect for the term of fifty years from and after the passage of this act.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXXIII.

opener.salute:
An Act to authorize the Commissioner of the General Land Office to issue to B. H. Davis, assignee, an unconditional second class head-
right certificate for six hundred and forty acres of land upon con-
ditional number ninety.

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the Commissioner of the General Land Office be and he is hereby authorized to issue to B. H. Davis, assignee of John Williams, an unconditional second class headright certificate, for six hundred and forty acres of land, which may be located, surveyed and patented as in other cases; said certificate to be patentable to assignee.

Section 2. That this act take effect and be in force from its pas-
sage.

The foregoing act, received in the office of Secretary of State May eleven, one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one,
Laws of the State of Texas.having been presented to the Governor of Texas for his approval, and not having been returned by him to the house in which it origi-
nated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has become a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXXIV.

opener.salute: An Act to amend an act entitled “An Act to consolidate in one act and amend the several acts incorporating the city of Houston, in Harris county,” passed August 2, 1870.

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That in addition to the powers and authority granted to said Corporation, the mayor and city council of the city of Houston are hereby empowered and authorized to take and condemn land and real estate in said city to the public use, viz: For streets, alleys and public ways; for extending, straightening and widening those streets now in use; for public wharves and landing places for steamers and other water craft; and for public squares, parks and pleasure grounds.

Sec. 2. For the condemnation of any land or real estate the fol-
lowing proceedings shall be had: The city attorney, or attorney em-
ployed by said city for that purpose, shall file a petition in the Dis-
trict Court of Harris county against the owner of land or real es-
tate sought to be condemned for any of the purposes aforesaid, set-
ting forth: First. The name or names and residence of the owner or owners if known, and if unknown the same shall be so stated. Second. The description, by metes and bounds of an actual survey had for that purpose, of the land or real estate sought to be con-
demned. Third. The purpose for which the same is proposed to be taken and applied. Fourth. The supposed value of the property sought to be condemned. Fifth. The prayer that the same be con-
demned to the public use for the purpose as stated. And upon the filing of such petition like proceedings shall be had thereon as in other civil suits; and when personal service cannot be had, by reason of the defendant being a non-resident or unknown, service by publi-
cation shall be made as provided in other cases in the district court;
Laws of the State of Texas.and upon trial the court shall proceed to render judgment, con-
demning the land to public use upon the payment of the value thereof as assessed by the jury; and upon any suit being brought thereafter against the said corporation for such property so con-
demned, a copy of the judgment and an actual tender of the money into court shall be a sufficient answer in bar of any such suit.

Sec. 3. All costs of proceedings for the condemnation of land and real estate under this act shall be taxed against and paid by the corporation, including the fees of the attorney, which the court shall appoint to represent the defendants cited by publication.
Sec. 4. This act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXXV.

opener.salute: An Act to amend an act entitled “An Act to incorporate the city of Columbus,” and for other purposes, approved August 5, 1870.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That so much of the above mentioned act as extends the cor-
porate limits of Columbus, east of Forrest street, south of Wallace street, and west of a street west of the cemetery, and parallel to Ramport street, be and the same is hereby repealed.
Sec. 2. That this act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXXVI.

opener.salute:
An Act to organize and incorporate the Marshall, Texas, and Mans-
field, Louisiana, Railroad Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That M. J. Hall, James H. Starr, A. M. Burnham, W. T.
Laws of the State of Texas.Scott, E. A. Blanch, J. B. Williamson, Dushee McKay, Wm. Sted-
man, S. B. Hendricks, Drury Fields, Thomas Black, Holland An-
derson, Wm. Undenstock, James Turner, G. B. Lipscomb, M. D. Ector, and such others as they may associate with them, be and they are hereby created a body corporate, and politic by the name and style of the “Marshall, Texas, and Mansfield, Louisiana, Railroad Company,” and by such name they may sue and be sued, make contracts, have and hold property, real, personal and mixed, by grant, gift, donation or purchase, or may sell, transfer or alienate the same. Said corporators, their successors or assigns, shall have succession for the term of ninety-nine years, and shall have and use a corporate seal.

Sec. 2. Said persons named in this charter or a majority of them, shall constitute the first board of directors. They shall have the right to elect a president, vice president, secretary, treasurer and attorney. The other officers and agents shall be appointed in such manner as the board of directors may determine. The said board of directors, or a majority thereof, shall have power to make by-laws, rules and regulations for their government, so as to carry out the intents of this act, and to appoint an executive committee, and to confer upon it such powers as they may see fit, not incon-
sistent with the laws of this State or of the United States; to pro-
vide for the future election of officers, and fix the place of superin-
tendents’ and engineers’ office on the line, and to change the same at pleasure along said line; to provide for the issue and transfer of stock, to provide for the issue of the bonds of the company, to mort-
gage and hypothecate the road bed, rolling stock, and all other prop-
erty of said company to raise funds to build or equip said road.

Sec. 3. Said company shall have the right to construct and op-
erate a first class single or double track railroad from Marshall, in Harrison county, to Elysian Fields, in said county, thence by the most practicable route through the county of Panola to the Louisi-
ana State line, so as to connect with any other road or roads enter-
ing the State of Texas from the State of Louisiaana. With the right to cross any other railroad track or tracks.

Sec. 4. Said company shall have the right of way along their entire route, not to exceed two hundred feet in width over all the public lands of this State, and free use of lumber, timber, gravel and earth, from the same, and the terms of the general laws of this State, to procure the release of the right of way from the owners of the lands along the route, to the extent of two hundred feet in width, with sufficient additional width of land for purposes of depots, machine shops, stock yards, switches or side tracks, wells, water
Laws of the State of Texas.tanks and stations; said company being required to establish stations at such places as shall be conducive to the interest of the people along the line, and not detrimental to the interest of the company; and shall have the right to construct and operate a telegraph line along the entire route.

Sec. 5. Said sompany shall have the right to build and con-
struct bridges across all streams or bodies of water along their line; provided, that no right is given to obstruct navigation.

Sec. 6. The capital stock of said company shall be two million of dollars, with the privilege of increasing the same not to exceed ten millions of dollars, divided into shares of one hundred dollars each.

Sec. 7. Said company may begin the construction of said road at any point or points along their line that they may deem proper, or at as many different points along said route as may be thought to the interest of said company, and shall have completed and in run-
ning order the said road to the Louisiana State line within three years from and after passage of this act; provided, that if said com-
pany should fail to construct their road within the time above men-
tioned, they shall forfeit all rights and franchises conferred by this charter upon all of said route not then in actual operation; and provided further, that should such failure be caused by war, epi-
demic, revolution and floods, such time shall be excepted from the limitation above mentioned, and shall not work a forfeiture in any respect.
Sec. 8. Said company shall receive such aid and immunities as may be granted to any railroad under any general law.

Sec. 9. Said company may locate their road upon the best and most practicable ground, and select the most suitable points for crossing or bridging streams or water courses on said line; provided, they do not vary more than ten miles from an air line to the right or left of the points named in the body of this charter.
Sec. 10. Said company may adopt the gauge of any road with which they may connect

Sec. 11. Said company shall have the right to join stocks or consolidate with any other company running in the same general di-
rection either in or out of this State, to receive subscriptions or loans from any county on its line, or adjacent thereto, or from any person, company, corporation, city or town, either in bonds, money, land or other property, the same to be used in the aid of said rail-
road, or may receive donations of lands or other property from in-
dividuals.

Sec. 12. That the incorporators named in the first section of this act, or a majority of them, shall meet and organize said com-
pany in ninety days after the passage of this act.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p: Sec. 13. The legal domicil of said company shall be in the city of Marshall.
Sec. 14. That this act take effect from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXXVII.

opener.salute: An Act to Incorporate the East Fork Plank Road Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That P. D. Crume, L. D. Walton, and such other persons as they may associate with them, are hereby declared a body corpo-
rate, to be named and styled the “East Fork Plank Road Com-
pany,” and under such name may sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, and shall have, own and use a corporate seal, and shall have succession for a term of twenty years, and shall have the right to own, hold and use property, real and personal, for the purposes hereinafter set forth, to the extent of fifty thousand dollars.

Sec. 2. That the said East Fork Plank Road Company shall have the right and are hereby authorized and empowered to con-
struct a plank road across the East Pork bottom, on the road lead-
ing from Plano, Collin county, Texas, to Greenville, Hunt county, Texas, crossing said river at Crume’s bridge, in Collin county, Texas.

Sec. 3. That said company shall commence the construction of said plank road on or before the first day of October, A. D. 1871, and shall complete the same within two years from the commence-
ment thereof; and from and after the completion of said plank road the said company shall cross over all manner of property and pas-
sengers, and shall keep said road and bridge, in good condition, and open for crossing day and night, and shall be responsible for all damages or losses, or injuries to persons or property.

Sec. 4. That said company, after the completion of their plank road, shall have the right to charge, demand and receive from all persons passing over said road the following rates of toll or pay, viz: For every six-horse wagon and team, one dollar; for every four-horse wagon and team, seventy-five cents; for every two-horse wagon and team, fifty cents; for every buggy and horse, twenty-
five cents; for every man and horse, ten cents; for every footman, five cents, for every ox wagon, twenty-five cents; for every yoke
Laws of the State of Texas.of cattle, twenty-five cents; for every head of led or loose horses, or cattle, two and one-half cents; for every hog, sheep or goat, one cent. All other kinds of property not herein provided for shall be charged rates in due proportion to the above; provided, that when said company shall have completed the road on the side of the river having the greatest width of bottom, the said company may charge one-half of the above rates of toll.

Sec. 5. That said, company shall have the right and they are hereby authorized to acquire any and all ferry franchises and privi-
leges now held or owned by persons over or across the said East Fork of the Trinity river, within two miles of said road and bridge, and no person or company, from and after the passage of this act, shall have the right to build or construct any road or bridge within two miles of said road; provided, that this act shall not prevent any railroad company from the erection of a bridge or bridges for rail-
road purposes.

Sec. 6. That the aforesaid corporators shall open books in the towns of McKinney, Plano and Millwood, in Collin county, and at the town of Rockwall, in Kaufman county, Texas, for subscriptions to the capital stock, which shall be at least fifty thousand dollars, and divided into shares of fifty dollars each; and as soon as five thousand dollars shall be subscribed the corporators shall call a meeting of said stockholders, who shall proceed to elect a president, secretary and three directors, whose duty it shall be to control the affairs of said corporation; and said president, secretary and direc-
tors shall hold their offices for one year, and until their successors are duly qualified.
Sec. 7. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

The foregoing act, received in the office of Secretary of State May eleventh, one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one, having been presented to the Governor of Texas for his approval, and not having been returned by him to the house in which it originated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has become a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXXVIII.

opener.salute: An Act for the relief of James E. Carlton, sheriff of Jasper county.

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the Treasurer of the State be and he is hereby authorized to refund to James E. Carlton, sheriff of Jasper county, the sum of five hundred and fifty dollars paid by him into the Treasury, the same having been collected by him through misconstruction of the tax law, as a tax on vocations under the tax law approved August 15, 1870.

Sec. 2. That the sum of five hundred and fifty dollars be and the same is hereby appropriated out of any money in the Treasury not otherwise appropriated, to pay said sum; and that this act shall be sufficient authority for the Treasurer of the State to pay the same.
Sec. 3. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXXIX.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the town of Ledbetter, County of Fayette.

div3.p: Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas as follows:

div4.head: Article One—Boundaries of the Town of Ledbetter.
div4.p:
That all that part of the county of Fayette within the following limits, to-wit: Beginning at the northern corner of a survey of one league, in the name of heirs of DeWitt, situated in Fayette county, on the waters of Cummings creek; thence with its north line south, forty-five degrees west, nineteen hundred varas; thence south forty-five degrees east, nineteen hundred varas; thence west forty-five degrees east, nineteen hundred varas to the eastern
Laws of the State of Texas.line of said survey; thence north forty-five degrees west, nineteen hundred varas, with said eastern line to the place of beginning, in-
cluding one square mile, shall constitute the town of Ledbetter.

div4.head: Article Two.
div4.p:
That the inhabitants of the town of Ledbetter, as the same ex-
tends and is laid out as above, and their successors, be and are hereby constituted a corporation and body politic, in fact and in law, by the name and style of the “Town of Ledbetter,” and by that name shall have succession; shall sue and be sued, implead and be impleaded, defend and be defended in all courts of law and equity, and in all actions whatsoever.

div4.head: Article Three.
div4.p:
That there shall be a town council to consist of a mayor and board of aldermen; that the board of aldermen shall consist of four members, to be Chosen for two years by the qualified voters; and no person shall be an alderman unless he be a citizen of the State of Texas and a bona fide resident of the town, and shall have resided within the town limits for six months preceding his election. That if any alderman shall, after his election, remove from the town, his office shall thereby be vacated. The town council shall judge of the election returns and the qualifications of its members, and shall de-
termine contested elections. The majority of the town council shall constitute a quorum to do business; but a smaller number may ad-
journ from day to day, and may compel the attendance of absent members in such manner and under such penalties as they may pre-
scribe. The town council may determine the rules of its proceed-
ings, and punish its members for disorderly behavior. All elections of officers shall be governed by the general law of the State con-
cerning elections, and no property qualification for voters shall ever be required.

div4.head: Article Four—Sessions of the Town Council.
div4.p:
That all ordinances of the town council shall be read on three different days, and a majority of the votes of the town council shall be necessary to pass all ordinances, aud on the passage of all ordi-
nances the yeas and nays shall be recorded.

div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div4.head: Article Five—General Powers of the Mayor and Town Council.
div4.p:
That the mayor and town council shall have power within the town by ordinance. First, to make regulations for preventing the introduction of contagious diseases into the town. Second, to estab-
lish a hospital, and to make regulations for the government thereof. Third, to make regulations to secure the general health of the in-
habitants, and prevent and remove nuisances. Fourth, to erect a market house and market place, and to provide for the government thereof. Fifth, to license, tax and regulate billiard tables, tippling houses and dram shops, and to suppress gaming and gambling houses and other disorderly houses. Sixth, to provide for the preven-
tion and extinguishment of fires, and organizing and establishing fire companies, and to regulate and restrain the carrying on of man-
ufactures dangerous in causing or producing fires. Seventh, to estab-
lish standard weights and measures, and to regulate the weights and measures to be used in the town, in all cases not otherwise provided by law. Eight, to fix the compensation of the town officers not otherwise provided for, and to regulate the fees of all jurors, wit-
nesses and others for services rendered under this act or under an ordinance. Ninth, to regulate the police of the town; to impose fines, forfeitures and penalties; to provide for the recovery and ap-
propriation of such fines and forfeitures, and the enforcement of such penalties; provided, no fine shall exceed one hundred dollars, nor shall any term of imprisonment exceed fifteen days for any one offense. Tenth, to prevent the assemblage of idle persons at or near store house doors, whereby the trade of such store is interrupted, and also to prevent or restrain any riot, disturbance or disorderly as-
semblage in any street, house or place in town. Eleventh, to prevent and remove all encroachments upon all streets, lanes, avenues and alleys established by law or ordinance. Twelfth, to exercise com-
plete and perfect control over the common and all property belong-
ing to the town, real or personal, whether lying within or beyond its limits of the corporation created by this act, and the same to lease, sell, transfer and dispose of, either absolutely or within limitations, to any person or persons whomsoever, and generally to make such rules, regulations, by-laws and ordinances, for the purpose of main-
taining the peace, good order and government of the “Town of Led-
better,” and the trade, commerce and manufactures thereof, as the council may deem expedient, and as may not be repugnant to the laws and Constitution of the State, and to enforce the observances of said rules, regulations, by-laws and ordinances, by inflicting penalties for the violation thereof, not exceeding one hundred dollars for any one
Laws of the State of Texas.offense, recoverable with costs in any action of debt, by and in the name of the “Town of Ledbetter,” for the use of the town, before any court having cognizance of the same.

div4.head: Article Six.
div4.p: That the mayor shall be the chief executive officer of the town, and shall be elected by the qualified voters thereof, and shall hold his office for the term of two years. His salary shall be fixed by the aldermen of the town, but shall not in any event exceed the sum of one hundred dollars per annum and his fees of office.

div4.head: Article Seven.
div4.p:
That there shall be a town marshal, whose duties shall be the same as those of other peace officers, and such other duties as may be prescribed by ordinances. The marshal shall be elected by the qualified voters of the town, for the term of two years, and shall re-
ceive such salary, besides his fees of office, as the mayor and board of aldermen may by by-law determine.

div4.head: Article Eight.
div4.p:
That the mayor and the other officers of the corporation shall reside within the limits of the town during their continuance in of-
fice; and if the mayor shall cease to reside within the limits of the town his office shall thereby be vacated. The mayor shall have the same jurisdiction as justices of the peace within the limits of the town in all State cases; he shall have jurisdiction over all cases aris-
ing under any ordinance of the town, subject to an appeal or writ of certiorari, in all cases, to the district court; and every such appeal shall be taken and granted in the same manner as appeals or writs of certiorari are taken and granted from the justice’s court to the dis-
trict court, under the general laws of the State. He shall charge, in all cases, the same fees as are now allowed to justices of the peace for the same kind of services, which fees shall be charged and collected as other costs, and he shall act as president of the board of aldermen.

div4.head: Article Nine.
div4.p: The mayor shall be authorized to procure a seal for the use of his office, on which shall be engraved, “Town of Ledbetter, Mayor’s Office.”

div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div4.head: Article Ten.
div4.p:
That from and after the passage of this act it shall be unlawful to fire any pistol, rifle, shot gun, or other kind of fire arms, within the limits of the town of Ledbetter, and any person violating this act shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and on conviction thereof shall be fined not less than five nor more than twenty-five dollars, to be collected by the mayor of the town; but this act shall not prevent any gunsmith within the limits of the town from discharging, on the premises thereof, fire arms made or repaired in his shop, for the purpose of training such fire arms; provided, that none but gun-
smiths shall have the privilege of being authorized to discharge fire arms; and for that purpose each gunsmith shall build a rock wall, in front of which he shall cause a target to be placed. The mayor shall issue to any gunsmith applying for the same, for the period of one year, which permit may be renewed after its expiration.

div4.head: Article Eleven.
div4.p:
Whoever shall in this town set up or keep any gaming table or gambling device, at which any game of chance shall be played for money or property, or anything representing money or property, or shall at any such table or device, or at any game of chance, bet, win or loose any money or property, either in specie or by means of any-
thing representing the same, or shall suffer any such table or device at which any game of chance is played, to be set up or used in any tenement in his possession or under his control, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and forfeit and pay a sum as is by statute in such case made and provided; and it shall be the duty of the mayor, on receiving satisfactory information of any such table or device being so set up and used, to issue his warrant to the city mar-
shal commanding him to destroy the same, which warrant shall be immediately executed.

div4.head: Article Twelve.
div4.p:
Whoever in this town shall keep a bawdy house, house of ill-fame or assignation, or shall permit any tenement in his possession or un-
der his control to be used for any such purpose, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and shall forfeit and pay not less than a sum of twenty dollars.

div4.head: Article Thirteen.
div4.p:
That it shall not be lawful for any person to establish a slaughter
Laws of the State of Texas.house within the corporate limits of the town without the permis-
sion of the town council, nor shall it be lawful for any person to slaughter any butcher’s meat of any kind within said corporate limits, except for the use of the person so slaughtering. Auy per-
son or persons so offending shall be deemed guilty of a misde-
meanor, and on conviction thereof shall be fined not less than ten dollars for each offense.

div4.head: Article Fourteen.
div4.p:
That any person offering to sell fresh meats by retail in the town before first procuring a license so to do shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and on conviction thereof shall be fined not less than five nor more than ten dollars: but this article shall not be so con-
strued as to prohibit any person from selling beef by the quarter, or pork or mutton by the quarter.

div4.head: Article Fifteen.
div4.p:
That this act shall take effect from and after its passage, and shall be subject to the provisions of an act entitled “An act to au-
thorize the Governor to appoint certain officers to fill vacancies,” approved June 28, 1870.

div4.head: CHAPTER CXXX.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the town of Linden, Davis County.

div4.p: Section. 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the citizens of the town of Linden, in Davis county, be and they are hereby declared a body politic and corporate under the name and style of the “Corporation of the Town of Linden,” and by that name shall have power to sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, and to hold and dispose of property, real and personal; provided, such real property is situated within the limits of said corporation.
Sec. 2. That the limits of said corporation shall extend one mile in a square, so laid off as to leave the public square in the centre of said corporation.
div4.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div4.p:
Sec. 3. That it shall be the duty of the citizens of said corpora-
tion to elect a mayor, five, aldermen, and a constable, who shall also be ex officio assessor and collector of taxes; and a treasurer and sec-
tary shall be elected by said mayor and aldermen. The treasurer and assessor and collector of taxes shall be required to give bond, with security, to be approved by the presiding officer, for the faith-
ful performance of their duties, and to make reports, when required by the mayor or board of aldermen; and the mayor shall have power, when necessary, to suppress riots and disturbances, and to call out the citizens of said corporation for the purpose of restoring order.

Sec. 4. The mayor, aldermen and constable shall, for the pres-
ent time, and until the next general election, be appointed as pro-
vided for, in an act entitled “An act to authorize the Governor to appoint certain officers to fill vacancies,” and upon the expiration of their term of office, there shall be an election held under the direction of the mayor, who shall give at least ten days’ notice of such election before his term of office shall expire; and said elec-
tions for the offices as aforesaid shall be held every two years there-
after; and all inhabitants who have resided within its limits for the space of four months preceding, and who are qualified voters under the Constitution and laws of this State, shall be deemed qualified electors of said corporation.

Sec. 5. That the mayor and board of aldermen of said corpora-
tion shall have power to pass such rules, regulations and ordinances as may be necessary for the regulation of the police, and the preser-
vation of order within the corporate limits, for the levying of taxes; for the removal of nuisances, and keeping the streets in good order; for building a market house; for improving and ornamenting public property within said corporate limits, and for any and all other purposes tending to promote good order and government; and they shall have power to prescribe and enforce the collection of penalties for the violation of the ordinances of the corporation; provided, no tax shall ever be levied exceeding one-half of the State tax allowed by law; and provided further, that they shall in no case prescribe penalties to exceed one hundred dollars, or imprisonment for more than one week.

Sec. 6. That the mayor, with a majority of the board of alder-
men, shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business, and in the absence of the mayor, the board of aldermen shall elect one of their number mayor pro tempore.
Sec. 7. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage, and that all acts and parts of acts in conflict herewith are hereby repealed.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXXXI.

opener.salute: An Act to authorize W. W. Knight to erect a toll bridge over Waxahachie creek, Ellis county, Texas.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That W. W. Knight, of the county of Ellis, be and he is hereby authorized and empowered to erect a toll bridge over Waxa-
hachie creek, at or near where the public road leading from the town of Waxahachie to the town of Milford crosses said creek; and he is hereby authorized to charge, collect and receive toll for cross-
ing the same at the following rates, to-wit: For man and horse, ten cents; for every vehicle, with one or two animals, twenty-five cents; for each additional animal, ten cents; for loose stock, horses or cat-
tle, five cents per head; for sheep, goats or hogs, two cents per head.

Sec. 2. That the rights and privileges herein granted shall inure to the said W. W. Knight, his heirs and assigns, for five years from from the passage hereof, with remainder to the county of Ellis for twenty years; provided, however, that in order to secure the bene-
fits and privileges of this act said W. W. Knight, his heirs and as-
signs, shall, within twelve months from the passage of this act, erect and construct a good, safe and substantial bridge over said Waxa-
hachie creek at the place aforesaid, and shall keep the same in good repair for a period of ten years, without expense to said Ellis coun-
ty; and provided, further, that no person or persons shall be allowed to build a bridge or construct a crossing on said creek within one mile of said bridge; and provided, further, that all resident citizens of Ellis county shall pass over said bridge free of charge.

Sec. 3. That when said bridge shall have been completed said W. W. Knight, his heirs and assigns, shall have authority to charge, collect and receive tolls according to the rates specified in section one; and, at the expiration of five years from the passage hereof, shall turn over said bridge with all its franchises to the county court of said Ellis county, and shall give satisfactory security that said bridge shall be kept in good repair for five additional years.
Sec. 4. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

The foregoing act, received in the office of Secretary of State May eleventh, one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one, having been presented to the Governor of Texas for his approval,
Laws of the State of Texas.and not having been returned by him to the house in which it origi-
nated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has become a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXXXII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Gymnastic Association of Yorktown.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That C. H. Heissig, Jacob Guggenheim, C. Dahlman, L. Riedesel, Hermann Kurst, H. Menn, Ch. Stephen, Jack Friar, T. H. Chote, Herman Eckhaxdt, and their associates, be and they are hereby constituted a body corporate and politic for gymnastic pur-
poses, and for the encouragement of bodily exercise, and for other purposes, under the name and style of the “Gymnastic Association of Yorktown,” and by that name shall have succession, and shall have the right to sue and be sued; to plead and be impleaded in any of the courts of this State; to acquire and hold estate, real, personal and mixed, and to sell, alienate, trade or otherwise dispose of the same as said association may see fit; provided, that the amount of property held by said association shall at no time exceed the sum of twenty-five thousand dollars.

Sec. 2. That said association shall be governed by such officers and trustees as it may deem expedient, and the said association shall have power to enact by-laws, rules and regulations for its govern-
ment, and to amend the same, not inconsistent with the laws of this State. The said association shall have a common seal.
Sec. 3. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage, and shall expire after the period of twenty years unless sooner renewed.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXXXIII.

opener.salute:
An Act to amend sections two and twelve of “An Act to incorpo-
rate the Hempstead, Eastern and Western Trunk Railway Com-
pany of Texas.”

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That section two of the above entitled act, approved August 12, 1870, shall be so amended as to read as follows: “That said com-
pany is hereby invested with the right to locate, construct, own, operate and maintain a railway and telegraph line, commencing at the town of Hempstead, in Austin county, and extending eastwardly to the town of Montgomery, thence to a bluff on the west bank of the Trinity river, immediately below he mouth of Pool’s Creek, in San Jacinto county; thence to the town of Sumpter, in Trinity county; thence to the town of Homer; thence to Loganspont on the Sabine river, or to some point on the Texas and Louisiana line, south of Logansport, so as to connect with a railroad to be con-
structed to the Texas line from the road from New Orleans to Shreveport, or to make any suitable connection with any such road south of Red River. The western trunk shall extend from the town of Hempstead in a southwesterly direction via Bellville, on the most practicable route to the point on the Rio Grande, at which the In-
ternational Railroad will cross said stream.”

Sec. 2. That section twelve shall thereafter read as follows: “That said company shall commence the construction of said railway at the town of Hempstead, within twelve months from the passage of this act, and shall construct fifteen miles of the Western Trunk within three years, and shall construct and equip the Eastern Trunk as far as Sumpter, Trinity, county, within five years.”
Sec. 3. That this act take effect and be in force ninety-nine years from and after its passage.

The foregoing act, received in the office of Secretary of State May sixteenth, one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one, having been presented to the Governor of Texas for his approval, and not having been returned by him to the house in which it originated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has become a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXXXIV.

opener.salute: An Act to authorize the board of aldermen of the city of Waco to lease a part of the ground on the public square of said city for certain purposes.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the board of aldermen of the city of Waco be and they are hereby empowered and authorized to lease for a term not exceeding ten years, such a part of the ground on the public square of said city of Waco as they may deem most suitable and convenient to the public, to such person or persons as may contract for the Same, for the porpose of erecting thereon proper and convenient scales, and a building for an office in connection therewith, under such regula-
tions and on such terms as may be agreed upon between said board of aldermen of the city of Waco and the person or persons to whom said ground shall be leased.
Sec. 2. That this act take effect from and after its passage.

The foregoing act, received in the office of Secretary of State May eleven, one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one, having been presented to the Governor of Texas for his approval, and not having been returned by him to the house in which it originated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has become a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXXXV.

opener.salute: An Act to authorize the fire engine, the hook and ladder and the hose companies, of the city of Galveston, to increase the number of men in each company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That it shall be lawful for each fire engine and hook and
Laws of the State of Texas.ladder company of the city of Galveston to increase the number of its members to any number not to exceed sixty-five men, and for each hose company to increase the number of its members to any number not to exceed forty men.

Sec. 2. That all laws and parts of laws conflicting with the provisions of this act be and the same are hereby repealed; and that this act shall be in force and take effect from and after its passage.

The foregoing act, received in the office of Secretary of State May eleven, one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one, having been presented to the Governor of Texas for his approval, and not having been returned by him to the house in which it orig-
inated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has become a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXXXVI.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Merchants’ and Planters’ Savings Bank of Texas.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That James H. Raymond, Eugene Bremond, John M. Swisher, John J. Anderson, James S. Clark, William S. Swymner, J. W. Allen, and such other persons as may hereafter be associated with them, and their successors, are hereby constituted a body cor-
porate under the name of the Merchants’ and Planters’ Savings Bank of Texas, to be located in the city of Austin, and by that name shall have succession for fifty years, and may sue and be sued, and shall possess such powers and privileges as are in this act con-
ferred upon the said corporation.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, etc., That the capital stock of the said corporation shall be one hundred thousand dollars, in shares of one hundred dollars each, but the same may be increased from time to time by a vote of the majority in interest of the stockholders of said corporation voting in person or by proxy, at any meeting duly held; provided, that the capital stock of said corporation shall never exceed two millions of dollars; such additional stock, as
Laws of the State of Texas.often as authorized, shall be offered for subscription to the actual stockholders proportionately to the amount of stock owned and held by them respectively, and any additional stock not taken by the stockholders entitled to subscribe for the same, or a pro rata distribution shall be thereupon offered to the other stockholders pro rata; and if not taken by them it may then be offered to other parties, and no shares of stock shall be offered or sold for less than their par value.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, etc., That the corporators men-
tioned in section one of this act shall open subscription books at such time and place as they may deem proper, and said subscrip-
tion books shall be kept open until one thousand shares of the capi-
tal stock of said corporation shall have been subscribed for. At least ten per cent. of the amount of each subscription shall be paid at the time the subscription is made, or the same shall be rejected. When the said boobs of subscription shall be closed the said corpo-
rators shall proceed to distribute the capital stock to those entitled thereto by the subscriptions; and in case there shall be more than one thousand shares subscribed for, it shall be the duty of said cor-
