porators to apportion stock to the extent of one thousand shares among the subscribers in the proportion which the amount of each subscription shall bear to the whole amount of all the subscrip-
tions, and no one of the corporators shall directly or indirectly, or any one in trust for him, subscribe for and receive more than one hundred shares of said stock. The said corporators shall within thirty days after the subscription books are closed and the stock apportioned, call a meeting of the stockholders to be held within thirty days after the date of such call, at a place which shall be named in the call, at which, meeting the stockholders shall elect from out of their number a board of five directors, who shall be the directors of the corporation for the ensuing year, and until oth-
ers are elected in their places; the directors of the corporation shall have power to require the stockholders to make a payment of their subscription at such times, in such proportions and on such notice as such directors shall prescribe, under penalty of forfeiture to said corporation in case of default of the shares upon which such pay-
ments shall be required and all previous payments thereon; the said corporation may sue for and recover the amount of such calls in its discretion, and when the amount of fifty thousand dollars of the stock of said corporation shall be paid up in cash the directors may organize by electing one of their number president and by the ap-
pointment of a cashier and such other officers and agents as they may deem necessary, and may then transact business as authorized by this act.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, etc., That the said corporation
Laws of the State of Texas.shall have the power of carrying on the business of banking by the purchase and discounting of bills, notes and other evidences of debt, at such rates of interest as its directors shall prescribe, by receiving deposits, by buying and selling foreign coin, gold and silver bullion and bills of exchange, and by issuing letters of credit and certifi-
cates of deposit. It shall also be lawful for the said corporation to make cash advances on cotton, sugar, wheat and other products of this State for shipment to domestic or foreign ports, to advance moneys to planters upon real or personal security, and to guarantee the punctual payment, performance and collection of promissory notes, bills of exchange, contracts, bonds, accounts, claims, rents, annuities, mortgages, choses in action and evidences of debt on such terms as to interest, commissions and compensation, and with such stipulations and provisions to enforcing liens and converting securities as may be prescribed by the directors of said corporation, and agreed to by the parties to any such transactions, and all such stipulations and provisions shall be lawful, and may be enforced and carried into effect subject to the general laws of the State; said corporation shall also possess and may exercise all incidental powers needful in conducting its said business.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted, etc., That it shall be lawful for the said corporation to employ all surplus capital or funds as may belong or accrue to the said corporation in the purchase of govern-
ment or other bonds, or in any other moneyed transactions, not in-
consistent with the Constitution and laws of the State, for the bene-
fit of said corporation.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted, etc., That the business and the corporate powers of said corporation shall be conducted and exer-
cised by a board of not less than five directors, and such officers and agents as such board shall appoint or authorize to be appointed, and empower or authorize to be empowered, to conduct any part of said business or exercise any of said powers, in accordance with its by-
laws. No person shall be a director who is not a holder of at least ten shares of the stock of said corporation; the directors may be elected annually by the stockholders, personally or by proxy, on such days as shall be provided by the by-laws, or designated at the next preceding election, and the directors shall have power to fill vacancies in their number caused by death or resignation.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted, etc., That it shall be lawful for the said corporation to purchase, hold and take security upon, and to sell, mortgage, lease, convey and dispose of real and personal property of every description, as fully and effectually as natural persons, not subject to legal disability, may lawfully do.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted, etc., That the directors, after
Laws of the State of Texas.each annual election, shall elect one of their number president of said corporation, and shall have power from time to time to appoint clerks, agents, attorneys and servants for carrying on the business of said corporation, with such powers and for such compensation as shall be deemed meet; and said directors shall also have power to make and prescribe such by-laws, rules and regulations, and from time to time to alter, amend or revoke the same, as they shall see fit, touching the government of said corporation, the transfer of its stock, the election of its officers, the management and disposition of its business, property and effects, the powers and conduct of its offi-
cers and agents, and all-other matters which Shall in any way per-
tain to the concern of said corporation.

Sec. 9. Be it further enacted, etc., That it shall be lawful for the said corporation to establish such and so many branch offices in this State and in such localities therein, and with powers to exercise such of its rights and privileges, and to constitute such fiscal agen-
cies in places beyond the limits of this State as its directors shall from time to time provide.

Sec. 10. Be it further enacted, etc., That this corporation shall be authorized to receive on deposit public or private trust funds, for which they may allow such rate of interest as may be agreed upon.
Sec. 11. That this act take effect and be in force for fifty years from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXXXVII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the town of Waxahachie, in Ellis County.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the citizens of the town of Waxahachie, in Ellis county, be and they are hereby declared a body corporate and poli-
tic, and under the style of the “Town of Waxahachie” may sue and be sued in all courts and suits whatever; and may purchase, hold and convey any real or personal estate within the limits of said town, and may have a corporate seal.
Sec. 2. That the limits of said town corporation shall extend to the present limits of said town, or one mile square.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p: Sec. 3. That all persona who are qualified voters under the Constitution of the State, and who have been citizens of said town thirty days next preceding an election, shall be authorized to vote in elections held in said corporation.

Sec. 4. That the qualified, electors of said corporation shall (as soon as authorized by law to do so) elect a mayor and five aldermen, who shall hold their offices for the term of two years thereafter and until their successors shall be elected and qualified.

Sec. 5. That there shall be a constable, treasurer, recorder and attorney of said corporation, who shall hold their offices for the term of one year and until their successors be appointed and quali-
fied; said officers shall be appointed at a regular meeting of the board of aldermen by a vote of two-thirds of the aldermen present; said appointments shall be made as soon as practicable after the aldermen shall have received their certificates of election, and as soon as practicable after any vacancies from resignation, death, ex-
piration of term of office, or other cause may occur.

Sec. 6. That at all elections held under this act the board of aldermen shall appoint judges of said election, who shall take an oath faithfully and impartially to discharge their duties. They shall open the polls at ten o’clock, A. M., and close the same at four o’clock P. M., on the day of election, and shall Within twenty-four hours thereafter make return of said election to the mayor, or in case of his absence or inability to act, or of a vacancy in his office, then the recorder and board of aldermen shall open such returns and determine the result of the election, and immediately issue cer-
tificates thereof to the persons elected.
Sec. 7. That when an election for mayor stall be contested, the board of aldermen shall determine such content.

Sec. 8. That in case of Vacancy in the office of mayor, the board of aldermen shall order an election to fill such vacancy; such elec-
tion shall be held as provided in this act for regular elections; and in case of vacancy in the office of alderman, such vacancy shall be filled at a regular meeting of the board of aldermen, by a vote of two-thirds of the aldermen present, and the person so appointed shall hold his office for the unexpired term.

Sec. 9. In case of the temporary absence of the mayor, the board of aldermen shall have the power to appoint one of their number to act as mayor pro tempore, who shall have the same powers and privileges as the mayor elect, and such appointment shall expire on the return of the mayor.

Sec. 10. That the mayor, when present, shall preside over the board of aldermen, and in case of a tie in the vote of the board, shall give the casting vote; provided, that three of the aldermen,
Laws of the State of Texas.either with or without the mayor, shall constitute a quorum to transact business.

Sec. 11. That the major, in addition to his powers and juris-
diction as such, is hereby vested with all the powers and jurisdic-
tion, civil and criminal, within the limits of said corporation, which may be by law exercised by justices of the peace under the laws of the State, and he shall be entitled to have and receive such fees as are or may be by law allowed to justices of the peace for similar services.

Sec. 12. The mayor, constable, recorder, treasurer and attorney of said corporation may be removed from office for any neglect of duty, misdemeanor or malfeasance in office, by a vote of two-thirds of the aldermen at a regular meeting of the board.

Sec. 13. That the mayor and aldermen shall have the power to enact such by-laws and ordinances or the government of said corpo-
ration, and for the quiet, peace, good order and happiness of the citi-
zens of the same, not inconsistent with the laws of the State, as may be deemed proper, and may impose fines and penalties for the violation of the same, not to exceed one hundred dollars in any one case.
Sec. 14. That the mayor and aldermen shall have and exercise control over the public square, streets, sidewalks and roads within said corporation.

Sec. 15. That the board of aldermen shall have power to levy and provide for the collection of an ad valorem tax on property situated in said corporation, taxable by the general law of the State, and also the power to levy and collect a poll tax not to exceed one dollar each, on all male persons of said corporation over the age of twenty-one years and under the age of fifty-five years, which tax shall be collected in such manner as may be provided by the by-laws of said corporation; provided, said ad valorem tax shall not exceed one-half of one per centum on the value of the property taxed, and that it shall require the vote of two-thirds of the members of the board of aldermen to levy such tax, and the same shall be done at a regular meeting of the board.

Sec. 16. That the board of aldermen, shall have the power to license, tax and regulate hawkers, peddlers, auctions, theatricals, and other exhibitions, shows and amusements, billiard tables, nine and ten pan alleys, groceries, tippling houses and dram shops, and to determine the amount of tax upon the same, and to supppress gaming or gambling houses by whatever description known, and all disordorly houses.

Sec. 17. That all officers of said corporation shall, before enter-
ing upon the duties of their office, take and subscribe the oath pre-
Laws of the State of Texas.scribed by the Constitution; and the mayor, constable, and treas-
urer, shall also enter into a bond with two good securities, to be ap-
proved by the board of aldermen, for the faithful performance of their duties, payable to the said corporation, in such sum as the board of aldermen may require, which bond shall not be void on first recovery.

Sec. 18. That the constable, in addition to his powers and priv-
ileges as such, be and he is hereby vested with all the powers and privileges which, are now, or may be by law, exercised by the con-
stable of the beat in which said corporation is situated; and for all services which may be rendered by him he shall have the same fees which are, or may be by law, allowed to constables of the beat for similar services.

Sec. 19. That the fees of the aldermen shall not be more than two dollars for each and every regular meeting of the board at which they may be in attendance; provided, they shall not be en-
titled to charge for more than twelve meetings in any one year That the fees of the recorder shall not be more than two dollars for each and every meeting of the board at which lie may be in attend ance. The fees of the treasurer shall not be more than live per centum upon all moneys received and paid out by him. The corpo-
ration attorney shall be entitled to have and receive a tax fee of two dollars and fifty cents on each and every conviction under this act and the by-laws of said corporation, which fee the mayor shall in-
clude and tax in the bill of costs on said conviction; provided, that when any person shall have committed any offense against the laws of said corporation and shall plead guilty of the same, said tax shall not be allowed nor taxed. And the board of aldermen shall have the power to regulate the compensation of the officers of said cor-
poration not definitely fixed and provided for in this act.

Sec. 20. That in all prosecutions, trials and proceedings under this act and the by-laws of said corporation, the mayor and con-
stable shall be governed by the laws regulating proceedings in just-
ices’ courts, in force at the time of said proceedings, prosecutions and trials, and shall be entitled to the same fees as justices of the peace and constables for similar services.

Sec. 21. That the first election, as provided for in the fourth section of this act, for corporate officers, shall be held as may be provided for by law; that, for the present, the Governor be re-
quested to appoint the officers of said corporation.
Sec. 22. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

The foregoing act, receded in the office of Secretary of State
Laws of the State of Texas.May eleventh, one thousand, eight hundred and seventy-one, hav-
ing been presented to the Governor of Texas for his approval, and not having been returned by him to the house in which it origi-
nated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has become a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXXXVIII.

opener.salute: An act for the benefit of James S. Montgomery, Assignee of H. O. Harra.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the bounty warrant No. 9444, issued to J. S. Mont-
gomery, assignee of H. O. Harra, by W. G. Cook, acting Secretary of War, and approved by W. G. Cook, Adjutant General, January 31, 1840, and not presented to the Court of Claims for approval, be and the same is hereby confirmed as a valid claim, and that said certificate be located and surveyed as other certificates, and that this act take effect and be in from and after its passage.

The foregoing act, received in the office of secretary of State May eleventh, one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one, having been presented to the governor of Texas for his approval, and not having been returned by him to the house in which it originated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has become a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXXXIX.

opener.salute: An Act for the relief of James Henderson.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted fey the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the Commissioner of the General Land Office be and he is hereby authorized and required to issue to James Henderson an unconditional land certificate for six hundred and forty acres of
Laws of the State of Texas.land, in lieu of conditional certificate No. 357, second class, issued by the board of land commissioners for Bastrop county on the tenth day of August, 1839.
Sec. 2. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

The foregoing act, received in the office of the Secretary of State the thirteenth day of May, one thousand eight hundred and sev-
enty-one, having been presented to the Governor of Texas for his approval, and not having been returned by him to the house in which it originated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has become a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXL.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the town of Dangerfield, in Titus County.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the citizens of the town of Dangerfield, Titus county, be and they are hereby declared a body politic and corporate under the name and style of the “Corporation of the Town of Danger-
field,” by which name they may sue and be sued, plead and be im-
pleaded, and acquire and hold real and personal property within the limits of said corporation, and at their pleasure sell and dispose of the same.

Sec. 2. That the limits of said corporation shall extend one mile in a square, so laid off as to have the west line to be one-fourth of a mile from the centre of the public square, and the north line one-fourth of a mile from the centre of the square.

Sec. 3. That it shall be the duty of the Governor to appoint a mayor and five aldermen and a constable, who shall hold their offices for the term of two years from the date of such appointment. The said mayor and aldermen shall elect a secretary and treasurer from their own body. The treasurer shall be required to give bond in a sum to be fixed by said mayor and aldermen, to be approved by the mayor, for the faithful performance of his duties, and shall make
Laws of the State of Texas.reports when required by the mayor and aldermen. The mayor shall have and exercise all the powers and jurisdiction of a justice of the peace, and before entering upon the discharge of the duties of his office shall take the oath prescribed in the Constitution, and give such bond with securities as justices of the peace are required to give, except the bond required to be given by a justice of the peace in his capacity of assessor of taxes. The constable shall have and exercise all the powers and discharge all the duties within said corporation of a constable of the county, and before entering upon the discharge of the duties of his office he shall give such bond with security as constables of the county are required to give, to be ap-
proved by the mayor. That said aldermen shall be required to take the oath prescribed in the Constitution of this State, for the faith-
ful performance of their duties as such aldermen.

Sec. 4. That the mayor and board of aldermen of said corpo-
ration shall have power to pass such rules and ordinances as may be necessary for the regulation of the police force and the preservation of order within the limits of said corporation; they shall have power to levy and collect, by ordinance, an ad valorem tax on all property, both real and personal, within said corporate limits; also a tax on occupations and a poll tax, not to exceed one dollar in any one year, from every male citizen between the ages of twenty-one and fifty years, within said corporate limits, and may prescribe penalties for violation of said ordinances or by-laws; provided, that in no case shall any penalty exceed the sum of one hundred dollars.

Sec. 5. The mayor, with a majority of said aldermen, shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business; they may enact and enforce such rules and regulations as they may deem necessary for the government of the said corporation; provided, that the same do not conflict with the Constitution or laws of this State.

Sec. 6. That no person shall be eligible to hold office in said corporation, or to vote for the officers thereof, unless he be a quali-
fied elector under the Constitution of this State, and shall have re-
sided in the limits of said corporation thirty days preceding any election which may be held in said corporation for the election of an officer or officers named in said corporation.

Sec. 7. That it shall be the duty of the mayor to cause an election to be held annually, at least ten days before the expiration of his term of office, and to fill vacancies which may occur, after giving at least ten days’ notice of said election by posting notices thereof in three public places in said town, for a mayor and five aldermen and a constable, who shall enter upon the duties of their offices respectively, upon the expiration of the term of office of their predecessors and compliance with the requirements of section three of this act.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p: Sec. 8. That in case of the failure of the mayor to order and hold such election as specified in the foregoing section, then any three citizens who are qualified electors within the limits of said corporation may, after giving ten days’ notice, order and hold said election.
Sec. 9. That this act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXLI.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Mansfield Male and Female College in Tarrant County.

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That Julian Field, L. H. Stephens, Win. Bratten, Joseph Nugent, J. N. Buchanan, W. D. Wear, E. Newton, R. Wallace, S. C. Graves, Richard Graves, Joseph Terrel, and their successors in office, be and they are hereby constituted a body corporate and politic for educational purposes, by the name and style of the Mansfield Male and Female College, by which name they may sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, and buy and sell property, real, personal and mixed, may have a seal to authenticate their acts for the purpose and object of maintaining an institution of learning at Mansfield, Tarrant county, Texas.

Sec. 2. That the management of said institution shall be Tested in the above named, and their successors, as a board of trustees, and they shall elect one of their number chairman of the board; they shall also elect one treasurer and secretary. The chairman shall preside at the meetings of said board, but in his absence a chairman pro tern, may be appointed by said board. The treasurer shall be elected for one year; he shall keep a fair record of all moneys, notes and papers of value received and paid out by him, paying out the same by order of the board of trustees, signed by the president of the board. He may at any time be removed for a direliction of duty by a two-thirds vote of the trustees, and shall keep a fair record of all its proceedings and resolutions, and also of such by-
laws and regulations as may be passed by said board, for the gov-
ernment of the school.

Sec. 3. No money shall be paid out of the treasury except by
Laws of the State of Texas.order of board of trustees or a majority of them, signed by the chairman. The said board shall have power to employ or elect one president and as many professors and teachers in the college as the educational interest may require, and they shall assign to all persons so employed their duties respectively and their salaries. They Shall have power to appropriate any money in the treasury, or that may come into the treasury by virtue of the public school fund to the payment of salaries of teachers of the college. The said board shall have power to enact such by-lays as they may deem necessary for the government of the college; provided, the same be not in contravention of the Constitution and laws of this State. The said board of trustees shall have power by a two-thirds vote of its mem-
bers to sell and dispose of any property of the said college, except the ground, buildings, books and apparatus used by said college; provided, that the proceeds of such sales shall be applied to advance the educational interests of the college.

Sec. 4. That the faculty shall consist of the president, profes-
sors and teachers, and shall have power to enforce all laws adopted by the board of trustees for the government of the college by such measures as may be considered reasonable, and shall have power to suspend any student who may knowingly violate the laws; which suspension shall last until the board of trustees can be convened, who conjointly with the faculty, shall have power to continue or remit the suspension; they shall also have power to expel disor-
derly students.

Sec. 5. That the board of trustees conjointly with the faculty, shall have power to confer such degrees in the arts and sciences upon any student of the college as they may consider worthy, as are usually conferred by other colleges, and to grant certificates thereof signed by the faculty and trustees, and they shall have a corporate seal by which their official acts shall be authenticated.

Sec. 6. That the corporation shall be competent to hold and receive contributions, gifts, donations and bequests of real and per-
sonal property of any kind, and all donations and bequests to said college shall be good and binding by the persons making the same; provided, however, that said college shall not hold property beyond the value of one hundred thousand dollars.
Sec. 7. This act shall take effect and be in force for fifty years from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXLII.

opener.salute:
An Act to incorporate the San Antonio and Sherman Bridge Com-
pany.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That a body politic and corporate be and the same is hereby created and established, under the name and style of the “San An-
tonio and Sherman Bridge Company,” with capacity to make con-
tracts, to have succession and a common seal, to make by-laws for its government, and in its corporate name to sue and be sued, and generally to do any act necessary to carry out the objects of the cor-
poration, not inconsistent with the laws of this State or of the United States.

Sec. 2. The capital stock of this company shall be one hundred thousand dollars, but may be hereafter increased to two hundred and fifty thousand dollars, at the discretion of the president and directors of the corporation; the stock to be divided into shares of one hundred dollars each, each share entitling the owner thereof to one vote by himself or proxy at all meetings of said company; the said shares shall be deemed personal estate, and if any member or stockholder shall neglect or refuse to make the payments on his shares as required, his stock may be sold by the president and directors in such manner as they may deem fit.

Sec. 3. That the said company be and hereby is invested with the right of building bridges over the following named streams, on the main public stage road from San Antonio, Bexar county, Texas, via Austin, Waco and Dallas to Sherman, Grayson county, Texas, viz: Blanco, Hays county; Brushy, Bear Creek and the San Ga-
briels, Williamson county; Lampasas river, Salado and Elm Creek, Bell county; North Cow Bayou, McLennan county; Richland Creek, Hill county; Red Oak and Mill Creek, Ellis county; Cedar creek, Five Mile creek, Ten Mile creek, Dallas county; White Rock, East Fork and Honey creek, Collin county; Post Oak and Choctaw creek, Grayson county.

Sec. 4. That C. Rhodius, of San Antonio; C. K. Hall, of Austin; J. T. Flint of Waco; J. M. Brown of Dallas; J. W. Throckmorton, of McKinney; J. C. D. Blackburn, of Sherman; are hereby ap-
pointed commissioners and invested with the right and privilege of forming and organizing the said company, of obtaining subscrip-
tions to the capital stock and distributing the shares thereof, and of taking such lawful measures to secure the effectual organization and operation of said company as they may deem expedient.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p:
Sec. 5. That the said commissioners shall open their books for subscriptions at San Antonio, Austin, Waco, Dallas and Sherman, and such other points in this State that they may select, and if it be found when the books are closed that more than the capital stock has been subscribed, the subscriptions shall be scaled pro rata down to the amount of the capital stock; and when fifty per cent. of the capital stock shall be subscribed, the commissioners shall collect ten per cent. of the same and immediately call a meeting of the stock-
holders for the election of a board of directors and other necessary actions.

Sec. 6. The number of directors shall not be less than three nor more than five, a majority of whom shall constitute a quorum. They shall elect their own president, and the president and direc-
tors shall have full power to appoint and remove at pleasure all offi-
cers and agents of this company, to fix their compensation and pre-
scribe their duties, and generally to manage the affairs of the com-
pany; to fill any vacancy that may occur in their body, and to ap-
point a president pro tern, when the president may be absent; they shall call an annual meeting of the stockholders to make an elec-
tion of directors, who shall hold their office for one year, or until their successors are elected, and the location of the principal office of the company shall be fixed by the directors.

Sec. 7. That when said bridges, or any of them, shall be built, said company shall be entitled to demand and receive from every person crossing any of said bridges a toll not to exceed the follow-
ing rates, viz: One horse vehicle, twenty cents; two horse or ox ve-
hicle, twenty-five cents; four to six horse or ox vehicle, fifty cents; horses, mules and cattle, per head, five cents; footmen, horse and rider, free; hoes, sheep and goats, free.
Sec. 8. That said bridges shall at all times be open for passing of persons and property, and shall be kept by the company in good repair.

Sec. 9. That any county within the limits of which any of the crossings hereinbefore described are situated may, by constructing bridges over the same before the fifteenth day of December, A. D. 1871, deprive this company of the privilege of building and control-
ing the same, and exercise under the same law the same privileges, subject to the same conditions, herein granted to this company.
Sec. 10. That this charter of incorporation continue and remain in force for thirty years, and that this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXLIII.

opener.salute: An Act for the relief of J. L. L. M’Call, late District Attorney of the Thirty-third Judicial District of this State.

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That an appropriation of eight hundred dollars, or so much thereof as may be required, be and the same is hereby appropriated out of any money in the State Treasury not otherwise appropriated, to pay the salary and fees of J. L. L. McCall, while acting as District Attorney for the Thirty-third Judicial District of the State, from August 20, 1870, to December 15, following.
Sec. 2. This act to take effect from and after its passage.

The foregoing act, received in the office of Secretary of State May eleven, one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one, having been presented to the Governor of Texas for his approval, and not having been returned by him to the house in which it originated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has become a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXLIV.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the town of Fairfield, in Freestone County.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the citizens of the town of Fairfield, in Freestone county, be and they are hereby declared a body politic and corpor-
ate under the name and style of the “Corporation of the Town of Fairfield,” and by that name shall have power to sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, and to acquire, hold and dispose of prop-
erty, real and personal; provided, such real property is situated within the limits of said corporation.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p:
Sec. 2. That it shall be the duty of the citizens of said corpora-
tion at the next general election and every two years thereafter to elect a mayor, a constable, and live aldermen; that the constable shall be ex officio assessor and collector of taxes for said corpora-
tion; that the aldermen shall elect from their own body a treasurer and a secretary, and shall have power to appoint such inferior of-
ficers as they may deem necessary for said corporation. The treas-
urer and the assessor and collector of taxes shall each be required to give bond, with security to be approved by the mayor, condi-
tioned for the faithful performance of their duties, and to make re-
ports when required by the board of aldermen. The mayor shall have power to suppress riots and disturbances of the peace, to call out the citizens of said corporation for the purpose of restoring or-
der, and to impose a fine, not exceeding twenty-five dollars, on any person refusing to obey such call.

Sec. 3. That the first election shall be held under the order of the judge of the District Court of Freestone county, of which elec-
tion ten days’ previous notice shall be given by said judge; and every two years thereafter, under the direction of the mayor, who shall give ten days’ notice thereof before his term of office shall ex-
pire. That in case of a vacancy in any of the offices of said cor-
poration, a special election to fill such vacancy shall be held under the direction of the mayor, but if there be no mayor, then such elec-
tion shall be held by order of the board of aldermen; provided, that all elections for officers of said corporation shall be conducted in accordance with the laws of this State regulating elections.

Sec. 4. That no person, shall be eligible to any office under the provisions of this charter, who is not a qualified voter of this State and shall have been a resident within the limits of said corporation for at least six months prior to his election; nor shall any person have a right to vote for officers of said corporation unless he be a qualified elector under the laws of this State and a citizen, and resi-
dent within said corporate limits for at least six months next pre-
ceding the day of said election; and all officers of said corporation shall take and subscribe the oath provided, by the Constitution of this State.

Sec. 5. That the mayor and board of aldermen of said corpora-
tion shall have power to pass such rules and regulations and ordi-
nances, not inconsistent with the laws of this State, as shall be necessary for the preservation of law and order within the corpor-
ate limits; for the levying of taxes; for the removal of nuisances; for repairing and keeping the streets in good order; and for any and all purposes necessary to promote the public welfare and to preserve good government within said corporate limits; and they shall have
Laws of the State of Texas.and exercise control over all public places within said town, and shall have power to provide penalties for the violation of the laws and ordinances of the corporation; provided, no tax shall ever he levied exceeding one-half the State tax allowed by law; and pro-
vided further, that they shall in no case, prescribe penalties to ex-
ceed one hundred dollars, or imprisonment for more than three months.

Sec. 6. That the mayor, in addition to this powers and jurisdic-
tion as such, is hereby vested with all the powers and jurisdiction, civil and criminal within the limits of said corporation, which may be exercised by justices of the peace under the laws of the State; and he shall be entitled to have and receive such fees as may be al-
lowed by law to justices of the perce for similar services; and shall have power to enforce the collection of the same by execution or otherwise, as may be provided by law. That the constable shall execute all writs and process that may come to his hands, and he is hereby vested with the same powers and privileges that may by law be exercised by other constables of said county, and shall receive the same fees as are or may be allowed by law to other constables for similar services.
Sec. 7. That the mayor and board of aldermen shall have power to suppress all gambling and gaming houses, and all disorderly houses of every character within the limits of said corporation.
Sec. 8. That the mayor’s court for the trial of criminal offenses against the rules and ordinances of said corporation shall be open at all hours.

Sec. 9. That the mayor shall hold a court on the third Monday in each month for the trial of civil causes, and all writs and process in civil suits shall be made returnable on that day, and all trials of civil causes before the mayor shall be conducted in the same manner and under the same rules and regulations as are or may be pre-
scribed by law for the trial of similar cases in justices’ courts.

Sec. 10. That the board of aldermen shall prescribe the com-
pensation to be allowed and paid to all the officers of the corpora-
tion.

Sec. 11. That the limits of said corporation shall be as follows: Beginning one-half mile north of the court house in the town of Fairfield thence east one-half mile; thence south one mile; thence west one mile; thence north one mile; thence east one-half mile to the place of beginning.
Sec. 12. That the mayor, with two of the board of aldermen, shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business.

Sec. 13. That this act shall take effect and be in force from and
Laws of the State of Texas.after its passage; provided, nothing contained in this charter shall interfere with an act entitled “An act to provide for the appoint-
ment by the Governor of certain officers to fill vacancies,” approved June 28, A. D. 1870.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXLV.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the city of Marshall, and to crant a new charter to said city.

div3.p: Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas as follows:

div4.head: Article First—Corporate Powers.
div4.p:
That the corporation now existing and known as the City of Mar-
shall, in Harrison county, shall continue to be a body corporate in fact, by the same name, and shall have succession, with all the grants, powers and privileges heretofore held by said corporation and not modified or repealed by the provisions of this act; said cor-
poration shall also have such enlarged jurisdiction and additional power as are hereinafter conferred by this act.

div4.head: Article Second—Limits of the Corporation.
div4.p: The limits of said corporation shall be as follows: The bounds and limits of said city within which such corporation shall have jurisdiction, shall include a square of which the sides shall be equal distances, measured from what is now known as the court house, one mile and a half thereof, making a distance of three miles square.

div4.head: Article Third—Extent of Jurisdiction.
div4.p: The jurisdiction of the corporation shall be co-extensive with the limits as defined in article second.

div4.head: Article Fourth—Officers.
div4.p: Section 1. The elective officers of the corporation shall be one mayor, five aldermen, one recorder, one treasurer and one marshal.
div4.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div4.p: Sec. 2. The mayor and aldermen shall constitute the common council of the city of Marshall, and when in session as such common council, may appoint and remove at their pleasure such subordinate officers as may be needed from time to time to secure an efficient administration of all ordinances of the corporation.

div4.head: Article Fifth—The Power of the Corporation.
div4.p: Section 1. The power of the corporation shall be Tested in the mayor and aldermen, and a majority of the aldermen present at any regular or called session shall constitute a quorum competent to do business.
Sec. 2. The form of all ordinances shall be as follows: “Be it ordained by the Common Council of the City of Marshall.”

Sec. 3. No ordinance shall take effect or be in force until the same is published for two weeks in a newspaper published within the corporate limits of the city, or, in the absence of such newspaper, by posting up such ordinance in at least six public places within the limits of the corporation, for the length of time above stated. (Sani-
tary ordinances, when their speedy enforcement is deemed necessary by the common council, may be made to take effect the day after they axe posted up in at least twelve public places within said limits.

Sec. 4. The common council, by ordinance, shall have power as follows: First, to appoint subordinate officers and require bond and proper securities for the faithful performance of their duties; to prescribe the duties to be performed by such subordinate officers; to prescribe the duties to be performed by the recorder and by the treasurer and marshal, respectively, and to enforce the performance in such manner and mode as said common council may deem appro-
priate, not inconsistent with the laws of the State. Second, to pay the salaries of all officers entitled to the same, either by this act or by an ordinance of the common council. Third, to levy taxes on all property within the limits of the corporation subject to taxation un-
der the laws of the State; but said taxation is not to exceed one-half of one per cent. ad valorem, as estimated in the ascessment for State taxes. Fourth, to collect such taxes through their own officers, and in the mode and manner as prescribed by law for the collection of the State taxes. Fifth, to license merchants and traders in goods, wares and merchandise of every description, wholesale and retail wine and liquor dealers, wholesale and retail grocers, apothecaries, innkeepers and boarding houses, brokers and money changers, carts, wagons, hackney coaches and livery stables, hawkers and peddlers, showmen, theatres, pawnbrokers, and the keepers of beer saloons,
Laws of the State of Texas.barbers and other occupations, beer gardens, and to collect licenses through their own officers in the mode and manner prescribed by law for the collection of licenses granted by the State. Sixth, to regulate the use of the streets, highways, roads and public places, by foot passengers, vehicles, railways and locomotives. Seventh, to regulate the use of the sidewalks. Eighth, to prevent and remove encroachments upon, and obstructions to the streets, highways and public places. Ninth, to regulate the opening of street surfaces, and to extend the streets as low down in the recorded plat of said city, in continuation to the corporate limits of said city. Tenth, to regu-
late the laying of gas or water pipes, and erecting of gas lights. Eleventh, to regulate or prevent the throwing of ashes or offal, dirt or garbage in the street. Twelfth, to regulate or prevent animals running at large or being ridden, driven or led through the city. Thirteenth, to regulate the cleaning and grading of the streets and sidewalks, the making and cleaning of gutters. Fourteenth, to regu-
late the erection, use and continuance of slaughter houses. Fifteenth, to define, regulate and control the conduct of policemen and their relation to other officers of the peace, and other persons in respect to maintaining peace and good order, and preserving the rights of persons and property. Sixteenth, in relation to street beggars, men-
dicants and vagrants. Sevententh, in relation to the use of guns, pistols, fire arms and fire crackers of all kinds within the city. Eighteenth, in relation to the keeping and storage of gun powder and other explosive materials. Nineteenth, in relation to intoxica-
tion, quarreling and fighting in the streets and in places of public amusement. Twentieth, in relation to the public health, the pre-
vention and removal of nuisances, the regulation of interments, the business of bone boiling or grinding, meat packing, soap making and other operations or occupations noxious to health or comfort, and the removal, keeping and deposit of manure, offal and garbage. Twenty-first, in relation to public morals, in exposing the person or exhibiting obscene pictures. Twenty-second, in relation to disorderly and gaming houses, their inmates and frequenters, and the suppres-
sion of vice and immorality. Twenty-third, in relation to the con-
struction, care and use of markets. Twenty-fourth, in relation to the prevention and extinguishment of fires, and the formation of a fire department, its officers, its regulations and support, Twenty-
fifth, in relation to the assessment and collection of assessments made on the owners of lots, for the grading, filling up and improving the sidewalks and streets adjacent to said lots, which assessment is hereby made a charge against the owners of such lots, and a charge and lien on such lots. Twenty-sixth, in relation to the affixing of a penalty for a violation of any ordinance and the collection of said
Laws of the State of Texas.penalty. Twenty-seventh, in relation to the inspection, weighing and measuring of fire wood, coal, hay and straw, and the cartage of the same. Twenty-eighth, in relation to the inspection and sealing of weights and measures, and enforcing the keeping and use of proper weights and measures by vendors. Twenty-ninth, in relation to the mode and manner of proceedings of their own body when in session. Thirtieth, in relation to public order and keeping the peace. Thirty-first, in relation to the time, necessary notice, mode and manner of holding elections for elective officers of the corpora-
tion, also in relation to contested elections for elective officers. Thirty-second, in relation to the employment of legal counsel for the assistance of the common council, and to prosecute on behalf of the corporation in criminal cases, and to institute and to defend civil suits in their behalf. Thirty-third, in relation to the employ-
ment of a city surveyor. Thirty-fourth, in relation to the employ-
ment of an adequate police force and night watchmen. Thirty-fifth, in relation to the imposition of fines and penalties for violation of ordinances. Thirty-sixth, in relation to trust property.

div4.head: Article Sixth—Tenure of Office of Elective Officers.
div4.p: Section 1. Elective officers shall bold their offices for two years from the date of their instalment, and until their successors are qualified.
Sec. 2. All elections to fill vacancies shall be for the unexpired term of the office to be filled.

div4.head: Article Seventh—Publicity of Proceedings.
div4.p: All the proceedings of the common council shall be recorded in proper order, and books kept for that purpose, and shall be open to the public.

div4.head: Article Eighth—The Mayor, His Duties and Salary.
div4.p:
Section 1. The mayor, when present at the session of the com-
mon council, shall be the presiding officer. He shall have the cast-
ing vote in case of a tie.

Sec. 2. The mayor shall have power to act in a judicial capacity and alone in all cases arising within the jurisdiction of the corpora-
tion; involving a breach of the peace, a violation of any penal ordi-
nance of the common council, and a violation of any law in the criminal code of the State.

Sec. 3. In case of breach of the peace or a violation of a law
Laws of the State of Texas.in the criminal code of the State, the mayor shall have the same power as is conferred by law on a justice of the peace in relation to the same subject matter. In relation to a violation of a penal ordi-
nance passed by the common council, he shall have power to try the same, and on conviction to execute the penalty through the marshal, sheriff or constable, in the mode and manner prescribed in the ordi-
nance violated.

Sec. 4. The mayor as a judicial officer, on complaint made be-
fore him under oath, shall have power to issue writs of arrest and warrants for all violations of the ordinances of the corporation, and for all violations of the criminal code of the State; and when such violations of ordinances, and of the criminal code of the State, are committed in his view, he shall have power to arrest without com-
plaint made, and without a writ of arrest or warrant; he shall also have power to issue subpoenas for witnesses.

Sec. 5. The mayor, as a judicial officer, shall keep a record of all his proceedings, and transmit the same to the common council on the termination of his office, and the same shall be kept as ar-
chives of the corporation.

Sec. 6. The mayor shall at all times, by virtue of his office, see that the ordinances of the common council are executed; that all subordinate officers perform their duties, and as occasion may re-
quire report to said council as to delinquencies and misconduct of such officers; he shall also, from time to time, recommend to the council such measures for consideration as he may deem important.
Sec. 7. The mayor shall receive an annual salary, to be fixed by the common council. As a judicial officer he shall receive the same fees as are or may be provided by law for a justice of the peace.

div4.head: Article Ninth—Finance.
div4.p:
Section 1. All property, real and personal, acquired by the cor-
poration, whether by conveyance, donation, bequest, or by the granting of licenses, or acquired from any other source, or in any other manner, shall be held in trust by said corporation for the use and benefit of the same, and shall be appropriated for no other pur-
pose.

Sec. 2. The funds of the corporation shall be used: First, to sustain the municipal government. Second, for the erection and maintenance of a city hospital. Third, for the erection and main-
tenance of a house of correction for juvenile delinquents. Fourth, for such improvements in and adornments of the city as shall be sanctioned by a vote of a majority of the legal votes, in an election to be held for that specific purpose.
div4.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div4.p:
Sec. 3. The corporation shall not incur debt to exceed at any one time the sum of five thousand dollars. If the common council deem it advisable to incur debts exceeding that amount, they may specify the amount desired and submit the question to the legal voters within the corporation limits, and the same shall be sanc-
tioned by a majority of the votes cast.

div4.head: Article Tenth—Electors.
div4.p:
The qualified electors for State and county officers who shall have resided three months next preceding an election within the corpor-
ate limits of the city, shall be allowed to vote for all elective officers of the corporation.

div4.head: Article Eleventh—General Provisions.
div4.p: Section 1. Upon the passage of this act the persons now filling the offices of the city of Marshall shall continue in office, subject to the provisions of an act entitled “An act to authorize the Governor to fill vacancies,” approved June 28, A. D. 1870.

Sec. 2. In all questions of conflict arising out of the terms used and provisions made in the original and amended acts of incorpora-
tion of the city of Marshall, and the terms used and provisions made in this act, this act shall have the preference and govern.
Sec. 3. This act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXLVI.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Jefferson Insurance Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That W. M. Harrison, J. W. Russell, J. M. Swisher, B. H. Epperson, F. A. Schluter, W. G. Bateman, Amos Morrill, D. Camp-
bell, M. Wright, J. S. Grinnin, D. B. Culbertson, N. A. Birge and P. M. Graham, and their associates, be and they are hereby con-
stituted a body corporate and politic, with succession, un-
der the name of the “Jefferson Insurance Company,” and as such by that name shall be capable of contracting and being con-
Laws of the State of Texas.tracted with, suing and feeing sued, in all matters growing out of said company’s business, and may purchase and hold real, personal and mixed property and dispose of the same, and have and use a corporate seal.

Sec. 2. That the capital stock of said company shall not be less than one hundred thousand dollars, divided into shares of one hun-
dred dollars each, transferable on the books of the company under such rules as shall be prescribed by the board of directors; but no stock shall be issued by the company except as the same is paid for in full, in cash.

Sec. 3. That said, company shall have power to do a general marine, fire, inland and life insurance business, and to make con-
tracts, issue policies, and to do all other acts necessary in carrying on such a business; to charge and receive such premiums, commis-
sions and compensation for the risks taken and the business done, as the president and directors may deem just; to loan money on bot-
tomry and respondentia security at marine interest; to deal in bul-
lion, stocks and public securities; to make loans on real estate, stocks and personal property; to discount notes and acceptances, buy and sell bills of exchange, receive money on trust and deposit, issue cer-
tificates of deposit, and use capital and funds in any other lawful manner.

Sec. 4. That the affairs of said company shall be under the con-
trol and management of a board of not less than seven directors, each of whom shall be the owner of not less than fifty shares of stock in said company. A majority of said directors shall form a quorum for the transaction of business, and they shall be elected at the an-
nual meeting of the stockholders, to be held on the second Wednes-
day in January of each and every year, after the passage of this act, by a majority of the stockholders present. Vacancies in said board may be filled by the remaining members thereof, until the next an-
nual election shall take place. The corporation shall not be dis-
solved by the failure of a regular meeting or election, but the di-
rectors for the time being shall call a meeting for an election at an early day, giving twenty days’ public notice of the time and place of such meeting, and shall continue in office until a new board be elected and organized; and it shall be the duty of a newly elected board to meet and organize within ten days after their election. Until the first annual meeting of the stockholders the persons named in the first section of this act shall constitute a board of directors, with power to elect, from their own number a president and vice president, and to perform every act within the powers hereby conferred upon the president and directors of said company.

Sec. 5. That in all elections, and upon all questions arising in
Laws of the State of Texas.a meeting of the stockholders, the vote shall be by ballot, and each stockholder shall be entitled to one vote for every share of stock he may hold in said company, and may vote in person or by proxy. To form a quorum to transact business a majority of all the stock must be present or represented at the meeting.

Sec. 6. That the board of electors shall elect from among their own number a president of the company and a vice president. The said president and directors shall have authority to adopt a by-law declaring and reserving a lien on the stock of any stockholder in-
debted to the company, and to adopt all such other rules, regulations and by-laws not in contravention of the Constitution and laws of the State, and to appoint all such subordinate officers as they may deem necessary for the proper management of the affairs of the company.

Sec. 7. That the principal office of said company shall be in the city of Jefferson, Marion county, Texas, and the company may es-
tablish such branch offices and agencies as its business may require.
Sec. 8. That said company shall be authorized to commence business under this act whenever one hundred thousand dollars of its stock shall have been taken and fully paid up in cash.
Sec. 9. That this act shall take effect from and after its passage, and continue in force for fifty years.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXLVII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the town of Marlin, Falls county.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the citizens of the town of Marlin, in Falls county, he and they are hereby declared a body politic and corporate, under the name and style of the corporation of the town of Marlin, and by that name shall have power to sue and be sued, plead and be im-
pleaded, and shall have and use a corporate seal. It shall also possess the power and franchises hereinafter declared. The town plot shall be one and a half mile square, the court house to be in the centre, and the lines running parallel with the lines of the Cham-
bers survey.

Sec. 2. Said corporation may hold and dispose of property, real
Laws of the State of Texas.and personal; provided, such property is situated within the limits of said corporation.

Sec. 3. That it shall be the duty of the citizens of said corpora-
tion to elect within sixty days after the next general State election, at such time and under such regulation as may be prescribed by or-
dinance, not inconsistent with the laws of this State, a mayor, live aldermen, and a marshal, who shall be ex officio assessor and collec-
tor of taxes; who shall hold their offices for the term of two years, and a treasurer and secretary shall be elected by the mayor and board of aldermen. The treasurer and assessor and collector of taxes shall be required to give bond with security, to be approved by the presiding officer (the mayor) in such sum as the board of al-
dermen may require, payable to the corporation of the town of Mar-
lin, and recoverable before any court having jurisdiction, for the faithful performance of their duties as defined by ordinance, and to make reports when required by the mayor or board of aldemien.

Sec. 4. No person shall vote at any election in said corpora-
tion unless he be a registered voter in the county and shall have re-
sided in the corporation thirty days. The mayor, aldermen, mar-
shal, treasurer and secretary, shall each qualify himself for the duties of his office by taking the oath prescribed in the Constitution of the State of Texas for members of the Legislature, who shall hold the said office until their successors have qualified and given bond as required by this charter, said oath to be administered by the presiding justice. The marshal and treasurer shall not be per-
mitted to act as such until they shall have executed their bonds as required by section three of this act, conditioned to account for all moneys which shall come info their hands by virtue of their offices, and otherwise to execute faithfully the dirties thereof: the said bonds shall be filed and recorded in the office of the District Clerk of Falls county, and may be put in suit either before or after their term of office expires by the corporation or by individuals sustaining injury through their malfeasance, default, misconduct or neglect.

Sec. 5. The mayor and aldermen, shall together compose a coun-
cil for the said corporation, of which the mayor shall be the presi-
dent, any four members of the council shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business, and in the absence of the president his place shall be supplied by a president pro tempore, elected from the number of aldermen present.

Sec. 6. The mayor shall, ex officio, be a justice of the peace in and for the said corporation, having the civil and criminal jurisdic-
tion conferred on such officers by the laws of this State, charging the like fees for his services, and subject in his acts to the same revisory power; his civil jurisdiction shall, as to the amount involved (except
Laws of the State of Texas.in the collection of taxes imposed by the council) be limited by the general law; and as to parties, shall embrace cases where the de-
fendant is a resident of the corporation where the subject to which the controversy relates is within its limits, and where the contract is required to be executed within the same. He may also impose fines, not exceeding one hundred dollars, for violation of the ordinances of the corporation. As chief executive officer, he shall order and control the police, and enforce the by-laws and ordinances passed by the council, prevent and punish breaches of the peace, and employ his delegated powers in promoting the peace and good order of the corporation. He shall also hold court at such times and places as the council by ordinance shall prescribe, and keep a record of his proceedings therein.

Sec. 7. The council shall have power, through ordinances and by-laws passed for the purpose, to lay off streets, walks and alleys, designating each by a name, a letter or a number, and may alter, im-
prove and light the same, and have them kept in good order; may lay off public grounds and erect or purchase all buildings proper for the corporation; establish and regulate markets; provide in or near the town water works and burial places, for the due protection of which the jurisdiction of the corporation shall embrace the same; provide proper safeguards against injury by fire; abate nuisances; prevent, remove or correct whatever endangers the health or com-
fort of the town and its inhabitants, and preserve peace and good order therein. To assist them in the discharge of these duties they may employ a surveyor whose duties they may define. They shall have power to appoint and organize a police force, to be controlled by the mayor, under such general regulations as the council may or-
dain, and may also appoint such other officers, temporary or perma-
nent, as in their judgment the wants of the town may require, They are, moreover, empowered to open streets and alleys through private lots if they deem it necessary, ascertaining the loss and injury to the proprietors by the verdict rendered under oath of six impartial free-
holders of the town, and paying the amount so assessed in compen-
sation therefor, and in absolute purchase of the premises thus appro-
priated. They may also divide the town into wards, containing, as nearly as maybe, equal populations, providing voting places therein at which only the residents in the respective wards shall vote, and apportioning and assigning to each an equal number of aldermen to be elected therefrom. In case of death, absence, sickness or other incapacity of the mayor, they shall select one of their own number who shall possess the powers and perform the duties of that office temporarily or during the unexpired residue of the term, as the occasion may require; and in case of such casualty to the marshal,
Laws of the State of Texas.his place may, in the discretion of the council, in like manner be filled temporarily by an appointment from the classes indicated in section four of this act as eligible to office, and shall take the pre-
scribed oath. To defray the resulting expenses of the corporation in its different departments, the council shall have power to impose, by a two-thirds voce, an ad valorem tax not to exceed one-half of one per centum on all taxable property, real and personal, within the limits of said corporation not exempt by law, and to exact a license tax not to exceed one-half of the tax levied by the State, from merchants, manufacturers, auctioneers, agents of joint stock companies and others exercising trades and vocations within the corporation; also keepers of hotels, of bowling alleys, billiard tables, and retail dealers in spirituous liquors, and from exhibitions of theatrical representations and other public amusements, shows and performances, excepting, however, mechanics and artists exhibiting the productions of their own skill, industry and invention, givers of musical concerts and lectures given on subjects of general interest. The violation of any ordinance respecting license, shall be a misde-
meanor punishable by fine and imprisonment, to be enforced by the mayor. The assessment of any tax shall constitute a lien for the payment thereof on real property. Taxes due and unpaid may be collected by sale under execution issued by the mayor.

Sec. 8. The marshal shall be the executive officer of the mayor’s court, and as such shall have and exercise the powers of a constable as determined by the laws of the State, within, the jurisdiction of said corporation.

Sec. 9. The council shall allow and pay to the mayor and mar-
shal an annual salary which, with their fees, shall constitute the compensation for their official duties. The aldermen may each re-
ceive for their services the sum of four dollars per day, for each day that they may be engaged in council, counting eight hours for one day; they shall also fix and pay a proper compensation, by sal-
ary or otherwise, to all such persons as under their general powers they may see fit to appoint.

Sec. 10. All laws of the State applicable to the corporation and franchises of towns, so far as they are not in conflict with the pro-
visions of this charter, shall be taken and construed as a part thereof.
Sec. 11. The mayor and board of aldermen now in office may hold and exercise the duties of their offices until their successors are sworn in and have given bond as required by this charter.

Sec. 12. That it shall be the duty of the district judge, when-
ever complaint is made to him under oath by any party or parties accusing the mayor, marshal or any member of the board of alder-
men, or any other officer appointed by them, of malfeasance, non-
Laws of the State of Texas.feasance, misfeasance or neglect of duty in any manner in office, to immediately examine into the truth of said charges, and if true he shall remove the party or parties from office at once.
Sec. 13. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage, and that the act incorporating the town of Marlin, passed in 1866, is hereby repealed.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXLVIII.

opener.salute:
An Act to incorporate the French Benevolent and Mutual Assist-
ance Society of Galveston, Texas.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That Hypoliie Reybaud, Aimable Dreuil, Jean Baptiste Borelly, Victor J. Baulard, Edward Borelly, Joseph Policarpe As-
tugne, Vielle, Henri Shaffter, Jean Baptiste Baroux, and their as-
sociates, are hereby incorporated into a body politic under the cor-
porate name of “Societe Francaise de Bienfaisance et d’Assistance Mutuelle de Galveston, Texas.”

Sec. 2. That said corporation shall have power to contract and be contracted with, sue and be sued, buy, sell and acquire, and ex-
change real and personal property necessary for their benevolent purposes, and transact the general business of a benevolent society.
Sec. 3. That said corporation shall have the right to make such laws, rules and regulations for their own government as they may deem meet and proper.
Sec. 4. That said corporation shall, by by-laws, establish a board of directors to govern its proceedings and direct its affairs.
Sec. 5. This act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXLIX.

opener.salute:
An Act to amend an act entitled “An Act to incorporate the Gal-
veston City Railroad Company,” approved October 8, 1866.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That section 5 of an act entitled “An act to incorporate the Galveston City Railroad Company,” approved October 8, 1866, be and the same is hereby amended so as to read as follows, viz: “Sec-
tion 5. Said company shall have and use a common seal, shall be subject to sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, and shall have a right to buy and hold, to sell and convey property, real, personal and mixed, for the uses of the company; but no real estate shall be bought or sold, nor shall there be any material extension of said tracks, or change or removal of main tracks or routes, except by consent of a majority of the stock voting under the rules of the company, or expressed in writing. The said tracks now laid may be doubled on any street, or changed and shifted to any street here-
tofore granted by the city council to the uses of said company. Said company shall, as soon as practicable, connect their tracks on Bath avenue and Centre street on the sea-side by a track, double or single, on Avenue R. Any action of a majority of the stock of said com-
pany voting under its rules, or expressed in writing, shall be bind-
ing on all the stock of the company.”

Sec. 2. That section 6 of the foregoing named act be, and the same is hereby amended so as to read as follows, viz: “Section 6. It shall be lawful for the corporators named in this act or their suc-
cessors, who are stockholders in said company or a majority of them, to reorganize this company immediately after the passage of this act, and the officers then and thereafter elected shall hold their of-
fices until their successors shall have been elected. This charter shall continue in force for fifty years, and the legal domicile of said company shall be in the city of Galveston."
Sec. 3. This act shall be in force from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER CL.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Sabine and Neches Mutual Insurance Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That B. F. McDonough, C. H. Alexander, William Allison, N. J. Moore, William Weiss, E. T. Seale, T. R. Buford, Geo. W. Rose and F. G. McReynolds, and their present and future associates, successors and assigns, be and are hereby incorporated and created a body politic and corporate, by the name and style of the Sabine and Niches Mutual Insurance Company, and by the same name and style they and their successors shall be capable of suing and being sued, and maintaining any action to final judgment and execution, and shall be in law capable of purchasing, holding, improving and conveying any estate, real, personal or mixed, for the use of said corporation; and the said corporation shall have the power to or-
dain, establish and put in execution such by-laws, ordinances and regulations as shall be necessary for the government thereof, and it shall be lawful for the said corporation, after the expiration there-
of, to use the corporate name, style and capacity for the purpose of suits for the final settlement and liquidation of the affairs and ac-
counts of the corporation; and for the sale and disposition of their estate, real, personal or mixed, but not for any other purpose, nor for a period exceeding three years after the expiration of the term of incorporation.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That the capital stock of said in-
corporation shall not be less than one hundred and fifty thousand dollars, divided into shares of one hundred dollars each, and the same shall be created and paid in such manner and at such times as the president and directors of said corporation shall require, of which requisition at least one month’s notice shall be given, by pub-
lication in two newspapers printed in the city of Sabine Pass, or elsewhere; and if any stockholder shall fail to pay any instalments so required to be paid, he or she shall cease to be a member of said corporation, and shall forfeit his or her stock, and the share or shares so forfeited may be sold by said corporation in such manner as they may think proper, but such, forfeiture and sale of such stock shall not release the holder thereof, nor his or her sureties, on the notes contemplated to be given in sections six and eight of this act, from his or her liability on account of said notes to any person or persons having a just claim against said corporation, which shall have accrued before such sale.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p:
Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, That for the well ordering of the affairs of said corporation, there shall be nine directors, who shall be stockholders of the corporation. They shall be elected by the stockholders at their annual meeting, to be held on the first Mon-
day in January of each year for that purpose, and the directors at their first meeting shall choose one of their own number as presi-
dent, and another as vice president; provided, nevertheless, that un-
til the first annual election the persons named in the first section of this act, shall have, and may exercise ail the powers given to the president and directors by this act; and in all elections for directors the vote shall be by ballot, and each stockholder shall have one vote for each share he may hold; but no stockholder shall vote at any election unless the share or shares upon which he may claim to vote shall have been standing in his or her name on the books of said corporation, fox at least three months previous to such election. In case of absence from any general meeting any stockholder may be entitled to vote by proxy.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, That the directors of said corpora-
tion for the time being, five of whom, including the President, shall form a quorum, shall have power to appoint such officers, clerks, agents and other persons, as shall be necessary for conducting the business of said corporation, and to allow said persons so appointed such compensation for their services as they shall deem proper, and generally to exercise all other powers and privileges as are given by law to corporations.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted, That it shall be lawful for the said company to employ the fund thereof in establishing and sus-
taining the business of marine and fire insurance; to insure vessels in port, buildings, merchandise, and all other perishable property on land, against loss by damage or fire; to make all and every insur-
ance appertaining to or connected with marine, inland and trans-
portation risks, and to charge, collect and receive for the same such premiums of insurance as the president and directors of said cor-
poration may deem just and reasonable. It shall be lawful for the said corporation to hay and sell exchanges, and to lend, at a rate of interest to be determined by the president and directors of said com-
pany, any surplus capital they may at any time possess; to lend money on bottomry and respondentia security at marine interest.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted, That the shares of said corpora-
tion shall be assignable and transferable upon the books of said company, according to such rules and regulations as the president and directors thereof shall, for that purpose, ordain and establish; and in case the assignee of any share or shares of stock shall deposit his note with securities, as contemplated and provided for in section
Laws of the State of Texas.eight of this act, then the assignor of such share or shares shall have the right to withdraw and cancel his note or notes and securi-
ties given for such share or shares of stock, otherwise the notes and securities of said assignor to be and remain subject and liable to all the conditions and provisions contained in section nine of this act.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted, That the president and directors of said corporation shall, annually or semi-annually, make such dividends of the net profits of the company as shall appear advis-
able; but the following rule of distribution shall in all cases be ob-
served, to-wit: One-half of said profits, after deducting twenty-five, per cent. thereof for a reserved fund, shall be credited to the stock-
holders in proportion to the stock owned by them, and endorsed upon their notes until such notes are paid in full, when it shall be the duty of the president and directors to issue certificates to the sockholders for full paid shares, and the remaining half shall be distributed in scrip to all those who shall have effected insurance with the company, which scrip shall be redeemable when the accu-
mulated net profits of the company shall exceed the sum of three hundred thousand dollars.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted, That the office of the company in-
corporated by this act shall be located in the city of Sabine Pass, and so soon as the president and directors thereof shall establish by evidence, to the satisfaction of the presiding justice of Jefferson county, that five per cent. of the capital stock of said corporation has been paid by the stockholders thereof, and that the balance or residue of said capital of one hundred and fifty thousand dollars has been secured, to be paid when called for as contemplated in section two of this act, by the notes of the holders of said capital stock, se-
cured by good and solvent security or securities; and shall also es-
tablish, to the satisfaction of said presiding justice, that the direc-
tors of said corporation have been organized in conformity with the provisions of section three of this act, then said presiding justice shall give them a certificate thereof, which shall be their warrant to commence business operations, under the authority vested by this act.

Sec. 9. Be it further enacted, That in case the corporation created by this act shall become insolvent, which fact shall be ascertained by the return of “no property found” upon execution issued on a judgment rendered against it, the said judgment creditor, or any other creditor thereof, may at once enter a suit in the district court of the county of its domicile, against said corporation for a decree of insolvency, which decree shall also provide for the appointment of a receiver or trustee, whose duty it shall be to demand and se-
cure from the said corporation all its property and assets of every
Laws of the State of Texas.description, and proceed to collect the same and pay the same out in satisfaction of the debts due by said corporation, in the same man-
ner and under the same rules and regulations as provided for an insolvent estate.
Sec. 10. Be it further enacted, That the charter granted by this act shall continue in full force and effect for the term of twenty-five years from and after the passage of this act.

div3.head: CHAPTER CLI.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the town of Mount Pleasant, in Titus County.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the citizens of the town of Mount Pleasant, Titus county, be and they are hereby declared a body politic and corpo-
rate, under the name and style of the “Corporation of the Town of Mount Pleasant,” by which name they may sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, and acquire and hold real and personal property within the limits of said corporation, and at their pleasure sell and dispose of the same.
Sec. 2. That the limits of said corporation shall extend one mile in a square, so laid off as to leave the public square in the centre of said corporation.
