Sec. 3. That it shall be the duty of the Governor to appoint a mayor and five aldermen and a constable, who shall hold their offices for the term of two years from the date of such appointment. The said mayor and aldermen shall elect a secretary and treasurer from their own body; the treasurer shall be required to give bond in a sum to be fixed by said mayor and aldermen, to be approved by the mayor, for the faithful performance of his duties, and to make re-
ports when required by the mayor and aldermen. The mayor shall have and exercise all the powers and jurisdiction of a justice of the peace, and before entering upon the discharge of the duties of his office he shall take the oath prescribed in the Constitution, and give such bond with securities as justices of the peace are required to give, except the bond required to be given by a justice of the peace in his capacity of assessor of taxes. The constable shall have and
Laws of the State of Texas.exercise all the powers and discharge all the duties within said cor-
poration of a constable of the county, and before entering upon the discharge of the duties of his office he shall give such bond with se-
curity as constables of the county are required to give, to be ap-
proved by the mayor. That said aldermen shall be required to take the oath prescribed in the Constitution of this State for the faithful performance of their duties as such aldermen.

Sec. 4. That the mayor and board of aldermen of said corpo-
ration shall have power to pass such rules and ordinances as may be necessary for the regulation of the police and the preservation of order within the limits of said corporation. They shall have power to levy and collect by ordinances an ad valorem tax on all property, both real and personal, within said corporate limits; also, a tax on occupations; and a poll tax, not to exceed one dollar in any one year, from every male citizen between the ages of twenty-one and fifty years within said corporate limits, and may prescribe penalties for violation of said ordinances or by-laws; provided, that in no case shall the penalty exceed the sum of one hundred dollars.

Sec. 5. That the mayor, with a majority of said aldermen, shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. They may enact and enforce such rules and regulations as they may deem necessary for the government of the said corporation; provided, that the same do not conflict with the Constitution or laws of this State.

Sec. 6. That no person shall be eligible to hold office in said corporation, or to vote for the officers thereof, unless he be a, quali-
fied elector under the Constitution of this State, and shall have re-
sided in the limits of said corporation thirty days preceding any election which may be held in said corporation for the election of an officer or officers named in said corporation.

Sec. 7. That it shall be the duty of the mayor to cause an election to be held annually at least ten days before the expiration of his term of office, and to fill vacancies which may occur, after giving at least ten days’ notice of said election by posting notices thereof in three public places in said town for a mayor, five alder-
men and a constable, who shall enter upon the duties of their offices respectively upon the expiration of the term of office of their pre-
decessors, and compliance with the requirements of section three of this act.

Sec. 8. That in case of the failure of the mayor to order and hold such election as specified in the foregoing section, then any three citizens who are qualified electors within the limits of said corporation may, after giving ten days’ notice, order and hold said election.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p: Sec. 9. That this act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CLII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the town of Cleburne, in Johnson County.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the citizens in the town of Cleburne, in Johnson county, be and they are hereby declared to be a body politic and corporate, under the name and style of the “Corporation of the Town of Cleburne,” and shall by that name have power to sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, and to hold and dispose of prop-
erty, real and personal; provided, such real property is situated within the limits of said corporation.

Sec. 2. That it shall be the duty of the citizens of said corpo-
ration to elect a mayor, five aldermen, and a constable who shall also be ex officio assessor and collector of taxes; and a treasurer and secretary shall be elected by said mayor and aldermen. The treasurer and assessor and collector shall be required to give bond, with security approved by the presiding officer, for the faithful per-
formance of their duties, and to make reports when required by the mayor or board of aldermen; and the mayor shall have power, when necessary, to suppress riots and disturbances, and to call out the citizens of said corporation for the purpose of restoring order.

Sec. 3. The mayor, aldermen and constable shall, for the pres-
ent time, be appointed, as provided for in an act entitled “An act to authorize the Governor to appoint certain officers to fill vacan-
cies,” and upon the expiration of their term of office there shall be an election, under the direction of the mayor, who shall give at least ten days notice of such election before his term of office shall expire; and said election for officers as aforesaid shall be held every two years thereafter; and all the male inhabitants of said town who have resided within its limits for four months preceding any elec-
tion, and who are qualified voters under the Constitution and laws of the State, shall be deemed qualified electors of said corpora-
tion.

Sec. 4. That the mayor and board of aldermen of said corpora-
Laws of the State of Texas.tion shall have power to pass such rules, regulations and ordinances, as may be necessary for the regulation of the police and the preser-
vation of order within the corporate limits; or the levying of taxes; for the removal of nuisances and keeping the streets in good order; for the building of a market house; for improving and ornament-
ing public property within said corporate limits; and for any and all purposes tending to promote good order and government; and they shall have power to prescribe and enforce the collection of penalties for the violation of the ordinances of the corporation; pro-
vided, no fine shall be imposed exceeding one hundred dollars, or imprisonment for more than twenty-four hours.

Sec. 5. The limits of said corporation shall extend one half-
mile in every direction from the center of the public square in the town of Cleburne.

Sec. 6. The mayor, with a majority of the aldermen, shall con-
stitute a quorum for the transaction of business; and in the absence of the mayor the aldermen (shall) elect one of their own number mayor pro tempore.
Sec. 7. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CLIII.

opener.salute: An Act to authorize certain persons therein named to operate a Ferry on Sabine River, in Upshur County.

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That A. W. Ferguson, William S. Wilburn, their associates and assigns, are authorized to operate a ferry at a place known as Camp’s Ferry, on Sabine river, in Upshur county, on the road from Tyler to Marshall, in the State of Texas.

Sec. 2. That said ferry shall be supplied at all times with one or more safe and substantial boats, for the crossing of persons and property, and the owners of said ferry shall be responsible in dam-
ages for any loss of life or property caused by the insecurity of any boat, the want of care or skill in any person employed to operate the same, or the want of security in any of the appliances used in operating said ferry; provided, that nothing shall in any manner prejudice the rights of other parties who have or may hereafter set
Laws of the State of Texas.up an adverse title to the land embraced within the limits of said ferry.
Sec. 3. No other person or corporation shall operate a ferry on said river within one mile of said ferry, on a direct line.

Sec. 4. This act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage, and the rights herein granted shall inure to the parties named and their successors, for a period of ten years from the pas-
sage of this act.

The foregoing act, received in the office of the Secretary of State the sixteenth day of May, one thousand eight hundred and seventy-
one, having been presented to the Governor of Texas for his ap-
proval, and not having been returned by him to the house in which it originated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has become a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div3.head: CHAPTER CLIV.

opener.salute: An Act for the relief of A. H. Cook.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the Treasurer of the State of Texas be and he is hereby authorized to pay to A. H. Cook the sum of twenty-five hundred dollars in United States currency; provided, that said A. H. Cook shall first file in the office of the Treasurer a receipt from the Secretary of State, that he has delivered to him five hun-
dred copies of a “Treatise on the civil jurisdiction of county courts and justices of the peace,” by John Savles, Esq.
Sec. 2. That this act take effect from and after the date of its passage.

The foregoing act, received in the office of Secretary of State May thirteenth, one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one, hav-
ing been presented to the Governor of Texas for his approval and not having been returned by him to the house in which it origi-
nated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has become a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER CLV.

opener.salute: An Act supplementary to an act entitled “An act to incorporate the Casino Society of Yorktown.”

div3.p: Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That nothing in the above recited act shall be so construed as to allow or authorize said corporation to pursue any occupation that is now or may hereafter be required to pay a license tax, except lectures, artistic exhibitions and dramatic performances given in Casino house in Yorktown. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

The foregoing act, received in the office of Secretary of State May sixteenth, one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one, hav-
ing been presented to the Governor of Texas for his approval, and not having been returned by him to the house in which it originated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has become a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div3.head: CHAPTER CLVI.

opener.salute: All Act to incorporate the West Fork Male and Female College.

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That an institution of learning is hereby established at Red Sulphur Springs, in the county of Tarrant, and shall foe called the “West Fork Male and Female College,” and shall be under the control of the West Fork Baptist Association.

Sec. 2. That A. Fitzgerald, J. F. Jones, J. Neice, A. F. Leon-
ard, B. Wilmot, D. M. Davis, J. A. Lindsey, A. H. Boyd, J. M. Rogers and H. N. Williams, be and they are hereby constituted trustees of said institution, with the power to elect the officers thereof, and to make such by-laws as they may deem necessary for
Laws of the State of Texas.the promotion of said institution of learning, and to hold their office for the term of twelve months from the passage of this act; their successors to be elected as their by-laws shall prescribe.

Sec. 3. The trustees aforesaid and their successors in office, shall be a body politic and corporate, in deed and in law, by the name of the Trustees of the West Fork Male and Female College, and by that name they and their successors may and shall have suc-
cession, and shall be capable in law of having, receiving and enjoy-
ing to them and their successors, lands, tenements and heredita-
ments of any kind in fee or for years, and personal property of any kind whatever, and also all sums of money which may be given, granted or bequeathed to them for the purpose of promoting the in-
terests of said institution of learning; provided, the amount of prop-
erty owned by said corporation shall not at any time exceed one hundred thousand dollars.

Sec. 4. There shall be a stated meeting of the board of trustees at the end of each collegiate year, and the president of said college shall have full power to call an occasional meeting of the board of trustees, or a quorum of the same, whenever he shall deem it nec-
essary.

Sec. 5. The trustees of said college shall and may have a com-
mon seal for the business of themselves and their successors, and by their aforesaid name they and their successors shall and may be able to sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, answer and be an-
swered, defend and be defended in all courts of law and equity in this State, and to grant, bargain, sell or assign any lands, tenements, goods or chattels now belonging to said college or that may hereaf-
ter belong to the same; to construct all necessary buildings for said college; to manage the finances thereof; to appoint all necessary committees, and to do all things whatsoever for the benefit of said college, in as ample a manner as any person or body politic or cor-
porate can or may do by law.

Sec. 6. The trustees shall have the power of framing and en-
acting all such ordinances and by-laws as shall appear to them necessary for the government of said college and of their own pro-
ceedings; provided, the same shall not be repugnant to the laws and Constitution of the State of Texas.

Sec. 7. The trustees shall be empowered to appoint a president and the professors, and they shall be styled the “Faculty of the West Fork Male and Female College,” which faculty shall have the power of prescribing the course of study to be pursued by the students, of enforcing the ordinances and by-laws adopted by the board of trustees for the government of the students, by rewarding or cen-
suring them, and finally by suspending such of them as, after
Laws of the State of Texas.repeated admonitions, shall continue disobedient and refractory, until a determination of a quorum of the board of trustees can be had, in whom alone the power of expulsion shall exist.

Sec. 8. The trustees shall have full power, with the president and professors of the said college, to give diplomas or certificates signed by them, and sealed with the common seal of the college, to authenticate and perpetuate the memory of such graduation.
Sec. 9. When any vacancy shall occur in the board of trustees, either by death, resignation or otherwise, such vacancy shall be filled by the West Fork Baptist Association.

Sec. 10. The West Fork Baptist Association shall have the power of fixing the salary of all Officers connected with said col-
lege, and of removing any of them for neglect or misconduct in office.

Sec. 11. The board of trustees shall, at the close of each year, make a full report of their proceedings and the condition of the college to the said West Fork Baptist Association, and said asso-
ciation shall have and exercise general supervision and control over the said board of trustees.
Sec. 12. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CLVII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate Waco Lodge No. 92, Ancient Free and Accepted Masons.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That “Waco Lodge No. 92, Ancient Free and Accepted Masons” in the city of Waco, be and the same is hereby declared to be a body corporate and politic, and that by said style and title of Waco Lodge No. 92, it may have succession, may sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded in any of the courts of this State; may have and use a common seal, and alter the same at pleasure; may hold real and personal property and estate to any amount not ex-
ceeding ten thousand dollars, and do all other things usually inci-
dent to such bodies corporate and politic not inconsistent with the laws and Constitution of this State or of the United States.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That this act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER CLVIII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the City of Huntsville, in Walker County, Texas.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That all the inhabitants of the city of Huntsville, in Walker county, be and they are hereby declared a body politic and corpo-
rate, under the name and style of the “Mayor, Aldermen and In-
habitants of the city of Huntsville,” and by that name they and their successors shall be known in law, and shall have power to sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded in all courts, and all actions and matters whatever, and may have a common seal, and by the same name shall have the power to acquire, hold and dispose of any estate, real and personal, for the benefit of said corporation; pro-
vided, such real estate be within the limits of said city.

Sec. 2. That the bounds and limits of said corporation shall in-
clude one mile square, to be run with the cardinal points of the Compass, of which the centre of the court house square, in the city of Huntsville, shall be the centre.

Sec. 3. That A. J. Rape, M. H. Goddin, H. C. Oliphant, W. B. Rome and A. L. McKinney be and they are hereby appointed com-
missioners to lay off said city, and make a plot defining its limits, which plot shall be filed in the county court of Walker county.

Sec. 4. That all persons who are qualified voters under the Con-
stitution of the State, and who have been citizens of said city four months next preceding an election, shall be authorized to vote in all elections held in said corporation.

Sec. 5. That the qualified electors of said corporation shall elect a mayor and five aldermen on the second Tuesday in March, eighteen hundred and seventy-three (1873), and every two years thereafter, who shall hold their offices for the term of two years, and until their successors shall be elected and qualified.
Sec. 6. That no person shall be eligible as an officer of said city who, at the time of his election, does not possess the qualifications of an elector under the Constitution and laws of the State.
Sec. 7. That the city authorities are authorized to divide the city into a convenient number of wards, and to fix and define the boundaries thereof.

Sec. 8. The city council of the city of Huntsville shall be composed of one mayor and five aldermen, who shall be appointed
Laws of the State of Texas.by the Governor, and hold their offices until their successors are duly elected and qualified.

Sec. 9. That the mayor and aldermen shall constitute the city council, over which the mayor, when present, shall preside, and in case of his absence they shall elect an aldermen to preside pro tempore, and in case of a tie in the vote of the board he shall give the casting vote.

Sec. 10. That the officers of said corporation, before entering upon the discharge of their duties, shall take and subscribe the oath of office required by the Constitution of the State, which may be taken before any officer legally authorized to administer oaths.

Sec. 11. The city council shall, at their first session, appoint a city marshal for and during his good behavior, who shall qualify as such in the manner prescribed by law; his duties and powers shall be co-extensive with the limits of said city, and similar to those of the sheriff of said county.

Sec. 12. The mayor of said city shall have the same jurisdic-
tion and power in all cases that are conferred on justices of the peace, and exclusive jurisdiction in all cases of offenses against the by-laws and ordinances of said city.

Sec. 13. No written process shall be necessary for the arrest of offenders against the by-laws and ordinances of said city, or against the laws of the State; should the mayor, a member of the city council or the city marshal so direct, arrests shall be made without warrants therefor, in all cases where escapes would otherwise be the consequence.

Sec. 14. The payment of all fines shall be enforced by hard labor upon the public streets, squares, or other works of said city, until said fine and costs are paid; for which capias may issue imme-
diately after the trial, and all expenses incurred in the custody and safe keeping of the offender, shall be considered a part of the costs, and he or she, as the case may be, shall not be discharged until said fine and costs are fully paid, or secured to be paid, as may be pre-
scribed by the by-laws and ordinances of said city.

Sec. 15. The city marshal shall be the assessor and collector of all taxes, fines and penalties due the city; and the city council shall appoint with his approbation, or he may appoint with their ap-
proval, as many deputies for this or any other purpose as may be deemed necessary under such by-laws and ordinances as may be enacted by the city council.

Sec. 16. All by-laws and ordinances shall take effect the day after their publication in a newspaper within the city, which shall publish the same upon a certified copy by the proper officer, under
Laws of the State of Texas.the seal of the city, which the city council shall adopt and pro-
cure.

Sec. 17. It shall be the duty of the city council to regulate by law, their regular meetings, at such times and at such places within said city as may be prescribed, and upon the call of the mayor, the said aldermen shall assemble at such time and place as may be named in said call, and if a quorum be present any business may be transacted as well at a called meeting as at a regular meeting; and the mayor shall have power to enforce the attendance of all mem-
bers at any meeting upon his own motion, or upon the motion of any other member; and unless by the consent of the quorum, no business shall be transacted until the meeting is full, or absent members excused by vote of the city council.

Sec. 18. The fees of the mayor shall be the same as those pre-
scribed by law for justices of the peace, together with such other salary as may be allowed by a general law of the city council; and the fees of the city marshal or his deputies, shall be made the same as State or county officers are allowed by law for similar services, and such other allowances as the board of aldermen may deem proper.

Sec. 19. That in case of the inability of the mayor of the city of Huntsville to perform his duties by reason of absence, refusal or other cause, or in the event of a vacancy in said office, occasioned by death, resignation or otherwise, the board of aldermen may be, and they are hereby authorized and empowered to appoint from their own body a presiding officer, who shall be mayor pro tempore, which said officer shall have and may exercise all the powers con-
ferred by law on the mayor, and shall perform all the duties of mayor until his return, or the removal of his inability, or until his successor shall have been elected or appointed, and shall have qualified as required by law.

Sec. 20. That in case any vacancy in the office of any elective officer shall occur, the same shall be filled by appointment of the Governor, if a mayor or alderman; and a similar vacancy in the of-
fice of any other elective officer shall be filled by election by the board of aldermen; and a similar vacancy in the office of an ap-
pointed officer shall be filled by appointment of the mayor.

Sec. 21. The city council when in session, shall have power to punish for contempt of its proceedings, and at each meeting of the council the doors shall be open and free access had by the citizens of said city to all the deliberations of the city council.

Sec. 22. It shall be the duty of the city council at its first meet-
ing to appoint a city treasurer, who shall possess the same qualifica-
tions, and shall perform like duties as county treasurers are required by law to perform, and he shall qualify as may be prescribed by law.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p:
Sec. 23. That the city council shall have power and authority to make and pass such by-laws and ordinances as they shall deem necessary to maintain the cleanliness and health of said city; to secure the safety and convenience of persons passing on the streets, sidewalks, squares and public highways of said city; to maintain and repair pavements in said streets at the cost of the proprietors of lands, houses and lots fronting thereon; and to prevent any en-
croachments upon the public streets, highways or alleys of the said city; to inspect premises and cause the abatement of anything what-
ever that may endanger the health and comfort of the inhabitants of said city; to organize an efficient police force, and to establish rules for the government of the same; to provide proper safeguards to prevent injury by fire; to cause theatres, playhouses, and other places for show or exhibitions to be closed, whenever the preserva-
tion of order may require it; to close dram shops and drinking sa-
loons whenever deemed expedient; to establish markets, and regu-
late the same; to define and suppress nuisances; to regulate and fix the compensation of draymen and other common carriers in said city; and to establish all such rules and regulations as they may deem useful and necessary to preserve the peace and promote the general welfare and happiness of the inhabitants of said city.

Sec. 24. That the city council, by a vote of two-thirds present at any regular meeting, taken by “yeas” and “nays” and entered upon their journals, shall have power to assess, license and tax hawkers, peddlers, auctioneers, theatrical and other exhibitions, shows and amusements, billiard tables, nine and ten pin alleys, pub-
lic drays and wagons, dram shops and drinking saloons, beer sa-
loons, and such other trades and occupations as may be taxed by any general law of this State; in no case to exceed one-half of the State tax allowed upon such occupations; and may in like manner assess and collect a direct annual tax upon all property, real and personal, situated within the limits of said city, not to exceed one-half the State tax allowed in any one year.

Sec. 25. That every person on whom, or on Whose vocation or occupation, a tax has been assessed, shall before engaging in such vocation pay to the city treasurer the amount of said tax, taking his receipt therefor, which receipt shall entitle him to a corresponding license, to be issued by the mayor. If any person or persons shall engage in any vocation within the limits of said city on which a license tax may have been assessed, without first having obtained a license therefor from the mayor, such person or persons shall be liable to additional assessment of fifty per centum of the amount so due, to be recovered by suit in any court having jurisdiction; all assessments and collections of taxes in said city shall be made in
Laws of the State of Texas.accordance with the laws of this State regulating the assessment and collection of taxes; and the mayor and aldermen are hereby em-
powered t oenforce the payment of all taxes due said city, under such rules and regulations and penalties as they may prescribe, in accordance with the laws of this State.

Sec. 26. That the city council shall have power to suppress all gambling houses, and all houses of prostitution, and disorderly houses of every character, and shall adopt summary measures to enforce the same.

Sec. 27. That the city council shall have power to prescribe penalties for the violation of the by-laws and ordinances of said city, not to exceed a fine of fifty dollars in any one case, or im-
prisonment for three weeks.

Sec. 28. That all acts and parts of acts conflicting with or con-
travening the provisions of this act are hereby repealed, and that this act take effect from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CLIX.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Germania Club of the city of Galveston.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That Aug. Butler, O. Garrison, A. Heydecker, Otto Artz, F. Lammers, F. Halff, S. Levy, I. Feist, A. Cohn, J. W. Jockusch, S. Rinker. C. F. Gaisbuesch, C. F. Hohorst, H. Frauenfeld, L. A. Walther, J. A. Braun, C. J. Thuessing, J. Focke, H. Wilkens, Carl Kloss, H. Runge, Jul. Runge, J. Frederich, P. Erhard, F. Wagner, C. H. Jordan, E. Niebour, C. L. Beissner, E. Reinecke, P. Lassow, A. Stein, F. Martini, L. Block, H. Steusse, Capt. Barnes, J. Foth, T. Rhode, G. W. Trapp, Id. Hirsch, P. Vogel, F. Gloor, G. Bon-
dies. J. Holstein, A. Bader, E. Burkhardt, E. Mate, F. Lindenthal, F. L. Becker, M. Ranger, A. Sporleder, C. Vidor, J. F. Rouk, Silvan Blum, W. J. Kampe, M. Kampe, M. Ortlieb, F. O. Meyer, H. Veers, E. Engelke, G. L. Voege, and their associates and suc-
cessors, are hereby constituted a body corporate, under the name of the “Germania Club of the city of Galveston,” to be located in said city, having for its object the promotion of social entertain-
ments, with power to take by purchase, devise, or otherwise, and to
Laws of the State of Texas.hold, transfer, mortgage and convey such real and personal estate as shall be necessary for the purposes of the corporation, to the amount of twenty-five thousand dollars, with the privilege of increasing to fifty thousand dollars.

Sec. 2. The said corporation shall have power to prescribe rules and orders for its general government, for the admission and ex-
pulsion of members, for the selection, term of office, number and duties of its officers, and for the direction and management of its affairs.

Sec. 3. The disposal and control of the funds, property and es-
tate of the said corporation shall be vested in a board of not less than five trustees, of which board the president, secretary and treasurer shall be members.

Sec. 4. The president, vice president, secretary and treasurer shall be elected annually, at the time and in the manner provided for in the by-laws of said corporation, and shall hold office until their successors shall be elected. The board of trustees shall be appointed annually by the president.

Sec. 5. T. Rhode, L. A. Whither, H. Frauenfeld, F. Linden-
thal and C. F. Hohorst shall constitute the first board of trustees of the corporation hereby created.
Sec. 6. This act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CLX.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the town of Lexington, in Burleson county.

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the citizens of the town of Lexington, in the county of Burleson, be and they are hereby declared to be a body politic and corporate under the name and style of the “Corporation of the town of Lexington,” by which name they may sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, and acquire and hold real and personal property within the limits of said corporation, and at their pleasure sell and dispose of the same.
Sec. 2. That the limits of said corporation shall be three square miles each way from the academy.

Sec. 3. The mayor and board of aldermen of said town shall
Laws of the State of Texas.be appointed by the Governor, and the board of aldermen shall con-
sist of five members, and shall hold their offices until the next gen-
eral election, unless sooner removed by the Governor. They shall have authority to appoint a constable, secretary and treasurer, and such other officers as they may deem necessary for said corporation. The treasurer, constable, and such other officers as they may require to do so, shall give such bonds as shall be approved by the mayor of said city, for the faithful performance of the duties of each office, and each officer shall make such reports, and at such times as the board of aldermen may require. The mayor shall hold and exercise all the powers and jurisdiction of a justice of the peace, and before entering upon the duties of his office shall take the oath prescribed by the Constitution, and give such bond and security as a justice of the peace is required to give. The constable shall hold and exercise all the powers and discharge all the duties within said corporation of a constable of the county.

Sec. 4. That the mayor and board of aldermen of said corpora-
tion shall have power to pass such rules and ordinances as may be necessary for the regulation of the police and the preservation of order within the limits of said corporation; to levy taxes for keeping the streets in order, for the removal of nuisances and for the gen-
eral maintenance of the property of said town and for the support of its officers; and said mayor and aldermen shall have authority to make penalties for the violation of said rules and ordinances; pro-
vided, that said penalties shall not be in conflict with the Constitu-
tion and laws of this State, and they shall have authority to enforce all such rules and ordinances.

Sec. 5. That the mayor, with a majority of the said board, shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of all business of the cor-
poration.

Sec. 6. That no person shall be eligible to hold an office in said corporation, or vote for the officers thereof, unless he be a citizen of the State, and shall have resided in the limits of said corporation six months immediately preceding such election; provided further, that all persons living in said corporation, legally qualified to vote in other elections, shall be entitled to vote and hold office at the first election.

Sec. 7. That it shall be the duty of the mayor to cause an elec-
tion to be held every two years, for the election of a mayor and al-
dermen, and he shall give public notice of said election at least ten days before the expiration of his term of office.

Sec. 8. That in case of failure of the mayor to order and hold such election as specified in this charter, then any five citizens
Laws of the State of Texas.within the limits of said corporation may, after giving ten days’ notice, order and hold such election.

Sec. 9. The number of aldermen to be elected in said city shall be determined by the mayor and aldermen first appointed under this charter by the Governor, and thereafter that number shall be elected at any election held for that purpose.
Sec. 10. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CLXI.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Union Coal, Iron and Copper Mining and Manufacturing Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That Benj. A. Botts, F. E. Grothaus, L. I. Levin, E. H. Cushing, Rowland Allen, Fitzhugh Ward, Fritz Tegener, J. W. Johnson and W. J. Locke, and such persons as may become asso-
ciated with them in manner as hereinafter provided, be and they are hereby made and constituted a body politic and corporate, by the name and style of the “Union Coal, Iron and Copper Mining and Manufacturing Company,” and by that name shall have succession, and be able to sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded in any court whatsoever, may contract and be contracted with, may have a com-
mon seal, and alter and renew the same at pleasure; and may make all necessary by-laws, rules and regulations for the transaction of the business and government of said company, not inconsistent with the Constitution and laws of the State and of the United States; and the said company shall have all the power, facilities, franchises, and rights necessary or convenient for carrying on within the limits of the State the mining of coal, and for the mining and manufac-
turing of iron, copper and other ores, and for the manufacture of lumber and other products of its property, and selling and disposing of the same; and for acquiring and holding within the limits of the State, by lease or purchase, lands and mines, and erecting factories, machinery and equipments convenient or useful for carrying on its business; provided, the quantity of land owned by it at any one time shall not exceed one hundred thousand acres.

Sec. 2. That to enable said company to transport the products
Laws of the State of Texas.of its mines, lands and manufactures to market, it shall have power to construct, lease, purchase and hold, such railroads or tram roads, not any one exceeding thirty miles in length, as it may deem neces-
sary; and said company may connect said railroads and train roads with any existing or future railroad in this State; and in surveying, locating, constructing and preserving such railroads with their ap-
purtenances and equipments, it shall have all the power, rights and privileges conferred, granted and given to railroads by the gen-
eral railroad laws of this State; provided, it shall not receive any land grant or other State aid.

Sec. 3. And be it further enacted, That the capital stock of said company shall not exceed one million of dollars, and shall be divided into shares of one hundred dollars each, and the subscrip-
tion to the said capital stock shall be made at such place and in such manner as shall be designated by the incorporators herein men-
tioned or a majority of them, and that the stockholders at all their meetings shall be entitled to one vote for each share of stock in per-
son or by proxy, and the shares of said capital stock shall be assign-
able or transferable as may be provided for by the by-laws of said company, and shall be considered as personal property, and lands may be subscribed instead of money in such manner and on such terms as may be agreed upon between the subscribers and the per-
sons who may be appointed by the incorporators to take the sub-
scriptions of said capital stock.

Sec. 4. That the affairs of the company shall be managed by a president and five directors, who shall be Chosen annually by the stockholders to serve one year, and until others shall be elected, and until the first election of directors shall be held, the said incorpora-
tors herein mentioned, or a majority of them, shall have full power and authority to exercise all corporate powers of said company, and in case of any vacancy occurring in the presidency or directors of said company, the remaining directors shall have the power to fill such vacancy by appointing some other stockholder until the next general election thereafter.
Sec. 5. That the said company shall be organized and a general meeting of the stockholders shall be held within one year from the final passage of this act.
Sec. 6. That this act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage, and continue for a period of fifty years.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER CLXII.

opener.salute:
An Act to incorporate the city of Brenham, and to grant a new charter to said city, and to repeal all acts heretofore passed in-
corporating said city, which may be in force by virtue of any ex-
isting charter.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That all the inhabitants within one and one-half square miles of the court house in Brenham shall constitute a body politic and corporate, with succession, by the name and style of the “City of Brenham,” and as such, by that name, shall be capable of con-
tracting and being contracted with, suing and being sued, implead-
ing and being impleaded in all courts and places and in all matters whatsoever; may purchase and hold real, personal and mixed prop-
erty, and dispose of the same for the benefit of said city, and may have and use a corporate seal and change and renew the same at pleasure.

Sec. 2. That the municipal affairs of said city shall be admin-
istered by a mayor and five aldermen, a marshal, an assessor and collector, a treasurer, and such subordinate officers as the mayor and aldermen may deem necessary; said officers shall be required to take and subscribe, before any officer authorized to administer oaths, the oath prescribed by the Constitution; the mayor and alder-
men to be elected, and the others appointed by the mayor, with the advice and consent of the board of aldermen.

Sec. 3. That every male person residing within the above named limits qualified by the existing laws of this State to vote for mem-
bers of the House of Representatives, shall be entitled to vote for municipal officers of said city.
Sec. 4. That any qualified voter for municipal officers shall be eligible to hold such offices, and none but such qualified voters, shall be entitled to hold the same.

Sec. 5. That an election for municipal officers shall be held every four years, on the first Monday in November; provided, that the Governor of the State of Texas may appoint the municipal offi-
cers, to act as such until the next general election to be held as aforesaid; and provided, that a majority of the board of aldermen shall have power to provide by ordinance for filling, by special elec-
tions, all vacancies occuring among the municipal officers after the next general election.

Sec. 6. That notice of election shall be given at least ten days previous thereto; by publication in one or more newspapers of said
Laws of the State of Texas.city; and elections shall proceed in all other respects as provided for the election of county officers by the laws now existing, or that may hereafter be enacted.

Sec. 7. That the mayor of said city shall be the chief executive magistrate thereof, and it shall be his duty to be active and vigilant in causing the laws, ordinances and regulations of the city, to be executed and enforced. He shall take instant measures for quelling all riots and disorders. He shall exercise general supervision over the conduct of all subordinate officers, and cause all violations of law or neglect of duty to be reported to the board of aldermen, to he punished by fine not to exceed one hundred dollars, or by dis-
missal from office, as they shall see fit. He shall, at the request of two aldermen, call special meetings of the board of aldermen, caus-
ing due notice to be given to each member thereof, and shall pre-
side at meetings of the board, but shall have no vote unless there be a tie, in which case he shall give the casting vote. He shall from time to time recommend to said board such measures as con-
cern the welfare of the city, and perform such duties as the board of aldermen may lawfully require of him, in his official capacity; and for his services shall receive such salary as may be determined by said board, which shall not be diminished during his term of office. The said mayor shall have the civil and criminal jurisdiction of a justice of the peace within the corporete limits of said city, in addi-
tion to that of enforcing the by-laws of his city and all other powers herein granted.

Sec. 8. That the board of aldermen, a majority of whom shall form a quorum, shall have full power and authority to pass such or-
dinances, regulations, laws and by-laws, as they may deem neces-
sary for their own government, and to preserve the peace, cleanli-
ness, comfort and salubrity of said city; to secure the safety and convenience of passing in the streets, alleys and squares; to direct the construction and repairs of sidewalks on the said streets, at the cost of proprietors; provided, the cost, shall not exceed one per cent. on the value of said property; to provide for draining all low grounds and lots in said city and filling the same; to establish a city guard or patrol and to regulate the same; to establish one or more market places and provide for inspection of articles sold there-
in; to prevent the establishment in said city of houses of ill-fame, or places of resort for gambling or other vicious practices, and generally to pass all such acts as may not be in violation of the laws of this State or the Constitution thereof; provided, that no ordi-
nance, law or by-law shall go into effect unless approved by the mayor, or being disapproved by him shall be passed by three-fifths of the board of aldermen.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p:
Sec. 9. That three-fifths of said board may at any time dismiss, for cause assigned, any officer except the mayor, and elect a new incumbent; and to defray the expenses of said city the said board are authorized to impose a direct property and license tax upon all such persons, property and employments, as are liable to taxation under the Constitution and laws of this State, and to make and exe-
cute all laws necessary to enforce the collection of the same; pro-
vided, that no property tax shall exceed, for any one year, one-half of one per cent. of the value of the property, nor shall any license tax exceed one-half of that levied by the State; nor shall the tax be levied without the concurrence of four-fifths of the whole board in its favor; and to enforce the ordinances of said city the said board shall impose, for the violation thereof, such fines and pen-
alties not exceeding one hundred dollars, and such imprisonment not exceeding five days, to be inflicted through the mayor’s court, as they may deem proper and necessary. The said board may pro-
vide for the mode of assessment and collection of taxes, and the safe keeping of the public moneys, including fines, which shall be paid into tire city treasury, and for the disbursement of the same.
Sec. 10. That the marshal shall perform such duties as shall be assigned him by the board of aldermen.

Sec. 11. That for the more efficient discharge of their duties the mayor and marshal are empowered to call to their aid the as-
sistance of any resident of said city whenever, in the discharge of their several duties in repressing disorders, they may need the same; and any person or persons who shall, when so called upon, neglect or refuse, shall be liable to such fine, not exceeding one hundred dollars, as the mayor may in his sound discretion impose.

Sec. 12. That in any suit in which said city may be a party it shall be no exception to the competency of a witness, that he is an inhabitant of or the owner of taxable property in said city, and all writs served upon the mayor shall be deemed to be served upon the city of Brenham.

Sec. 13. That all acts and parts of acts in conflict with the pro-
visions of this act are hereby repealed.
Sec. 14. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER CLXIII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Casino Society of Victoria.

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That L. F. Mack, H. Fischer, E. Schadnitz, A. Hensoldt, F. Praeger, and their associates be and they are hereby constituted a body politic and corporate, under the name and style of “The Casino Society of Victoria,” for the purpose of encouraging and advancing tine arts and literary sciences and social intercourse. That by the above name they shall have succession, and have the right to sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, in any of the courts of this State; to acquire and hold estate, real, personal or mixed; to sell, alienate, trade, traffic, or otherwise dispose of the same, as said society may deem expedient; provided, that the amount of property held by said society shall at no time exceed the sum of sixty thousand dollars.

Sec. 2. That the surplus remaining of any proceeds derived from lectures, artistic exhibitions and dramatic performances, after the necessary expenses or improvements Shall have been paid, shall be used for the support and benefit of any public school or schools in the city of Victoria that the incorporators or their successors may designate, and to no other purpose.

Sec. 3. That said society shall be governed and controlled by a president, a vice president, secretary and treasurer, together with a board of trustees, and shall have power to enact by-laws, rules and regulations for its government, not inconsistent with the existing laws of this State, and to alter and amend the same. The said so-
ciety shall also have a common seal.
Sec. 4. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage, and remain in force for thirty years.

div3.head: CHAPTER CLXIV.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Hempstead and West Liberty Air Line Railway Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That E. S. Graham, G. T. Allen, J. W. Howard, R. H.
Laws of the State of Texas.Wynne, W. S. Dugat, J. B. Shepherd, W. W. Leggett, C. C. Nash, George Laurence, Wm. W. Upham, Chas. Dilloway, I. C. Day, John Phelps, of Louisiana, and their associates and successors, be and they are hereby created and appointed a body politic and corporate in deed and in law, to be known by the name and style of the “Hempstead and West Liberty Air Line Railway Company,” and as such shall have succession for ninety-nine years, and a common seal, with capacity to sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, buy and sell, grant and receive, contract and be contracted with, make and enforce by-laws, and generally to perform all such acts as may be necessary and consistent with the Constitution of this State and the laws regulating railroads; and the first named seven of the above written incorporators shall constitute the first board of direc-
tors, and shall continue in office until their successors have been elected as hereinafter provided for, and said board of directors shall fix the amount of capital stock of said company and the amount to be subscribed before a permanent organization is perfected, and the amount or amounts to be paid down.

Sec. 2. When the amount of capital stock of said company has been fixed by the board of directors, it shall be divided into shares of one hundred dollars each, and each share shall entitle the holder thereof to one vote, and when the amount of stock to be subscribed before permanent organization has been taken up by bona fide hold-
ers, the president, by the direction of the board, shall call a meeting at such time and place as he may be so directed for the permanent organization of said company, by the election of such officers and adoption of such by-laws and rules as may be deemed expedient.

Sec. 3. That the said company is hereby authorized and em-
powered to construct, own, equip, maintain and operate a continu-
ous line of railroad, with a double or single track, and a telegraph line from Hempstead, Texas, across the State of Texas, as nearly as practicable and expedient on an air line to West Liberty, Texas, with such branches and connections with other railroads as may be for the best interest of trade and the company, and to cross all streams by bridge or ferry, and to cross the track of any intersecting railroads.

Sec. 4. The State of Texas hereby grants to said company the right of way, to the extent of two hundred feet in width, over all lands in the State along the line of its route as above stated for the laying of its track, and such lands as may be necessary for sidings, turn tables, depots, station houses, machine shops, wells, water tanks, etc., etc., and the right to make preliminary surveys for the location of their said road, and the further right to take from any
Laws of the State of Texas.lands belonging to the State within ten miles of its said track any wood, stone, earth or other materials.

Sec. 5. That should the owner or owners of any land or lands over which such road of said railroad company must pass disagree with said company as to the amount to be paid for said land or lands, such disagreement shall be settled according to the general railroad laws of this State; and said company shall commence the construction of its road within three years from and after the pas-
sage of this act.
Sec. 6. That any general law allowing benefits to railroads in this State shall apply to said company and road.
Sec. 7. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CLXV.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the “Hope Independent Fire Company No. 4,” of Galveston, Texas.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That Ebenezer Pye, William Lockerbie, Pat Dougherty, C. F. Keenan, and James Raycraft, and their associates and succes-
sors and assigns, are hereby declared to be a body corporate in law and in fact, under the name and style of the “Hope Independent Fire Company No. 4,” of Galveston, Texas, and in that name they may sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, contract and be con-
tracted with, may have and use a common seal, may buy and hold or lease, or sell and convey real and personal property, not to exceed in amount twenty thousand dollars, for the use of the company.
Sec. 2. The actual members of said company shall not exceed in number one hundred and twenty-five members.

Sec. 3. The members of said company in active service shall be exempt from serving on juries, except in criminal cases. The cer-
tificate of the proper officers of the company with the seal of the company thereon, shall be sufficient evidence that said member is in active service.

Sec. 4. The company shall have authority to make by-laws for its government, to compel the attendance and services of mem-
Laws of the State of Texas.bers, or expel them for non-attendance or refusal to do service by a majority vote of the members in active service.
Sec. 5. This act shall be in force from and after its passage, for the time of twenty years.

div3.head: CHAPTER CLXVI.

opener.salute: An Act to prohibit the sale of intoxicating or spirituous liquors within two miles of Mansfield College, Tarrant county.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That it shall be unlawful for any person or persons, to dis-
pose of any intoxicating or spirituous liquors, by sale or otherwise, except for medicinal or sacramental purposes, within two miles of Mansfield College, in Tarrant county.

Sec. 2. That any person or persons violating the provisions of the foregoing act, shall upon conviction thereof in any court of com-
petent jurisdiction, be fined in any sum not less than ten nor more than one hundred dollars for each and every offense.
Sec. 3. That this act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CLXVII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Bluffton Male and Female Academy.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That J. B. Maxwell, C. A. Davis, S. K. McFarland and J. B. Pankey are hereby constituted a board of trustees for the man-
agement and control of an institution of learning, to be located fif-
teen miles northeast of the town of Llano, in the county of Llano, in the State of Texas, and that they and their successors in office
Laws of the State of Texas.are hereby declared a body corporate and politic, capable, under the name and style of “Bluffton Male and Female Academy,” of suing and being sued, of pleading and being impleaded, and Of acquiring, holding and disposing of property, real and personal; provided, the amount of property shall not exceed in the aggregate the sum of twenty-five thousand dollars; and provided, further, that no prop-
erty, either real or personal, shall be bought or sold, acquired or held by said academy for speculative purposes, but solely for the objects for which this charter is granted, which are hereby declared to be the promotion and advancement of education, literature and good morals.

Sec. 2. That said board of trustees shall have succession, and may have and use a common seal for the authentication of their acts, and may do all other things consistent with the Constitution and laws of the United States or of this State, that may be neces-
sary for or incident to the objects for which this charter is granted as aforesaid.

Sec. 3. That said board of trustees shall maintain a school or-
ganization during the accustomed scholastic months of the year, and should they fail or neglect to do so in any one year, then this charter of incorporation and the privileges therein granted shall cease.

Sec. 4. That the said board of trustees shall make annually, to the Superintendent of Public Instruction, such reports as he may require, concerning the statistics, educational or otherwise, of the said Bluffton Male and Female Academy.
Sec. 5. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CLXVIII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the “Bank of Sabine Pass.”

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas. That there may be established at Sabine Pass an association for the purpose of transacting a general banking and exchange busi-
ness, which association shall be called and known by the name of the “Bank of Sabine Pass,” and the stockholders and their successors shall have continuous succession, and by that name shall be capable of suing and being sued in all the courts of this State; of purchas-
Laws of the State of Texas.ing, holding and conveying property of all descriptions; to make, have and use a common seal, and generally to do any act necessary to carry into effect the objects of the corporation not inconsistent with the laws of this State or of the United States.

Sec. 2. That the capital stock of this association shall be not less than two hundred and fifty thousand dollars, to be divided into shares of one hundred dollars each, to be paid for at the time of sub-
scription, which capital stock may be increased to one million dol-
lars at the discretion of the president and directors of this corpora-
tion. The said stock shall be deemed and held as personal property, and be represented by certificates under the seal of the association, signed by the president and countersigned by the treasurer or cash-
ier.

Sec. 3. That the books of subscription to said capital stock shall be opened at Sabine Pass under the supervision of C. H. Alexander, B. F. McDonough, T. R. Buford, J. B. Likens, W. W. Morris, Wm. Allison, N. J. Moore, or any three of them, and at such place at said Sabine Pass as they or any three of them may direct. Ad-
vertisement of the time and place of opening such books to be made for one week in some newspaper published at the said Sabine Pass; and they shall be kept open until the sum of two hundred and fifty thousand dollars shall be subsribed for; and the said commission-
ers, or any three of them, shall as soon as may be after the books of subscription are closed, call a meeting of the subscribers, and shall proceed to the election of not less than seven directors as may be de-
termined by them, and the said directors shall elect one of their own number president, and the said president and directors elected in pursuance of this act and their successors, shall have full power and authority to make, appoint and remove at pleasure, all officers and agents of said association; to fix their compensation; prescribe their duties, and to provide for the taking of bonds for faithful discharge of their duties, as well as generally to manage the affairs of the asso-
ciation. They shall also have power to fill any vacancy that may occur in their own body, and also appoint a president pro tem, when the president may be absent from their meetings, and if the presi-
dent or any director be absent without leave for five successive reg-
ular meetings of the board, a majority of the same may declare his place vacant, and proceed to fill it without notice to such president or director.

Sec. 4. That, the directors of this corporation shall call an an-
nual meeting of the stockholders to make such election for direc-
tors, who when so elected shall hold their offices for the term of one year, or until their successors are elected; and no person shall be eligible to the office of director, unless he owns at least five shares of stock.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p:
Sec. 5. That in all meetings of the stockholders those repre-
senting a majority of the stock shall constitute a quorum; and each stockholder shall be allowed one vote for each and every share he may hold, and the power to cast the vote of any absent stockholder may be constituted by written power in such form as the directors may prescribe by the by-laws.

Sec. 6. That said corporation shall have full power to receive money and other valuables to keep for depository; to issue certifi-
cates or bills payable on demand or at specified times; to buy and sell coin and uncurrent money; and to buy, sell, draw or negotiate bills of exchange or other securities. It may loan its money and discount any promissory note, or negotiable paper, or other security assignable by law, receiving the interest or discount thereon in ad-
vance.

Sec. 7. That the president and directors of said corporation shall have full power to pass such by-laws as may be necessary, to carry this act into effect; to delegate authority to such officer or agent as they may think proper; and to execute, or authorize the execu-
tion, of all such bargains and contracts as may seem to them for the best interest of this corporation; and it is provided that a ma-
jority of the board of directors shall, constitute a quorum for the transaction of all business.

Sec. 8. That the president and directors of said corporation shall have full power to fix the places and mode of transfer of stock, as well as the payment of interest and dividends; and any person in whose name shares of stock stand on the books of this corporation Shall, so far as affect the rights and acts of the association, be deemed at law and in equity the owner.

Sec. 9. That if any stockholder shall for valuable consideration sell, pledge, or otherwise dispose, of any of his shares of stock to another, and deliver to him the certificate of such shares, with a power of attorney authorizing the transfer of the same on the books of the association, the title of such stockholder, both at law and in equity, shall vest in the purchaser so far as may be necessary to ef-
fect the purpose of the sale, pledge, or other disposition, not only as between the parties themselves, but also as against the creditors of and subsequent purchasers from such stockholder, subject to the provision of the eighth section.

Sec. 10. That when any person to whom a certificate of stock shall have been issued alleges it to have been lost, he shall file in the office of this corporation: first, an affidavit, setting forth the time, place and circumstances of the loss; second, proof of his having ad-
vertised the same in some newspaper once a week for two months; and third, a bond to the aesoceiation, with one or more sureties, condi-
tioned to indemnify all persons and against any loss in consequence
Laws of the State of Texas.of issuing a new certificate in place of the former; and thereupon the board of directors, if satisfied of such loss, and with such secu-
rity, may direct such new certificate to be issued.

Sec. 11. That this charter, and all the privileges and powers herein granted, shall continue in force and effect for the full term of twenty-five years from the passage of this act, and that this cor-
poration shall be responsible to the extent of its property, both real and personal, and that the funds, property and business transactions of the association shall be subject to the same rate of taxation by law imposed on the funds, property and similar transactions of in-
dividuals, and the stockholders shall not again be subject to tax on their Shares or dividends.
Sec. 12. This act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CLXIX.

opener.salute: An Act to prohibit the sale or distribution of spirituous or other intoxicating liquors, or the establishment of any drinking saloon, gambling house, house of ill-fame, etc., within certain limits.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That it shall not be lawful for any person, either with or without license, to establish or keep any drinking saloon, beer garden or dance house, or to sell or in any manner to dispose of any spirit-
uous, vinous or other intoxicating liquors, within half a mile of the cemetery ground of the Magnolia Grove Association, on Galveston island.
Sec. 2. That no person shall open, maintain or keep within the limit prescribed in section one of this act, any gambling house, house of ill-fame, cock pit, or place for prize fighting or dog fights.

Sec. 3. That any person violating any of the provisions of this act shall, upon conviction of any court of competent jurisdiction, be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and for the first offense be fined not less than twenty dollars nor more than one hundred dollars; and when convicted a second or other time of an offense under this act, shall for each separate offense be fined not less than fifty dol-
lars nor more than four hundred dollars, or by imprisonment in the
Laws of the State of Texas.county jail for not less than ten nor more than sixty days, either or both, in the discretion of the court or jury.
Sec. 4. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CLXX.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Seguin Manufacturing Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That T. S. Walker, J. M. Cox, J. F. McKee, and their associates and successors, be and they are hereby created a body corporate and politic, by the name and style of the “Seguin Manufacturing. Com-
pany,” for the manufacturing of woolen and cotton goods and other fabrics, spinning of thread, manufacture of wooden ware, and for general manufacturing purposes, and for doing and performing all other things necessary for the successful prosecution of the business and objects of said association, with capacity to own and hold real and personal property, to sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, and to take all other legal ways and means to carry out the objects of said company. Suits may be instituted against said company by service being had upon the president or secretary of the company. Said company shall pass and make such by-laws as they may deem necessary, not contrary to the Constitution and laws of this State or of the United States.

Sec. 2. That said factory be located on or near the Guadalupe river within five miles of the town of Seguin. The office of said company shall be in the county of Guadalupe, and said company shall have authority to draw water from the Guadalupe river by dam, race or otherwise, not to exceed one-fourth of the water of said river, for the purpose of running the machinery or other purposes, and the said company shall have the necessary right of way, not ex-
ceeding fifty feet wide, over any land on which it may be necessary to run said race; provided, said company shall pay the owner or owners the value of said right of way and such other damages, if any, that may be sustained by said owner or owners by the locating of said race; that in case the said company and the owner or owners of land cannot agree upon the value of the right of way over the same, and the damages, if any, in that case said company shall file
Laws of the State of Texas.a statement describing the land required and statement of facts con-
nected with the offer to purchase the same, with the judge of the county court, who shall thereupon appoint three disinterested per-
sons who shall value said land and assess said damages, if any; and in case either party is aggrieved at the award of said persons, in that case they can appeal from said award to the county court at its next term thereafter, whereupon said court shall order a jury to determine the matter in controversy as in other cases.

Sec. 3. That the capital stock shall not exceed two hundred thousand dollars, which may be invested in any way best calculated to insure the successful prosecution of the business of the company. The parties named and appointed by this act are hereby invested with rights and powers of directors, until directors may be chosen or elected by the stockholders of said company.

Sec. 4. That when the sum of five thousand dollars of the capi-
tal stock is subscribed on the books of the company, the directors shall proceed to organize said company by calling the stockholders together, and dividing the capital stock into shares of one hundred dollars each; each share will entitle the holder to one vote by him-
self or proxy; any stockholder may transfer his or her stock or shares by a transfer on the books of the company.

Sec. 5. That no person shall be eligible to the office of director who shall not be the holder of at least ten shares of the capital stock. The government of the affairs of said company shall be vested in a board of not less than three nor more than five directors, who shall be chosen annually by the stockholders. The board of directors shall elect one of their own members president, and ap-
point a secretary and treasurer, and such other officers as they may deem necessary. The directors shall have power to fill any vacancy that may occur by death, resignation or otherwise until the next regular election, which shall be held at the office of the company at the expiration of twelve months after the organization of said com-
pany, after having given at least ten days’ notice in such manner as may be prescribed by the by-laws of the company; and the company may require bond and security for the faithful performance of their several duties The books of the company shall be open to the in-
spection of the stockholders at all times.

Sec. 6. That if any stockholder shall refuse or fail to pay in his or her stock, or any instalment thereof, as may be required by the by-laws of said company, after ninety days’ notice from the di-
rectors, without good and sufficient cause shown, said stock shall be forfeited to the company, together with all instalments previously paid. No stockholder shall be liable for any debt or liability of
Laws of the State of Texas.said company for more than the amount of stock subscribed by him or her.

Sec. 7. That the rights, powers, privileges and immunities here-
by granted and conferred shall remain in force for the term of thir-
ty-years from and after the passage of this act, and this act shall take effect from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CLXXI.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Draymen’s Savings Club of Houston, Texas.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That Henry Furguson, Silas Phelps, F. W. Wilson, W. F. Rice, H. Taylor, Johnson Rice, Ed Craven, John Perry, and their associates and successors, are hereby made and declared to be a body politic and corporate, to be known by the name of the “Dray-
mem’s Savings Club of the city of Houston.”

Sec. 2. The said Drayman’s Savings Club shall have the right to sue and be sued in its corporate name; to hold and possess real estate and personal property; to receive gifts and bequests, and en-
joy all the civil rights of bodies corporate.

Sec. 3. The affairs of said body shall be managed by a board of officers consisting of a president, vice president, secretary and treasurer, and not less than five directors; they may have a common seal with such device as they may adopt, and an office for the trans-
action of their business.
Sec. 4. That this act take effect from date of its passage, and remain in force for and during the space of twenty years.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER CLXXII.

opener.salute:
An Act to prohibit the sale or otherwise disposing of spirituous or vinous liquors within three miles of Baylor University, in Wash-
ington County.

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the sale, furnishing or giving away of any intoxicating liquors or drinks to any student or students of Baylor University, situated in Washington county, Texas, is hereby prohibited within three miles of said university.

Sec. 2. That any person or persons violating the provisions of the foregoing section shall be fined in any sum not less than ten nor more than one hundred dollars for each violation of the same by any court of competent jurisdiction.

Sec. 3. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage; provided, a school organization be maintained in said university during the accustomed scholastic months of each and every year.

div3.head: CHAPTER CLXXIII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate Cedar Male and Female Institute.

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That for the management and control of an institution of learning, located in the county of Grayson, and styled “Cedar Male and Female Institute,” R. D. King, W. O. King, and A. P. King, are hereby constituted a board of trustees, and that they and their successors in office are made a body corporate, capable in law of suing and being sued, and of holding or alienating property, real or personal.

Sec. 2. That said board of trustees shall have succession, shall have a common seal, may hold property to the amount of twenty thousand dollars, may do all things necessary and incident to the maintenance and promotion of good morals and sound learning, not
Laws of the State of Texas.inconsistent with the Constitution and laws of the United States or of this State.
Sec. 3. That this act take effect from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CLXXIV.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the “Protection Fire Company No. 8,” of the City of Galveston, State of Texas.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That M. J. Freeman, H. L. Jones, Denny May, Noah L. Green, M. J. Freeman, Geo. P. Douglas, S. Heiman, C. B. Sheri-
dan and Arthur O’Mara, of the county of Galveston, and State of Texas, and their associates and successors, are hereby constituted a body politic and corporate under the name and style of the “Pro-
tection Fire Company No. 8,” and by that name shall have succes-
sion, and may sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, have and use a corporate seal, buy, sell and hold property, real, personal and mixed, not to exceed in value twenty thousand dollars; may contract and be contracted with, and make all rules and by-laws that may be necessary for the government of the company, and have and ex-
ercise all the powers and rights generally incident to such com-
panies.

Sec. 2. That said company shall have the right in its constitu-
tion or by-laws, to impose fines upon its members for neglect of duty, not to exceed, in any one instance, the sum of five dollars, which may be collected in the name of said company by suit before any justice of the peace in and for the county of Galveston.
Sec. 3. That the members of said company shall never be less than twenty, nor more than seventy-five in number.
Sec. 4. That the active members of the company, who shall have served therein for one year, shall be exempt from service as jurymen, except in capital cases.
Sec. 5. Thai neither the company, nor its members, shall be liable in damages or otherwise, for property destroyed or injured by the company while in the discharge of their duties as firemen.
Sec. 6. That all property of the company shall be exempt from taxation for State, county and city purposes.
Sec. 7. That this act take effect from and after its passage.

div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p:
The foregoing act, received in the office of the Secretary of State May nineteenth, one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one, having been presented to the Governor of Texas for his approval, and not having been returned by him to the house in which it orig-
inated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has become a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div3.head: CHAPTER CLXXV.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the town of Ysleta, in El Paso county.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the citizens of the town of Ysleta, in the county of El Paso, be and are hereby declared a body corporate, by the name and style of “The Town of Ysleta,” and by that name may sue and be sued, may have and use a corporate seal, may hold real and personal estate, and may dispose of real estate in the manner herein-
after provided, and in no other manner.

Sec. 2. That the corporate limits of said town shall include all within the following boundaries: Commencing at the northwest corner of the Socorro grant, on the Rio Grande; thence up the Rio Grande, with its meanderings, to the point where the Rio Grande and river Viejo separate; thence down the east bank of the river Viejo, with, its meanderings, to the southeast corner of survey No. 12; thence north with the east line of survey No. 12 to where it crosses the northern line of the “Cinecue tract;” thence southeast along the line of hills to the northeastern corner of the Socorro grant; thence along the northern boundary of the Socorro grant to the place of beginning.

Sec. 3. That no person shall be a qualified voter in said cor-
poration, unless he be a registered voter in the State, and shall have resided in said corporation six months.

Sec. 4. That no person shall be eligible to office in said corpora-
tion unless he be a qualified voter therein.

Sec. 5. That the corporate affairs of said town shall be admin-
istered by a mayor and nine aldermen, who shall be styled the “Town Council of the town of Ysleta.”
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p:
Sec. 6. The justice of the peace in the precinct in which said town is situated shall be ex officio mayor of the town; he shall pre-
side over the town council, and shall have no vote except in case of tie, when he shall give the casting vote.
Sec. 7. Two-thirds of the aldermen elected shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business, but a less number may at a regular meeting enforce the attendance of absent members.

Sec. 8. That at the first and each subsequent general election for State or county officers there shall be nine aldermen elected by the qualified voters of said town, who shall hold their office for two years, and until their successors shall have been elected and qualified, and said election shall be conducted in conformity with the laws regulating elections in this State.

Sec. 9. That should the election of any one of the aldermen be contested, said contest shall be tried by the town council, and shall be determined by a majority vote of those present when the contest is tried.
Sec. 10. That there shall be a constable, secretary, treasurer, assessor and collector, and alcalde of acequias for said town.
Sec. 11. The constable of the precinct in which the town is situated shall be ex officio constable of the town.

Sec. 12. That all officers of said town, before entering upon the duties of their office, shall take and subscribe the oath pre-
