scribed by the Constitution; and the mayor, constable, assessor and collector, and treasurer, shall also enter into bond with two good securities, to be approved by the town council, for the faithful performance of the duties of their office, payable to said corporation in such sum as the town council may require, which said bond shall not be void on the first recovery, but may be sued on from time to time in the name of any person injured by a breach thereof until the whole of the penalty is recovered.

Sec. 13. That the secretary, treasurer, assessor and collector and alcalde of aceqnias, shall be elected by the town council, and shall hold their office for two years and until their successors are elected and qualified; said officers shall be elected by a majority of the aldermen present. Said election shall be at a regular meeting of the town council as soon as possible after the aldermen have re-
ceived their certificates of election; and any of said officers may be removed at any regular meeting of the town council by a vote of two-thirds of the aldermen elected.
Sec. 14. The town council may, from time to time, provide by ordinance for the election or appointment of such other officers as they may deem necessary.

Sec. 15. The town council shall have and exercise control over
Laws of the State of Texas.the public square, streets and roads within said corporation; they shall have power to license, tax and regulate hawkers, peddlers, auctioneers, theatrical and other exhibitions, shows and amuse-
ments, billiard tables, nine and ten pin alleys, tippling houses, dram shops and groceries, and to determine the amount of tax on the same, and to suppress gaming or gambling houses, by whatever name or description known, and all disorderly houses; to establish and regulate public pounds, and to regulate the running at large of horses, mules, cattle and sheep; to regulate, restrain and prohibit the running at large of swine or other animals, and to authorize the distraining, impounding and sale of the same for the costs of the proceeding and the penalty incurred, and to impose penalties on the owners thereof for a violation of any ordinance in relation thereto; to tax, regulate, restrain and prohibit the running at large of dogs, and to authorize their destruction when at large, contrary to ordi-
nance, and to impose penalties on the owners or keepers thereof; to provide by ordinance for the opening, widening and cleaning of acequias, (or irrigating canals,) and to regulate the manner of working thereon; to provide by ordinance for the distribution of wa-
ter for irrigating purposes, and generally to do such other acts, and to pass such ordinances, not inconsistent with the Constitution and laws of this State or of the United States, as may conduce to the interest and welfare of said town; provided, that any ordinance, law or by-law, passed in pursuance off this act, shall not go into effect unless the same be approved by the mayor, or being disapproved by him, it be passed by a vote of two-thirds of the whole council; nor until five days after the same shall have been published by post-
ing copies thereof in three public places in said town, unless, in the opinion of three-fourths of said council, the emergency may be such as to require a departure from this rule.

Sec. 16. To defray the expenses of said town the said council are hereby fully authorized and empowered to impose a direct property and license tax upon all such persons, property and em-
ployments as are liable to taxation under the Constitution and laws of this State, and to make and execute all laws necessary to enforce the collection of the same; provided, nevertheless, that no property tax (unless for special purposes, and specially provided for by act of the Legislature,) shall for any one year exceed the one-half of one per cent. of the value of the property, nor any license tax the sum of one hundred dollars, nor shall any tax be levied without the con-
currence of three-fourths of the whole council in its favor. And in order the more effectually to enforce the ordinances of the said town the said town council shall impose upon the violation thereof such fines and penalties not exceeding one hundred dollars and such im-
Laws of the State of Texas.prisonment not exceeding fifteen days, to be collected and inflicted through the mayor’s court, as they may deem necessary and proper.

Sec. 17. The started meetings of the town council shall be on the second and fourth Saturdays of each month, and the mayor, whenever he considers it necessary, may call special meetings by notice to each of the members of said council, served personally or left at their usual places of abode; and the mayor shall, on applica-
tion of any three members of the council, call a special meeting.

Sec. 18. The council shall determine the rules of its own pro-
ceedings, and be the judge of the election and qualification of its own members, and shall have power to compel the attendance of absent members, and punish them for disorderly conduct, and with the concurrence of two-thirds of the council may expel a member.

Sec. 19. It shall be the duty of the secretary of said town to beep a correct record of the proceedings of the town council in a book kept for that purpose; to take charge of and keep safely all books, papers and accounts of the said council. He shall keep the town seal, and use it in the attestation of all documents signed by him by direction of the mayor or council. He shall receive and re-
ceipt for all moneys paid into the mayor’s court on account of fines imposed by said court, and shall pay the same to the treasurer, tak-
ing his receipt therefor, and shall generally perform such other duties as the town council may lawfully require of him. He shall receive for his services such compensation as the town council may determine, not to be changed during the term of service of the in-
cumbent.

Sec. 20. That the treasurer of said town shall receive, and keep securely, all moneys belonging to the said town, and make all pay-
ments for the same upon the order of the mayor, attested by the sec-
retary and the seal of the town; he shall keep regular and correct accounts of their real, personal and mixed property; and shall ren-
der a correct statement of his receipts and payments to the town council at their first regular meeting in each quarter, and whenso-
ever at other times he be required by them to do so; and at the end of every half year shall cause to be published at the expense of the town a statement, showing the amount of receipts and expenditures for the six months next preceding, and the general condition of the treasury; and shall do and perform such other acts and duties as the town council may lawfully require of him as the treasurer of the town. And for his services the said treasurer shall receive such compensation as the town council may deem sufficient, said compensation not to be changed during the term of service of the incumbent.

Sec. 21. That the assessor and collector of the town shall make up the assessment of all the property taxed by the town, and collect
Laws of the State of Texas.the taxes of every kind as they shall become due and owing, and generally perform all the duties in relation to town taxes as are re-
quired of the justices of the peace and sheriffs in regard to the State and county taxes, under such forms and regulations as the town council may prescribe, and shall pay over to the treasurer every month the moneys he shall have received, and make a report thereof to the town council at their first regular meeting in every quarter. All assessments of property shall be made under oath by the party returning the same; if the appraisement be unsatisfactory to the as-
sessor it shall be referred to a board of three commissioners, being owners of real estate in the town to the value of five hundred dollars, each and entirely disconnected with the administration of the town, who shall be appointed by the town council, and whose decision shall be final. The same commissioners shall assess [the] value of all property whose owners are unknown, or which may not have been returned, and receive for their services such remuneration, not being a per centage, as the town council shall think proper.

Sec. 22 The alcalde of acequias shall supervise all work un-
dertaken by the town council on the acequias; he shall see that the acequias are kept clean and in good condition, and shall supervise the partition of water for irrigating purposes.

Sec. 23. That whenever a vacancy shall occur in the town coun-
cil or any other office in said town by death, resignation, removal or otherwise, or whenever from any cause the regular election shall not be held at the proper time, the town council shall as soon as practicable thereafter, order an election to fill such vacancy, or to supply the place of such omitted election, and the said elec-
tion so ordered shall be conducted in all things in the same man-
ner as hereinbefore prescribed for the regular election; and in case of the sickness of any officer, and until the vacancy shall be filled by such election, the town council are hereby fully authorized and empowered to appoint other persons (if it be the office of the mayor, from their own, and if any other officer, from without their body) to fill such office until such sick person shall recover, or such vacancy be filled by election by the people, or by the town council, and the person so appointed shall have the same powers, perform the same duties, be subject to the same penalties and receive the same compensation for the time being, as if he had been duly elected to said office.

Sec. 24. That the town council shall have the power, in the manner hereinafter specified, to grant or sell portions of real estate, the property of said town Ysleta, to any of the following per-
son or persons, and to no other: First, to actual settlers on said lands who are citizens of the town of Ysleta; second, to any per-
Laws of the State of Texas.son or company for the erection of buildings to be used for mechan-
ical or manufacturing purposes, or for the building of railroad de-
pots or workshops; provided, that the land granted or sold shall not exceed the quantity to be actually covered by the erection of said buildings; third, to any person or persons who may desire to become citizens of Ysleta, and who shall become actual settlers on the land sold or granted.

Sec. 25. That whenever any person shall desire to purchase or obtain a grant of land for the purpose specified in the foregoing section, he or they shall make an application to the town council, at a regular meeting thereof; said application to be in writing, in duplicate, and in the following form: “To the town council of the town of Ysleta, Texas: Your petitioner (or petitioners) respect-
fully prays that the following described tract of land, situated with-
in the corporate limits of Ysleta, be sold (or granted) to him by your honorable body. (Here must follow a correct description of the land.) Your petitioner desires to use said land for the follow-
ing purposes: (Here follow the purposes for which the petitioner desires the lands.)

Said petition shall be read in open meeting of the council when it is received, but no further action shall be had thereon at that time. At least ten days before the next regular meeting of the town coun-
cil, the secretary shall publish the duplicate copy of the petition by posting it in a conspicuous place near the door of the town council hall, and shall post underneath a notice advising all parties inter-
ested that said petition will be acted on at the next regular meeting of the council. At the next regular meeting the petition shall be taken up and read, and the presiding officer shall ask if there is any person present who has anything to say in favor of or against the granting of this petition; and any citizen of Ysleta may appear in person or by attorney, before the council and speak in favor of or against the granting of the petition. When argument has been finished, the council shall proceed to vote by ayes and noes, which shall be entered upon the journal, and if two-thirds of the council elected shall vote in favor of the petitioner, the petition shall be considered as granted. If the petition is for the purchase of lauds, the council shall then proceed by a two-third vote to fix the price to be paid by the petitioner.

Sec. 26. When a petition has been granted in the manner speci-
fied in the foregoing section, the secretary shall furnish the mayor with a correct copy of the petition, on which shall be endorsed the action of the council in the premises, and state the consideration, if any; when the said consideration shall have been paid, or the con-
Laws of the State of Texas.ditions of the sale or grant shall have been complied with to the satisfaction of the mayor, he shall issue to the petitioner a deed to the said real estate, which deed shall be signed by the mayor and attested by the secretary, and shall be in words and form as follows: “Whereas,................has fully complied with the provisions of section twenty-five of an act entitled ‘An act to incorporate the town Ysleta;’ and whereas, the town council of the town of Ysleta, at a regular meeting thereof held on the...... day of............, did, by a two-thirds vote, authorize me to sell (or grant) to the said petitioner the hereinafter described parcel of land situated within the corporate limits of the town of Ysleta, in the county of El Paso, State of Texas, on condition that the petitioner shall have complied with certain considerations herein set forth, to-
wit: (Here follows the consideration.) And, whereas, said consid-
eration has been fully complied with to may satisfaction; now, therefore, know all men by these presents that I,......, mayor of the town of Ysleta, by and in virtue of the authority in me vested by the act hereinbefore recited, have granted, bargained, sold and released, and by these presents do grant, bargain, sell and release unto the said............... all that—(here describe the land) together with all and singular the rights, members, heredita-
ments and appurtenances to the same belonging, or in any wise in-
cident or appertaining; to have and to hold all and singular the lands and premises above mentioned unto the said............, his heirs and assigns forever.
Witness my hand and the corporate seal of the town of Ysleta, this the..... day of........ in the year of..
(Signed) .............. Mayor of the Town of Ysleta.
Attest:
And the foregoing deed shall be considered in law and equity a good and sufficient conveyance of all the right, title and interest which the said town of Ysleta may have in the premises.
Sec. 27. That this act take effect and be in force from, and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER CLXXVI.

opener.salute: An Act to reincorporate the City of Navasota, Grimes County, and to grant a new charter to said city, and to repeal an act approved October 27, 1866, incorporating the City of Navasota.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That all inhabitants of the city of Navasota, in the county of Grimes, be and they are hereby constituted a body politic and corporate with perpetual succession, by the name and style of the “City of Navasota,” and as such they and their successors, by that name, shall have, exercise and enjoy all the rights, immunities, powers, privileges and franchises now possessed and enjoyed by said city, and herein granted and confirmed, and shall be subject to all the duties and obligations now appertaining to or incumbent on said city as a corporation, and may ordain and establish such acts, laws, regulations and ordinances, not inconsistent with the Constitution or laws of this State, as shall be needful for the government, inter-
est, welfare and good order of said body politic, and under the same shall be known in law, and be capable of suing and being sued, impleading and being impleaded, answering and being answered unto in all courts and places and in all matters whatever; may take, hold and purchase, lease, grant and convey such Teal and per-
sonal or mixed property or estate as the purposes of the corporation may require, within or without the limits thereof, and may make, have and use a corporate seal, and change and renew the same at pleasure.

Sec. 2. That the limits of the said city shall be as follows, to-
wit: Beginning at a point one mile due north of the crossing of the Houston, Texas and Central Railroad, over the Washington and Anderson public road; thence due east one mile; thence due south two miles; thence due west two miles; thence due north two miles; thence due east one mile, to the place of beginning; provided, said limits may be hereafter extended by adding additional territory to the same, whenever a majority of the inhabitants of said territory shall indicate a desire to be included within the limits of said city.

Sec. 3. That the municipal affairs of said city shall be adminis-
tered by a mayor, eight aldermen, a secretary or recorder, a treasu-
rer, a marshal, assessor and collector, a superintendent of streets, and such other subordinate officers as the board of aldermen may, in their judgment, deem necessary to the due regulation thereof; and that whenever complaint is made to the district judge, under oath, by any person of persons, accusing the mayor or any member of the
Laws of the State of Texas.board of aldermen, or any officer appointed by them, or elected by authority of this act, of malfeasance, misfeasance or nonfeasance in office, or any neglect of duty, he shall immediately examine into the truth of said charges, and if true, he shall remove the person or persons from office at once.

Sec. 4. That every male person who shall have attained the age of twenty-one years, and become a citizen of this State, and shall have resided within the limits of said city for twelve months next preceding the election, shall be entitled to vote for mayor and al-
dermen of said city.

Sec. 5. That for the purpose of holding elections for city offi-
cers, the said city shall be divided into four wards, to contain, as near as may be practicable and convenient, an equal number of voters; and it shall be the duty of the board of aldermen to alter said wards from time to time, in such manner as to preserve, as nearly as may be, an approximated equality of voters. The mayor shall be elected by the qualified voters of the city, voting by ballot in their respective wards, and shall hold his office for four years from the date of his election, and until his successor shall be elected and qualified. At the first election held under this charter, there shall be elected by the same voters voting in their respective wards, two aldermen from the first ward, two aldermen from the second ward, two aldermen from the third ward, two aldermen from the fourth ward, according to the provisions of the next succeeding sec-
tion of this act; said aldermen to hold their office for two years from the date of their election, and until their successors in office shall be elected and qualified. The said mayor and aldermen, before en-
tering on the duties of their offices, shall take and subscribe to the same oaths which are administered to county officers, before the incumbent mayor, county judge, or any justice of the peace of the county.

Sec. 6. That the said city election shall be held at the same time of the general election during the year 1873, and shall be conducted as follows: There shall be chosen by the board of aldermen at least ten days previous thereto, for each and every ward, three good and competent men as managers of the election, of which appointment, and of the time and place of election, the mayor shall give at least ten days’ public notice. On the day of election the said managers shall meet at the place designated, and having appointed two Clerks, and being themselves and their clerks duly sworn by the mayor or any justice of the peace to the faithful performance of their duties without fear or favor, shall proceed to receive the votes of their ward for one mayor and such aldermen as are to be elected, admin-
istering to each voter, of whose qualification there may be doubt, previously to his voting, the following oath: “You do solemnly
Laws of the State of Texas.swear, or affirm, that you are qualified by law to vote for officers of this city, so help you God.” The managers shall hold the polls open from ten o’clock A. M. until four o’clock P. M., and shall keep a correct list of all persons admitted by them to vote, number-
ing each vote and marking each ticket with a corresponding num-
ber, as in the case of State elections. As soon after the closing of the polls as practicable they shall proceed to count the rotes, and shall make due return thereof, certified under their hands and seals, which said return, together with a certified list of the persons voting, they shall envelop under seal and transmit by one of themselves to the mayor incumbent. The said mayor incumbent shall, within twenty-four hours after receiving the said returns, call together the board of aldermen, who shall in public meeting proceed to open the returns and decide upon the election; he having received the great-
est number of votes for mayor being declared elected mayor, and the person having received the highest number of votes in each ward for alderman, being declared elected alderman of his ward; in accord-
ance therewith the mayor incumbent shall deliver to the mayor and aldermen elect the certificates of their election, under his hands and the seal of the city (if no seal, using a scroll for a seal); and in case the mayor incumbent be absent, indisposed, or for any other reason unable or refuse to receive said returns, or having received the same, neglect to call a meeting of the board of aldermen, or having called a meeting thereof, the said board shall not meet, or having met within the time prescribed, shall not open the returns and declare the election then—in either case the election shall not be void, but the managers shall make out duplicate returns of the said election, and having certified, sealed and enveloped the same as before, shall transmit them to the county judge of the county, who shall forthwith proceed to determine the election and deliver certifi-
cates of the same, under his hand and official seal, to the person en-
titled, in the same manner as the board of aldermen and mayor should have done. The mayor and aldermen elect shall, on the first Monday after their election, or as soon thereafter as practicable, be regularly installed into their offices, in conformity with the last clause of the fifth section of this act. Should any of the managers of the election fail to attend at the proper time and place, the one or two who may be present shall elect from among the by-standers a suitable person or persons to fill the vacancy so occasioned; and should none of said managers be present, then the by-standers, being voters, shall themselves select three suitable persons to conduct said election, who shall proceed to hold the election and make returns thereof in the same manner as the regular managers should have done, had they been present.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p:
Sec. 7. That the board of aldermen at its first meeting, after that in which the members were installed into office, shall proceed to elect from without their own body a recorder or secretary, a treas-
urer, an assessor and collector, a marshal and superintendent of streets, and such other subordinate officers as may have been cre-
ated under the third section of this act, the candidate receiving the highest number of votes being declared elected. The treasurer, as-
sessor and collector, recorder or secretary, and marshal, shall each enter into bond, payable to the mayor of the city and his successors in office, with two or more good and sufficient securities, in such sum as the board of aldermen may direct, conditioned for the faith-
ful performance of the duties of their several offices; whereupon the board of aldermen shall by motion, order the treasurer, assessor and collector, recorder or secretary and marshal, lately incumbent, to deliver over to those several officers elect, all moneys, books, papers, records and all matters and things Whatsoever, which they or either of them may have in his or their possession belonging to their said several officers; without which order, under the hand and seal of the mayor, the said several officers shall not permit any mon-
eys, books, papers, records and other things to be taken from the pos-
session of them or either of them; and if the said several officers or either of them shall, upon the receipt of such order so certified, refuse or neglect to deliver over to their several successors the said moneys, books, papers, records and other things, or any of them, they or either of them so offending, shall be deemed guilty of contempt, and on conviction thereof in the city court, shall be adjudged to pay a fine not exceeding one hundred dollars, and to be imprisoned not exceeding seven days for every week that he or they shall so re-
tain the same; said fine to be collected by execution issued from the said court against the estate of them or their securities; pro-
vided, that for the time being, or as long as it may be good policy and to the interest of the city, the board of aldermen shall have power to consolidate the offices of assessor and collector, superin-
tendent of streets and marshal, and require of the marshal to per-
form all the duties of the same under penalties and bond deemed sufficient by the board of aldermen.

Sec. 8. That the mayor of the said city shall be the chief execu-
tive and judicial magistrate, and ex officio chief of police within said city, and as such he shall maintain peace and good order, and for that purpose he shall have the same authority to call out the power of the city and the military as is given or may be given by law to sheriffs of counties. He shall be vigilant and active at all times in causing the laws and ordinances for the government of said city to be duly executed and put in force; to inspect the conduct of
Laws of the State of Texas.all subordinate officers in the government thereof, and as far as may be in his power to cause all negligence, carelessness, and positive violations of duty to be duly prosecuted and punished. He shall have power, whenever in his judgment the good of said city may require it, to summon meetings of the city council, and he shall from time to time communicate to that body all such information, and recommend all such measures, as may tend to the improvement of the finances, the police, health, security, cleanliness, comfort, ornament and good government of said city.

Sec. 9. That whenever the mayor shall deem it necessary, in order to enforce the laws of the city, ox to avert danger, or protect life and property in case of riot, or any outbreak or calamity or pub-
lic disturbance, or when he has reason to fear any serious violation of law or order, or any other danger to said city or its inhabitants thereof, he shall summon into service as a special police force all or as many of the citizens as in his judgment and discretion may be necessary and proper, and such summons may be by proclamation or order addressed to the citizens generally, or those of any ward of the city or subdivision thereof, or such summons may be by per-
sonal notification. Such special police, while in service, shall be subject to the orders of the mayor, through the city marshal; shall perform such duties as he may require, and shall have the same power while on duty as the regular police of said city; and any per-
son so summoned and failing to obey, or appearing and failing to perform any duty that may be required by this act, shall be fined in a sum not exceeding one hundred dollars.

Sec. 10. The mayor shall preside over the meetings of the city council but shall have no vote unless there be a tie, in which case he shall give the casting vote. He shall have like power with a justice of the peace to administer oaths of office, and also all other oaths and affirmations, and to give certificates thereof. He shall possess and execute in the city, in criminal cases, all the powers and duties of a justice of the peace. He shall be compensated for his services by a salary to be fixed by the city council, which shall not be in-
creased or diminished during the term of service of any incumbent, and shall receive fees the same for services of like character as those of justices of the peace as allowed by law. He shall have power to dismiss and discharge any member of the police, with the consent of the city council, and to remove or suspend any officer holding an office created by any ordinance of the city, until the cause of such removal or suspension can be acted on by the city council, and may fill by appointment any vacancy so occasioned. He shall have au-
thority, in case of a riot or any unlawful assembly, or to preserve peace and good order in said city, to order and enforce the Closing of
Laws of the State of Texas.any theatre, hall room, grog shop, tippling house, bar room, or other place or resort, or public room, or building, and may order the arrest of any person or persons in his presence violating the laws of the State, or any ordinance of the city, and shall perform such other duties, and possess and exercise such other power and authority, as may be prescribed and conferred by the city council. In case of a vacancy in the office of mayor, or of his being unable to perform the duties of his office by reason of temporary or continued absence or sickness, the city council shall appoint by ballot, by a majority of all the members present, [one] of their number to preside over their meetings whose official designation shall be “acting mayor,” and the aldermen so appointed shall be vested with all the powers and perform all the duties of mayor of the city, until the mayor shall resume the duties or his office, or the vacancy be filled by a new election. The said mayor, as judge thereof, shall hold court within said city daily, which court shall have jurisdiction and cognizance of all misdemeanors, breaches of the peace, infractions of ordinan-
ces, and all other causes arising under the laws of said city, and shall be deemed always open for the trial of said cases. The said court shall have full power, authority and jurisdiction, in all cases arising under the ordinances of said corporation, and for any breaches and violations thereof, and of any and all persons thus offending, and to try and determine all suits, actions, and complaints charging a violation of any ordinance of said city, and may if it sees fit grant new trials, on motion in writing showing sufficient cause and duly sworn to. The mayor may require of any person arrested under provisions of this act a bond for his or her good behavior, and to keep the peace. He shall have full power and authority to issue subpoenas for witnesses, to compel their attendance by process of at-
tachment. He may punish all contempts by fine and imprisonment or either; may issue subpoenas, [writs of] capias, warrants of arrest, search warrants, executions, and all other process known to the law which a justice of the peace of this State may lawfully issue.

Sec. 11. The city marshal shall, either in person or by deputy, if sick, attend upon the mayor’s court while said court is in session, and shall promptly and faithfully execute all writs and process is-
sued from said court. He shall also attend all general and special meetings of the city council; he shall be the chief police officer of the city under the mayor; he shall have power, with the sheriff of the county, to execute the writ of search warrant, and shall be active in quelling riots, disorders and disturbances of the peace within the limits of said city, and shall take into custody all persons so offending against the peace of the community or infraction of the ordinances
Laws of the State of Texas.of said city, and shall have authority to take suitable and sufficient bail for the appearance before the mayor’s court of any person charged with an offense against the ordinances or laws of the city. It shall be his duty to arrest all violators of the public peace, and all persons who shall obstruct or interfere with him in the execution of the duties of his office, or who shall be guilty of any disorderly conduct or disturbance whatever. He may appoint one or more deputies, with the consent of the mayor, who shall have the same power and perform the same duties as the marshal. He shall re-
ceive a salary to be fixed by the city council, and shall receive the same fees as the sheriff of the county does by law for like services. The city marshal shall give such bond for the faithful performance of his duties, as the city council may require, and he shall perform such other duties, and possess such other power, rights and author-
ity, as the city council may, by ordinance, require and confer, not inconsistent with the Constitution and laws of the State.

Sec. 12. The powers and duties of the street commissioner, and the salary for his services, shall be prescribed by resolution or ordi-
nance of the city council.

Sec. 13. That it shall be the duty of the secretary to attend every meeting of the city council and to keep accurate minutes of the proceedings thereof in a book to be provided for that purpose, engross and enroll all laws, resolutions and ordinances of said coun-
cil; to take charge of, preserve and keep in order all the books, records, papers and files of said council, and shall countersign all warrants drawn on treasurer, and keep an accurate account of same, and do and perform whatever may be required of the city council, and for his services he shall receive an annual salary prescribed by the city council.

Sec. 14. The treasurer of said city shall give bond in favor of the city of Navasota, in such amount as may be required by the city council, and with sufficient securities, conditioned for the faith-
ful discharge of his duties. He shall receive and securely keep all moneys belonging to the city, and make all payments for the same upon the order of the mayor, attested by the secretary and the seal of said corporation. He shall keep regular and correct accounts of their real, personal and mixed property, and shall render a full and correct statement of his receipts and payments to the city council at their first regular meeting in every quarter, and whensoever at other times he may be required by them so to do; and at the end of every half year shall cause to be published, at the expense of the city, a statement showing the amount of receipts and expenditures for the six months next preceding, and the general condition of the treasury, and shall do and perform such other acts and duties as the
Laws of the State of Texas.city council may require, and for his services shall receive such com-
pensation as shall be fixed by the city council.

Sec. 15. That the assessor and collector of the city shall make up the assessments of all the property taxed by the city, and collect the taxes of every kind as they are due when assessed, and generally perform all the duties in relation to city taxes as are required of the State Treasurer and collectors in regard to the State and county taxes under such forms and regulations as the board of aldermen may prescribe, and shall pay over to the treasurer every month the moneys he shall have received, and make a report thereof to the board of aldermen at their first regular meeting in every quarter. All assessments of property shall be made under oath by the party returning the same; if the appraisement be unsatisfactory to the assessor, it shall be referred to a board of three commissioners, being owners of real estate in the city to the value of one thousand dollars, and entirely disconnected with the administration of the city, who shall be appointed by the board of aldermen, and whose decision shall be final. The same commissioners shall assess the value of all property whose owners are unknown or which may not have been returned, and receive for their services such remuneration, not being a per centage, as the board of aldermen shall think proper.

Sec. 16. The mayor and aldermen shall constitute the city council of said city. The city council shall meet at such times and places as they shall by resolution direct. The mayor, when present, shall preside at all meetings of the city council, and shall have in all cases a casting vote, except in elections. In his absence any one of the aldermen may be appointed to preside.

Sec. 17. The city council shall hold stated meetings, and the mayor, of his own motion, or on the application of three aldermen, may call special meetings, by notice to each of the members of said council, served personally or left at their usual place of abode. Pe-
titions and remonstrances may be presented to the council in writing only, and the council shall determine the rules of its own proceed-
ings, and have power to compel the attendance of absent members, and punish them for disorderly conduct, and with the concurrence of two-thirds of the members elected, may expel a member; and shall have the management and control of the finances and all other property, real, personal and mixed, belonging to the corporation, and shall likewise have power within the jurisdiction of the city, by ordi-
nance: First, to borrowmoney on the credit of the city, and issue the bonds of the city therefor; but no sum of money shall be bor-
rowed at a greater rate of interest than the rate allowed by law. AH bonds shall specify for what purpose they were issued, and shall not be invalid if sold for less than their par value. Second, to ap-
Laws of the State of Texas.propriate money, and to provide for the payment of the debts and expenses of the city; to make regulations to prevent the introduc-
tion of contagions diseases into the city; to make quarantine laws for that purpose, and to enforce them within the city and within one mile thereof; to establish cisterns and reservoirs in the streets or elsewhere within said city, for the extinguishment of fires and the convenience of the inhabitants, and to prevent the unnecessary waste of water; to have the exclusive control and power over the steets, alleys and public grounds and highways of the city; and to abate and remove encroachments or obstructions thereon; to estab-
lish and keep in repair, bridges, culverts, sidewalks and crossways, and to regulate the construction and use of the same, and to punish any encroachments thereon. Third, to establish and erect markets and market houses, designate, control and regulate market places and privileges, prohibit and punish the opening or establishment of private markets, and inspect and determine the mode of inspection of meat, and every article offered for sale, and to require the hides and skins of all animals slaughtered for sale thereat, to be brought to said market place or such other place as directed by the mayor, that the marks and brands thereof may be examined by the city mar-
shal; to provide for the inclosing and improving of public grounds and cemeteries, and to direct and regulate the planting and preserv-
ing of ornamental and Shade trees in the city; to prevent the en-
cumbering of the streets, alleys, sidewalks with any vehicles what-
ever, boxes, lumber, firewood, awnings, or any other substance or material whatever; to compel all persons to keep all weeds, fi th and any kind of rubbish, from the sidewalks and streets and gutters in front of the premises occupied by them; to require and compel the owners of property to fill up, grade, and otherwise improve the side-
walks in front of and adjoining their property; to license, tax, and regulate merchants, commission merchants, hotel and inn keepers, drinking houses or saloons, bar rooms, beer saloons, and all places or establishments where intoxicating or fermented liquors are sold, brokers, money brokers, real estate agents, insurance brokers and agents, auctioneers; to license, tax and regulate, suppress and pro-
hibit hawkers, pawnbrokers and keepers of theatrical or other exhi-
bitions, shows and amusements; to license, tax and regulate public hacks and draymen, billiard tables, ten pin alleys, ball alleys; to suppress and restrain disorderly houses, tippling shops and groce-
ries, bawdy houses, houses of prostitution or assignation, gamb-
ling houses, lotteries, and all fraudulent devices and practices. Fourth, to make such rules and regulations, in relation to butch-
ers, as they may deem necessary and proper. Fifth, to cre-
ate, establish and regulate the police of the city; to appoint
Laws of the State of Texas.watchmen and policemen, and prescribe their duties and powers, giving the mayor the right of nomination of said watchmen and po-
licemen. Sixth, to prevent, prohibit and suppress horse racing, im-
moderate riding or driving in the streets; to punish the abuse of animals; to compel persons to fasten their horses or other animals attached to vehicles or otherwise while standing or remaining in the streets. Seventh, to punish and restrain vagrants, mendicants, street beggars and prostitutes. Eighth, to establish and regulate the running at large of horses, mules cattle and sheep; to regulate and prihibit the running at large of swine, goats, and to authorize the distraining, impounding and sale of the same, and to impose penalties on the owners thereof for a violation of any ordinance relative therto; to tax and prohibit the running at large of dogs, and to authorize their destruction when at large contrary to ordi-
nance, and to impose penalties on the owners or keepers thereof. Ninth, to restrain and prohibit the rolling of hoops, flying of kites, firing of fire crackers, or use of any pyrotechnic or any other amuse-
ment or practices tending to annoy persons passing in streets, or to frighten horses or teams. Tenth, to abate all nuisances which may injure the public health, and do to all acts and make all regulations which may be necessary or expedient for the promotion of health or the suppression of disease. Eleventh, to direct the location and re-
strain and prohibit within the city slaughtering establishments. Twelfth, to abate and remove nuisances and punish the authors thereof by penalties, fine and imprisonment, and to define and declare what shall be nuisances; to compel and force all offenders against any ordinance of the city, found guilty by the mayor and sentenced to fine, to labor on the streets under such regulations as may by or-
dinance be established; to prevent cock and dog fighting, and pun-
ish all persons offending; to prevent all tresspasses and breaches of the peace and good order, assaults, assaults and batteries, fighting, quarreling, using abusive and insulting language, misdemeanors and all disorderly conduct, and punish all persons thus offending. Thir-
teenth, to prevent and punish the keeping of houses of prostitution within the city, and to adopt summary measures for the suppression of all such houses. Fourteenth, to require the owner, agent or occupant of any ground, lots, yards, private drains, privies, to fill up, cleanse, drain and improve the same as may be ordered by the mayor, or any resolution or ordinance of said city; and in the event of any failure, neglect or refusal to comply with any such order, the party so failing shall be liable to fine and imprisonment. Fifteenth, to require railroad companies to construct and keep in repair suitable crossings at the intersection of streets, avenues and
Laws of the State of Texas.alleys and ditches, sewers and culverts, and to direct the use and regulate the speed of locomotive engines within said city.

Sec. 18. The mayor and city council shall, at their first meeting or as soon as practicable thereafter, give public notice to its cred-
itors to present their claims for payment, or for acceptance, or for certificate, within a certain time, or such claims shall be forever barred.

Sec. 19. The members of the city council shall be emempt from jury service during their term of office. Each alderman shall re-
ceive two dollars for each meeting attended, and be fined in a like sum for every meeting he fails to attend without sufficient excuse for each absence. The city council shall have power to prevent and prohibit the dangerous construction and condition of chimneys, flues, fire places, stove pipes, ovens, and cause the same to be re-
moved when considered dangerous.

Sec. 20. The city council may procure fire engines and other ap-
paratus for the extinguishing of fires, and have control thereof, and provide engine houses and other places for keeping the same, and shall have power to organize fire, hook and ladder, hose and axe companies. Each company shall have the right to elect its own members and officers, and all officers so elected shall be commis-
sioned by the mayor. When any building in the city is on fire, it shall be lawful for the chief or acting chief engineer, with the concurrence of the mayor, to direct such building, or any other building which they may deem hazardous and likely to take fire and communicate to other buildings, to be torn down, or blown up, or destroyed, and no action shall be maintained against any person or against the city therefor; but any person interested in any such building so destroyed or injured may, within three months and not thereafter, apply in writing to the city council to assess and pay the damages he has sustained, and if the city council and the claimant cannot agree on the terms of adjustment, then the application of such claimant shall be referred to three commissioners, one to be ap-
pointed by the claimant, one by the city council, and the the third by both. They shall be sworn faithfully to execute their duty ac-
cording to the best of their ability; shall have power to subpoena and swear witnesses, and shall give all parties a fair and impartial hearing, and give notice of time and place of meeting. Said com-
missioners shall take into account the probability whether the said building would have been destroyed or injured by fire if it had not been, so pulled down or destroyed, and may report that no damages should equitably be allowed to such claimant. Whenever a report shall be made and finally confirmed for the appraising said damages,
Laws of the State of Texas.a compliance with the terms thereof by the city council shall be deemed a full satisfaction, of said damages.

Sec. 21. The city council shall have power to take such meas-
ures as they shall deem effectual to prevent the entrance of any pes-
tilential, contagious or infectious disease into the city; to stop, de-
tain and examine for that purpose any person coming from any place infected or believed to be infected with such disease. Any person who shall bring, procure or cause to be brought into the city, any person or any property of any kind tainted or infected with any malignant fever, or pestilential or infectious disease, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable by fine and imprisonment, or either.

Sec. 22. The city council may abate all nuisances of every de-
scription, which are or may become injurious to the public health, in any manner that they may deem expedient, and from time to time do all acts, make all regulations and pass all ordinances, which they shall deem necessary or expedient for the preservation of health and the suppression of disease in the city, and any citizen or citizens who shall be called on by the mayor to assist in carrying out any ordinance pertaining thereto, and refusing, shall be guilty of a mis-
demeanor and contempt, and may be fined and imprisoned, or either.

Sec. 23. In all cases where, by any provisions of this act, or by any ordinance passed in pursuance thereof, a person is required to obtain a license for any calling, occupation, business or avocation, and has, on complaint before the mayor, been adjudged guilty of violating any rule, regulation or ordinance of the city council in re-
lation thereto, the mayor, in adddition to fine and imprisonment, or either, may suspend or revoke the license so granted. The ground on which the town hall stands, and in which shall be held the mayor’s court and his office shall be therein, the cemetery, lots, which have or may be hereafter laid out and sold by said city for private places of burial shall, with the appurtenances, forever be ex-
empt from taxes, execution, attachment or forced sale.

Sec. 24. To defray the expenses of said city the said board of aldermen are hereby fully authorized and empowered to impose a direct property and license tax upon all such persons, property and employments as are liable to taxation under the Constitution and laws of the State, and to make and execute all laws necessary to enforce the collection of the same; provided, nevertheless, that no property tax (unless for special purposes) shall for any one year ex-
ceed the one-half of one per cent. of the value of the property, nor any license tax to exceed one-half the license tax of the State, nor shall any tax be levied without the concurrence of three-fourths of the whole board in its favor.

Sec. 25. That the act so far as relating to the city of Navasota,
Laws of the State of Texas.namely: “An act to incorporate the city of Navasota, Grimes coun-
ty,” approved October 27, 1866, be and the same is hereby repealed, and that all property, actions, rights of actions, claims and demands of any nature and kind whatsoever vested in said corporation, under and in virtue of said law hereby repealed, shall vest in, remain and inure to the said corporation under this act, as fully and completely, in all respects, as if the law had not been repealed; and that all by-
laws, resolutions and ordinances made and passed under or in pur-
suance of the said law hereby repealed, shall continue and remain in full force until repealed by the proper authorities of said corpora-
tion; and this act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTED CLXXVII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Galveston Hotel Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That J. F. H. Chapman, C. W. Hurley, Thomas M. Jack, W. B. Norris, C. L. Beissner, T. E. Thompson, C. M. Mason, W. E. Gregory, E. C. Jefferies, Willard Richardson, and their asso-
ciates and successors, be and they are hereby constituted a body politic and corporate under the name and style of the “Galveston Hotel Company,” and under such name may sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, defend and be defended in all courts whatsoever in this State, may have and use a common seal, and may acquire, hold and convey real and personal estate; provided, that such estate shall at no one time exceed one million of dollars.

Sec. 2. The purpose and object of said company is the building of one first class hotel in the city of Galveston, and to furnish and Tent, or otherwise dispose of the same, to the best interests of the stockholders, and as they shall determine.
Sec. 3. The orifice or said company shall be established in the city of Galveston, and in all suits against the same, service may be made upon the president or secretary.

Sec. 4. The capital stock of said company shall be two hun-
dred and fifty thousand dollars, with the privilege of increasing the same at the discretion of not less than three-fourths of the issued stock to any sum not to exceed one million dollars. Said capital
Laws of the State of Texas.stock shall be divided into shares of five hundred dollars each, to be. paid for in the following manner: ten per cent of the amount sub-
scribed for, to be deposited with the treasurer of the company at the time of subscribing, and the balance at such times and in such amounts or instalments, as the board of directors may order; pro-
vided, that not more than ten per cent. shall be called for oftener than once within any thirty days.

Sec. 5. Said company shall be organized whenever fifty thou-
sand dollars of the capital stock shall be subscribed for.

Sec. 6. The affairs of said company shall be conducted and man-
aged by a board of not less than three, nor more than seven direc-
tors, two thirds Of whom shall constitute a quorum, who shall be elected from among the stockholders, by the stockholders, at the first organization of the company, and annually on the first Monday in February of every year thereafter. All elections for directors shall be by ballot, and every shareholder shall be entitled to one vote for each and every share of stock, which he, she or they may respectively hold; and such votes may be given personally or by written proxy; provided, that no person shall vote on any share transferred to him within fifteen days next prior to such election. Any action or decision for any purpose, not inconsistent with law and this act, or three-fourths of the issued stock, shall be binding on all the stock.

Sec. 7. Said directors shall have the power to make and ordain all necessary by-laws, rules and regulations for the good ordering and government of said company; and such by-laws, rules and reg-
ulations when not inconsistent with law and the provisions of this act, and when they shall have been approved by a majority of the issued stock, shall be binding upon all the stockholders of said company. Said directors shall also have the power to employ counsel to prosecute or defend all suits for or against said company, and to enforce, by legal proceedings, payment from any stockholder of the per centage of his subscription as hereinbefore provided.

Sec. 8. In case any stockholder shall fail or neglect to pay any instalment upon his subrcription, as hereinbefore provided, the di-
rectors shall have power to sell his stock at public auction, after-
ten days’ notice in any one public Journal in Galveston, and out of the proceeds of such sale, shall pay all expenses of sale; and the un-
paid instalments due on the stock, and the balance, if any, pay over to the defaulting stockholder.

Sec. 9. The officers of said company shall be a president, vice president, secretary and treasurer, and such others as the by-laws may, from time to time provide for. The officers shall be selected by the directors at their first meeting after their election, the two first
Laws of the State of Texas.named to be taken from among the directors, and to constitute a portion of the board; the others to be taken from among the body of the stockholders. The duties of the officers shall be such as may be prescribed in the by-laws, and their compensation shall be such as the directors may determine.
Sec. 10. This act shall take effect from and after its passage, and continue in force for the space of twenty-five years.

div3.head: CHAPTER CLXXVIII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the “Sherman Gas Company.”

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That John Dorchester, of the State of Texas; Benjamin Mordecai, of the city of New Orleans, in the State of Louisiana; and Julius Hayden, of the city of New Orleans, in the State of Louisiana, their associates and successors, be and are hereby consti-
tuted and declared to be a body po itic and corporate, under the name and style of the “Sherman Gas Company,” with capacity to make contracts, to have succession and a common seal, to make by-
laws for its government, and in its corporate name to sue and be sued, to grant and receive, and generally to do and perform such acts and things as may be necessary and proper for or incident to the fulfillment of its rights under this act, and consistent with the provisions of the State Constitution.

Sec. 2. That the said company be and is hereby established, with the rights of erecting, owning and maintaining works for the generation of gas, in the town of Sherman, in the county of Gray-
son and State of Texas, and laying down in the streets, lanes and alleys, and other public grounds within the town of Sherman, and the suburbs thereof, pipes for the conveyance of gas in and through said, town and its suburbs.

Sec. 3. That the capital stock of said company shall be divided into shares of one hundred dollars each, and the holders of such shares shall constitute said company, and each share shall entitle the holder thereof to one vote, in person or by prosy; and such shares of stock shall be transferable only upon the books of the com-
pany.

Sec. 4. That the affairs and business of said company shall be
Laws of the State of Texas.conducted and managed by a board of directors, of not less than three nor more than five, who shall be elected by the company at such time as the stockholders may appoint, and thereafter on the first day of January of each year; provided, that in case of failure to elect at the stated time, the board of directors incumbent shall continue in office until there be an election, the time for which may be fixed by said board, whereof reasonable notice shall be given.

Sec. 5. That no person shall be eligible as a director unless he be the owner of ten (10) shares of the capital stock. The said beard shall elect a president from their number, fill vacancies, and appoint such other officers and agents as they may deem necessary, and require securities for the faithful performance of their duties; also prescribe the time for the payment of instalments or assesments upon the capital stock, and the amount of such instalments or as-
sessments; declare the forfeiture of such stock for non-payment; and do or cause to be done all other lawful acts of things which they may deem necessary or proper in conducting the business of said company. A majority of said board of directors shall constitute a quorum for doing business. All instruments in writing executed by the president and secretary, under the seal of the company, with the consent of the board of directors, shall be valid and binding.

Sec. 6. That the board shall have power to elect an agent or agents, who shall be members of said company and whose names shall be made known to the public, and by whom the business of the corporation may be conducted, under the powers given him by the board.
Sec. 7. That this act shall take effect from and after its passage and shall continue in force for twenty-fire years.

div3.head: CHAPTER CLXXIX.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Buffalo Bayou and Trinity Railway Company.

div3.p:
Section. 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That James Wrigley, J. C. Day, B. E. Cameron, E. P. Hill, J. T. Terrey, E. D. Morgan and L. H. Terry, and such, others as they may associate with them, are hereby created a body politic and corporate under the name of the “Buffalo Bayou and Trinity
Laws of the State of Texas.Railway Company,” by which title the said company may sue and he sued, plead and be impleaded, make contracts, take and hold property, both real and personal, by grant, donation or purchase, and sell, transfer and convey the same. Said company shall enjoy succession for ninety-nine years, and have a corporate seal.

Sec. 2. That the said persons named in the first section of this act, their associates or assigns, shall constitute the first board of directors for said company. They shall have the power to elect a president, vice president, secretary and treasurer, and such other officers as may be required, and generally to do and perform all things within the scope and design of this charter, that may be necessary to the speedy organization of said company, and the effec-
tive prosecution of the work hereinafter provided for. The said directors shall have the power to make by-laws, rules and regula-
tions for the government of said company, in conformity with the intent hereof; to name and appoint an executive committee, and confer upon the same all such powers and privileges, not inconsist-
ent with law, as they may deem proper; to provide for all subse-
quent elections; to fix the permanent domicile of said company, and change the same at pleasure; to provide for the issuance of stock, scrip or bonds, and the manner of transferring the same; to provide for issuing the bonds of said company; to mortgage or otherwise hypothecate the road bed, rolling stock, together with all and sin-
gular the other properties of the road, in order to acquire the requisite funds for the construction and equipment thereof.

Sec. 3. That the said company shall have the right to construct a single or double track railway from Buffalo Bayou, at some con-
venient point near or within the corporate limits of the city of Houston, to some point on the Trinity river within the corporate limits of the town of Liberty, east of the Trinity river, with the privilege of constructing and using bridges across said streams and all intermediate streams, the same to be constructed in such a man-
ner as not to interfere with navigation; the said company shall also have the right to connect with any and all other railroads inter-
sected by their said line, and to form a junction or junctions with other railroads at the termini of said company’s line, or to consoli-
date with any road or roads along their said general line.

Sec. 4. That said company shall have the right of way along the entire route, not to exceed two hundred feet in width over all lands of the State, and the benefit of the general law regulating the acquisition of the right of way from private property owners.

Sec. 5. That the capital stock of said company shall be one million of dollars, with the privilege of increasing the same to five
Laws of the State of Texas.millions of dollars, the same to be divided into shares of one hun-
dred dollars each.

Sec. 6. That a majority of the said directors may act in all matters in which the said company may be interested, until other-
wise regulated.
Sec. 7. That said company may adopt such gauge as may suit their convenience, and be conformable to the gauge of such road or roads as a function may be made with.

Sec. 8. That said company shall commence the construction of their said road at such point on their said line as may be most con-
venient and practicable, and shall complete and have in operation the entire line of said railway within the term of one year from the date hereof, or failing therein, shall forfeit the rights, grants and franchises herein conveyed.
Sec. 9. That this act take effect from its passage.

The foregoing act, received in the office of Secretary of State May twenty-third, one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one, having been presented to the Governor of Texas for his approval, and not having been returned by him to the house in which it originated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has be-
come a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div3.head: CHAPTER CLXXX.

opener.salute: An Act incorporating the West Texas Road Steamer Transportation Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That A. Pope St. John, F. R. Pridham, D. R. Diffender-
fer, J. J. Hand, T. W. House, G. Lawrence and their associates, or those who may hereafter be associated with them, and their succes-
sors, are hereby created a body corporate and politic, under the name and style of the “West Texas Road Steamer Transportation Company,” with all the rights, privileges and immunities of bodies corporate under the laws of the State of Texas; and shall have the-
Laws of the State of Texas.power to sue and be sued, to plead and be impleaded, and shall have and use a common seal.

Sec. 2. That the object of said corporation is declared to be for the transportation of freights and passengers; to establish transpor-
tation routes; to own road steamers, cars, wagons and vehicles used for transportation purposes; to run their steamers over all roads west of the Colorado river, from all ports of entry and survey be-
tween the mouth of the Colorado river and the port of Brazos San-
tiago, and from the termini of all railroads now constructed, or that may hereafter be constructed, west of the Colorado river within the limits of the State of Texas.

Sec. 3. That the above named incorporators and their associates agree and do hereby bind themselves to place one or more road steamers, with the necessary freight wagons and passenger cars or carriages, upon such public roads from the above several cited forts, and from the termini of the several railroads now constructed, or to be hereafter constructed, west of the Colorado river, for the purpose of transporting freights and pessengers at such rates as may be agreed upon by parties transporting.

Sec. 4. That the said body corporate and their successors is hereby granted the right of transporting freights and passengers by said road steamers from all the points above enumerated west of the Colorado river, and that they and their successors shall have this right for the term of fifteen years from the first day of January, 1872.

Sec. 5. That if the said body corporate and their successors shall fail to put in operation one or more road steamers for the transportation of freights and passengers from any one of the above designated points within eighteen months from the passage of this act, then in that case this charter shall be deemed forfeited so far as such point and route upon which said corporation may fail to put one or more road steamers is concerned; but this charter shall re-
main in full force and effect as to all the above designated points and routes upon which said corporate body shall place one or more road steamers in operation within eighteen months from the passage of this act.
Sec. 6. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER CLXXXI.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Houston Cemetery Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That Alfred Whitaker, of Houston, in the county of Harris, and such other persons as may associate with him, be and they are hereby created a body politic and corporate, under and by the name of the “Houston Cemetery Company,” and by that name shall have succession, and be capable of contracting and being contracted with; of pleading and being impleaded; and they may have a common seal, and do all such things as are incident to corporations, not in-
consistent with the Constitution and laws of the State of Texas.

Sec. 2. The said company shall have full power and authority to acquire, take, receive and hold such a quantity of land in Harris county as shall be considered desirable by the company, not exceed-
ing five hundred acres, which shall be held for cemetery purposes only; to enclose, lay out, ornament and improve such land; to erect such buildings, tombs, monuments, inclosures and other structures thereon as may be deemed advisable; to arrange and dispose of burial lots on such terms, and with such conditions for the perma-
nent care and preservation of the cemetery and grounds, or any part thereof, as may be agreed upon between the company and the pur-
chasers; to take and hold any grant, donation or bequest of prop-
erty, real or personal, upon trust; to apply the same under the su-
perintendence of the directors, for the improvement or embellish-
ment of the cemetery or for the erection, repair, preservation or re-
moval of any tomb, monument or grave stone, fence railing or other erection, or for the planting or cultivation of trees, shrubs, flowers or plants, in or around any cemetery lot, or for improving the said premises in any other manner or form, consistent with the design and purposes of this act, according to the terms of such grant, dona-
tion or bequest.

Sec. 3. The capital stock of said company shall be divided into shares of one hundred dollars each, and each and every share shall entitle the holder and owner thereof to one vote either in person or by proxy, in all meetings of the stockholders; and the said shares shall be held and deemed personal property, and shall be assignable in such manner as may be prescribed by the by-laws of the com-
pany.

Sec. 4. That it shall be the duty of the said A. Whitaker within ninety days after the passage of this act, to open books of subscrip-
tion to the capital stock of said company, and whenever the sum of
Laws of the State of Texas.ten thousand dollars is subscribed for, and ten per cent. of the amount paid in, the company shall be organized by the subscribers, after ten days’ notice of the time and place of meeting shall have been given in some newspaper published in the city of Houston.

Sec. 5. The stockholders shall have power and authority to make by-laws defining and establishing: first, the amount of the capital stock, and to increase the same from time to time to any amount not exceeding the sum of one hundred thousand dollars; second, the number of directors, officers and agents, prescribe their respective duties and powers, and the manner of filling vacancies, and fix the compensation of its officers and agents; third, what number of shares represented shall constitute a quorum in stock-
holders meetings, and the number of directors to constitute a quorum for the transaction of business; fourth, the time for hold-
ing the annual election for officers; fifth, how and in what manner the delinquent stockholders may forfeit their stock to the company for non-payment of calls and assessments upon stock; sixth, rules and regulations for the government of lot holders and visitors in the cemetery; seventh, and generally to make, fix and establish all need-
ful and proper rules and regulations as may be deemed expedient for the management of the business affairs of the company and the proper regulation of the cemetery.

Sec. 6. That it shall be the duty of said company at some general meeting of its stockholders, before any lot or lots in said cemetery are sold, to pass a resolution, which shall be entered upon the min-
utes and record of its proceedings, by which resolution shall be fixed and established a per centage upon the receipts from the sale of lots in said cemetery, which shall constitute a permanent fund for the purpose of improving and keeping the cemetery in order, the prin-
cipal of which shall be invested by the company in bonds and mort-
gages upon unencumbered real estate in the county of Harris, with at least double the amount of the sum loaned, with interest payable semi-annually, and the interest thereof only shall be used and ex-
pended upon said cemetery. The said per centage shall never be les-
sened by any action of the said company, but shall constitute a per-
petual fund for the purposes aforesaid, and shall be held by said company as a trust to be administered by the directors of said com-
pany; and upon the dissolution of said corporation by lapse of time or otherwise, the proper court having jurisdiction in matters per-
taining to estates of deceased persons in Harris county shall be au-
thorized to appoint three suitable persons as trustees—lot holders in said cemetery—to demand, receive, take charge of and administer said fund in the same manner, and for the same, purposes as herein
Laws of the State of Texas.expressed, and said court shall make such appointments from time to time as vacancies may occur.

Sec. 7. The said company may by any lawful means, acquire and hold the property in other lands and grounds in the city of Houston which are now used for cemeteries, and hold the same for cemetery purposes, or upon and after the removal of the remains which may have been heretofore deposited therein, to their general cemetery, the said lands and grounds may be held or alienated at pleasure, but upon a sale thereof the same per centage upon the re-
ceipts or proceeds thereof shall belong to the permanent fund, as provided for in the preceding section of this act.

Sec. 8. That the said company shall have a map and plot of their grounds and cemetery, made from an actual survey, on which shall be plainly and correctly delineated the lots, drives, walks and alleys; and the said map shall be deposited in the office of the clerk of the district court, or with the register of deeds, and the sales of the lots shall be made with reference to said map.
Sec. 9. That so much of said land and property therein, as may be appropriated to the burial of the dead, shall never be subject to State, county or municipal taxation.
Sec. 10. That this act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CLXXXII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the “European and Texan Immigration Association.”

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That Augustus B. Palm and James P. Dumas, of Texas; Edward Rowe, James M. Motley, John C. Wyman, Walton O. White and John B. White, of New York; and James Henry Rich-
ardson, of London, England; and their associates and successors, are hereby created a body corporate and politic, with full power in their corporate name, viz., the “European and Texan Immigration Asso-
ciation,” to make contracts for the purpose of carrying out the ob-
jects of said association; to purchase, hold, sell and convey property, both real and personal; to make leases, mortgages and trusts, and all other instruments necessary in the transaction of their business;
Laws of the State of Texas.to take and receive grants and gifts; to have succession and a com-
mon seal; to make by-laws, rules and regulations; sue and be sued in all the courts of the State; to buy or charter vessels; to erect houses or stations, and use such agents as they may desire to carry out the purposes of this incorporation.

Sec. 2. That said incorporators may elect a president, secretary and treasurer, and appoint such other officers and agents as may be necessary for the transaction of their business; provided, that the above named incorporators shall constitute a board of directors for the time being, a majority of whom shall constitute a quorum to do business, and they shall meet at such time and place as shall be designated by a majority of them and organize by the election of their officers. The capital stock of said association shall not exceed ten millions of dollars, to be divided into shares of one hundred dol-
lars each, and at all future elections of officers of said association, which shall take place annually on the first day of January, each share shall entitle the owner thereof to one vote, by himself or by proxy appointed by a written instrument. They shall have the right to appoint an executive and financial board, whose duties shall be prescribed by the by-laws of the association. They may establish agencies in Europe and in America for the purpose of soliciting and forwarding immigrants to the State of Texas.

Sec. 3. The Superintendent of the Bureau of Immigration shall furnish to said association, for distribution, such books, pamphlets, maps, and other printed matter, as may be provided by the Bureau of Immigration.

Sec. 4. That this act shall take effect immediately after its pass-
age and shall remain in force for twenty-fire years thereafter.

div3.head: CHAPTER CLXXXIII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Alta Viesta Female Seminary, in Austin county, Texas.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That Helen Kirby, and such others as she may associate with herself, be and they are hereby constituted a body corporate and politic, for educational purposes, by the name and style of the “Alta Viesta Female Seminary,” by which name they may sue
Laws of the State of Texas.and be sued, plead and be impleaded, by and sell property, real, per-
sonal and mixed, and may have a seal to authenticate their acts, for the purpose of maintaining an institution of learning in Alta Viesta, five miles east of Hempstead, Austin county, Texas.

Sec. 2. That the said Helen Kirby may establish a course of studies, grant diplomas or certificates of scholarship, and do all other things necessary and incident to the maintenance and promo-
tion of good morals and sound learning, not inconsistent with the Constitution and laws of the United States or of this State.
Sec. 3. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CLXXXIV.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Waco City Cemetery Association.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That D. T. Chamberlin, Geo. A. O’Brien, J. E. Sears, J. W. Baar, J. D. Wallace, O. H. Leland, of the county of McLennan, and State of Texas, be and are hereby created a body politic and cor-
porate, with succession under the corporate name and style of the “Waco City Cemetery Association,” and by that name may sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, in the courts of this State, and may contract and be contracted with, and may adopt a common seal.

Sec. 2. Said association may acquire by gift, device or purchase, the title to any quantity of land, not to exceed one hundred acres, within two miles of the city of Waco, for cemetery purposes; and the capital stock of said association shall not exceed fifty thousand dollars, and upon twenty-five thousand dollars of the same being subscribed, and ten per cent. of the same being paid in upon the opening of the books for the same by the said corporators, the said association may organize, and the stockholders thereof may elect a board of directors, seven in number, a majority of whom shall con-
stitute a quorum to do business, and they shall elect one of their number president, and they shall elect out of their stockholders a vice president and also a secretary and treasurer, which last two officers may be combined in one person, and such other officers as
Laws of the State of Texas.they may deem necessary, and such may be elected annually; such association may adopt such by-laws as they may deem necessary.

Sec. 3. Said association shall have as much of said land as they may deem necessary, laid off in suitable burying lots, with the neces-
sary streets, lanes and alleys, and cause a complete map thereof to be made with the proper number plainly put on each lot, one copy of which shall be deposited in the district clerk’s office of McLen-
nan county, and the said association may sell such lots at public or private sale. The purpose of the Legislature in this act being to dedicate the lands authorized to be held by said association for burial purposes, it is enacted that said lands so authorized to be held by said, association, shall be exempt from forced sale, levy or execu-
tion, except for the purchase money, or for labor and material in or-
namenting or embellishing the same; provided, that if such sale he made the grounds so sold shall not be appropriated to any other purpose than is set forth in this act, and the lots thereof hereby au-
thorized to be sold shall not be subject to forced sale under any cir-
cumstances after they are sold.

Sec. 4. At least one-half of the money arising from the sale of such lots shall be used in enclosing, protecting, beautifying, adorn-
ing and improving said grounds. That so much of said land and property thereon as may be appropriated to the burial of the dead, shall never be subject to State, county or municipal taxation; pro-
