port the same to the company, and comply with their decision thereon, otherwise their policy of insurance shall be null and void; and no policy shall be assignable without the consent and endorse-
ment of the company or its duly authorized agents. The number of the board of directors shall not be more than nine.
Sec. 12. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXCIX.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate Lamar Female Seminary.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the female institute of learning, situate at the city of Paris, in the county of Lamar, south of and adjoining Clarksville street in the eastern part of said city, be and the same is hereby in-
corporated in the name and style of the Lamar Female Seminary, under the ownership, control and supervision of the Rev. Oliver P. Stark, who is hereby made principal of said institution.

Sec. 2. That the said Oliver P. Stark, and his successors in of-
fice, be and are hereby constituted and appointed sole trustees of said institution, and shall have the right to have and receive, to hold and use, all lands and tenements, moneys or other property, real, personal or mixed, belonging to, hereafter descending, or acquired, for the use and benefit of said Lamar Female Seminary, to sue and be sued, to plead and be impleaded, and to do and perform any and all other acts necessary to the protection, maintenance and advance-
ment of the rights and interests of said institution, the same as in-
dividuals may of right do in the management of their own private affairs.

Sec. 3. That the said Oliver P. Stark have power and authority to frame and adopt such ordinances and by-laws for the good gov-
ernment of said institution as shall appear to him necessary and ex-
pedient; provided, the same be not repugnant to the Constitution and laws of the United States and of this State.

Sec. 4. That the said Oliver P. Stark, by and with the consent of the faculty, shall have full power and authority to confer such de-
gree or degrees in the arts and sciences to any student of said insti-
tute, who may be by them deemed worthy, as are usually conferred in any of the similar seminaries of learning, to give diplomas or cer-
tificates thereof with adequate marks and designations, to authenti-
cate and perpetuate the memory of such degrees and graduations.

Sec. 5. The said institute may have a common seal for the trans-
action of its business.

Sec. 6. All donations and bequests to said institute shall be good and binding, although the corporate name of said institute may not have been properly stated by the person making such donation or bequest.

Sec. 7. The seal of the corporation, with the attestation or the principal, shall be sufficient to authenticate any act of the corpora-
tion.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p: Sec. 8. This act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CC.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Navarro Jockey Club.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That J. H. Baden, president, and F. M. Martin, vice presi-
dent, W. R. Powers, secretary, J. W. Baker, treasurer, W. A. Jen-
nison, J. H. Brent, S. M. Potts, J. M. Rucker, Thomas H. Patter-
son, Phillip Tramel, W. Y. Davidson, directors, and their successors in office, be and axe hereby declared to be a body politic and corpor-
ate, with succession, under the name and style of “The Navarro Jockey Club,” and by that name may sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, in all courts of law and equity; and shall be capable of acquiring, by purchase or otherwise, any quantity of land not ex-
ceeding one hundred acres, and may improve, sell and convey the same or any part thereof at pleasure; and may acquire, hold and dispose of such personal estate, as the president and directors of said club may deem necessary and proper. The said club may adopt and use a corporate seal and alter the same at pleasure, or may use the seal of its president for the time being.

Sec. 2. That there shall be elected by the stockholders of said club,...... or such other time as may be fixed upon, and annually thereafter, a president, vice president and directors, who shall con-
tinue in office and perform the duties assigned to them respectively by this act and the constitution and by-laws of said club, for one year from the date of their election, and until their successors shall be elected and qualified, and shall be eligible to re-election.

Sec. 3. The business of said club stall be under the direction and control of the president, vice president and directors of said club, whose duty it shall be to appoint a treasurer and secretary, either from their own number or from the body of the subscribers to the capital stock of said company, and may require bond and security for the faithful performance of the duties assigned to them. They may also adopt a constitution and by-laws, necessary for the gov-
ernment of said club and its officers and business, not inconsistent with this act or the Constitution of this State, and to pass a code of
Laws of the State of Texas.police regulations, to enforce good order on its race grounds and protect said club in its legitimate pursuits; and to alter, amend or abolish the same, as they may deem proper. To make all contracts, or appoint agents to contract for them, on behalf of said club, and to perform such other duties as may be assigned them by the con-
stitution and by-laws of said club.

Sec. 4. Two-thirds of the directors aforesaid shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. The president if present, shall preside at the meetings of said directors, and in his absence the vice president shall preside; if he also shall be absent a chair-
man shall be elected for the time from among the directors present.

Sec. 5. The stock subscriptions, together with the property, real and personal, of said company or club, shall constitute the capital stock thereof, which shall be liable for the debts of said company. The subscriptions may be collected by the company, or by such per-
son as they may appoint, and in no case shall the individual or any subscriber be further liable for the debts of said club.

Sec. 6. Those who have subscribed or may hereafter subscribe to the stock of said club shall be deemed members thereof, and certifi-
cates of stock shall issue to them, corresponding with the number of shares which shall have been subscribed and paid, which may be transferred by assignment on the books of said company.

Sec. 7. Said drib may establish, race grounds, and during the continuance of any meeting of said club the mayor of the town of Corsicana, or any justice of the peace within the precinct in which said club may hold their meetings, shall have jurisdiction to hear, try and determine all causes for alleged violations of the by-laws or police regulations of said club, and their judgments in said causes shall be enforced as other judgments in said courts.
Sec. 8. That this act take effect and be in force for fifty years from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CCI.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Stock Traders’ Bank.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted, by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That C. C. Cooper, W. Frank Carter, R. E. Bell, John Hittson, J. F. Cock, A. J. Hood and Samuel H. Milliken, and such
Laws of the State of Texas.other persons as they may, after organization, associate with them-
selves, and their successors, be and they are hereby created a body politic and corporate, under the name and style of “The Stock Traders’ Bank,” and by said corporate name shall have succession, and may sue and be sued, and may have and use a corporate seal, may own property, real, personal and mixed, and may mortgage and alien the same; they may also borrow and loan money.

Sec. 2. The legal domicile of the company shall be in Weather-
ford, county of Parker, Texas.

Sec. 3. That the said company, under their corporate name, shall be empowered to deal in foreign and domestic exchange, bank motes, coin, bullion, and other things of value, and to buy and sell the stock of any other incorporated company, as well as of any county, city or State; to issue stock, and to do and perform all acts necessary for or incident to the carrying out of the objects of the company, or appertaining to a banking and exchange company.
Sec. 4. That the capital stock of said company shall be one hundred thousand dollars, including all of its property, real and personal, franchises and rights to property.

Sec. 5. The stock of the company shall be divided into shares of one hundred dollars each, which shall be considered personal prop-
erty, and shall be transferable in such manner as may be provided in the by-laws of said company, and payable at such times and in such sums as the company may determine in their by-laws. The said company, a majority of the members thereof concurring, shall have power to organize at any time; provided, such organization of the company shall not be deferred for a longer term than twelve months from the passage of this act. Said company, after its organization, shall have the right, from time to time, to associate with them-
selves, as members of the company, such other persons as they may deem advisable; but no person can be associated and made a mem-
ber unless two-thirds of the members of the company concur there-
in.

Sec. 6. The company shall make by-laws for the government of its affairs and officers, which by-laws may be altered or amended from time to time in such manner as may be deemed advisable by the company; but no such alterations and amendments of the by-
laws shall be of any force until the same has been concurred in by a two-third vote of the stockholders.

Sec. 7. The members of this company shall each have the right, in such manner and under such rules and regulations as may be prescribed by the by-laws, to withdraw from the company, and the management of the company shall be by a board of directors of not less than three nor at any time more than five in number, to be
Laws of the State of Texas.elected annually by the stockholders from the members of the com-
pany; and the members of the company shall select annually from the board of directors a president and cashier; such other officers as may have been deemed necessary by the company shall also be elected in such manner as may be prescribed by the by-laws and the respective terms of all officers shall be for one year, or until their successors qualify.
Sec. 8. All obligations of the company shall be signed by the president and cashier.

Sec. 9. The capital stock of the company may be increased by its members from time to time; provided, that two-thirds of the members of the company assent, in such manner as the by-laws may prescribe to such increase of stock; and further provided, that the said capital stock of said company shall never exceed five hundred thousand dollars.
Sec. 10. That this act of incorporation shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage, and shall be and remain in force for the period of fifty years.

div3.head: CHAPTER CCII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Bank of Cleburne.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That there may be established in the town of Cleburne an associa-
tion for the purpose of transacting a general banking and exchange business, which association shall be called and known by the name of “The Cleburne Bank,” and the stockholders and their successors shall have continuous succession, and by that name shall be capable of suing and being sued in all the courts of this State; of purchas-
ing, holding and conveying property of all descriptions, and the right to establish as many branches and agencies as they may see proper; to make, have and use a common seal, and the same to alter and renew at pleasure; and generally to do any act necessary to carry into effect the objects of the corporation not inconsistent with the laws of this State or the United States.

Sec. 2. That the capital stock of this association shall be two hundred thousand dollars, to be divided into shares of one hundred dollars each, which capital stock may be increased to one million
Laws of the State of Texas.dollars at the discretion of the president and directors of this cor-
poration. The said stock shall be deemed and held as personal property, and be represented by certificates under the seal of the association, signed by the president and countersigned by the treas-
urer or cashier.

Sec. 3. That the books of subscription to said capital stock shall be opened in the town of Cleburne, under the supervision of S. P. Hollingsworth, J. H. Stein, M. A. Otis, George Phifer and J. W. Brown, or any of them, and at such place in said town as they or any of them may direct; advertisement of the time and place of opening books to be made for one week in some newspaper pub-
lished in the said town of Cleburne, and they shall be kept open until the sum of fifty thousand dollars shall be subscribed for, and ten per cent. of the same paid in, and the said commissioners, or any of them, shall as soon as may be after the books of subscription are closed, call a meeting of the subscribers, and shall proceed to the election of not less than three nor more than five directors, as may be determined by them; and the said directors shall elect one of their own number president, and the said president and directors elected in pursuance of this act, and their successors, shall have full power and authority to make, appoint and remove at pleasure all officers and agents of said association; to fix their compensation, prescribe their duties and provide for the taking of bonds for faith-
ful discharge of their duties, as well as generally to manage the affairs of the association. They shall also have power to fill any vacancy that may occur in their own body, and also appoint a presi-
dent pro tern, when the president may be absent from their meer-
ings; and if the president or any director be absent without leave for five successive regular meetings of the board, a majority of the same may declare his place vacant, and proceed to fill it without no-
tice to such absent president or director.

Sec. 4. That the directors of this corporation shall call an an-
nual meeting of the stockholders to such election for directors, who, when so elected, shall hold their offices for the term of one year, or until their successors are elected, and no person shall be eligible to the office of director unless he owns at least five shares of stock.

Sec. 5. That in all meetings of the stockholders those represent-
ing a majority of the stock shall constitute a quorum, and each stockholder may be allowed one vote for each and every share he may hold; and the power to cast the vote of any absent stockholder may be constituted by written power in such form as the directors may prescribe by the by-laws.

Sec. 6. That said corporation shall have full power to receive money and other valuables to keep for depositors; to issue certifi-
Laws of the State of Texas.cates or bills payable on demand, or at specified times; to buy and sell coin and uncurrent money, and to buy, sell, draw or negotiate bills of exchange or other securities. It may loan its money and discount any promissory note or negotiable paper, or other security assignable by law, receiving its interest or discount thereon in ad-
vance.

Sec. 7. That the president and directors of said corporation shall have full power to pass such by-laws as may be necessary to carry this act into effect; to delegate authority to such officer or agent as they may think proper, and to execute or authorize the execution of all such bargains and contracts as may seem to them for the best interest of this corporation; and it is provided that a majority of the board of directors shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of all business.

Sec. 8. That the president and directors of said corporation shall have full power to fix the places and modes of transfer of stock, as-
well as the payment of interest and dividends; and any person in whose name shares of stock stand on the books of this coporation shall, so far as it affects the rights and acts of this association, be deemed at law and in equity the owner.

Sec. 9. That any stockholder shall, for valuable consideration, sell, pledge, or otherwise dispose of, any of his shares of stock to-
another, and deliver to him the certificate of such shares, with a power of attorney authorizing the transfer of the same on the books of this association the title of such stockholder both at law and in equity shall rest in the purchaser, so far as may be necessary to effect the purpose of the sale, pledge or other disposition, not only as between the parties themselves, but also as against the creditors of any subsequent purchasers from such stockholder, subject to the provision of the eighth section.

Sec. 10. That when any person to whom a certificate of stock shall have been issued alleges it to have been lost, he shall file in the office of this corporation, first, an affidavit setting the time, place and circumstances of the loss; second, proof of his having adver-
tised the same in some newspaper once a week for two months; and third, a bond to the association, with one or more sureties, condi-
tioned to indemnify all persons as against any loss in consequence of issuing a new certificate in place of the former, and thereupon the board of directors, if satisfied of such loss and with such secur-
ity, may direct such new certificate to be issued.

Sec. 11. That this charter and all the privileges and powers herein granted shall continue in force and effect for the full term of twenty-five years from the passage of this act, and that this corpora-
tion shall be responsible to the extent of its property, both real
Laws of the State of Texas.and personal; and that the funds, property and business transac-
tions of the association shall be subject to the same rate of taxation by law imposed on the funds, property and similar transactions of individuals, and the stockholders shall not again be subject to tax on their shares or dividends.
Sec. 12. This act shall be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CCIII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Texas Dental Association.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That R. Grant, G. W. Levin, Thomas Robinson, H. J. Mc-
Bride, E. D. Hammer, L. D. Estabrook, James McBride, their as-
sociates and successors, are hereby created and declared a body cor-
porate and politic, under the name and style of the Texas Dental Association, and under said name and style shall have succession and a common seal, shall be capable of contracting and being con-
tracted with, suing and being sued in all courts whatsoever; may ac-
quire by purchase, donation or otherwise, property, both real, per-
sonal and mixed, and may dispose of the same in any manner what-
ever for the benefit of said association, and may make and enforce all necessary by-laws, rules and regulations, for carrying out the ob-
jects of this charter; provided, the same be consistent with the Con-
stitution of the United States and the State of Texas.

Sec. 2. That the officers of this association shall consist of nine directors, from which number there shall be elected a president and vice president. Said directors (five of whom shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business,) to include the president or vice president, or any other director acting as president pro tempore, by appointment, during the absence of the president, shall be elected annually after the first election, and shall have power to appoint such subordinate officers as they may deem necessary, the term of office of such subordinate being at the will of the appointing power.

Sec. 3. That the persons named in the first section of this act shall act as directors of the Texas Dental Association until an elec-
tion for officers can be had, and for this purpose shall call together, as soon as practicable, the dentists of the State, who may meet in convention and transact all business appertaining to and necessary for the permanent organization of the association.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p:
Sec. 4. That the objects of this association are declared to be, the elevation of the science of dental surgery in the State of Texas to the standard which it is entitled; the interchange and diffusion of scientific knowledge in the sphere of legitimate practice, and to pro-
tect the profession and the public against the gross impositions of inexperienced and incompetent persons styling themselves dentists, but who really know nothing of the practice, and are wholly without authority to operate.

Sec. 5. That the directors of the association shall cause to be printed annually and immediately after the adjournment of the as-
sociation sine die, a correct list of the names of all members of the association and their places of residence, together with such of their proceedings as they may see proper, and shall circulate the same to the best advantage throughout the State, but in no instance shall the name of any party who is incompetent, and has not re-
ceived a diploma from a legally authorized college appear on said list of associated dentists.

Sec. 6. That it shall be within the power of the board of direct-
ors of the association for the purpose of properly carrying out the objects of this charter, to appoint such committees as they may deem proper, located at convenient points through the State, to examine into the claims of any parties desiring to become members of the association, which committees after examining into such claims, shall report thereon to the board of directors, and if favorably, upon complying with the rules of the association, the names of such ap-
plicants shall be enrolled upon the list of associated dentists.

Sec. 7. That any party desiring to become a member of this as-
sociation, who is a graduate of a legally authorized dental college, and who is not within convenient distance of an examining com-
mittee or the office of the board of directors, the official certificate of the clerk of the district court of the county in which such party resides, to the effect that he has seen the diploma of such applicant, will be sufficient, upon complying with the rules of the association, to have the name of such party entered upon the list of associated dentists.
Sec. 8. That this act take effect and be in force for twenty-five years from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER CCIV.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Texas Dental College.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That B. Grant, of Travis county; Thomas Robinson, of Harris county; G. W. Levin, E. D. Hamner and L. D. Estabrook, of Gal-
veston county; H. J. McBride, of Smith county; H. R. Hammell, of Harrison county; W. T. C. Campbell, James H. Johnston, George B. Slaughter, I. P. Nixon, their associates and successors, are hereby created and declared a body corporate and politic, by the name and style of the “Trustees of the Texas Dental College,” and by said name and style shall have succession and a common seal, sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded in all courts whatsoever, in like man-
ner, and as fully as natural persons, and by said corporate name and style shall be capable of contracting and being contracted with; shall have the power of acquiring, by purchase, donation or other-
wise, property, both real, personal and mixed, and may dispose of the same in any manner whatever for the benefit of said college; to construct all necessary buildings for said institution, and may es-
tablish such dependent departments as they shall deem necessary. They shall have the privilege of electing their own officers, who shall have the management of the finances, and may do all things whatsoever, for the benefit of said institution, as fully as any person or body politic or corporate may or can do by law.

Sec. 2. That the trustees shall have the power of prescribing the course of studies to be pursued by the students, and of framing and enacting all such ordinances and by-laws as shall appear to them necessary for the good government of said college, and for their own proceedings; provided, that the same be in accordance with the Constitution of the United States and the State of Texas.

Sec. 3. The trustees shall appoint a clean and the professors, who shall be styled the faculty of the Texas Dental College, which fac-
ulty shall have power of enforcing the ordinances and by-laws adopted by the trustees for the government of the students, to the extent of suspending such of them as shall become disobedient or refractory, until a determination of a quorum of the trustees can be had; but it shall only be in the power of a quorum of the trustees to expel a student from the college.

Sec. 4. That the faculty shall be authorized and required to reject the application of any and all parties for admission to the
Laws of the State of Texas.college, who are unable to stand favorably the preliminary examina-
tion as established by the ordinances and by-laws of the trustees.

Sec. 5. That the trustees shall be empowered by the faculty of said college, to confer on the students of said college, and any other persons worthy thereof, the degree of “Doctor of Dental Surgery,” and to give certificates thereof, or diplomas, signed by the faculty, and sealed with the common seal of the trustees of said college; to authenticate and perpetuate such graduation, and secure to the same all the privileges and protection of legally authorized dentists.
Sec. 6. That whenever any vacancy may occur in the board of trustees, either by death, resignation or otherwise, such vacancy or vacancies shall be filled by the selection of the remaining trustees.
Sec. 7. That all the officers of said college shall be appointed by a majority of the board of trustees, and shall be subject to removal by the appointing power for cause.

Sec. 8. That the salaries of all officers connected with the col-
lege, shall be fixed by a majority of the board of trustees.
Sec. 9. That the Texas Dental College shall be free from all taxation whatsoever for five years, following the commencement of its first session.
Sec. 10. That the Texas Dental College shall be located and established at or near the city of Galveston, and within Galveston county.
Sec. 11. That this act shall take effect and be in force for fifty years from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CCV.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Marion County Agricultural, Mechanical and Blood Stock Association.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That A. H. Montgomery, W. C. Batte, James Arbuckle, George A. Kelly, L. H. Norwood, L. T. Gray, Eli Moore, M. D. K. Taylor, C. F. Moseley, P. M. Graham, V. H. Claiborne, John C. Murphy, John C. Bolster, E. Marx, John V. Ford, J. H. Mc-
Garity, T. B. Goyne, J. W. Bussell, K. D. Bateman, E. W. Taylor, J. T. Veal, Ward Taylor, jr., William Young, B. F. Williams and others, their associates and successors, be and they are hereby de-
Laws of the State of Texas.dared a body corporate and politic, under the name and style of the “Marion County Agricultural, Mechanical and Blood Stock Asso-
ciation,” and by said corporate name shall be capable of suing and being sued, pleading and being impleaded, contracting and being contracted with, and of doing and performing all things necessary to carry into effect the objects of this act. They shall also have a common seal.

Sec. 2. That the objects of said association are declared to be the improvement of the breed of domestic animals, and the en-
couragement of agricultural and mechanical improvements; and for these purposes said association is authorized to purchase, import, breed, exhibit and sell, any kind of domestic animals; to purchase, import, manufacture, exhibit and sell, such improved machinery and implements as will promote the mechanical, agricultural and manufacturing interests of the people of this State; provided, noth-
ing herein contained shall infringe upon the rights of patentees. For the further purpose of carrying out the objects and purposes above declared, said association is hereby authorized to own the necessary real estate for fair grounds, pastures and farming grounds, not to exceed six hundred and forty acres, and to erect upon the same such improvements as may be necessary to carry out the objects of this association. That the fair grounds and other improvements of said association shall be located in the county of Marion, in this State.

Sec. 3. The capital stock of said association shall consist of all its property, real and personal, and shall be divided into shares of twenty dollars each, and that the affairs of said association shall be conducted by a board of directors, to be elected by and from the stockholders of said association, and that said board shall consist of not more than twelve, and a president and vice president, secretary and treasurer, who shall be elected from and by the stockholders of this association. These officers and the board of directors shall make such by-laws, rules and regulations, and appoint such other officers and agents as may be necessary for the government and conduct of said association.

Sec. 4. Said association shall, hold at least one fair in each year at such time as they may select, and shall publish in at least one newspaper in the county a list of premiums to be offered, at least one month before holding said meeting or fair.

Sec. 5. All medals or tokens awarded at such fair shall be en-
graved as follows: “First premium for................, M. C. A. I. M. and B. S. Association”; provided, however, if they prefer, said so-
ciety may pay its premiums in money.
Sec. 6. Not exceeding twenty-five per cent. of the value of the premiums offered shall be exacted by said association from owners for the privilege of competing.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p: Sec. 7. Said association shall keep a seal, engraved thus: “M. C. A., M. and B. S. Association.”
Sec. 8. The domicile of said association shall be at the city of Jefferson.
Sec. 9. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage, and continue in force for the period of thirty years.

div3.head: CHAPTER CCVI.

opener.salute: An Act to Incorporate the Paris Real Estate and Banking Association.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That A. S. Johnson, Travis Henderson, John C. Gibbons, H. H. Dohoney and F. W. Johnson, and their associates and successors, be and they are hereby created a body politic and corporate, under the name and style of the “Paris Real Estate and Banking Associa-
tion,” with the power of succession and a seal, to sue and be sued in their corporate name, and to own, hold, buy, sell and dispose of real estate, on commission or otherwise; to contract and be con-
tracted with, to borrow and loan money, execute mortgages, deeds of trusts, etc., and also receive money on deposit, and to deal in all kinds of exchange, foreign and domestic; to discount notes and bills, and engage in a general land and money brokerage, and may adopt by-laws consistent with the laws of the State.
Sec. 2. That the legal domicile of this association shall be at Paris, Texas.

Sec. 3. That the capital stock of this association shall not be less than twenty-five thousand nor more than two hundred and fifty thousand dollars, and shall consist of shares of one hundred dollars each, which shares shall be transferable as may be directed by the by-laws.

Sec. 4. The business of this association shall be controlled by a directory of not less than three nor more than five persons, to be elected annually by the stockholders, and which directory shall elect annually from its own members a president, secretary, and cashier, and which officers, as well as directors, shall hold their re-
spective offices until their successors are elected.

Sec. 5. This association shall organize for active business when-
Laws of the State of Texas.ever one-fourth of the capital stock is paid in, or ready to be paid. It shall organize by the stockholders electing the directory, and the directory the officers, as specified in the preceding section. And the directory shall enact the necessary by-laws for the government of the association not inconsistent with this act and the laws of the State.
Sec. 6. This association can only be sued by service of process on the president or cashier, at the place of its legal domicile.
Sec. 7. This act shall be in force from its passage, and may continue in force for twenty-five years.

div3.head: CHAPTER CCVII.

opener.salute: An Act to Incorporate the Galveston and Colorado Railway Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That J. H. Hutchings, George B. Nichols, Waters S. Davis, J. P. Barrett, T. J. Davis, J Sealey, B. B. Davis, B. H. Wynn, W. W. Up-
ham, T. Camp, Chas. Schmidt, and George Lawrence, and those they may associate with them, their successors or assigns, be and they are hereby constituted a body politic and corporate, under the name of the “Galveston and Colorado Railway Company,” by and under that name, they and the stockholders in the same, their suc-
cessors and assigns shall have succession for ninety years, and are hereby granted the right, power and authority to enter into con-
tracts to borrow money, to issue bonds, to execute mortgages, to sue and be sued, to plead and be impleaded, and to establish such by-
laws and regulations as the board of directors may deem proper, not inconsistent with the Constitution and laws of Texas and of the United States.

Sec. 2. That the parties above named, or a majority of them, shall act as commissioners to receive subscription to the capital stock of said company, and shall select from their number seven to act as the first board of directors, and who shall continue in office until their successors are duly elected and qualified, in accordance with the by-laws of the company, to be by them or a majority of them adopted. The capital stock of said company shall be five million dol-
lars, to be divided into shares of one hundred dollars each, and each
Laws of the State of Texas.share shall be entitled to one vote in all elections for directors, or in all stockholders’ meetings, either personally or by proxy; said shares shall be deemed personal property, and shall be transferred in writing, recorded by the secretary in the books of the company, or in such other or further manner as the by-laws of said company may provide.

Sec. 3. That said company shall have the right, and the author-
ity is hereby given them, to construct, equip, operate and own a line of railroad with single or double track, together with a telegraph line from the city of Galveston; thence down the island, westwardly, to some eligible point of crossing the bay that divides the island from the main land; thence to or near the town of Columbia, on the Brazos river; thence through the county of Wharton, to some point to make a connection with the Galveston, Harrisburg and San An-
tonio railroad; and the right is hereby granted to said company to construct and build any and all bridges on said line that may be necessary in the construction and completion of said road.

Sec. 4. That said company shall have the right to make any and all preliminary surveys; to enter upon and take possession of lands to the extent of two hundred feet in width, for purposes of road bed and construction, and such additional quantity of land for pur-
poses of depots, sidings, turn outs, machine shops and other build-
ings as may be necessary, by any agreement had to and with the owner, if the property of private owners, and if no agreement can be made, or the owner or owners be absent or unknown, then the property shall be acquired in accordance with the general railroad law of the State.

Sec. 5. That said company shall commence and have completed said road within four years from and after the approval of this act, or the charter to so much of the same as may be incomplete at the time specified shall be declared null and void and of no effect.

Sec. 6. That said company shall be entitled to any and all rights, powers, provileges, aid, benefits and immunities conferred by any general laws now existing, or that may hereafter be passed by the Legislature of the State of Texas in relation to railroad corpora-
tions.
Sec. 7. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER CCVIII.

opener.salute: An Act to authorize the citizens of Wallace’s Prairie, in Grimes County, to erect gates across the public roads in said Prairie.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the citizens of Wallace’s Prairie, in the county of Grimes, be and they are hereby authorized to erect gates across the public roads in said prairie, where said roads pass through cultivated lands: such gates to be of such dimensions as to admit horsemen, and wagons and other vehicles to pass through freely and without ob-
struction.
Sec. 2. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

The foregoing act, received in the office of Secretary of State May twenty-fourth, one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one, having been presented to the Governor of Texas for his approval, and not having been returned by him to the house in which it origi-
nated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has become a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMBS P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div3.head: CHAPTER CCIX.

opener.salute:
An Act to incorporate the Hearne and Little Brazos Bridge Com-
pany.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That M. R. Rowland, F. M, Hall and Ira W. Smith, and such other persons as they may associate with them, and their suc-
cessors in office, be and they are here hereby created a corporation under the name and style of “The Hearne and Little Brazos Bridge Company,” and may sue and be sued, may have a corporate seal, and may hold and own such property, both real and personal, as
Laws of the State of Texas.may be necessary to carry out the objects of this character, not to exceed ($10,000) ten thousand dollars in value.

Sec. 2. It shall be the duty of said company to build a safe and substantial bridge across the Little Brazos river, at some point on the same, between the city of Hearne, in Robertson county, and the mouth of Little River, in Milam county, and westwardly from Hearne. Said bridge shall be completed before the expiration of three years, and work thereon commenced within twelve months after the passage of this act, otherwise this act shall be null and void.

Sec. 3. That when said bridge shall be completed, said company are authorized to demand and receive from each and every person crossing said bridge, or crossing their property over the same, a toll not to exceed the following rates, to-wit: For each wagon, cart, carriage, or other vehicle drawn by more than two horses or other animals, twenty cents per wheel, and five cents for each animal by which the same is drawn, and where the same is drawn by two ani-
mals or less, ten cents per wheel, and five cents for each animal by which the same is drawn; for each animal and rider, five cents; for each loose animal of the cattle kind, five cents; for each foot passen-
ger, five cents; for each sheep, hog or goat, three cents.

Sec. 4. That no person or persons shall be authorized to con-
struct any other toll bridge or ferry within two miles above or below said bridge across said river.

Sec. 5. That said company shall cause its bridge gates to be opened night and day for the passing of persons and property; and said company shall be responsible in damages for unreasonable de-
lays and for injuries to persons and property resulting from the bad condition of said bridge.

Sec. 6. That this charter of incorporation continue and remain in force for twenty years from and after the completion of said bridge; and this act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

The foregoing act, received in the office of Secretary of State May twenty-ninth, one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one, having been presented to the Governor of Texas for his approval, and not having been returned by him to the house in which it origi-
nated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has become a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER CCX.

opener.salute: An Act to establish a bridge across the San Gabriel River, at or near the Compton crossing, below the mouth of Brushy Creek.

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That James H. Holtzclaw be and is hereby authorized to build and establish a toll bridge across the San Gabriel river, at or near the Compton Crossing, below the mouth of Brushy creek.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That it shall be the duty of said James H. Holtzclaw to build and keep in good repair a suffi-
cient bridge above high water across the channel of said river for the transportation of all passengers, wagons and other wheel car-
riages, horses, oxen and stock of every description. And that upon the building and keeping in good repair said bridge, he shall have the right to use and enjoy said bridge, precluding all others from building any bridge or establishing any ferry within the limits of three miles above and three miles below the point on said river, where said bridge is so established, for and during the term of twenty years.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, That said James H. Holtzclaw shall have for and during said term of twenty years the right to charge as toll for crossing said bridge the rates which the county court of Milam county may establish, which shall not exceed the rates of toll now established by law for ferry boats.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, That said Holtzclaw shall enter into bonds with sufficient security of one thousand dollars, payable to the county judge of Milam county and his successors in office for all damages that may accrue from neglect of duty.
Sec. 5. That this act shall take effect from and after its passage.

The foregoing act, received in the office of Secretary of State May twenty-ninth, one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one, having been presented to the Governor of Texas for his approval, and not having been returned by him to the house in which it originated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has become a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER CCXI.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Dallas and Kaufman East Fork Bridge Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That A. B. Norton, A. T. Gardner, J. W. Johnson, S. S. Jones, J. C. Leydel, J. Brown, and such other persons as they may associate with them, be and they are hereby created a body corpo-
rate and politic, under the name and style of the Dallas and Kauf-
man East Fork Bridge Company, and as such may make contracts, sue and be sued, have a corporate seal, and may own such property, real and personal, as may be necessary to carry out the objects of this charter, not to exceed in value one hundred thousand dollars.

Sec. 2. That it shall be the duty of said company to build a good, safe and substantial bridge across the East Fork of the Trin-
ity river, at such point as they may deem best adapted to accom-
modate travel between Dallas and Kaufman, and to construct a good and substantial causeway across the bottom of said stream.

Sec. 3. That the immediate control and direction of the affairs of said company shall be vested in a board of directors, who shall elect from their own number a president, secretary and treasurer, who shall perform such duties as may be required by the company.

Sec. 4. That for the purpose of raising the necessary funds with which to build said bridge and causeway, the said company may issue and sell their bonds, which, when issued and sold, shall constitute a lien upon said bridge and causeway for the payment of the prinicipal and interest thereof.

Sec. 5. That when said bridge and causeway shall be completed, said company are authorized to demand and receive from each and every person crossing said bridge or causeway, or crossing their property over the same, a toll not to exceed the following rates, to-
wit: For each wagon, cart, carriage or other vehicle, drawn by more than two horses or other animals, twenty cents per wheel and five cents for each animal by which the same is drawn, and when the same is drawn by two animals or less ten cents per wheel, and five cents for each animal by which the same is drawn; for each animal and rider, ten cents; for each loose horse, mule, jack or jennet, five cents; for each loose animal of the cattle kind, five cents; for each foot passenger, five cents; for each sheep, hog or goat, two cents.

Sec. 6. That said company shall have the right to regulate the
Laws of the State of Texas.crossing of persons and property over said bridge and causeway by appropriate rules and regulations not incompatible with this act or the laws of the State of Texas, and any person who shall wilfully violate the regulations of said company in crossing their property over said bridge or causeway shall be liable to forfeit and pay to said company the sum of five dollars and cost of suit, and all dam-
ages that the property of the company may sustain by reason of the violation of such rules and regulations, recoverable before any court of competent jurisdiction; provided, that such rules and regulations are plainly posted at each end of said bridge and causeway at the time.

Sec. 7. That it shall be the duty of the county court of Dallas county from time to time to examine said bridge, and whenever they shall consider the same unsafe for crossing, they may cause the gates thereof to be closed, and to remain closed until said company shall put said bridge in sufficient repair.

Sec. 8. That the gates of said bridge shall at all times, day and night, be open for passing of persons and property; and said com-
pany shall be responsible in damages for unreasonable delays, and for injuries to persons or property resulting from the bad condition of said bridge.

Sec. 9. That no person shall be authorized or allowed to erect any bridge, or keep any ferry across said East Fork of the Trinity river at or within five miles after the said bridge herein authorized is completed; provided, that said company may keep a ferry boat while said bridge is in process of construction and at such times as said bridge may be out of repair, with the tolls allowed in this act, until the said bridge is put in order and safe condition. That said company shall have the right of way over any land on which they may locate their bridge and causeway in accordance with this act, and may enter upon and take possession of said land; provided, the same shall not exceed one hundred feet in width, by paying the owner or owners whatever may be agreed upon, and should the said owner or owners of said lands and said company not be able to agree as to the price, the said company may petition the judge of the dis-
trict court, giving a description of the land which they require, with the owner’s name, and the said judge shall summon a jury of six freeholders not in any manner interested, who shall on oath make a report of the value of the land so required, and upon the payment to the owner or owners, or his or their agents, a good and bona fide title shall be granted by said judge to said company for said lands, a copy of which shall be recorded in the office of the district clerk of the county in which said land is situated.

Sec. 10. That this charter of incorporation continue and re-
Laws of the State of Texas.main in force for fifty years from and after the completion of the bridge of said company, and that this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

The foregoing act, received in the office of the Secretary of State May twenty-ninth, one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one, having been presented to the Governor of Texas for his approval, and not having been returned by him to the house in which it orig-
inated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has become a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div3.head: CHAPTER CCXII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the San Gabriel Bridge Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That S. B. Slocomb, J. W. McCown, W. M. Williams, R. Van Slyke, be and they are hereby constituted and declared to be a body corpo-
rate and politic, under the name and style of the “San Gabriel Bridge Company."

Sec. 2. That the said persons their associates and successors, under the name and style aforesaid, may sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, defend and be defended, in the courts of this State, and may have a common seal and may alter or change the same at pleasure.

Sec. 3. That the said persons, their associates and successors, under the name and style aforesaid, shall be authorized to construct a bridge over the San Gabriel river, in Milam county, at or within fifteen miles of the mouth of said river, at such place as may by them be deemed most eligible; and to purchase and hold property, real, personal and mixed, as far as necessary for the construction and maintenance of said bridge; and to do all other acts and perform all other work that may be necessary, not contrary to the Constitution and laws of this State.

Sec. 4. That said corporation may enact such by-laws, rules and regulations for the management of their affairs, as may be con-
sistent with the Constitution and laws of the State, and they shall
Laws of the State of Texas.have power to elect a director by whom the business of the company may be conducted, and whose name shall be made known to the public.
Sec. 5. That said bridge must be completed within five years from and after the passage of this act, otherwise this charter shall be null and void.

Sec. 6. That said corporation shall be authorized to charge tolls; provided, the rates shall never exceed, for a wagon with four horses, mules or oxen, fifty cents; for each additional pair of oxen, horses or mules, ten cents; for every wagon with one pair of oxen, horses or mules, twenty-five cents; for a two horse pleasure carriage thirty cents; for a one horse buggy twenty-five cents; for a horse and rider fifteen cents; for every footman five cents; for all loose ani-
mals five cents per head; and for all other things not herein enumer-
ated, at proportional rates to those herein specified.

Sec. 7. That the said company be and they are hereby required to keep said bridge in good repair, and to keep in constant attend-
ance at the toll gate of the same a sufficient number of persons to admit passengers and property to cross at any time by day or by night.

Sec. 8. That the privileges granted in this charter shall cease and determine after the expiration of twenty-five years from and af-
ter the passage of this act.
Sec. 9. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

The foregoing act received in the office of Secretary of State May twenty-nine, one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one, having been presented to the Governor of Texas for his approval, and not having been returned by him to the house in which it originated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has become a law-
without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER CCXIII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Little Brazos and Robertson County Bridge Company.

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That Thomas J. Garrett, D. W. Burley and P. W. Hall, and such other persons as they may associate with them, and their successors in office, be and they are hereby created a corporation, under the name and style of the “Little Brazos and Robertson County Bridge Company,” and may sue and be sued, may have a corporate seal, and may hold and own such property, both real and personal, as may be necessary to carry out the object of this charter, not to exceed twenty-five thousand dollars in value.

Sec. 2. It shall be the duty of said company to build a safe and substantial bridge across the Little Brazos river, at some point on the same in Robertson county westwardly from Calvert, said bridge to be commenced within twelve months from and after the passage of this act, and completed in three years, otherwise this act to be null and void.

Sec. 3. That when said bridge shall be completed, said company are authorized to demand [and] receive from each and every person crossing said bridge, or crossing their property over the same, a toll not to exceed the following rates, to wit: For each wagon, cart, carriage or other vehicle drawn by more than two horses or other animals, twenty-five cents per wheel, and five cents for each animal by which the same is drawn; and when the same is drawn by two animals or less, ten cents per wheel, and five cents for each animal by which the same is drawn; for each animal and rider, five cents; for each loose horse or animal of the cattle kind, five cents; for each foot passenger, five cents; for each sheep, hog or goat, three cents.

Sec. 4. That no person or persons shall be authorized to con-
struct any other bridge within three miles in a straight line above or below said bridge, across said river.

Sec. 5. It shall be the duty of the County Court of Robertson county from time to time to cause said bridge to be examined, and whenever they shall consider the same not to be in good and safe condition for crossing, they may cause the gates thereof to be open-
ed for the free crossing of the public, and so to remain until said company shall place said bridge in repair; provided, that nothing in this section shall prevent said company from closing said bridge
Laws of the State of Texas.while running a ferry during the time actually required for making such repairs.

Sec. 6. Said company shall cause its bridge gates to be opened night and day for the passing of persons and property, and said company shall be responsible in damages for unreasonable delays, and for injuries to persons and property resulting from the bad con-
dition of said bridge; provided, that nothing in this charter shall be so construed as to interfere with any chartered ferry, and this bridge company is to have no exclusive rights until after the com-
pletion of said bridge, and this charter to be null and void if said bridge is not completed within three years from the passage of this act.

Sec. 7. That this charter of incorporation continue and remain in force for twenty-five years from and after the completion of said bridge, and this act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

The foregoing act, received in the office of Secretary of State May twenty-ninth, one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one, having been presented to the Governor of Texas for his approval, and not having been returned by him to the house in which it origi-
nated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has become a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div3.head: CHAPTER CCXIV.

opener.salute: An Act to authorize certain persons therein named to erect a Toll Bridge across Harris Creek, in Smith County.

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That A. W. Ferguson, Isaac W. Guitor, their associates and assigns, be and they are hereby authorized to construct and keep a toll bridge across Harris creek, at Keys Crossing, in Smith county, on the road leading from Tyler to Camp’s ferry, on the Sabine river.

Sec. 2. That said persons named in the first section of this act, shall be authorized to collect such toll from all persons crossing said bridge as may be determined by the County Court of Smith county;
Laws of the State of Texas.and said court shall prescribe the dimensions of said bridge, and the material out of which it shall be constructed.

Sec. 3. That said bridge shall be completed within one year from the passage of this act; and this act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage, and remain in force for the period of twenty years.

The foregoing act, received in the office of Secretary of State May twenty-ninth, one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one, having been presented to the Governor of Texas for his approval, and not having been returned by him to the house in which it originated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has become a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div3.head: CHAPTER CCXV.

opener.salute:
An Act to incororate the Austin Council No. 94, Friends of Tem-
perance.

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That William D. Shepherd, president, and the subordinate officers and members of Austin Council No. 94, Friends of Temperance, located at Austin, Texas, and their successors, are hereby created a body corporate and politic, with power to sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, hold, own and convey property, real and personal, and receive conveyances of the same; have a common seal; make all needful rules and regulations consistent with the objects and terms of its organization, and to do and perform all other acts and things necessary to carry out the purposes of its organization.
Sec. 2. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage, and remain in force for a period of fifty years.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER CCXVI.

opener.salute:
An Act to authorize the City Council of the City of Austin to con-
struct a bridge across the Colorado River.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the city council of the city of Austin is authorized and em-
powered to construct a bridge across the Colorado river, and estab-
lish and collect tolls and make all necessary rules and regulations for the control of the same; provided, the debt of the city shall not, at any time, exceed the sum of five thousand dollars, unless the same shall be created by the consent of two-thirds of the qualified voters of said city, voting at an election for that purpose, ordered by the city council.

Sec. 2. That for the purposes of carrying out the provisions of the first section of this act, and subject to the restrictions and conditions therein contained, the said city council may issue the bonds of the city, not exceeding in amount the sum of five hundred thousand dol-
lars, due and payable not less than twenty years from date, and to draw interest not to exceed eight per centum per annum. It shall be the duty of said city council to appropriate and set apart the net proceeds arising from tolls received from said bridge for the pay-
ment of the current interest on said bonds, and a sinking fund for the redemption of the principal; and, if at any time, the amount so collected shall be insufficient for the payment of the current interest and an annual sinking fund of at least two per cent., the said city council shall provide for such deficiency by taxation. The sinking fund herein provided for shall be collected semi-annually and shall, as soon as collected, be invested as follows: First, in the purchase and retirement of said bonds; second, in coupon bonds of the United States.

Sec. 3. The said city council shall be authorized to purchase, re-
ceive, hold and own a sufficient amount of land on the west bank of the Colorado river, opposite said city, for the successful erection of said bridge.
Sec. 4. This act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER CCXVII.

opener.salute:
An Act to authorize Howard Keyes to erect a toll bridge at Crock-
ett’s Bluff on Sabine River.

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That Howard Keyes, and such others as he may wish to associate with him, are hereby authorized to erect a toll bridge over the Sabine river, at or near what is known as Crockett’s Bluff, in Wood county, on the direct road leading from Quitman to Canton, and the above named Howard Keyes and his associates and successors shall be allowed to erect a toll gate, and shall have the right of way and all other rights and privileges necessary to keep up said toll bridge, slough bridges and road for twenty-five years.

Sec. 2. Said Howard Keyes and His associates and successors shall keep said toll bridge and road through the bottom of said river in good repair, under the supervision of the County Court of Wood county, and shall be allowed to charge the following rates of toll and no more, to-wit: For each head of stock cattle, three cents; for each head of beef cattle or loose horses, four cents; for each man and horse, ten cents; for a horse and buggy, twenty-five cents; for a two horse carriage or buggy, thirty-five cents; for a wagon and two horses or one yoke of oxen, twenty-five cents; for each addi-
tional pair of horses or oxen, fifteen cents; for each led horse, five cents; for each footman, five cents.

Sec. 3. That said Howard Keyes and his associates shall con-
struct the said bridge from the timber and dirt of the land which they may purchase, and shall not be permitted to prevent individ-
uals from traveling any other road than by said bridge.

Sec. 4. That if any person shall wilfully fail or refuse to pay tolls after crossing the said bridge, he shall be liable to forfeit and pay to said corporation the sum of five dollars and costs of suit, re-
coverable before any justice of the peace as in other cases.

Sec. 5. That no other bridge shall be constructed across the Sabine river within three miles above or three miles below said bridge, and that said bridge shall be completed within two years after the passage of this act.
Sec. 6. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

The foregoing act, received in the office of Secretary of State May twenty-ninth, one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one,
Laws of the State of Texas.having been presented to the Governor of Texas for his approval, and not having been returned by him to the house in which it origi-
nated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has become a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div3.head: CHAPTER CCXVIII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Austin City Railroad Company.

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That E. C. Dewey, Weston Raymond, John H. Robinson, Geo. T. Haswell, W. D. Price, J. G. Tracy, Eugene Bremond, Julius Schultze, J. M. Swislier, Geo. W. Sampson, and such other persons as they associate with them, and their successors, be and they are hereby constituted and declared to be a body corporate and politic, under the name and style of the “Austin City Railroad Company."

Sec. 2. Said company shall have the right to construct, equip and run a horse railroad from the depot of the Houston and Texas Central Railroad Company, in the city of Austin, by and upon such streets as they may think proper, to Congress Avenue, in said city; thence, up said avenue to the Capitol enclosure, and from there, by such route as they may deem best, to a point at or near the State Lunatic Asylum; and the said company may, from time to time, construct, equip and run horse railroads upon and along such streets of the city of Austin, as the public convenience or the in-
terest of the company may require, to any point or points not ex-
ceeding four miles beyond the present corporate limits of the city of Austin.

Sec. 3. The capital stock of said company shall not exceed five hundred thousand dollars, which may be divided into shares sub-
scribed and paid for in such manner as the company may, by its by-
laws, prescribe.

Sec. 4. The affairs of said company shall be managed by a board of directors in number not more than five, nor less than three. Said directors shall elect one of their number to be the president of the board, and they shall designate and appoint all officers of the company, and shall manage its affairs under rules and by-laws made by the board, and approved by a majority of the cor-
Laws of the State of Texas.porators herein named, and their associates and successors, who may be stockholders in the company; any action of two-thirds of the issued stock shall be binding on all the stock of the company.

Sec. 5. Said company shall have a common seal; and shall have the right to sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, contract and be contracted with, buy and hold property for the use of the com-
pany, and to sell and convey the same.

Sec. 6. It shall be lawful for the corporators named in this act, or a majority of them, to organize this company within sixty days after the passage of this act; and the officers then and thereafter elected shall hold their respective offices until their successors are elected. This charter shall continue in force for the period of twenty-five years. The legal domicile and place of business of said company shall be in the city of Austin, Texas.
Sec. 7. That this act be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CCXIX.

opener.salute:
An Act to prohibit the sale of intoxicating liquors within certain limits of “Tennessee Colony High School,” in the town of Ten-
nessee Colony, in Anderson County.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That no person shall be permitted to make, sell, or dis-
tribute any spirituous, vinous or other intoxicating liquors within two miles of “Tennessee Colony High School,” situated in the town of Tennessee Colony, in Anderson county; provided, that this act shall not prohibit any person from purchasing the same for medical purposes, under the prescription of some practicing physi-
cian, or for sacramental purposes.

Sec. 2. Any person violating the provisions of this act shall be uilty of a misdemeanor, and on conviction thereof before any court aving jurisdiction, shall be fined in a sum not less than ten nor more than one hundred dollars for every such offense.
Sec. 3. That this act take effect and be in force for fifty years from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER CCXX.

opener.salute: An Act incorporating the Texas and Europe Steamship Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That J. C. C. Halkett, Bennet G. Burley, Lewis T. Mer-
row and their associates, or those who may hereafter be associated with them, and their successors or assigns, are hereby created a body corporate and politic, under the name and style of the Texas and Europe Steamship Company, with all the rights, privileges and immunities of bodies corporate under the laws of the State of Texas, and shall have power to sue and be sued, to plead and be im-
pleaded, and shall have and use a common seal. The capital stock of said company shall be five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000), with privilege to increase the sum to five million dollars ($5,-
000,000). The stockholders shall be organized under the direction of the incorporators herein named, and shall have the right to elect a president and such other officers, including directors, as they may desire, (and the same are not required to be residents of Texas) by a two-thirds vote of stockholders, and shall in the same mode adopt by-laws for the government of the company, and shall have an office in the city of Galveston, or any other port or city in said State.

Sec. 2. That the said company shall have the right to run a line or lines of steamers or other vessels from and to any port or ports in Great Britain to and from the State of Texas, and to and from the continent of Europe, with power to touch at any intermediate port or ports on said voyages, end with such auxiliary or connecting line or lines as may be desired to promote the interests of this cor-
poration, and may acquire and bold any property deemed useful or necessary for the successful accomplishment of the purposes ex-
pressed in this charter, including the right to construct machine shops, etc., whenever the same may be incidental to the proper busines of said company.

Sec. 3. That the said company undertake to establish a monthly line of steamers between Texas and Europe, or as often as may be necessary for the requirements of freight and passenger traffic be-
tween the aforementioned places. The said steamers shall be in all respects high-classed ocean steamships, built expressly with a view to suit the trade and traffic in which they are to be employed. Am-
ple and suitable accommodation shall also be provided to meet the demands of immigration to Texas.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p:
Sec. 4. That if the said body corporate shall fail to run one or more ocean steamers of a high class, suitable for freight and pas-
senger traffic, as aforesaid, within eighteen months from the pass-
age of this act, and regularly thereafter monthly, or as the demands of freight and passenger traffic may require, then and in that case this charter shall be deemed forfeited.
Sec. 5. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage and be in force for twenty-five years.

div3.head: CHAPTER CCXXI.

opener.salute: An Act to encourage the Gulf, Western Texas and Pacific Railway Company in the construction of their railways.

div3.p: Whereas, Henry S. McComb and Charles Morgan, owners of the San Antonio and Mexican Gulf Railroad, and the franchises of the San Antonio and Mxican Gulf Railroad Company, have agreed with the Indianola Railroad Company upon the terms of consolidation, pursuant to the provisions of the charters of the two companies, and have actually consolidated said companies into one company, under the name and style of the “Gulf, Western Texas and Pacific Railway Company,” and have organized the same to he managed according to the provisions of the charters aforesaid, and for the purpose of constructing, running, using and owning the railways of the two joined companies; therefore,

Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That said agreement of consolidation is hereby ratified and confirmed, and that said joined and consolidated companies shall hereafter be one corporation, with powers, rights and privileges as provided in said original charters, under the name and style of the “Gulf, Western Texas and Pacific Railway Company.”

Sec. 2. The Gulf, Western Texas and Pacific Railway Company may borrow money on bonds secured by mortgage or deed of trust, with power of sale, including in such mortgage or deed of trust their franchises as well as roadway, and any other property of said com-
pany; such mortgage or deed of trust may be enforced according to its terms, and the franchises as well as roadway and all other prop-
erty included in such mortgage or deed of trust may be conveyed to the purchaser at any legal sale, under such mortgage or deed of trust,
Laws of the State of Texas.and be as fully owned, used and enjoyed by the purchaser thereof as they were by said company before the sale; provided, that no bonded debt, secured as aforesaid, shall exceed the sum of twenty-
five thousand dollars per mile of single track railway of said com-
pany, the company having the privilege of increasing said debt pro-
portionately upon a double track railway.

Sec. 3. The Gulf, Western Texas and Pacific Railway Com-
pany are required to construct at least thirty miles of their track above Victoria per annum, and have the same fully equipped and in-
running order, and upon failure to do so, from year to year, they shall forfeit all the benefits of this act.
Sec. 4. This act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

The foregoing act, received in the office of Secretary of State May twenty-ninth, one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one, having been presented to the Governor of Texas for his approval, and not having been returned by him to the house in which it origi-
nated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has become-
a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div3.head: CHAPTER CCXXII.

opener.salute: An Act for the relief of John Dobbin, late Sheriff of Bexar County.

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the Comptroller of Public Accounts be and be is hereby authorized to draw his warrant upon the Treasurer of the State in favor of John Dobbin, late sheriff of Bexar county, for the sum of eleven hundred and fifty-three dollars and eighty cents, for services rendered by him in his said capacity of sheriff prior to the twenty-eighth day of January, 1861, and that the Treasurer of the State be and he is hereby authorized and required to pay the same out of any money not otherwise appropriated.
Sec. 2. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p:
The foregoing act, received in the office of Secretary of State May twenty-ninth, one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one, having been presented to the Governor of Texas for his approval, and not having been returned by him to the house in which it origi-
nated with the time prescribed by the Constitution, has become a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMBS P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div3.head: CHAPTER CCXXIII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Sabine and Neches Bridge Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That George Yarbrough, A. W. Ferguson and J. P. Smith, their associates and successors, are hereby declared a body corporate and politic, under the name and style of the Sabine and Neches Bridge Company, by which name they may contract and be contracted with, sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, issue bonds and bor-
row money, own property real and personal, convey and receive con-
veyances to real estate, and do and perform such acts and things as may be necessary to carry out the objects of this charter.

Sec. 2. Said company are hereby authorized to construct a safe and substantial bridge across the Sabine river, at a point below the mouth of Lake Fork, as near as practicable on a direct route from Tyler to Quitman, in this State. Also, to construct bridges of similar description across the Neches river and Kickapoo creek, be-
tween Tyler and Athens.

Sec. 3. That when said bridges, or either of them, shall have been completed, said company is authorized to demand and receive from each and every person crossing said bridges, or either of them, or crossing their property over the same, a toll, to be regulated by the police court of the county in which said bridge or bridges are situated.

Sec. 4. That no other person or persons shall be authorized to construct a toll bridge, or operate a ferry, and collect toll, within two miles of said bridge on Sabine river, nor within one mile of said bridges on Neches river and Kickapoo creek; provided, that this section shall not prevent the construction of a bridge or bridges
Laws of the State of Texas.across Sabine river above the mouth of Lake Fork, in Wood county.

Sec. 5. It shall be the duty of the police courts of the counties in which any of said bridges are situated to cause said bridges to be inspected once in every three months; and said courts shall in like manner cause the inspection of all public roads leading to said bridges; and whenever either of said bridges, upon such inspection, shall be judged not to be in good and safe condition for crossing, or when, upon such inspection, it shall be judged that any of the public roads leading to either of said bridges are not in a good state of repair for a distance of one mile from said bridge, such court may cause the gates of said bridge to be opened for the free crossing of the public, until said bridge or roads are repaired; provided, that said company may operate a ferry across Sabine river while con-
structing said bridge across said stream, or while making repairs on said bridge.

Sec. 6. Said company shall cause its bridge gates to be kept open night and day for the passing of persons or property, and said company shall be responsible in damages for unreasonable delays and for injuries to persons and property resulting from said bridges being out of repair.

Sec. 7. That nothing in this act shall interfere with the rights of any ferry or bridge now chartered; and if said company shall fail to construct either of said bridges within three years from the passage of this act, their rights to construct said bridge under this act shall cease.
Sec. 8. That this charter of incorporation shall continue and remain in force for twenty years, and shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

The foregoing act, received in the office of Secretary of State May twenty-ninth, one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one, having been presented to the Governor of Texas for his approval, and not having been returned by him to the house in which it orig-
inated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has become a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER CCXXIV.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the San Antonio and Victoria, Indianola and New Orleans Express and Transportation Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That B. W. Peay, James P. Newcomb, W. J. Locke and A. J. Fountain, be and they are hereby declared to be a body cor-
porate in law and in fact, under the name of the “Sian Antonio, Victoria, Indianola and New Orleans Express and Transporation Company.” In that name they may sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, buy and hold or sell and convey property, real and per-
sonal, for the uses of the company, and may have and use a com-
mon seal.
Sec. 2. The legal domicile of the corporation shall be in the city of San Antonio, Texas.

Sec. 3. The object of said company is declared to be the express and transportation business: to establish express and transportation routes from San Antonio, via Victoria and Indianola, to New Or-
leans; front San Antonio to Austin; and from San Antonio to Eagle Pass and El Paso; to om ears, wagons and other vehicles used for express and transportation business; to run its own cars over all railroads, subject to existing laws, and to the terms of contract with any railroad company; to make contracts to forward by railroad, steamboats, steamships and other rapid modes of con-
