veyances, by sea or land, bank notes, coin, jewelry, and valuables of every description, all kinds of merchandise, stock, animals, and all kinds of personal and movable property; to draw bills of exchange; to make collections of money, drafts, notes, and all other species of debts, claims and demands; and to insure articles of all kinds sent by their express on transportation; and generally to transact all business direct and incidental connected with the express or trans-
portation business.

Sec. 4. That this corporation shall have all the privileges and immunities of bodies corporate under the laws of the State of Texas, and shall have power to acquire, Toy grant, donation or purchase, and to use, occupy and sell, bargain, lease and convey all kinds of property, real and personal, necessary or convenient to operate, use or maintain its business; to make by-laws for the government of the corporation and its officers and affairs, not contrary to the laws of the State of Texas, or of the United States, or of this act. The
Laws of the State of Texas.president shall be the proper officer upon whom may be served cita-
tions, notices, and all other legal process against the company.
Sec. 5. That this charter shall continue in force for the period of twenty-five years.

Sec. 6. That all the corporate powers of this corporation shall be vested in and exercised by a board of directors, and such officers as they may create. The board of directors shall consist of five or seven members of said company, to be elected by ballot on the first Monday in May in each year, under such rules as the by-laws of said company may prescribe, of which election fifteen days’ notice shall be given, by advertisement in at least one daily newspaper pub-
lished in that city. At all elections of directors by the stockholders a majority of all votes cast shall be required for the election of a director. Each share of stock shall be entitled to one vote, either by the owner thereof or by his proxy; and if, from any cause, the stockholders fail to elect such directors, the old board shall con-
tinue until their successors are elected. Any action of tthree-fourths of stock shall be binding on all the stock of the company.

Sec. 7. That the board of directors, at their first meeting, shall elect from their number a president, who shall hold his office until his successor is elected. He shall preside at all the meetings of the board of directors, and shall conduct the business of the company generally, under the supervision of the board of directors; and in case of his absence or incapability to act, a president pro tempore may be appointed by the board. The president shall sign all con-
tracts and other papers, but, when necessary, may act through agents appointed by him, with the consent of the board of directors. The board of directors shall have full power to fill all vacancies that may occur in their body, and to appoint a secretary and treas-
urer, all superintendents, agents, clerks, messengers, and other em-
ployes, and to remove them at pleasure; and they may delegate this power to the president, subject to their supervision. They shall fix salaries of all officers and employes of the company, and may au-
thorize the president to do so, and may also designate such powers for the transaction of the ordinary business of the company as they may deem expedient, and shall have full power to do all other acts which may be necessary for carrying into effect the purpose of this company.

Sec. 8. That this company shall commence business as soon as ten thousand dollars shall have been subscribed to its capital stock. The capital stock shall be one hundred and fifty thousand dollars, divided into shares of fifty dollars each, five per cent. of which shall be payable at the time of subscribing, and other instalments as they may be called by the board of directors. The company shall have
Laws of the State of Texas.power to increase its capital stock to any sum not exceeding one million dollars, said increase in any amount not to be made unless by consent of three-fourths of the issued stock. If any stockholders refuse or neglect to pay the instalments within thirty days after the specified time of payment, the board of directors shall have the right of causing any share upon which any instalment may be due to be sold at public auction after ten days’ notice thereof through any newspaper published in the city of San Antonio.

Sec. 9. That this company shall have the right to sell at public auction any unclaimed freight or freights having been refused by the consignees, after having held the same for four months, and having given notice in not less than one newspaper published in San Antonio at least ten days before date of such sale; and to sell for account of whom it may concern any perishable freight within twenty-four hours after its receipt, or sooner if necessary.

Sec. 10. That all transfers of stock or issuance thereof shall be under such regulation as the board of directors may prescribe; minutes of the board of directors shall be kept by the secretary and verified by the president. The president and the secretary shall sign all certificates, bonds, drafts, notes and checks.

Sec. 11. That no stockholder shall be liable or responsible for contracts or faults of the company in any amount exceeding the amount of his stock in the company. No mere informality in the organization shall have the effect of rendering this charter null, nor of exposing a stockholder to any liability beyond the extent of his stock.

Sec. 12. That the corporators in this act, or a majority of them, shall have authority to organize the company within twenty days after the passage of this act; and this act shall be in force and take effect from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CCXXV.

opener.salute:
An Act to incorporate the San Antonio City Street Railroad Com-
pany.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That J. H. Kampman, David Bell, Nat. Lewis, Jas. P. Newcomb, W. J. Locke, Bussell Norton, Peter Schemer, George M.
Laws of the State of Texas.Maverick, J. J. Duerler, Senior, S. G. Newton, Stanley Welch, and their associates, be and are hereby declared a body corporate and politic, under the name and style of the “San Antonio City Street Railroad Company,” with power to sue and be sued, to plead and be impleaded, and in such name to do and perform all acts generally pertaining to corporate bodies.

Sec. 2. That said company shall have the right to construct, equip and run street railroads upon such streets of the city of San Antonio, within the present or future corporate limits of said city as may be approved by the mayor and city council, and may use either horse or steam power, subject to the approval of the mayor and city council.

Sec. 3. The capital stock of said company shall be five hundred thousand dollars, divided into shares of fifty dollars each. Said company shall have the right to issue said stock upon such terms as they may deem essential to the construction and maintenance of their roads, and said company may, if required, increase their capi-
tal stock to the amount of one million dollars.

Sec. 4. The affairs of the company shall be managed by a board of directors consisting of five members, to be elected by the stock-
holders from their number at their annual meeting. Said directors shall elect one of their number to be president of the board, and they shall designate all officers of the company, and shall manage its affairs under such rules and by-laws as they may make, and a majority of the stockholders ratify.

Sec. 5. Said company shall have a common seal, and have the right to buy and hold property for the use and benefit of the com-
pany, and to sell and convey the same; but no property shall be bought or sold, nor shall there be any material alteration or exten-
sion of the road or tracks, except by consent of a majority of the stockholders voting under the rules of the company.

Sec. 6. It shall be lawful for the corporators named in this act (or a majority of them) and their associates, subscribers to the stock of the company, to meet at the city of San Antonio and organize this company, at any time within six months after the passage of this act, and the officers then and there elected shall hold their of-
fices for the period of two years from date of election. They shall be elected annually thereafter, and each share of stock shall entitle the holder to a vote in person or by proxy. The place of business of said company shall be at the city of San Antonio.
Sec. 7. That this act shall take effect from and alter its passage, and shall continue in force for the period of twenty years.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER CCXXVI.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the “Gymnastic Association of High Hill,” Fayette County, Texas.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That J. Mernitz, G. Nordhausen and F. Seyder be and they are hereby, with their associates, constituted a body politic and corporate for gymnastic purposes, and for the encouragement of bodily exercise and other purposes, under the name and style of the “Gymnastic Association of High Hill;” and by that name shall have succession, and be capable of suing and being sued, of defend-
ing and being defended in any court of this State; to acquire and hold estate, both real and personal and mixed; to sell, alienate, trade, traffic, or otherwise dispose of the same, as said association deem expedient; provided, the amount of property held by said corporation shall at no time exceed fifty thousand dollars.

Sec. 2. That said association shall be governed and controlled by a president, vice president, secretary and treasurer, together with a board of trustees; and the said association shall have power to enact by-laws, rules and regulations for its government, and to alter and amend the same, not inconsistent with the laws of this. State, and shall have a seal for the authentication of its acts.
Sec. 3. That this act take effect from and after its passage and remain in force thirty years.

div3.head: CHAPTER CCXXVII.

opener.salute: An Act to prohibit the sale of intoxicating or spirituous liquors within two miles of Grapevine Masonic Institute, in the town of Grapevine, Tarrant County, Texas.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That no person shall be permitted to sell any intoxicating, or spirituous liquors within two miles of Grapevine Masonic Insti-
tute, in the town of Grapevine, in Tarrant county, Texas, except for sacramental, or upon the prescription of some practicing physi-
cian for medical purposes.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p: Sec. 2. Any person violating the provisions of the foregoing section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and on conviction thereof before any court having jurisdiction of the same, shall be fined in any sum not less than ten nor more one hundred dollars for every such offense.

Sec. 3. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage; provided, that a school organization in said Grapevine Masonic Institute be maintained during the accustomed scholastic months of each and every year.

div3.head: CHAPTER CCXXVIII.

opener.salute:
An Act incorporating the East Texas Road Steamer and Transpor-
tion Company.

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That Albert L. Catlin, John Dulahan, Bennett G. Burley, Rowland Allen, and their associates, or those Who may hereafter be associated with them, and their successors, are hereby created a body corporate and politic, under the name and style of the East Texas Road Steamer Transportation Company, with all the rights, privileges and immunities of bodies corporate under the laws of the State of Texas, and shall have the power to sue and be sued, to plead and be impleaded, and shall have and use a common seal.

Sec. 2. That the object of said corporation is declared to be for the transportation of freight or passengers by means of road steam-
ers; to establish transportation routes; to own road steamers, cars, wagons and vehicles, or other machines to be impelled or drawn by said steamers and used for transportation purposes; to run their steamers over such roads as said company may construct east of the Colorado river, and south of parallel thirty-two of north latitude, from all ports of entry and survey between the mouth of the Colo-
rado river and the port of Sabine Pass, and from the stations on all railroads now constructed, or that may hereafter be constructed, or other places or interior towns east of the Colorado river, south of the thirty-second parallel of north latitude, within the limits of the State of Texas.

Sec. 3. That the above named incorporators and their associates agree and do hereby hind themselves to place one or more road
Laws of the State of Texas.steamers, with the necessary freight wagons or passenger cars or carriages, upon such public roads from the above several cited ports, and from the stations on the several railroads now constructed or to be hereafter constructed, east of the Colorado river and south of thirty-second parallel, for the purpose of transporting freight or passengers at such rates as may be agreed upon by the parties trans-
porting.

Sec. 4. That the said body corporate and their successors are hereby granted the right of transporting freights or passengers by said road steamers from all points above enumerated east of the Col-
orado river, and that no other person or persons shall be permitted to run road steamers or other machines drawn or impelled by other than animal power, for the purpose of carrying freight or passengers over any of the bridges built, roads constructed or improved and routes established, or over which steamers are run by said corpora-
tion or their successors, during the term of fifteen years from the first day of May, 1871.

Sec. 5. That if the said body corporate and their successors shall fail to put in operation one or more road steamers for the transpor-
tation of freight or passengers from any of the above designated points, within twenty months from the passage of this act, then in that case this charter shall be deemed forfeited so far as such point and route upon which said corporation may fail to put one or more road steamers is concerned; but this charter shall remain in full force and effect as to all the above designated points and routes upon which said corporate body shall place and keep running one or more road steamers in operation within twenty months from the passage of this act.
Sec. 6. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

The foregoing act, received in the office of Secretary of State May twenty-fourth, one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one, hav-
ing been presented to the Governor of Texas for his approval, and not having been returned by him to the house in which it origi-
nated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has become a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER CCXXIX.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Land Owners’ Association of Texas.

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That John Adriance, and such other persons as may be associated with him, are hereby incorporated and created a body corporate and politic, under the name and style of the “Land Owners’ Association of Texas,” and by that name may make contracts, sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, and have succession and a common seal.

Sec. 2. The capital stock of said association may be fixed by the stockholders at any amount not exceeding one million dollars, to be divided into shares of one hundred dollars each, to be deemed per-
sonal estate; each share to entitle the owner to one vote, either in person or by proxy, in all meetings of the stockholders.

Sec. 3. The stockholders may make and establish by-laws, rules and regulations providing for the organization of the association, the management of its business affairs, the number of its officers and agents, and their duties, and such other matters and things as they may deem necessary or expedient, not inconsistent with the laws of the State of Texas.

Sec. 4. The lands of the stockholders may be received by the as-
sociation in lieu of money in payment of the capital stock, at such valuation as may be agreed upon between the association and the stockholders.

Sec. 5. The said association shall have power and authority, first, to make contracts for the introduction of immigrants to settle upon their lands; second, to acquire and hold property, real and personal, and the same to alienate at pleasure; third, to make any contracts in relation to its property which any citizen of this State may make concerning like property; fourth, and such other powers and au-
thority as may be incidental to those above enumerated.

Sec. 6. The said association shall be liable, upon its contracts, to the extent of its property; and the individual members only to the amount that may be due upon their subscriptions to the capital stock.

Sec. 7. The said association shall have its office in the city of Houston, county of Harris, and all legal process may be served on its president, secretary or principal managing agent, by whatever name he may be known.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p:
Sec. 8. This association may be dissolved at any time by an affirmative vote of two-thirds of the stock, and in such an event the stockholders shall, at the same time, appoint some proper per-
son to wind up the affairs of the association; provided, that nothing herein contained shall release said stockholders from any outstand-
ing indebtedness that may have accrued to said association remain-
ing unpaid.

Sec. 9. That this act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage, and shall continue in force for the term of twenty-
five years.

div3.head: CHAPTER CCXXX.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Marshall Female College.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That an institution of learning, for the education of fe-
males, be and the same is hereby established in the city of Mar-
shall, in the county of Harrison, to be known as “The Marshall Female College.”

Sec. 2. That J. T. Montgomery, J. H. Calloway, B. H. Mar-
tin, Geo. L. Hill, R. Knight, Jas. Brookmiller, Geo. B. Adkins, R. C. Garrett, George Lane, W. M. Copeland, Wm. E. Miller, and their successors, be and they are hereby declared to be the trustees of said college, and are constituted a body politic, in deed and in law, by the name of “Trustees of the Marshall Female Col-
lege;” and by that name may sue and be sued, plead and be im-
pleaded, and to grant, bargain, and sell any lands or personal prop-
erty now belonging or that may hereafter belong to the college; to purchase real and personal property for the same; to construct all buildings they may consider necessary for the use of said college; to establish preparatory departments; to elect their own officers and appoint committees, and to act and do all things whatsoever for the benefit of said college in as full and ample a manner as any person or body politic or corporate may or can do by law.

Sec. 3. That the said trustees shall have the power of framing and enacting all such ordinances and by-laws as shall appear neces-
sary for the good government of said college, and for their own pro-
ceedings, not in contravention of law.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p: Sec. 4. The trustees shall elect a president and professors, to be styled the “Faculty of the Marshall Female College,” who shall manage and control in the government of said college.

Sec. 5. The trustees are empowered to confer such degree or degrees in the arts and sciences to the students of said college, and on other persons worthy thereof, as are usually granted and con-
ferred by other colleges, and to give certificates thereof, or diplo-
mas, signed by the president of the college and at least five trustees and sealed with the common seal of the trustees of the college, to authenticate and perpetuate the memory of such graduations.

Sec. 6. That five trustees shall constitute a quorum for trans-
action of all business; and whenever any vacancy may occur in said board of trustees, either by death, resignation, or otherwise, such vacancy or vacancies shall be filled by said board by election of another or others.

Sec. 7. That “The Marshall Female College” shall be purely literary and scientific, and no religious test shall be made in the re-
ception and advantages enjoyed by the students, nor shall the pecu-
liar doctrines of any religious denomination, be taught therein.

Sec. 8. The board of trustees shall meet at the end of each col-
legiate year, and whenever the president of said board may call them together.
Sec. 9. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CCXXXI.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the town of Kosse, in Limestone county.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the citizens of the town of Kosse, in the county of Limestone, be and they are hereby declared a body politic and cor-
porate, under the name and style of the “Town of Kosse,” and by that name shall have power to sue and be sued, plead and be im-
pleaded, and to acquire, hold and dispose of property real and per-
sonal; provided, such real property shall be situated within the limits of said corporation, and the limits of said corporation shall be one mile square.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p:
Sec. 2. That G. Y. Beaumont, D. T. Igleheart, J. Huey, R. H. Fielder and Mr. Young be and they are hereby appointed commis-
sioners to lay off said town, and make a plat defining its limits, which plat shall be filed in the office of the county clerk of Lime-
stone county; and that said commissioners be and they are hereby authorized to do any act or perform any duty necessary to carry this act into effect, not inconsistent with the Constitution and laws of this State.

Sec. 3. That all persons who are qualified voters under the Con-
stitution of this State, and who have been citizens of said town six months next preceding an election, shall be authorized to vote for officers of said corporation.

Sec. 4. That until the next general election, to-wit: on the sec-
ond Tuesday in November, A. D. 1872, all the officers of said town shall be appointed by the Governor.

Sec. 5. That at the next general election, to-wit: on the second Tuesday in November, A. D. 1872, there shall be elected by the qualified voters of said town a mayor, a constable and five aldermen, who shall hold their offices for the term of two years, and until their successors be elected and qualified. The other officers of said town shall consist of a secretary and treasurer, to be selected by the alder-
men from their own number; an attorney, to be elected by the board of aldermen, and such other inferior officers as the board of aldermen may from time to time appoint, who shall hold their offices until the next election for town officers succeeding their election or appointment, unless sooner removed by the board of aldermen.

Sec. 6. That in all elections held under the provisions of this act the board of aldermen shall appoint judges of said election, who shall take an oath faithfully and impartially to discharge their du-
ties. They shall open the polls at ten o’clock A. M. and close them at four o’clock P. M. on the day of election, and shall, within twenty-
four hours thereafter, make returns of said election to the mayor, or, in case of his absence or inability to act, or of a vacancy in his office, then the aldermen, in presence of the judges of election, shall open the returns and declare the result, and shall immediately issue certificates thereof to the persons elected.
Sec. 7. That when an election for mayor shall be contested, then the board of aldermen shall determine such contest.

Sec. 8. That in case of a vacancy in the office of mayor, the board of aldermen shall order an election to fill such vacancy. Such elec-
tion shall be held as provided in this act for general elections; and in case of a vacancy in the office of aldermen, such vacancy shall be filled at a regular meeting of the board of aldermen, by a
Laws of the State of Texas.vote of two-thirds of the aldermen present, and the person so elected shall hold his office for the unexpired term.

Sec. 9. In case of the temporary absence of the mayor, the board of aldermen shall have power to appoint one of their own number to act for the time being as mayor, who shall have the same powers and privileges as the mayor elect, and such appointment shall expire on the return of the mayor.

Sec. 10. That the mayor, when present, shall preside over the board of aldermen, and, in case of a tie, shall give the easting vote; provided, that three of the aldermen, either with or without the mayor, shall constitute a quorum to transact business.

Sec. 11. That the mayor, in addition to his powers and juris-
diction as such, is hereby vested with all the powers and jurisdic-
tion, civil and criminal, within the limits of said town, which may, by law, be exercised by justices of the peace, under the laws of this State; and he shall be entitled to have and receive such fees as are or may be allowed by law to justices of the peace for similar services.

Sec. 12. That the constable, in addition to his powers and duties as such, is hereby vested with all the powers and privileges which are or may, by law, be exercised by other constables of Limestone county; and for all services rendered by him shall receive the same fees that are or may be allowed by law to other constables.

Sec. 13. That the mayor and aldermen shall have power to enact such rules and regulations and ordinances for the government of said town, and for the quiet, peace and happiness of the citizens thereof, not inconsistent with the Constitution and laws of this State, as may be deemed proper, and may impose fines and penalties for the violation of the same, not to exceed one hundred dollars in any one case, or imprisonment exceeding three months.
Sec. 14. That the major and board of aldermen shall have and exercise control over the streets, sidewalks, roads, and all public places in said town.

Sec. 15. That the board of aldermen shall have power to levy and provide for the collection of an ad valorem tax upon all prop-
erty situated in said town, and taxable by the laws of this State; and also power to levy and collect a poll tax not to exceed one-half dollar, on all male persons of said corporation over the age of twenty-one and under the age of fifty years; provided, said ad va-
lorem tax shall not exceed one-half of one per cent.

Sec. 16. That the constable shall be ex officio assessor and col-
lector of taxes for said town.

Sec. 17. That the mayor and board of aldermen shall have power to license, tax and regulate hawkers, peddlers, auctions, thea-
Laws of the State of Texas.trical and other exhibitions, shows, billiard tables, nine and ten pin alleys, groceries, bar rooms, tippling houses and dram shops, and to determine the amount of tax upon the same; and shall have power to impose and collect an occupation tax upon all occupations taxed by any general law of this State, not to exceed one-half the amount of State tax allowed by law for any one year; and shall have power, and it is hereby made their duty, to suppress all gambling and gam-
ing houses, and all disorderly houses of every description.

Sec. 18. That all officers of said town shall, before entering upon the dirties of their offices, take and subscribe the oath pre-
scribed by the Constitution; and the mayor, constable and treas-
urer shall each give bond, with good and sufficient securities, to be approved by the board of aldermen, in such sum as they may direct, conditioned for the faithful performance of their duties, which bonds shall be made payable to the “Town of Kosse,” and shall not be void on the first recovery.

Sec. 19. That the board of aldermen shall regulate the salaries and fees of all officers; provided the fees of the attorney shall not exceed two dollars and fifty cents for each conviction, to be taxed in the bill of costs against the accused; and provided, further, that the treasurer shall not be allowed more than five per centum upon all sums of money received and paid out by him.

Sec. 20. That the constable, treasurer and attorney of said cor-
poration may be removed from office for any neglect of duty, mis-
demeanor or malfeasance in office, by a vote of two-thirds of the aldermen at any regular meeting of the board; and it shall be the duty of the district judge, whenever complaint is made to him un-
der oath by any person or persons, accusing the mayor, or any member of the board of aldermen, of malfeasance, nonfeasance or neglect of duty in office, immediately to examine into the truth of the said charges, and if true, he shall remove such person or per-
sons from office at once.
Sec. 21. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER CCXXXII.

opener.salute:
An Act amendatory of “An Act to incorporate the Home Insur-
ance Company, of Houston, Texas.”

div3.p:
Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the first section of the above recited act, approved August 13, 1870, be-
so amended that the name of the company incorporated in said act shall be changed from the Home Insurance Company, of Houston, Texas, to that of the Planters’ Insurance Company, of Houston, Texas; so that the first section of the above named act shall read as follows: “Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That there may be established in the city of Houston a company for the purpose of transacting a general insurance busi-
ness, which company shall be called and known by the name of the Planters’ Insurance Company, of Houston, Texas; and the stock-
holders and their successors shall have continuous succession, and by that name shall be capable of suing and being sued, of purchas-
ing, holding and conveying property of all descriptions; to make, have and use a common seal, and the same to alter and renew at pleasure, and generally to do any act necessary to carry into effect the objects of the corporation, not inconsistent with the laws of this State or the United States.”

div3.head: CHAPTER CCXXXIII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Carthage Branch Railway Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That A. W. De Berry, Drury Field, J. H: Booty, T. S. Black, T. J. Beagan, W. B. Bockmore, T. J. Knight, H. L. Ander-
son, Thomas Horton, Allen H. Baker, E. S. Hull, T. W. Garner, A. S. Wall, and J. M. Waskom, and such others as they may as-
sociate with them, are hereby created a body politic and corporate, under the name of the “Carthage Branch Bailway Company;” and by such name they may sue and be sued, make contracts, have and
Laws of the State of Texas.hold real and personal property, by grant, donation or purchase, or sell, transfer or alienate the same. Said corporation shall have suc-
cession for ninety-nine years, and a corporate seal.

Sec. 2. The said, persons named in the first section of this act, their associates or assigns, shall constitute the first board of direc-
tors. They shall have the right to elect a president, vice president, secretary, treasurer, and attorney; the other officers and agents of the company shall be appointed in such manner as the said, direc-
tors may ordain and establish. The said directors shall have power to make by-laws, rules and regulations for their government, so as to carry out the intent of this act, and to appoint an executive com-
mittee, and confer upon it such powers as they may see fit, not inconsistent with the laws of this State or the United States; to provide for the future election of officers, and to fix the place of the principal office of the company, and change the same at pleas-
ure; to provide for issuing of stock, and the transfer of the same; to provide for the issuing of the bonds of the company; to mort-
gage and hypothecate the road bed, rolling stock, and all other property of said company, to raise funds to build or equip said road.

Sec. 3. That said company shall have the right to construct, own and operate a first class railroad, of whatever gauge they may see proper, from any point on the Southern Pacific Railroad, within five miles of Waskom’s station; thence in a southwesterly direction, by the nearest practicable route, to the town of Carthage, in Panola county. That said company shall have the right to connect their road with the Southern Pacific Railroad, and to connect with or cross any intervening railroad chartered by this State.

Sec. 4. That said company shall have the right of way along their entire route, not to exceed two hundred feet in width, over all lands of the State, and the free use of rock, timber, gravel, and earth thereof, and the terms of the general laws of this State to procure the release of the right of way from the owners of the lands along the route; and shall have the right to construct and operate a telegraph line along their entire route, and to build and construct bridges across all streams along their line; provided, that no right is given to obstruct navigation.

Sec. 5. That the capital stock of said company shall be one mil-
lion of dollars, with the privilege of increase to any sum not to ex-
ceed three millions, divided into shares of one hundred dollars each.
Sec. 6. That said company shall have the whole line completed in five years from and after the passage of this act.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER CCXXXIV.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate Charles Sumner Male and Female Academy, in the town of Henderson, county of Rusk.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That for the management and control of an institution of learning located in the town of Henderson, Rusk county, Texas, to he styled the “Sumner Male and Female Academy,” Osburne Tol-
bert, William Cumby, Thomas Harris, Henry Bowden, Jerry Lee, James Holliman, Aleck Cumby, Stafford Wolf, Henry Hicks, Hugh Wilson, George Blair, Rolla Lee, Jesse McElroy and John Bums, are hereby constituted a board of trustees for said academy, and that they and their successors in office are made a body corporate, capable in law of suing and being sued, holding or alienating prop-
erty, real and personal.

Sec. 2. That said board of trustees shall have succession, shall have a common seal, may hold property to the amount of one hun-
dred thousand dollars, may establish a course of studies, grant cer-
tificates of scholarship, and do all other things necessary and inci-
dent to the maintenance and promotion of good morals and sound learning, not inconsistent with the constitution and laws of the United States or of this State.

Sec. 3. That this act of incorporation and this charter for said academy shall remain in full force and effect until said trustees, or their successors, shall neglect or refuse to maintain in said academy school organization during the accustomed scholastic months of any year.
Sec. 4. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CCXXXV.

opener.salute:
An Act to incorporate Rockwall Institute, in the county of Kauf-
man.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That J. S. Griffith, A. D. Edwards and N. H. O. Polly, and their successors in office, be and they are hereby constituted a
Laws of the State of Texas.body corporate and politic, for educational purposes, by the name and style of the “Rockwall Institute,” by which name they may sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, buy and sell property, real and mixed, and have a seal to authenticate their acts; which privilege shall continue for a term of five years, for the purpose of maintaining an institution of learning in Rockwall, Kaufman coun-
ty, Texas.
Sec. 2. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CCXXXVI.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the “Excelsior Transfer and Transportation Company.”

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That Robert Colwell, W. W. Willard, E. C. Bartholomew, W. H. Hawkins, W. E. Gregory and Starr Jones, and those that may asso-
ciate with them, be and they are hereby declared a body corporate and politic, under the name and style of the “Excelsior Transfer and Transportation Company,” and by that name may sue and be sued, have succession, make contracts, have and use a seal, acquire, hold, manage and alienate property, real and personal, and possess generally all the rights, powers, privileges and immunities necessary to carry into full effect the provisions and objects of this act, They may establish, manage and control such line or lines with vehicles or boats propelled by steam or sail, for the transfer of passengers and transportation of baggage and freight, within the limits of Galveston county, as may be necessary and for the interest of the company, and may charge and collect such rate or toll for the trans-
fer of passengers or transportation of freight or baggage as may be established by said company.

Sec. 2. That the capital stock of said company shall be one hun-
dred thousand dollars, and when twenty thousand dollars of said capital have been subscribed the same shall be organized by the stockholders, or a majority of them, who shall proceed to elect a board of directors of not less than five; said directors shall elect from their number a president, one vice president, a secretary and treasurer, and such other officers as may be provided for in their
Laws of the State of Texas.by-laws, and all elections shall be annual, at such time and places as may be designated in the by-laws, and each share shall be entitled to one vote in election for directors. The company shall establish such rules, by-laws and regulations as may be required for the use and government of said company, and not contrary to the Constitution and laws of Texas and of the United States.
Sec. 3. That this act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CCXXXVII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Dallas City Railroad Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That J. W. Smith, W. W. Peak, John J. Good, T. C. Jordan, W. L. Murphy, J. K. P. Record, J. W. Lane, J. W. Swindells, George M. Swink and their associates, subscribers to the capital stock of the Dallas city railroad, be and the same are hereby declared to be a body corporate in law and in fact, under the name and title of “Dal-
las City Railroad Company.”

Sec. 2. Said company shall have the right to construct, equip and run horse or steam street railroads upon Elm, Main, Commerce, Jackson and Wood streets, of the city of Dallas, Dallas county, Texas, and all other streets of said city that may be hereafter desig-
nated by the mayor and aldermen of said city, being within the corporate limits of said city at the time of such designation. Said company shall construct, equip, own, conduct and run said horse railroads in the streets of the city of Dallas, subject to such munici-
pal regulations for the repair and good condition of said roads, and for the regulation of the speed of travel and the safety of passen-
gers, and for the assessment of ordinary municipal taxes, as the mayor and aldermen may provide and direct.

Sec. 3. That the capital stock of said company shall not exceed five hundred thousand dollars, divided into shares of one hundred dollars each. Said company shall have the right to issue said stock upon such terms as they may deem essential to the construction and maintenance of their road or roads.

Sec. 4. That the affairs of said company shall be managed by a board of directors, not exceeding five, to be elected by the stock-
Laws of the State of Texas.holders. Said directors shall be elected by the stockholders annu-
ally, and said board of directors shall elect from their number a president of the board, also a treasurer and secretary who may be one and the same person, but who shall not be a director of the com-
pany, whose duties shall be determined by said board, and who shall hold their offices respectively until their successors are elected.

Sec. 5. That said company shall have a common seal, and shall have the right to sue and be sued, to purchase real estate, hold or sell the same; provided, that all purchases or sales must be author-
ized by a vote of the majority of the stockholders, voting under the rules of the company. That said company shall have the right to make all such rules and regulations for the government and man-
agement of said company, as a majority of the board of directors, approved by a majority of the issued stock of the company, may de-
termine, not inconsistent with this act, nor the provisions and or-
dinances of the said city of Dallas.

Sec. 6. That the corporators named in this act, and their asso-
ciates, subscribers to the stock of the Dallas city railroad, may or-
ganize this company immediately after the passage of this act, by the election of a board of directors, and a president, secretary and treasurer, by these incorporators and their associate subscribers. This charter shall continue and remain in force for the period of twenty-five years.
Sec. 7. That the legal domicile and place of business of said company shall be in the city of Dallas, Texas.
Sec. 8. That this act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

The foregoing act, received in the office of Secretary of State May twenty-ninth, one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one, having been presented to the Governor of Texas for his approval, and not having been returned by him to the house in which it or-
iginated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has become a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER CCXXXVIII.

opener.salute:
An Act to release John Bartley from paying State, county or city incorporation tax on exhibitions of gymnastic feats and enter-
tainments in the State of Texas.

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That John Bartley be and he is hereby authorized to exhibit and perform gymnastic feats and entertainments, in person and not otherwise, anywhere in the State of Texas, free of any State, county or city incorporation tax.
Sec. 2. That this act to take effect from and after its passage, and be in force for the period of five years.

The foregoing act; received in the office of Secretary of State May twenty-ninth, one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one, having been presented to the Governor of Texas for his approval, and not having been returned by him to the house in which it or-
iginated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has become a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div3.head: CHAPTER CCXXXIX.

opener.salute: An act to incorporate the town of Yorktown.

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the citizens of the town of Yorktown be and they are hereby declared a body corporate, under the name and style of the “Town of Yorktown,” and by that name may sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded in all the courts of the State, and may hold and dispose of property, real, personal and mixed, within the limits of said corporation.

Sec. 2. That the limits of said town shall be as follows, to-wit: Beginning at a post oak marked H, for a southeast corner; thence north twenty-five degrees east, eleven hundred and ninety-five varas;
Laws of the State of Texas.thence north sixty-five degrees west, five hundred and forty-one varas; thence north twenty-five degrees east, six hundred and sixty-
three varas; thence north forty-one degrees fifty-two minutes west, fourteen hundred and sixty varas; thence south twenty-five degrees west, twelve hundred and seventy-two varas; thence north sixty-five degrees west, three thousand eight hundred and thirty-seven varas; thence south twenty-five degrees west, three thousand eight hun-
dred varas; thence east six thousand three hundred and eighteen varas, to the place of beginning.

Sec. 3. That the Governor is hereby authorized to appoint a mayor and five aldermen for said town of Yorktown, who shall hold their offices until the next general election, unless otherwise pro-
vided by law. An assessor and collector, treasurer, secretary and constable shall be elected by said aldermen, and shall be required to take the oath prescribed by the Constitution of the State of Texas; the assessor and collector and treasurer shall be required to give bond with security, to be approved by. the presiding officer, for the faithful performance of their duties, and to make reports when re-
quired by the mayor and board of aldermen, and the mayor shall have power, when necessary, to suppress riots and disturbances, to call out the citizens of said corporation for the purpose of restoring order.

Sec. 4. That the offices of mayor and aldermen, and constable, and assessor and collector, shall become elective from and after the next general election, and the first election shall be held under the direction of the presiding justice of DeWitt county, after having given ten days’ notice thereof, and annually afterwards, under the direction of the mayor, at least ten days before the expiration of his term of office, and that in case of death or resignation the vacancies shall be filled by new elections to be ordered by the mayor; and in case the office of mayor shall be vacant, then the aldermen shall elect one of their own body to act as mayor until the next annual election, or they may order an election for mayor to fill the unex-
pired term, after giving ten days’ notice of such election.

Sec. 5. That no person shall be eligible to any office under the provisions of [this] charter who is not a citizen and a qualified elector of this State, and a resident within the limits of this corpora-
tion for the space of sixty days, nor shall any person have a right to vote for any officers who is not a citizen and qualified elector, and a resident within said corporate limits.

Sec. 6. That the mayor and board of aldermen of said corpora-
tion shall have the power to pass such rules and ordinances as may be necessary for the regulation of the police and the preservation of order within the corporate limits; for the levying of taxes; for the
Laws of the State of Texas.removal of nuisances; for the keeping of the streets in good order, and other objects promotive of the public good; and to prescribe penalties for the violation of the ordinances and by-laws of the cor-
poration; provided, that in no case such penalties shall exceed one hundred dollars.

Sec. 7. That the mayor, with the majority of said aldermen, shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business, and shall enact and enforce such rules and regulations as they may deem necessary for the government of said corporation and the promotion of public health; provided, that the same do not conflict with the laws and the Constitution of the State.
Sec. 8. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CCXL.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Cedar Bayou Bar Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That B. M. Perryman, W. D. Williams, James Wrigley, Eugene Pil-
lott, E. W. Cave, Ashbel Smith, Henry F. Gillette, S. J. Ashe, Hous-
ton Hopkins, and their successors and associates, are hereby con-
stituted and declared to be a body corporate and politic, under the name and style of the “Cedar Bayou Bar Company,” and that by said name and style they shall have succession; may sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded in all courts in the State of Texas; shall be capable in law of contracting and being contracted with, and shall have the power of acquiring by purchase, donation or otherwise, such property, both real and personal and mixed, as may be neces-
sary to carry into full effect the objects of this incorporation as hereinafter mentioned.

Sec. 2. The said Cedar Bayou Bar Company shall be and is hereby authorized to dredge out and otherwise deepen the bar at the mouth of Cedar Bayou where it enters into Galveston Bay, and to construct and keep up whatever works may be necessary for deepen-
ing and cleaning out said bar, and for maintaining the depth of water over said bar, or in any canal made for this purpose.

Sec. 3. When said company shall have completed a canal or passage for boats of not less than five feet in depth and of thirty-five feet width, from the deep waters within the Cedar Bayou to the waters of like depth in Galveston Bay, to be determined by a com-
Laws of the State of Texas.petent engineer appointed by the County Court of Harris county, then said company shall be authorized to collect from all boats drawing two feet and over, when loaded, crossing over said bar in either direction, so long as said canal or passage shall be kept in good repair, tolls not exceeding one-half of the tolls authorized to be collected by law on vessels passing through the canal of the Ship Channel Company constructed through Morgan’s point.

Sec. 4. Said company shall be and is hereby required to place piles on heavy stakes on either side of the passage or canal, to indi-
cate the location of the same, and at distances of not more than one hundred fathoms between any two on the same side of the passage or canal.

Sec. 5. The privileges granted in this charter shall cease and de-
termine at the expiration of thirty-three years after the works shall be declared ready for rise.

Sec. 6. The company shall complete their work by removing, as herein provided, the obstructions to navigation over the bar of Cedar Bayou within three years from the passage of this act, and in default thereof this act of incorp ration shall be null and void, and all rights under it shall cease and determine. No banking privi-
leges shall be exercised under this act.

Sec. 7. If any person shall willfully do, or cause to be done, any act to injure the works or obstruct the canal, passage or channel way, or otherwise impede its use for navigation, the person so of-
fending shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and, being convicted thereof, shall be punished by fine not exceeding three hundred dol-
lars, or by imprisonment, at hard labor, in the penitentiary, or by both, at the discretion of the jury; provided, that, such criminal prosecution shall not in any wise impair the rights of action for damages by a civil suit hereby authorized to be brought for any such injury or damage as aforesaid, by and in the name of said corpora-
tion, in any court of this State having cognizance of the same.
Sec. 8. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

The foregoing act, received in the office of Secretary of State May twenty-fifth, one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one, having been presented to the Governor of Texas for his approval, and not having been returned by him to the house in which it origi-
nated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has become a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER CCXLI.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Austin Homestead Building Association.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That G. D. Scott, J. W. Alexander, H. Willis, Ed. Car-
rington, H. Madison, J. Pollard, J. Royma, A. Pennington, T. Reithley, their associates and successors, are hereby created and es-
tablished a body corporate and politic, under the name and style of the “Austin Homestead Building Association,” of the city of Aus-
tin, with capacity in said corporate name to make contracts, to hold, buy and sell property, to contract and execute deeds, mortgages and deeds of trust, to have succession and a common seal, to make a con-
stitution and by-laws for the government and regulation of its af-
fairs, to sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, to declare divi-
dends and make divisions of property, and to do and perform all such things as may be necessary and proper for and incident to the fulfilment of its obligations and maintenance of its rights under this enactment, and consistent with the laws of the State.

Sec. 2. The capital stock of this association shall be twenty thousand (20,000) dollars in shares of twenty-five dollars each, with power and privilege of increasing the same to eighty thousand (80,000) dollars.

Sec. 3. Whenever stocks to the amount of ten thousand (10,000) dollars have been subscribed, and two per cent. on the same paid in, the association shall be deemed organized and competent to trans-
act business, and be entitled to all the grants and privileges con-
ferred in this enactment.

Sec. 4. Service of any and all process in any suit or proceedings against the association, shall be sufficient if made upon the presi-
dent or secretary of the association.
Sec. 5. That this act take effect from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER CCXLII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Llano Mining Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That W. J. Locke, Fritz Tegener, G. H. Kalteyer, B. F. Casey, Wil-
liam Lockhart, E. D. Hall, P. G. Temple, and their associates, be and they are hereby created a body corporate and politic, under the name and style of the “Llano Mining Company;” with power to sue and be sued; to contract and be contracted with; to grant, receive, purchase and hold real and personal estate; to borrow money and contract debts; to have and use a corporate seal, and generally to do and perform such acts and things as may be necessary and proper for, or incident to the fulfillment of its obligations and maintenance of its rights under this charter, not inconsistent with the Constitu-
tion and laws of the State.

Sec. 2. The capital stock of said corporation shall not exceed the sum of five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000), which shall be divided into shares of one hundred dollars; each share shall entitle the owner thereof to one vote, in person or by proxy, at all meetings of the company, which meetings may be held at such times and places as may be named by the persons herein named as corporators, or by the directors, after the company is organized. The shares shall be deemed personal estate, and may be transferred by con-
veyance recorded in the books of the company at its principal office, or in books kept at such other places as the directors may appoint; and any transfer recorded at any other place than the principal office of the company, shall be communicated to the principal office, and recorded there within thirty days after the same was made.

Sec. 3. The immediate control, government, and direction of the affairs of the company shall be vested in a board of not less than five directors, to be elected by the stockholders. The directors shall elect one of their number to be president of the company. No per-
son shall be eligible to the office of director unless he shall own at least ten shares of the stock of the company. The directors shall have power to fill any vacancy that may occur in the board, and may appoint such officers and agents as they may consider necessary for the management of the affairs of the company, and prescribe and re-
quire bonds and security from such officers or agents for the faithful performance of their duties. The said directors shall cause to be kept a correct record of all proceedings at meetings of the directors
Laws of the State of Texas.and company, and of all matters pertaining to the management and business of the company; and shall keep a correct account of the receipts and expenditures of the company. A majority of the board shall have the power of a full board, and all conveyances and con-
tracts executed in writing, signed by the president and attested by the seal of the company, and in pursuance of a vote of the direct-
ors, shall be valid and binding upon the company. The first board of directors shall be chosen by the corporators named in this act, and such persons as they may associate with them, at such time and place as a majority of them may name; and all subsequent elec-
tions for directors shall be made by the vote of a majority of stock-
holders at the principal office of the company, and at such time as may be appointed by the company, or a majority of the board of directors.

Sec. 4. The board of directors may acquire by purchase, or in payment for stock of the company, such real estate as they may think desirable for the mining of gold, silver, copper and lead, or any other minerals; and the said company shall have full power and authority to carry on the business of mining in gold, silver, copper and lead, or any other minerals, upon any lands they may acquire in this State; and to smelt, refine or manufacture any min-
erals, with the right of owning and operating any buildings, works or machinery that may be necessary for their object, and also with the right of building, owning and operating any vehicles that may be needed for the transportation of their ores.
Sec. 5. That this company shall have the right to rise timber or other material of the public land adjacent to their mine or mines for building and operating said mine or mines.
Sec. 6. That this act shall be in force for the period of fifty years, and shall take effect from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CCXLIII.

opener.salute: An Act to prohibit the sale of ardent spirits and other intoxicating liquors within certain limits of Lebanon High School, in Collin County, Texas.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That it shall be unlawful for any person or persons to dis-
pose of any intoxicating or spirituous liquors, by sale or otherwise,
Laws of the State of Texas.except for sacramental or medical purposes, within two miles of Lebanon High School, an institution of learning, located some twelve miles from the county seat of Collin county.

Sec. 2. That any person or persons violating the provisions of this act shall, upon conviction thereof in any court of competent jurisdiction, be fined in any sum not less than fifty nor more than one hundred dollars for each and every offense.
Sec. 3. That this act shall be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CCXLIV.

opener.salute:
An Act to incorporate the “C” Sugar and Tobacco Planting Asso-
ciation.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That John L. Simo, J. B Casablanca, E. F. Cavada, G. S. Spofford and their associates, be and they are hereby incorporated under the name and style of the “C” Sugar and Tobacco Planting Association, with power and authority as such to organize a com-
pany for the purpose of purchasing lands for the cultivation of sugar and tobacco.
Sec. 2. That said company shall have right to erect all buildings, machinery and improvements that are necessary to the successful operation of their business.

Sec. 3. That the capital stock of said company shall not exceed one hundred thousand dollars, United States currency, and shall be divided into shares of two hundred and fifty dollars each, to be taken and subscribed, and such amount paid thereon at the time and after subscriptions as the board of directors of said company may prescribe in accordance with the provisions of this act.

Sec. 4. That the corporate powers of said company shall be ex-
ercised by a board of directors to be elected by the stockholders of said company, each share being entitled to one vote; the directors to elect a president, secretary and treasurer of the company.

Sec. 5. The company to be allowed to have a common seal, and all contracts and acts of the company, shares or document of any value, shall be authenticated by the signatures of the president and secretary of the board, with the impress of the seal thereon affixed, and said company to sue and be sued, answer and be answered, plead
Laws of the State of Texas.and be impleaded in all matters and things appertaining to the busi-
ness of such incorporation.

Sec. 6. The said company shall have the powers to make by-
laws, rules and regulations for the government of said company, and for the conducting and regulating its business, and said company as soon as its regular officers are elected shall give notice thereon in the public newspapers of the city of Galveston and Houston.

Sec. 7. That said company shall annually report to every Stock-
holder a complete statement of the business operation of the same, including the proceeds of the crops obtained annually after the third year of the establishment of the company, the proceeds to be divided among the shareholders. This act shall take effect from its passage and remain in force for twenty years.

div3.head: CHAPTER CCXLV.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the “Navasota Hook and Ladder Company Number One,” of the city of Navasota, State of Texas.

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That T. N. Elson, J. N. Guy, John B. Farris, C. D. Harn, J. M. Osbourn, Tite Johnston, P. A. Smith, U. P. Melton, P. Miller, John Arnold, Webb Teague, J. H. Teague, of the county of Grimes, and State of Texas, and their associates and successors, are hereby constituted a body politic and corporate, under the name and style of the “Navasota Hook and Ladder Company, Number One,” and by that name shall have succession, and may sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, have and use a corporate seal; buy, sell, and hold property, real and personal and mixed, not to exceed in value one hundred thousand dollars; may contract and be contracted with, and make all rules and by-laws that may be deemed necessary for the government of the said company, and have and exercise all the powers and rights generally incident to such companies in the State of Texas.

Sec. 2. That said company shall have the authority and right in its constitution, rules and by-laws, or either of them, to impose fines upon its members for neglect of duty, not to exceed in any one in-
stance the sum of five dollars; and that all fines and dues may be
Laws of the State of Texas.sued for and collected in the name and for the benefit of said com-
pany, by suit before any justice of the peace or other authority in and for the county of Grimes.
Sec. 3. That the members of said company shall not be less than twenty, nor more than one hundred in number.
Sec. 4. That each and every member of said company shall be exempt from serving on juries, except in capital cases.
Sec. 5. That neither the company, nor any of its members, shall be liable in damages or otherwise, for property destroyed or injured by the company while in the discharge of their duties as firemen.
Sec. 6. That all the property of the company shall be exempt from taxation for State and county or for city purposes.
Sec. 7. That this act take effect from and after its passage.

The foregoing act, received in the office of the Secretary of State May twenty-ninth, one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one, having been presented to the Governor of Texas for his approval, and not having been returned by him to the house in which it origi-
nated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has become a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div3.head: CHAPTER CCXLVI.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Jefferson Ice Manufacturing Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That H. C. Hynson, R. A. Johnson, E. W. Taylor, J. H. Roberts, W. T. C. Campbell, W. M. Harrison, and their associates, be and they are hereby constituted and declared a body corporate and politic, under the name and style of the “Jefferson Ice Manu-
facturing Company,” with power, in their corporate capacity, to make contracts; to have succession and a common seal; to make by-laws for its government; and in its corporate name to sue and be sued; to grant, take and receive, and generally to do and perform all such acts and things as may be necessary and proper for and in-
Laws of the State of Texas.cident to the fulfillment of its obligations, or the maintenance of its rights and privileges under this act, not inconsitent with the con-
stitutional provisions and the laws of the State of Texas.

Sec. 2. That said company be and is hereby established with the right of erecting, owning, maintaining and operating buildings and works for the manufacture of ice in the city of Jefferson, county of Marion, and State of Texas, and for owning and keeping up such vehicles as may be necessary for the delivery of the same in said city, and with the privilege of delivering the ice thus made to purchasers in said city and surrounding country.

Sec. 3. That the capital stock of said, company shall be two hun-
dred thousand dollars, which may be increased to a sum not to ex-
ceed five hundred thousand dollars, and said stock shall be divided into shares of one hundred dollars each, and the owners of said shares shall constitute the said company, and each member shall be entitled to one vote for each share he or she may own or represent by proxy, and such share shall be deemed as personal property, trans-
ferable only on the books of the company, and in such manner as they may prescribe.

Sec. 4. That the business and affairs of said company shall be conducted and managed by a board of directors of not less than three nor more than seven, who shall be elected by the company at such time as the stockholders may designate, and annually there-
after; provided, that in case of failure to elect at the appointed time, the board of directors incumbent shall continue in office until there be an election, the time for which shall be fixed by said board, they giving reasonable notice of the same by advertisement in a newspaper published at the place where the office of said company is located.

Sec. 5. That the board of directors shall elect from among their members a president, fill all vacancies that may occur, and appoint a secretary and treasurer, and such other officers and employes as they may deem necessary, and require security for the faithful per-
formance of their duties, prescribe the time for the payment of assessments on the subscribed stock of the company, and the rate of such assessment thereon, declare the forfeiture of such stock for the non-payment of stock or assessments thereon, or any part thereof, and do or cause to be done all other lawful acts or things which they may deem necessary and proper in conducting the business of said company. A majority of said board of directors shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of the business of the company. All instruments in writing, executed by the president of said company, and countersigned by the secretary, with the consent, by resolution
Laws of the State of Texas.of the board of directors, and in accordance with this act, shall be binding on said company.

Sec. 6. That said company shall have the right and privilege of owning real estate. The owners of the said ice machine shall enjoy all the privileges and rights granted them by this charter for the term of twenty-five years from and after the passage of this act; provided, that said company shall have two years from the passage of said act, to put into operation the machinery for the purpose of manufacturing ice.
Sec. 7. That this act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CCXLVII.

opener.salute: An Act for the relief of the heirs of Isham Davis, deceased.

div3.p: Whereas, On the first day of May, A. D. 1838, there issued to Isham Davis, a soldier of the Republic, bounty land warrant No. 3104, for three hundred and twenty acres of land; and
Whereas, Said warrant was located in Fannin county in 1848, and soon after said Davis died leaving his heirs infants; and
Whereas, Said heirs have occupied and improved said land for ever twenty years, thinking their title good; and
Whereas, Said survey of land can not be patented because the aforesaid warrant was never presented to the Commissioner of Claims for approval; therefore

Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That said bounty warrant No. 3104, for three hundred and twenty acres of land, be and the same is hereby approved and vali-
dated, and the survey and field notes made by virtue thereof, now on file in the General Land Office, are hereby validated, and the Commissioner of the General Land Office is hereby authorized and required to issue thereon a patent to the heirs of Isham Davis, de-
ceased.
Sec. 2. That this act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p:
The foregoing act, received in the office of Secretary of State May twenty-ninth, one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one, having been presented to the Governor of Texas for his approval, and not having been returned by him to the house in which it origi-
nated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has become a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div3.head: CHAPTER CCXLVIII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the “Galveston Hook and Ladder Company Humber One,” of the city of Galveston, State of Texas.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That Nahor B. Yard, Frank D. Harrar, William H. Shields, James Sorley, Fred. A. Smith, and Peter Gray Nichols, of the county of Galveston and State of Texas, and their associates and successors, are hereby constituted a body politic and corporate, un-
der the name and style of the “Galveston Hook and Ladder Com-
pany, Number One,” and by that name shall have succession, and may sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, have and use a cor-
porate seal, buy, sell and hold property, real, personal and mixed, not to exceed in value ten thousand dollars; may contract and be contracted with, and make all rules and by-laws that may be deemed necessary for the government of the said company, and have and exercise all the powers and rights generally incident to such com-
panies in the city of Galveston, State of Texas.

Sec. 2. That said company shall have the authority and right, in its constitution, rules and by-laws, or either of them, to impose fines upon its members for neglect of duty, not to exceed in any one instance the sum of five dollars; and that all fines and dues may be sued for and collected in the name of and for the benefit of said company, by suit before any justice of the peace or other authority in and for the county of Galveston.
Sec. 3. That the members of said company shall not be less than twenty nor more than sixty-fine in number.

Sec. 4. That each and every member of said company shall be exempt from serving on juries, except in capital cases, and shall fee
Laws of the State of Texas.forever exempt from militia service after having served seven years as an active member of the company.
Sec. 5. That neither the company nor any of its members shall be liable in damages or otherwise for property destroyed or injured by the company while in the discharge of their duties as firemen.
Sec. 6. That all property of the company shall be exempt from taxation for State, county and corporation purposes.
Sec. 7. That this act shall take effect from and after its passage.

The foregoing act, received in the office of Secretary of State May twenty-ninth, one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one, having been presented to the Governor of Texas for his approval, and not having been returned by him to the house in which it originated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has become a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div3.head: CHAPTER CCXLIX.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Board of Fund Commissioners of Trinity. Conference, M. E. Church South.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That L. B. Ellis, W. C. Young, J. M. Binkley, J. L. Angel, clerical; W. I. Clarke, K. D. Bateman, Asa Holt, E. J. Shelton, J. R. Cole, lay members, and citizens of the State of Texas, and their successors, be and they are hereby constituted a body corporate and politic, under the name and style of “The Board of Fund Commissioners of Trinity Conference,” and by that name and style shall have succession, and be capable in law of suing and being sued, plead-
ing and being impleaded, of having a common seal and the same to make, break or alter at pleasure; to acquire, have and hold estate, real, personal and mixed, and the same to buy, sell, exchange, mort-
gage, transfer, pledge, or otherwise encumber or alienate, as said board may deem expedient; and said board shall be capable of re-
ceiving, by donation, bequest, devise, or in any other manner of power, from any person or persons, or body corporate, in or out of this State, any manner of estate or property as above enumerated.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p: Sec. 2. That said board shall make a constitution and by-laws for its government, and shall have the power to alter or amend the same at pleasure.

Sec. 3. That the power and authority of this board shall be lim-
ited to the adoption of a plan for the raising of a permanent fund for the support of the widows and orphans of deceased traveling preachers, and other benevolent enterprises of the church, and to the management and control of said fund when raised.

Sec. 4. That this board shall be subject in all things and make annual reports to the Trinity Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church South, and shall hold the property, etc., which they arc herein authorized to acquire, in trust as a permanent fund belonging to the said Conference, for the purposes herein designated.

div3.head: CHAPTER CCL.

opener.salute:
An Act to amend an act entitled “An Act to incorporate the Nava-
sota and Washington County Ferry Company,” passed April 26, 1870.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That section one of an act entitled “An act to incorporate the Nava-
sota and Washington County Ferry Company,” passed April 26, 1871, be and the same is hereby amended so as to read as follows: “Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That Ed. T. Randle, C. D. Harn, Mathew Gaines, and such other persons as they may associate with themselves, are hereby incor-
porated under the name and style of the Navasota and Washington County Ferry Company, and under such name may sue and be sued, and have succession for the term of thirty years; that they may have a corporate seal and the right of holding property, real, personal and mixed, for the purpose of carrying on the objects of this incorpora-
tion; and they may transfer, alienate and dispose of their joint or individual interests therein at pleasure.”

Sec. 2. Amend section three so as to read as follows: “Section 3. That the said Ed. T. Randle, C. D. Harn, Mathew Gaines and their heirs and assigns shall be bound during the term aforesaid to beep in good order a boat or float, sufficient, at all times, to transport and ferry across said river all wagons, horses, cattle, per-
Laws of the State of Texas.sons and property with safety and convenience, and to keep and maintain the banks on each side of said river to low water mark, so as to ensure the safe embarkation of all persons and property across said river at said ferry; and no other ferry shall be established on either side of said ferry for the distance of one and one-half miles above and below said ferry.”
Sec. 3. This act shall be in force and effect from and after its passage.

The foregoing act, received in the office of Secretary of State May twenty-ninth, one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one, having been presented to the Governor of Texas for his approval, and not having been returned by him to the house in which it origi-
nated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has become a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div3.head: CHAPTER OCLI.

opener.salute: An Act fort he relief of Theodore S. Lee.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That certificate No. 10, which. was issued to Theodore S. Lee, by the Board of Land Commissioners of Brazoria county, for two-thirds of a league and one labor of land, is hereby legalized, and the Commissioner of the General Land Office is hereby author-
ized and required to issue a certificate for two-thirds of a league and one labor of land in lieu thereof.
Sec. 2. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

The foregoing act, received in the office of Secretary of State May twenty-ninth, one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one, having been presented to the Governor of Texas for his approval, and not having been returned by him to the house in which it origi-
nated within the time prescribed by the Constitution, has become a law without his approval.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER CCLII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Society of the Sisters of Charity of Saint Vincent de Paul.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That in order that the Sisters of Charity may more widely diffuse their usefulness to the sick, the poor, and the fatherless of this State, the superiors of said Sisters of Charity, viz. : Sisters Eu-
phemia Blankensop, Agnes Steven, Teresa Healy, Baptista Dowds, and Mary Louise Scofield, residing at the mother-house of Sisters of Charity in the United States, situated at Emmetsburg, Frederick county, and State of Maryland, and their legitimate successors, are hereby created and established a body corporate under the name and style of the “Society of the Sisters of Charity of Saint Vincent de Paul;” and as such, they are hereby authorized and empowered to erect hospitals, infirmaries, asylums, for destitute female children, and schools for girls, and houses of charity, according to their in-
stitute, within the limits of the State of Texas.

Sec. 2. The said sisters, under their said corporate name, can sue and be sued, and are capable of holding, enjoying, possessing, and selling any property, real and personal, of any nature, by con-
tracts, purchase, transfer, and all other modes or forms of contracts of any kind known, to the laws of this State; they are also author-
ized to receive and accept any donations, inter vivos or causa mortis, from any private person or persons or body politic.

Sec. 3.
