ity, in a sum to be fixed by the board of aldermen and approved by the mayor, and payable to the said corporation, for the faithful dis-
charge of his duties; that he shall have the same power as a con-
stable, and be entitled to the same fees for similar services.

Sec. 8. That the treasurer shall keep safely all the money be-
longing to said corporation; shall pay out the same upon the order of the board, and perform such other duties as may be assigned to his office by the rules, by-laws and ordinances of said corporation. He shall give a bond, with good security, payable to said corpora-
tion and approved by the mayor, in such a sum as may be deemed proper by the board, conditioned for the faithful performance of his duties, and he shall be allowed such compensation as may be allowed the county treasurer.

Sec. 9. That the aldermen shall be entitled to such compensation as may be allowed them by the board; provided, in no case shall the same exceed two dollars per day for each day they may be required to sit as such aldermen.

Sec. 10. That whenever a vacancy shall occur, by death, resigna-
tion or otherwise, in the office of mayor, there shall be elected by the aldermen one of their own number to fill such vacancy, and the per-
son so elected shall hold his office until the next general election, or until his successor shall be duly qualified.

Sec. 11. That in case of the death, resignation or removal of any alderman, treasurer or marshal, the mayor shall order an election, under such rules and regulations as may be prescribed by the board, to fill such vacancy.

Sec. 12. That the salary of the mayor shall be fixed by the board of aldermen, but shall not in any event exceed the sum of one hun-
dred dollars.

Sec. 13. The mayor shall be authorized to procure a seal for the use of his office, on which shall be engraved, “City of Corsicana, Mayor’s Office,” with which all official papers shall be authenticated.
Sec. 14. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Gilmer Manufacturing Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That a body corporate and politic, by the corporate name of the “Gilmer Manufacturing Company,” be and the same is hereby created and established, to consist of a board of directors, stock-
holders, president, of a company or association of individuals, under the corporate name and style of the “Gilmer Manufacturing Com-
pany,” with the right and privilege of manufacturing cotton and woolen goods, and running turning lathes, shops and such other machinery as shall be necessary and beneficial to said company; to own real and personal property; to sue and be sued, to plead and be impleaded; to contract and be contracted with; to take, buy and sell, and convey real, personal and mixed property, and to do and perform all other acts and things necessary to the successful prose-
cution of the objects of the company; and that W. S. F. Wilkins, D. L. Neel, J. H. Rucker, J. L. Camp, J. M. Simpson, E. T. Jones, R. L. Boothe, E. F. M. Wilkerson, A. Phillips and E. Woods, are hereby appointed commissioners to open books and receive subscriptions to the capital stock of said company; and as soon as the sum of thirty thousand dollars in cotton, wool, real and personal estate, or money shall have been subscribed, the commissioners herein named, or a majority of them, shall meet and organize said company. A ma-
jority of said commissioners shall constitute a quorum to do busi-
ness, and shall hold their first meeting at the town of Gilmer, Up-
shur county, Texas, as soon as consistent after the passage of this act. Of the time of the first meeting, proper notice shall be given by said commissioners in the newspaper or papers published in the town of Gilmer, or in such other way as they may think best for the company.

Sec. 2. The capital stock of said company shall not exceed one hundred and fifty thousand dollars, which may be invested in any manner calculated to insure the successful prosecution of the busi-
ness of the company.

Sec. 3. The parties named and appointed commissioners by this act are hereby invested with the rights and powers of directors until directors are chosen by the stockholders when the powers of said commissioners shall cease.

Sec. 4. When the sum of thirty thousand dollars of the capital
Laws of the State of Texas.stock is subscribed on the books of the company, the commissioners shall proceed to organize said company by calling the stockholders together, and shall divide the capital stock into shares of one hun-
dred dollars each; each share entitling the owner thereof to one vote, by himself or by written proxy; provided, that no one individ-
ual shall be entitled to vote more than fifty shares; said shares shall be deemed personal property, and shall be transferable at any meet-
ing of the stockholders by any conveyance in writing, which may show that the stock has changed hands. That no stockholder shall at any time, nor under any circumstances whatever, be made liable for more than the amount in shares taken by him, her or them.

Sec. 5. The government of the affairs of said company shall be vested in a board of directors, a majority of whom shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business; they may elect one of their number president, also a secretary, treasurer and superintend-
ent of the company. The commissioners aforesaid shall give at least thirty days’ notice of election for directors, who shall be chosen from among the stockholders, and may hold their office one year, and until their successors supply their places, and shall have the power to fill any vacancy that may occur in their board until the next regular election; they may also appoint such other officers and agents as may be required, and shall require bonds for the faithful performance of the duties of the different officers in said board as they may think necessary in order to secure and protect the interest of the company.

Sec. 6. They shall have the right to pass and adopt all needful by-laws and regulations necessary for the proper conduct of their business, and keep or cause to be kept accurate records of all meet-
ings of the board of directors and company, which records shall always be open to the inspection of the stockholders; together with such other books as may be necessary to show at all times the amount of expenditures, receipts and disbursements of the com-
pany.

Sec. 7. The board of directors shall be convened by the presi-
dent once in three months, and at such other times as the good of the company may demand, who shall preside at all meetings of the board, and in his absence a president pro tempore shall be chosen by the directors.

Sec. 8. Any agreement in writing by which any person shall be-
come a subscriber to the capital stock of said company may be en-
forced against him or her, according to its terms; and if any sub-
scriber shall fail to pay any installment called for or amount due upon his or her share or shares so subscribed, and called for by the directors, within ninety days from the date said installment is re-
Laws of the State of Texas.quired to be paid, the directors may sell at auction and transfer to the purchasers the share or shares of such delinquent; and if the proceeds of sale shall not be sufficient to pay the amount due on said subscription, with interest and cost of selling such share or shares, such delinquent shall be held responsible and liable for the remainder due the company; and if the proceeds shall exceed the amount so due the company, with interest and charges deducted, said delinquent shall be entitled to the surplus.

Sec. 9. The rights, powers, privileges and immunities hereby granted and conferred under this act of incorporation shall be and remain in force for thirty years from and after the passage of the same.

Sec. 10. That when a dividend shall accrue, the same shall be paid over to the shares of said company, unless it is thought advis-
able by the directors of said company to invest the same in enlarging and extending the operations of said company.

Sec. 11. That no one shall be a director of this incorporation unless he is the owner of five shares; that an election shall be held on the first day of May, unless the same comes on Sunday, then to be on the second of May, annually, after the first election for di-
rectors.
Sec. 12. That this act shall take effect from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CCXCV.

opener.salute: An Act to prohibit the sale or otherwise disposing of spirituous or vinous liquors within two miles of Bagdad Masonic Institute, in Williamson county, Texas.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the sale of all intoxicating liquors, including all vinous, fer-
mented or medicated liquors (except for medical or sacramental purposes) within two miles of Bagdad Masonic Institute, in Wil-
liamson county, Texas, is hereby prohibited, and that the furnish-
ing or the giving away of any intoxicating liquors or drinks to any student or students of said institute is hereby prohibited.

Sec. 2. That any person or persons violating the provisions of the foregoing section shall be fined in any sum not less than ten nor
Laws of the State of Texas.more than one hundred dollars for each violation of the same, by any court of competent jurisdiction.
Sec. 3. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CCXCVI.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Young Men’s Real Estate and Building Association of Tyler, Texas.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That Henry G. Askew, Archy Boren, Hall McFarland, B. N. Boren, E. H. Wells, John Flynn, John Whitaker, E. Albertson, S. D. Wood, George H. Slaughter, B. G. Duval and Camp Robards, W. J. Saunders, and their associates and successors, be and they are hereby created and appointed a body politic and corporate, under the name and style of the “Young Men’s Real Estate and Building Association of Tyler,” and by that name shall have succession for ninety-nine years, and a common seal; with capacity to sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, contract and be contracted with; buy, hold, sell and convey real, personal and mixed property; to rent and lease, execute deeds, mortgages and deeds of trust; to loan, borrow, discount, or take on deposit, money, exchange, bullion, bank notes, government securities or stocks, and other valuables, in ac-
cordance with bank usages; to make divisions of property, declare dividends, and to do and perform all such acts, including the making and enforcing of by-laws, rules and regulations for their govern-
ment, as may be necessary and consistent with law, and a constitu-
tion; provided, that nothing in this act shall be construed to au-
thorize the issuance of notes for a circulating medium.

Sec. 2. The capital stock of the said asosciation shall be thirty thousand dollars, with the power in the association to increase the same to three hundred thousand dollars, and shall be divided into sixty shares of five hundred dollars each, payable in United States currency, in monthly installments of ten dollars, each share entitling the owner thereof to one vote.

Sec. 3. Whenever stock to the amount of fifteen thousand dol-
lars has been subscribed, and two per cent. on the same paid in, the association shall be deemed organized, and competent to transact business, and entitled to all the provisions of this act.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p: Sec. 4. When any deposit is made or any transaction had, by or with a minor, or female being or hereafter becoming a married woman, said association may pay to said party any sums of money due them, and their receipt shall be a legal discharge therefor.

Sec. 5. Service of all legal process against said association shall be made on the president or secretary. All stock of the association shall be deemed personal property, transferable only on the books of the association; and no transfer shall be valid while the stock-
holder is indebted to the association. In making deeds or other in-
struments for the conveyance of property or other matters of im-
portance, the same shall be signed by the president, attested by the secretary, and sealed with the seal of the association.

Sec. 6. The association may, when the provisions of section three have been complied with, adopt a constitution, by-laws and rules, but the above written incorporators shall be the first board of di-
rectors, and shall hold office until their successors have been elected, which shall not be before the whole amount of shares shall have been taken up, and two per cent. thereon paid in.
Sec. 7. The domicile of said association shall be in the city of Tyler, Texas.
Sec. 8. This act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CCXCVII.

opener.salute: An Act to amend section twenty-nine of an act entitled “An Act to incorporate the city of Dallas, in Dallas county.”

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the twenty-ninth section of the act entitled “An act to incor-
porate the city of Dallas,” shall be so amended as hereafter to read as follows, to wit: Section 29. That the city council, by a vote of a majority of the whole number of the aldermen, taken by yeas and nays and entered upon their journal, may assess and collect an annual direct tax upon all property, real and personal, situate and being within the limits of the corporation, not exceeding four-
tenths of one per centum ad valorem; and upon all merchants, traders and fabricators, who purchase and introduce stocks of
Laws of the State of Texas.goods for sale, or material to be converted into articles of trade, or sale, a tax not exceeding three-tenths of one per cent. upon the real cost of such goods or articles at the time of their receipt; and it shall be the duty of the assessor and collector of taxes to call upon all such merchants, traders and mechanics, at least once in three months, for a list of said stock; provided, however, that at any time, upon a vote of two-thirds of the property holders within the cor-
porate limits of the said city, taken in such manner as may be di-
rected by the city council, the said council shall have the power to assess, levy and collect a tax upon all property, real and personal, situate within the corporate limits of said city, for the benefit of said city, not exceeding five dollars upon the one hundred dollars ad valorem; and provided further, that a certain ordinance passed by the board of aldermen of said city on the third day of April, 1871, ordering the assessment, levy and collection of a special tax of four-
teen thousand six hundred and fifty dollars ad valorem upon the real estate situate within the corporate limits of said city, for the purpose of securing the location of a depot of the Houston and Texas Central Railway within the corporate limits of said city, be and the same is hereby in all things legalized and made valid, and the said council is hereby fully authorized and empowered to assess, levy and collect said tax, as therein provided.
Sec. 2. That this act shall be in force from and after its passage.

THE STATE OF TEXAS,
DEPARTMENT OF STATE.

I, JAMES P. NEWCOMB, Secretary of State of the State of Texas, certify that the Acts contained in this volume (except the number of chapter on page 59, which should be “XXXI” instead of “CXXXI,” and the number of chapter on page 68, which should be “XXXVII” instead of “CXXXVII,”) are true copies taken from the originals in the Department of State, with which they have been carefully compared.

And I further certify that this session of the Legislature of said State commenced at the city of Austin on Tuesday, the tenth day of January, in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one, and adjourned on Wednesday, the thirty-first day of May. in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one.

In testimony whereof I have hereunto signed my name and have caused the seal of the Department of State to be
[L. S.]affixed at the city of Austin, this first day of August, in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and seventy-one.

closer.signed:
JAMES P. NEWCOMB,
Secretary of State.
